HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. Races to Trace Roots Of Diseased Dairy Cow
Federal authorities said that it could take weeks or months to trace where a dairy cow in Washington State with the nation's first case of mad cow disease was born.
 Finding the birthplace and the so-called birth herd of the diseased Holstein dairy cow, which was slaughtered Dec. 9, are crucial to determining whether other animals may have also contracted mad cow disease. The disease, a degenerative brain ailment, is thought to take at least four years to incubate. Page A1. 

The discovery of mad cow disease continued to roil the cattle markets and the beef industry as the prices of live cattle and stock in meat processors were pummeled for a second day. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures for delivery in February fell 3 cents, to 86.175 cents a pound, after the normal limit of 1.5 cents a pound was doubled for the day because of the crisis. A14.

The emergence of a case of mad cow disease in the United States has created an unparalleled opportunity for Brazil and Argentina, two of the main competitors of the United States in the booming international beef export market, to capture new foreign customers. A14.

Stocks Rise for the Day and Week
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 1.85 points, to 1,095.89. It gained 0.7 percent for the week, and is up 45.6 percent so far this year. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.48 points, to 10,324.67. It was up 0.5 percent for the week. The Nasdaq composite index increased 3.91 points, to 1,973.14, and gained 1.1 percent for the week. C4.

Promises and Perils of Free Trade
The North American Free Trade Agreement, which took hold 10 years ago, has stimulated trade among the United States, Canada and Mexico and overall growth, but it has also brought jarring dislocations. A1.

Parmalat's Auditor Says It Is Victim
Grant Thornton rejected accusations that it had masked losses at Parmalat and said that it had been the victim of fraud in the multibillion-euro corporate scandal engulfing Italy's biggest food group. C3.

Still No Bidders for LG Card
There were no bidders for LG Card, South Korea's financially troubled and largest credit card company, after a second deadline passed. Efforts to find a buyer will continue, its biggest creditor said. C3.

Big Japanese Lender Is Indicted
The Takefuji Corporation was indicted on charges of wiretapping the conversations of a journalist critical of the company. Earlier this month, the company's founder, Yasuo Takei, left, was arrested on charges that he ordered the illegal wiretaps. Mr. Takei has since resigned as chairman and admitted that he asked employees to listen in on phone conversations of journalists. C3.

China Lifts Tariffs on Steel
China removed import tariffs of as much as 23 percent on five types of steel products, three weeks after President Bush ended American tariffs on steel. C2.

US Air Tickets Return to Expedia
US Airways said that customers could again buy US Airways tickets on Expedia. C4.

Judge Denies Mirant's Request
Pepco Holdings said that a federal judge in Texas denied a request from the bankrupt Mirant Corporation to reject two power-purchase agreements. C2.

Argentina Sets Up a Debt Registry
Argentina will set up a voluntary registry of creditors holding the country's $88 billion in defaulted bonds, the announcement comes after a visit from an International Monetary Fund team. C3.

HEADLINE: Some Doctors Letting Patients Skip Co-Payments 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
For years, health plans have sought to control medical costs by negotiating fees with a group of preferred doctors and requiring patients to pay extra for going outside the network. But some doctors and clinics -- eager to help hard-pressed patients or calculating that it can benefit their business -- have begun to foil the cost-control efforts by waiving those extra charges.
 The move by these providers to dispense with collecting what are known as coinsurance payments comes as employers and insurers try to discourage overuse of health care by making patients pay more costs from their own pockets. But those efforts -- and the squeeze on doctors as health plans shrink payments for in-network care -- are generating resistance, experts say. 
 Health plan members are "going out of network for surprisingly expensive medical services," said Tom Farley, who audits managed care plans across the country for the Towers Perrin consulting firm. That behavior suggests "some sort of tacit agreement between the provider and the patient to not bill for some of those out-of-pocket expenses," he said.
Dr. Michael O. Fleming, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, said that doctors' efforts to find ways around the insurers' cost-control strategies are "a reaction to the ratcheting down of managed care fees."
Doctors are waiving coinsurance payments for several reasons, analysts say: to recruit patients who would otherwise go to doctors on a health plan's preferred list; to help people struggling with the cost of care, and to reduce their own costs for processing insurance paperwork and dunning patients who are slow to pay.
These doctors can afford to pass up the payments because the out-of-network fees they collect from insurers often are higher than those they would collect as members of a health plan's network.
Dr. Herbert Dardik, chief of vascular surgery at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center in New Jersey, scorns collecting co-payments. "I look at it as a demeaning process," he said. "I tell my secretary upfront, if there's any issue, just forget it." 
While most doctors still work within managed care networks, waiving patients' payments appears to be most prevalent in the Northeast, South Florida, the West Coast and the upper Midwest -- "areas that are saturated with managed care," Dr. Fleming said.
In 2003, more than half of workers faced co-payments of 30 percent or more of the fees charged for visits to out-of-network doctors, according to a September report by the Kaiser Family Foundation. The average out-of-pocket costs, including co-payments and other charges, for employees of large companies doubled in the last five years, to $2,126, and are expected to jump another 22 percent next year, Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm, reported recently.
From the health plans' perspective, moves by providers to waive the payments are "exactly what managed care plans are supposed to protect against," Mr. Farley said. "The physicians can go back to practicing without constraints," he said, for example ordering more tests and procedures.
For out-of-network care, doctors at the Alliance Surgical Group in Morristown, N.J., ask patients to pay any deductible owed under terms of their health plan, a sum that can be as much as several thousand dollars, according to Dr. David Ward, a member of the group. But they do not press for payment if a patient cannot pay a follow-up bill for 20 percent or 30 percent coinsurance. "The deductible could be the whole bill," Dr. Ward said. He does general surgery and specializes in bariatric procedures for people who are obese.
Not surprisingly, patients are pleased. "I was amazed that these doctors do not come after the patient demanding the uncovered costs," said Lauren Dasylva, one of Dr. Ward's patients, in a statement she posted on a patient support Web site. "I think that is a testimony to why they do this surgery, I am convinced that they have a heart." 
But patients who choose an out-of-network plan run the risk of paying more than if they selected one of their health plan's preferred providers, said Randy Kammer, a vice president of Florida Blue Cross and Blue Shield. "There is no obligation for an out-of-network physician not to balance bill," she said, using the term for collecting charges in excess of those approved by the health plan.
Regularly waiving co-insurance payments or co-pays -- the $10 or $20 payments many plans impose for office visits -- is against the rules in the government Medicare and Medicaid programs. A few states -- Colorado, Georgia, Nevada, South Dakota and Texas -- also prohibit the practice for patients covered by commercial insurance, according to Dennis M. Barry, a Washington lawyer who studies health care reimbursement issues.
Colorado and Georgia also forbid advertising the waivers to attract business. A handful of states have banned the waiver of co-payments and deductibles by dentists and chiropractors. And Ohio prohibits routine waivers of co-payments, but not deductibles, by physicians, pharmacists, psychologists, physical therapists, nurses and optometrists, according to a survey published last month by Mr. Barry and Lori Mihalich.
Waiving payments for indigent patients or to placate those who have complaints about their treatment "should not pose legal issues," however, they said.
A policy statement by the American Medical Association's Council on Ethical and Judicial Affairs says that "physicians should forgive or waive the co-payment" if it would pose "a barrier to needed care because of financial hardship." The statement warns, though, that "routine forgiveness or waiver of co-payments may constitute fraud under state and federal law."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Indexes Post Gains, but Meat Companies Are Hit Again

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks finished higher on Wall Street yesterday as investors picked up bargains in an abbreviated post-Christmas session. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced for a fifth consecutive week.
 Despite the over all market gains, stocks of companies that process or sell meat took a further beating on news of the nation's first case of mad cow disease. 
 The Dow industrials rose 19.48 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 10,324.67. It was up 0.5 percent for the week. 
Broader stock indicators also gained. The S.&P. 500 index advanced 1.85 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,095.89, for a gain of 0.7 percent for the week. The Nasdaq composite index was up 3.91 points, or 0.2 percent, at 1,973.14 and was up 1.1 percent for the week.
Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee, said the advance appeared to be the continuation of a "Santa Claus rally" that had bolstered stocks in recent days. "Wednesday's news about mad cow disease had kind of taken the wind out of the sails," he said, noting that most of the selling Wednesday was in companies that process or sell beef and beef products.
"The market today is bouncing back from that," he said, "though volume is really light so you don't want to read alot into it."
Investors responded to reports from retailers that Christmas sales were up modestly. Wal-Mart Stores rose 8 cents, to $52.52, after it said last-minute holiday sales were good, although not good enough to lift sales growth at stores open more than a year above the low end of its projected range of 3 percent to 5 percent. 
Sharper Image rose $2.42, to $32.39. The company, the San Francisco-based specialty retailer, raised its fourth-quarter earnings estimates. 
Amazon.com, the online seller, reported its best holiday season ever, and its shares advanced 15 cents, to $53.47.
Confirmation that a Holstein cow in Washington State had the deadly mad cow disease continued to depress the stocks of companies in the meat industry, which suffered widespread losses on Wednesday. But restaurant shares staged a bit of a recovery.
Jack Caffrey, vice president and an equity strategist for J.P. Morgan Private Bank, said investors were making a distinction between processors, which may face higher testing and distribution costs for beef in the near term, and restaurants, which typically have diversified menus. "You can go to Wendy's for the chicken, the salad and other things, too," Mr. Caffrey said.
He said that he expected to see "more differentiation of results."
While processors may be the first to face higher costs in dealing with mad cow fallout, those costs eventually could be passed on and affect the profits of restaurants and food retailers. Tyson Foods fell 31 cents, to $12.59, after Morgan Stanley cut its investment rating to equal weight from overweight and cut its profits outlook. 
ConAgra Foods dropped 12 cents, to $26.01, while Smithfield Foods was down 24 cents at $21.91. 
McDonald's, a Dow index component hit hard in Wednesday selling, opened down but later rose, gaining 13 cents on the day and closing at $24.09. Wendy's International rose 20 cents, to $37.99.
Companies that specialize in meat purification processes gained. Bio-Rad Laboratories of Hercules, Calif., which sells diagnostic instruments was up $2.33, or nearly 4 percent, to $62.15. Bio-Rad is the leading provider of tests for mad cow disease worldwide.
Shares in Biopure of Cambridge, Mass., fell 39 cents, to $2.43, after the company, which is the developer of an artificial blood product, said it expected civil charges against it by the Securities and Exchange Commission over disclosure of its communications with drug regulators.
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday. The 10-year Treasury note jumped 9/32, to a price of 10025/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, declined to 4.15 percent from 4.19 percent Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 9/32, to 106. The bond's yield fell to 4.97 percent from 5 percent on Wednesday.

SECTION: Section B; Column 2; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk; Pg. 7

HEADLINE: 2003's Most Overrated and Underrated Ideas; 
Omnipresent Overachievers . . .

BYLINE:  Emily Eakin and Felicia R. Lee compiled the responses. 

 BODY:
At the end of each year, Arts & Ideas asks a handful of writers, scholars and other opinionated people to identify the year's most underrated and overrated ideas.
 Contributors may choose any subject they please, from designer chocolate to extreme makeovers, but most pick Big Concepts like religion, money or politics. 
 If you find yourself outraged by the suggestion that monotheism is overrated or baffled by the possibility that hip-hop politics is underrated, please send your own candidates to ideas@nytimes.com.
Emily Eakin and Felicia R. Lee compiled the responses.

Beauty
An essential component of beauty is being undermined and will soon be practically eliminated, and that is scarcity. Botox is to cosmetics what cut-and-paste software is to music production. Whatever was precious five minutes ago becomes overbearingly omnipresent five minutes from now. The quest for beauty coupled with technological proficiency undermines the relative value of each beautiful invention. Find beauty in nature, but when it comes to culture, it's time to forget beauty. It will soon be nothing more than another word for nostalgia.
 Jaron Lanier, a computer scientist, composer and virtual-reality pioneer.

Repeal of the Estate Tax
We pay taxes only because the alternative is worse: no taxes, no government; no government, no army. Among our myriad taxes, none is as efficient and painless as the estate tax. It's like a lawyer's contingency fee: injured parties who couldn't otherwise afford legal access can try to recover damages because lawyers are willing to forgo their fees unless they win. Similarly, the estate tax lets us
finance valuable public services with a surcharge that kicks in only if we end up among the wealthiest 1 percent. It also permits lower income-tax rates, encouraging effort and investment. It stimulates charitable giving, reducing the need for tax-financed public services. And a tax levied after death is surely less unpleasant than one collected from the living.
But if the estate tax is so great, why do 70 percent of surveyed voters favor the Bush administration's efforts to repeal it permanently? Perhaps this tax would fare better if pollsters began with a question like this: "If the estate tax were repealed, which other taxes should be increased, or which government services should be eliminated, to make up for the lost revenue?"
 Robert H. Frank, professor of economics at Cornell University and author of the forthcoming book "What Price the Moral High Ground?"

Monotheism
In their most extreme forms, monotheistic religions are deeply intolerant. If there is only one right way of doing things, every other way is wrong. If we are good, others are evil. By contrast, the ancient Greeks and Romans welcomed new gods into their pantheon and worshiped them alongside the old. They had no crusades or jihads. The Roman authorities threw Christians to the lions because they mistook the early Christians' intolerance for seditiousness. They did not seek to kill them because they rejected the Christians' God.
 Mary Lefkowitz, author of "Greek Gods, Human Lives: What We Can Learn From Myths."

Rapper Beefs
Long an aspect of hip-hop, battles between M.C.'s this year took on a marketing twist, as record labels and artists consciously tried to cash in on hip-hop drama. Beef was repackaged and sold to hip-hop consumers both in the form of a film bearing the name as well as in more transparent ways. The face-off between Ja Rule and 50 Cent culminated with an MTV lovefest featuring Ja Rule and Louis Farrakhan (with a conspicuously absent 50 Cent) on the eve of Ja Rule's album release. The enigmatic rapper Benzino, a k a Raymond Scott, who this year emerged as co-founder of the hip-hop bible The Source, kept alive a yearlong war of words with the white rapper Eminem by accusing him of stealing sales from black rappers. Unfortunately for reporters frantically in search of that special hip-hop moment to rival the East Coast-West Coast war of the 1990's, the beefs of 2003 came up short.
 Bakari Kitwana, author of "The Hip-Hop Generation: Young Blacks and the Crisis in African American Culture."

Public Intellectuals
Intellectuals and professors who write for a general audience are always valuable, but the idea of the "public intellectual" as a specific role is now well past its sell-by date. Being a public intellectual has degenerated from a calling to a career. Aspiring public intellectuals can now get a Ph.D. to prepare them for this academic market niche, and some enterprising professors have already added the term "public intellectual" to Web sites. In theory, the public intellectual could address any subject, even -- imagine! -- teaching and higher education; but public intellectual purists reserve the title for social critics who take an exclusively oppositional stance to political policies in general, and American foreign policy in particular. The public intellectuals' lack of accountability -- no bucks stop at their desks -- and their remoteness from the world of difficult, flawed, risky but necessary decision-making (the "tenured gadfly," as Richard Posner says in his updated "Public Intellectuals," is an oxymoron), makes their critical posture seem self-indulgent despite its virtue. Anybody can complain, blog and find fault; the real intellectual might try to solve problems.
 Elaine Showalter, professor of English emerita at Princeton University.

America
What Americans overrate most is -- America. They imagine that they live in the most democratic nation on earth, but in the United States, to a far greater extent than in many other democracies, electorates are shamelessly gerrymandered, the voting system squeezes out minor parties, Wyoming has as many senators as California, and money gives the rich a wildly disproportionate share of power and influence.
Americans think they are the freest people on earth, but the president keeps American citizens in detention for nearly two years without even allowing them to talk to a lawyer, let alone putting them on trial. And no one in America has the freedom of the Dutch to choose how they die, should they become incurably ill.
Americans also favor "American pre-eminence" -- the Hobbesian view that the United States ought to rule the world, simply because it has the military muscle to do so.
 Peter Singer, professor of bioethics at Princeton University.

Straussianism
Last spring it suddenly became fashionable to assign blame (or, if you prefer, credit) for the Iraq invasion to the University of Chicago political theorist Leo Strauss. A bevy of articles explicated Strauss ideas (often inaccurately) and traced his influence among neoconservative policymakers -- including Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz, a former student of his, who was deemed (again inaccurately) the architect of the invasion. 
In fact, Strauss wasn't mainly concerned with geopolitics; his cult following stemmed from his frankly elitist brand of conservatism, which prized the study of classical philosophy and what he called an esoteric tradition of writing and teaching. More important, the major movers behind the war were not intellectuals but thoroughgoing political animals named Donald H. Rumsfeld, Dick Cheney and George W. Bush. 
 David Greenberg, author of "Nixon's Shadow: The History of an Image."

Capitalism
When Sitting Bull toured with Buffalo Bill's Wild West circus, he gave his earnings to the street urchins he met, appalled that a society that could produce such wealth could permit such poverty. He commented that white men were good at production but bad at distribution, a criticism of capitalism that's still trenchant. In the wealthiest society the world has ever seen, education, health care and housing are deteriorating into speculative commodities out of reach for many, and the "economic recovery" -- of what? for whom? -- is jobless. Capitalism and democracy are sometimes equated, but you only have to look at the Bush administration, with its passion for unfettered corporate privilege and loathing for civil liberties and public participation, to get over that fairy tale. Happily, it's not overrated everywhere; Latin Americans are looking for more humane models, from Argentines' surviving the collapse of their model neoliberal economy by creating community alternatives to Bolivians' ousting a president who tried to sell off the nation's natural gas, to the landless people's movement in Brazil. 
 Rebecca Solnit, author of "River of Shadows: Eadweard Muybridge and the Technological Wild West."

Psychology
Psychologists and psychiatrists can do wonderful things. But these days you would think that there is no such thing as normal, thanks to the hand-in-glove working of the drug and insurance companies with the American Psychiatric Association, which publishes the handbook of 374 "mental illnesses." If you are still grieving a loved one's death two months later, you fit the category of "major depressive disorder." Insurance companies want you quickly fixed, drug companies have a pill for every occasion, and friends and family are too overworked to provide the irreplaceable support for grief that is present in other countries. We are damaging the nature of friendship, teaching people that they need experts to treat them for everything.
 Paula J. Caplan, Ph.D., author of 12 books about mental health and social issues, including "They Say You're Crazy: How the World's Most Powerful Psychiatrists Decide Who's Normal."

Metaphors
Metaphors have become the verbal equivalent of grade inflation. You are a goddess! Everyone is a hero! (Thanks to Joseph Campbell for that one). Gods were immortal, ageless and powerful; heroes were extraordinary. No ancient person would have made that mistake. There was only one Hercules.
 Mary Lefkowitz, author of "Greek Gods, Human Lives."

HEADLINE: Undaunted by Polls, Faithful Keep Edwards Banner Aloft 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Dec. 23 

 BODY:
Their candidate's gray minivan had just departed. The "Edwards for President" yard signs that nobody wanted were restacked on the dirty linoleum floor of the former shoe repair shop turned campaign office.
 An hour earlier, the small cluster of people in Portsmouth who feel passionately that Senator John Edwards should be the next president was euphoric. They listened to him speak at the packed Friendly Toast restaurant, applauding his positions on health care and jobs. Now, as they sat on the office's tattered puce couch and peeled campaign stickers off sweaters, their high was tinged with forlornness. Polls indicate that if the New Hampshire primary were held this month, Mr. Edwards would get at most 7 percent of the vote, putting him fourth. 
 "Seeing him today helped because it recaptures the feeling I had when I first saw him," said Connie Williams, a retired psychotherapist who is writing letters and making calls. "But it is discouraging. If he could only come across as more forceful, I think he'd have a chance." 
Nine candidates are in the crowded Democratic field, and behind each underdog candidate is a band of these devoted supporters who provide the fuel that keeps the campaign process going. They lick envelopes, organize rallies and harass neighbors to come out and vote. It is a mostly thankless task, carried out by idealists and optimists who take heart if they convert a single supporter in an afternoon of knocking on doors.
Here in Portsmouth, a core crew of about a dozen Edwards supporters vowed to march on despite polls showing their candidate in the middle of the pack, far behind Howard Dean, and garnering only 4 percent to 6 percent in national surveys. But his workers were hopeful that the unexpectedly large crowd of 150 at the Friendly Toast indicated that there were still many undecided votes to be had.
Luke Shulman, 18 and a freshman at Tufts University in Medford, Mass., is spending his winter break at home to work in Mr. Edwards's office here. He keeps a picture of himself with Mr. Edwards on top of his computer -- he has sent it to all of his friends -- and said it kept him going when he was feeling low. "Absolutely, this gets discouraging, we are not blind to the polls," said Mr. Shulman, whose enthusiasm for the senator is nearly palpable. "I think it shows that we have to work harder. I mean, people are looking for hope and vision. And I see that in John Edwards."
Despite the long odds, there is clearly a love affair between John Edwards and these supporters, a mysterious chemistry, and their passion cannot transfer elsewhere. 
"This is a cause, not a job, and that is why I'm 1,000 miles from my girlfriend -- there's no other candidate who I'd do this for," said Paul Dunn, a former investment banker in Illinois who moved here to be Mr. Edwards's local coordinator. "This is not a horse race, about who's first and who's second. It's about issues like kids needing health care. It's about a belief that elections matter and that John Edwards can do this job better than anyone else.
Despite their convictions, all of the Edwards volunteers in Portsmouth said they would vote for another Democrat if someone else won the party's nomination. "The first priority is defeating George Bush, and I could switch my vote if there was a front-runner," said Ms. Williams, the retired psychotherapist. "But I've never been politically active before and don't think I could work for anyone else, and that's a real quandary."
One of the die-hards is Francis A. Ford, a court clerk in Worcester County, Mass., who took the day off this week and drove 100 miles to Portsmouth to hold up an "Edwards for President" placard on the sidewalk outside the Friendly Toast's front door. 
"I know how this is a critical ingredient, holding up a sign, talking to people, and it is frequently overlooked when manpower is short," said Mr. Ford, impeccably dressed in a suit and tie and lifting his sign high.
It was his fourth visit to New Hampshire. He believes that Mr. Edwards can unite the country and that his economic recovery programcan return some of the nearly three million jobs lost during the Bush administration. But while campaign workers for the leading candidates are encouraged by cheering crowds, Mr. Ford must be content with little gestures.
"Today, when I held up my sign, there were a few people who gave me the thumbs up or tooted their horn," he said hopefully. "That's new, and I think people are just starting to tune in. I think the momentum's growing."
Mr. Edwards, 50, a moderate Democrat from North Carolina, has the kind of profile that should put him in good stead with the backbone of the Democratic Party. A lawyer before he became a senator five years ago, the youthful, telegenic candidate comes from a working-class background, his father having worked in a mill. 
Mr. Edwards voted for the resolution to invade Iraq but against the president's request for money to occupy and rebuild Afghanistan and Iraq because he felt the Bush administration's goals were unclear. His platform is filled with carefully articulated programs to assist middle-class workers, including a plan that would provide health care for every child, a financial package that would allow every qualified teenager to attend college and economic incentives to draw back jobs that have gone overseas. 
To supporters, it is an exasperating mystery that he has not fared better. Does he come across as too young? Too inexperienced in national politics?
Once when Mr. Edwards spoke in New Hampshire, Allan Lurvey, a psychologist and an enthusiastic campaign worker, invited 12 friends to attend. Only one became a supporter. "They just didn't see what I saw," Dr. Lurvey said with a shrug.
Elissa and Tim Stone, who are holding a party for Mr. Edwards next week, are serious about Democratic politics and defeating President Bush. They "looked at the strengths and weaknesses of all the candidates" and chose Mr. Edwards, both because they thought that as a Southerner he was eminently electable and because they liked his ideas. 
"I think if people gave him a close look they would like what they saw," said Mr. Stone, who like his wife is an environmental consultant. "But, when I say to my mother in Long Island that we are hearing John Edwards and she replies, 'Who?' well, that's pretty tough to hear." 
Working for the underdog is not the domain of pragmatists but of people obsessed with ideas. 
Mr. Shulman, the Tufts freshman, said he was drawn to the candidate's policies, but also to his character. 
Mr. Shulman makes calls, hands out fliers and -- though he hates it -- canvasses door to door. He was recently buoyed when he knocked on a door and found an enthusiastic supporter. That is not the norm. Perhaps it is such moments of hope that have convinced Mr. Shulman that support in his hometown is growing for Mr. Edwards. He said that each time he had volunteered in the office recently, undecided voters had come in to find out more. 
It is the kind of work that gives underdogs a chance.
"People like us, our job is to fight like hell for our candidates," said Mr. Dunn, the former banker. "Look, I will work for a year, and then people will go into a booth and make their decision in 30 seconds. My job is to make sure they know about Senator Edwards."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Luke Shulman, a John Edwards supporter, with Nancy Pollack, who was signing a mailing list on Tuesday in Portsmouth, N.H. Mr. Shulman is enthusiastic even though he says campaign work can get discouraging. (Photo by Jodi Hilton for The New York Times)(pg. A12)

HEADLINE: China Removes Tariffs on 5 Kinds of Steel 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 26 

 BODY:
China, the world's largest steel consumer, removed import tariffs on five types of steel products Friday, three weeks after President Bush ended American tariffs on steel. 
 The Chinese tariffs, of as much as 23 percent, were imposed on some types of hot- and cold-rolled steel, stainless steel and other steel products in November last year after the United States imposed its own tariffs in March 2002, to protect steel makers like U.S. Steel and Nucor. Mr. 
Bush lifted the tariffs on Dec. 4 after they were declared illegal by the World Trade Organization. 
 In Tokyo, shares of JFE Holdings, Nippon Steel and other Japanese steel makers surged on optimism that China's decision would help them increase sales in China, the world's fastest-growing steel market. 
In the United States, shares of U.S. Steel, AK Steel and Nucor also rose after the tariffs were removed. 
"It's good news that the China market has been opened," said Kaoru Yamakawa, a spokesman at Sumitomo Metal Industries, Japan's third-largest steel maker. "In the long run, this tendency will be welcomed by all steel making companies."
Rising demand for steel in China, which consumes about a quarter of the world's production, has caused shortages of almost all steel products and has led to higher prices, the China Steel Corporation of Taiwan said last month. China's government has forecast that the economy will expand by about 8.5 percent this year, further raising steel demand in the country.
"China has greatly contributed to gains this year among some of the raw material stocks and that's going to continue into next year," said Kikuo Osone, who helps manage $7.1 billion at Fukoku Capital Management in Tokyo. Japan's steel makers are the world's biggest exporters of steel.

HEADLINE: As Tribe Plans Hotel for Casino, Niagara Falls Weighs Effects 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
After opening a casino in downtown Niagara Falls, N.Y., the Seneca Indian tribe will begin construction next spring of a $140 million hotel -- the tallest building in the city skyline -- as part of the gambling complex. 
 The hotel is to stand 26 floors high and have 600 rooms, including those reserved for high rollers, and a full-service spa. A top-floor lounge will have a view of the falls and of the Niagara Gorge. Construction should be completed in 16 months, said Mickey Brown, president and chief executive of Seneca Niagara Casino. 
 Luring tourists from Ontario, where the Rainbow Falls are more picturesque, to the New York side has never been easy. The Canadians poured money and attention into developing their natural wonder into an attraction, including opening a government-backed casino in 1996. Efforts to promote tourism on the New York side, however, have been rather wan, said Byron W. Brown, a state senator whose district includes Niagara Falls.
So far, the 88,000-square-foot Seneca Niagara Casino, which opened last year, has not inspired a building frenzy in the city, where a chemical and manufacturing industry once thrived. In the 1950's, as many as 100,000 people lived here. Today, the population is about 55,950, said Cynthia Baxter, the city clerk. About 700 of them work at the casino.
The state is expected to receive $40 million based on casino slot machine revenue. Under an agreement between the Seneca Nation and New York State, the state will receive 18 percent of the casino slot revenue from Seneca Niagara Falls Gaming Corporation, which operates the casino. The state is expected to allot the city of Niagara Falls 25 percent of that share or $10 million. The question is how the money will be spent and when it will arrive. A seven-member commission that includes the mayor and three members of the State Legislature, including Senator Brown, one of two nonvoting members, will decide how the money is apportioned.
But some elected officials and business owners are concerned that the new project could hurt downtown businesses and might not help revive its flagging property tax base.
Vince V. Anello, who will become mayor in January, said the city's casino allotment should be used to compensate for property tax revenue lost when the tribe built downtown; the 55-acre parcel owned by the Seneca Nation is exempt from taxes. The city's tax base has been declining for the past 30 years, he said. When he takes office, just $250,000 will be available to pay city expenses until property tax payments are collected. He noted that other commission members have said that all of the money should be spent on downtown redevelopment.
Mr. Anello, who said he was happy to have the casino and hotel downtown, noted that downtown businesses are somewhat in the shadow of the casino, which has its own bar and restaurant, and soon, a hotel.
"The people in Niagara Falls have been struggling for years," said Mr. Anello, who has lived here since 1956. "The casino was supposed to be the light at the end of the tunnel for downtown development." 
But Mr. Brown said those concerns were outside the scope of his casino, which he said brought five million people to Niagara Falls this year.
"We're not a social service agency," said Mr. Brown, who was president of Foxwoods Casino in Connecticut from 1992 to 1997. "I think we've made our contribution. It's up to them to work on private sector development."
Asked about another construction project on the horizon for the city, a state-financed $17 million conference center, Mr. Anello said flatly, "Another nonrevenue-producing project.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
AMERICA WEST ANNOUNCES PLANS TO EXPAND WORK FORCE

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 America West Airlines said yesterday that it planned to hire more than 1,000, expanding its work force for the first time since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks as part of a plan to increase the number of passengers carried next year by 10 percent. 
The hiring will increase the number of employees 7.7 percent from 13,000, said Janice Monaghan, a spokeswoman. America West also said that it would be adding four leased planes to its fleet. The airline, the nation's eighth largest, increased passenger traffic 7.3 percent in the first 11 months of 2003, joining low-fare airlines like Southwest Airlines in increasing business. America West shares rose 19 cents, to $11.62.

HEADLINE: To Do: Kill Self 

BYLINE:  By Emily Nussbaum; Emily Nussbaum contributes the Reruns column to the Arts & Leisure section of The Times.

 BODY:
 THE TRUE AND OUTSTANDING ADVENTURES OF
THE HUNT SISTERS
By Elisabeth Robinson.
327 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $23.95.
 Olivia Hunt has been working on her suicide note -- her fourth attempt, since she's having trouble getting the tone right. But in truth, Olivia's whole life feels like a rough draft. At 33, she's a Hollywood discard: unemployed, homeless (in a stylish, house-sitting sense), recently dumped and stalled on her pet project, producing a film version of "Don Quixote." 
Then her younger sister, Maddie, gets leukemia, and Olivia's life lurches forward. Panicked by the bad news, Olivia struggles to fix everything at once: her family, her love life, her movie. By turns pleading, bitter, resigned, romantic and businesslike, she shoots off a series of letters from the road, willing her world into order. It's a hopeless project, and an admirable one. Even in grief, Olivia's got a producer's instinct: the desire to micromanage the universe, to force something great out of the chaos.
A novel about Hollywood and cancer seems doomed to bathos, especially given that this epistolary narrative springs from the author's own life. (Elisabeth Robinson helped produce "Braveheart," and she nursed her own sick sister. What's more, like Olivia, she once worked on an adaptation of "Don Quixote" that she hoped would star John Cleese and Robin Williams.) And there are moments when "The Hunt Sisters" can feel uncomfortably like a big-screen tear-jerker, alternating streaks of sap and cynicism. But like the breakout sentimental best seller "The Lovely Bones," "The True and Outstanding Adventures of the Hunt Sisters" is finally wryly effective, capturing the momentum of family sorrow, the ways in which people can care for each other without ever quite coming to terms.
Part of this is due to Olivia herself, who makes an appealingly flawed protagonist: she is sharply compassionate but also self-pitying and impatient, the sister everyone resents for having "gone Hollywood." She's critical of Los Angeles yet full of its values, using industry connections to get her sister a call from Bruce Springsteen. Olivia's worst critics each have a point: her married friend Tina, who wearies of Olivia's relationship melodrama; her corporate nemesis Josh, who accuses her of having "a superiority and an inferiority complex." But like Carrie Bradshaw in "Sex and the City," Olivia is lovable for her contradictions -- her generosity tinged by guilt, her intimacy-impaired romanticism and her peculiar amalgam of artistic dreaminess and pointy-elbowed careerism.
For anyone curious about Hollywood machinations, Robinson provides plenty of dish: there are weasel producers, macho screenwriters, dates with a thinly (which is to say not at all) disguised Steve Martin. On the set of "Don Quixote," Olivia fends off studio demands for a happy ending and a closing song by J.Lo. But unlike her hero, she's no raw idealist. Wooing Robin Williams ("a beaver in a sweatshirt and jeans") for the role of Sancho Panza, Olivia finagles with the best of them: "Robin can think it's about Rice Krispies," she reasons, "as long as he makes the movie."
But if these Hollywood outtakes are often scathingly funny, it's Maddie's medical struggle that dominates the story. Olivia flies back and forth endlessly, berating doctors and cajoling them, trying to be the good, responsible, affectionate sister she sometimes fears she has forgotten how to be. Such scenes of family desperation can feel at once wrenching and manipulative; perhaps there's no way to write about a serious illness without moments of "E.R."-style melodrama, and, however heartfelt, Olivia's musings on the meaning of life can feel familiar. But Robinson overcomes these obstacles with her gift for the small details: the "blue freckles" of injection bruises, the horror of watching one's sister become "a wild, frightened, hairless cat." 
And Maddie herself is no plaster saint. In her letters, Olivia struggles to capture her sister's persnickety individuality, her peculiar mix of party girl, Midwestern homemaker and critical idealist. Even in illness, Maddie urges Olivia on and needles her all at once, providing a cranky counterpoint to her sister's tendency to stew. "Just don't be gloomy or snotty," she warns Olivia. "Nobody likes that." In both her movie and her life, Olivia struggles to provide her sister and herself with an ideal ending -- a perfect moment that will satisfy everyone. But, finally, this book is a paean to the compromises made out of love: Olivia may be an unreliable narrator, but as a storyteller she comes through in the clutch.

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED; 
Birth of a Vacation

BYLINE:  By Walter Kirn; Walter Kirn, a frequent contributor to the magazine, is the author, most recently, of "Up in the Air," a novel.

 BODY:
Kemmons Wilson b. 1912
In hard-boiled novels of the 30's and 40's, the American highway is a sinister place lined with greasy spoons and fleabag tourist camps and populated by felons and fornicators whose original sin, it's suggested, is transience. The coffee cups in the cheap diners are smeared with lipstick, the bedsheets of the dimly lighted motels soiled by illicit embraces between strangers, and the truckers, traveling salesmen and painted ladies who make the road their home trail an odor of moral degradation. The atmosphere is blacktop noir, and carnality and corruption rule.
 Making this gloomy setting safe for families -- families on vacation, in station wagons, bound for Yellowstone or Yosemite -- was the personal mission of Kemmons Wilson. In 1951, while driving his brood from his home in Memphis to Washington, Wilson was offended and disgusted by the gritty accommodations along the way. He took the problem personally, but he set about solving it publicly -- by founding and then running Holiday Inn, the iconic chain of wholesome roadside lodgings that took its name, appropriately enough, from a Bing Crosby movie. 
 Like Walt Disney, who tamed the county fair and came up with the sanitized amusement park, and Ray Kroc of McDonald's, who standardized the burger joint, Wilson was a can-do visionary of the everyday. Such hygienic reformers were common at midcentury, and their love of clean surfaces and predictability re-engineered our landscape and our culture in a manner that highbrow social critics found ominous and middle-class moms and dads found liberating. As homogeneity triumphed over seediness and the shadows gave way to a uniform fluorescence, America's children were finally free to play in places they formerly didn't dare set foot in, and at prices their parents could afford. Men like Wilson, it might even be said, helped invent the postwar families they sought to serve by building them a stage.
The Holiday Inn was a brilliant social technology, changing human behavior on a large scale without coercion or manipulation. The notion that families could pile into a car with coolers and coloring books and atlases and drive a thousand miles across the country, not in some "Grapes of Wrath"-style forced migration but simply to have fun, only made sense with Wilson's guarantee of certain amenities along the way: swimming pools, child-friendly restaurants, bedbugless mattresses and so on. So what if the places had no soul? Soul is a luxury of the well rested, and grouchy, exhausted travelers can't afford it, especially when they're traveling with kids.
The long-distance car vacation was born, a peculiar family ritual whose manifold consequences are unknowable. Still, it's interesting to speculate. The baby boomers and their parents who were the hotel chain's first generation of customers aged into people whose willingness to move -- from city to city, state to state and opportunity to opportunity -- was an engine of major demographic change. By the millions they abandoned the chilly North and crowded into the air-conditioned South. In droves they set out under cloudy Eastern skies bound for clear and sunny California. The prospect of relocation didn't frighten them -- perhaps because Wilson's bright, antiseptic inns had taught them the unconscious lesson that wherever one goes one can land in the same place and count on similar comforts. Staying in Holiday Inns had proved to them that regional differences needn't be a factor in the geographical pursuit of happiness.
Wilson may have flattened the cultural landscape, but he also widened its horizons. His ice machines, spotless bathrooms and smiling clerks made wanderlust safe and economical and helped reinforce an abiding appetite, especially among the young, for self-discovery along the road. He blazed a great trail for suburban pioneers, the Davy Crockett of the Interstates.

HEADLINE: THEATER: THE HIGHS; 
The Plays And Players Of the Year

BYLINE:  By BEN BRANTLEY

 BODY:
 1. VANESSA REDGRAVE, 'LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT' -- As the morphine-addicted mother in Eugene O'Neill's masterpiece, she went way out on a limb and took us all with her.

2. DONNA MURPHY, 'WONDERFUL TOWN' -- Absolute blissful perfection.

3. KEVIN KLINE, 'HENRY IV' -- With his fine-grained portrait of Falstaff in the superb Lincoln Center Theater revival, he found far more than ham in Shakespeare's porcine hedonist.

4. BERNADETTE PETERS, 'GYPSY' -- Redefining both a classic character (Mama Rose) and her own adorable image, she gave the gutsiest musical performance of the year.

5. TONYA PINKINS, 'CAROLINE, OR CHANGE' -- As a Southern maid in 1963 in this musical economics lesson from Tony Kushner and Jeanine Tesori, she finds a dazzling ferocity in self-repression.

6. EDDIE IZZARD, 'A DAY IN THE DEATH OF JOE EGG' -- The year's No. 1 crossover performance by a cross-dresser. Mr. Izzard, who wore fishnet stockings for "Sexie," his scintillating one-man show, proved himself equally at home in trousers as the attention-hungry schoolteacher in the revival of Peter Nichols's wrenching drama.

7. NED BEATTY, 'CAT ON A HOT TIN ROOF' -- Let others debate his offstage etiquette. As Tennessee Williams's Big Daddy, he is a life-affirming expert in bad manners.

8. KRISTIN CHENOWETH, 'WICKED' -- Her skill, sparkle and high-sheen soprano gave depth and contours to the year's most superficial heroine, Glinda the Good Witch.

9. HUGH JACKMAN, 'THE BOY FROM OZ' -- As the singer Peter Allen in this bathetic bio-musical, he drew blood from papier-mache and confirmed his status as a serious musical star.

10. DENIS O'HARE, 'TAKE ME OUT' -- As an accountant in love with baseball in Richard Greenberg's Tony-winning play, this actor's actor infected even nonsports fans with his character's galloping enthusiasm.

11. AIDAN GILLEN, 'THE CARETAKER' -- Making his Broadway debut in the smallest role in this lukewarm revival, he demonstrated that silence in Pinterland is worth a thousand spoken threats and snatched the show from his more famous co-stars (Patrick Stewart, Kyle MacLachlan).

12. MELANIE GRIFFITH, 'CHICAGO' -- Taking over the role of the narcissistic Roxie Hart, she proved you don't have to be able to sing or dance to dominate a musical. Let's just hope this isn't a trend.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Fairfield County; 
In a Clouded Market, Is the Economy a Silver Lining?

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
COMMERCIAL real estate brokers in lower Fairfield County, looking back on a disappointing 2003, are divided between those who foresee a brighter new year and those who doubt there will be much short-term improvement. Vacancy rates remain high, rents are down and a succession of corporate relocations have hurt the market. 
 While optimism is rising on reports of a recovering economy, "there isn't a whole host of robust proof," said Ed Tonnessen, executive vice president at Albert B. Ashforth Inc. "It's circumstantial, in people's bones." 
 Asking rents for first-class space are beginning to move above $70 a square foot a year in Central Greenwich, he noted, but have slumped to the high $20's and low $30's from $40 peaks in Stamford. "There is not enough activity to raise all boats," he said, "although companies are more willing to make commitments now than they were a year ago.' 
Stamford's position as the commercial hub of the state, with a downtown remade into an entertainment center, is being increasingly threatened by traffic gridlock and the high cost of living, said Dean J. Shapiro, senior managing director of CB Richard Ellis. 
Big out-of-state companies are going to Westchester, not Fairfield, he said. "Twenty years ago we saw corporate migration from the city to Fairfield," he said. "Now the market is different. We don't see corporations moving lock, stock and barrel, but only moving portions of their operations."
"Clearly, there is a push eastward," Mr. Shapiro said, to Trumbull and Shelton, where rents are lower, employees can find affordable housing and commuting is less frustrating.
Scott Landis, head of the Landis Group, which owns 400 Atlantic Street in Stamford, has 195,000 square feet for sublease as a result of the 10-year lease that American Express took in the building after the Sept. 11 attack. It subsequently vacated most of the space by October 2002 to return to Manhattan. The 510,000-square-foot building has six tenants, he said, including American Express, UBS, International Paper's global headquarters and the United States headquarters of Abbey National Treasury Services.
Unlike Stamford, Mr. Shapiro said, "Greenwich avoids being impacted because it fills space quickly." But even Greenwich now seems less immune to economic vagaries.
"IN the last two or three weeks, the Greenwich market has done a 180-degree turnaround," said John Goodkind, managing principal at the Greenwich office of Newmark & Company Real Estate. On top of a third-quarter vacancy rate of 11.1 percent, he said, more than half a million square feet of space have returned to the market in the fourth quarter.
Unilever, the consumer products company, will leave 126,000 square feet in three Greenwich buildings and consolidate in Trumbull; A.I.G. at Greenwich Plaza is consolidating in Wilton: Quebecor World (USA) is moving from The Mill; FactSet Data Systems and other tenants are moving out of Greenwich Plaza, Greenwich Office Park, 1 Fawcett Place and 165 Mason Street, leaving spaces of 20,000 to 66,000 square feet. 
Andor Asset Management, a hedge fund adviser, never moved into 146,000 square feet it leased last year at the Greenwich American Center and wants to sublet. The sprawling landscaped former American Can headquarters was a pioneer corporate campus. But the company moved out in the mid 1980's, and in the early 1990's the site was adapted for use by multiple tenants. 
On the upside, the center gained a 123,074-square-foot lease by the Amaranth Group, and Ziff Brothers Investments has leased 61,177 square feet at 55 Railroad Avenue.
In Norwalk, Gibbs College and Tauck Tours have taken a total of 117,115 square feet at the handsomely restored Norden Building, and GE Commercial Finance took 221,000 square feet at Merritt 7. The 1.2 million-square-foot former Union Carbide headquarters in Danbury reduced its vacant space to 329,000 square feet by leasing 229,000 square feet to Boehringer Engleheim Pharmaceuticals.
Like the Greenwich American Center, the building that Unilever will leave at 33 Benedict Place in Greenwich is a piece of the town's history. Built in the early 70's to be fully occupied by Chesebrough Pond's, it was a harbinger of the corporate exodus from New York. In 1986, Unilever purchased Chesebrough and its 233,575-square-foot building for $3.1 billion. The building will be marketed in the first quarter of 2004.
Unilever has broken ground for a 72,000-square-foot, $20 million addition to a similar-sized building it owns in the Trumbull Industrial Park, where it has several other sites. Eventually, it will employ some 1,500 workers, about one-third coming from its New Jersey and Greenwich locations. They will occupy a total of 403,000 square feet of Unilever space, according to Katherine Beyer, public relations manager for Unilever United States in New York. 
Leasing activity is concentrated almost entirely within Fairfield County and its existing buildings produced a variety of third-quarter statistics. 
Greenwich's available space was put at 16 percent by Grubb & Ellis, or 652,900 square feet out of a total of 4.08 million square feet, not including the recent rash of fourth-quarter vacancies. Average asking rentals were $48 a square foot annually. CB Richard Ellis's figures showed a rise in vacancies from 9.7 percent last year to a third-quarter rate of 15.5 percent this year, with rents around $42. 
CB Richard Ellis puts Stamford's vacancy rate at 16.3 percent, up from 16.1 percent in the second quarter. Stamford has a total of 16.9 million square feet of office space, with asking rents averaging $28.59. Third-quarter figures from Grubb & Ellis show a 20.8 percent vacancy rate, with 2.8 million square feet available as direct or sublet space out of a total of 12.75 million square feet, with rents at $34.48. 
"It's a difficult time for Stamford," said Kim Mowers, senior vice president at Grubb & Ellis, "in that availability is increasing in all its markets -- the central business district, and North and South Stamford. There doesn't seem to be job growth now or maybe not until a year or two out. One good thing is the pressure downward on rents and total landlord packages, giving businesses an opportunity to reduce their real estate costs." 
The vacancy rate in Norwalk, according to Grubb & Ellis, was 27.4 percent, with 1.3 million square feet available out of 4.7 million square feet, while CB Richard Ellis put Norwalk vacancies at 22 percent, up from 18.6 percent in the second quarter, on a total of 5.4 million square feet. Rents range from $25 to $30. 
Norwalk is now regarded as the third most desirable location after Greenwich and Stamford, its status best illustrated by Diageo, the global wine and liquor company, which is leaving Stamford to establish its American headquarters at Merritt on the River in Norwalk when its 275,000-square-foot building is completed next year. 
While leasing is stagnant, buildings for sale remain attractive to investors, said Jeffrey Dunne, vice chairman at CB Richard Ellis. "People continue to want to invest in real estate given the alternative, even though the stock market has been doing quite well," he said. 
Mr. Dunne's Connecticut deals this year included State House Square, an 845,000-square-foot building in downtown Hartford that the Aetna Insurance Company sold to the Harbor Group of Norfolk, Va., for $66 million. It is 92 percent leased.
"There is a lot of interest in Hartford," Mr. Dunne said. "This was the city's biggest deal in 20 years and by someone who never invested a nickel there before. The larger the deal, the more it attracts out-of-state capital."
NEW YORK-BASED George Comfort, a first-time buyer in Fairfield County, bought High Ridge Office Park in Stamford for $85 million. Cadbury-Schweppes, a longtime resident of the park, is moving to Rye Brook as part of a company consolidation in the spring. Early next year Mr. Dunne will be selling Osprey House, an 85,000-square-foot consortium-owned building at 1 Weaver Street in Greenwich. J.W.M. Partners, Omnicom and Blyth Industries are its principal tenants. 
In Greenwich, the sale of 80 Field Point Road, a 30,000-square-foot building designed by Philip Johnson, this month brought $19.8 million, or $600 a square foot. Peter Brant, head of Brant-Allen Industries of Greenwich, was the seller, and the Mannheim Group of Germany the buyer. Tenants include a variety of financial companies and a branch of the law firm of Robinson & Cole, based in Hartford. 
FOR more than a decade, Equity Office of Chicago has been the largest commercial property owner in Stamford, with 1.8 million square feet in seven of the city's most prestigious buildings: 177 Broad Street, 300 Atlantic Street, the offices at Canterbury Green and 1, 2, 3 and 4 Stamford Place.
"That's 30 percent of the market," said Thomas Bakke, regional vice president for Equity. "Year-end leasing is 10 percent off normal."
But, he added, "We're bullish on Stamford and we'd like to expand there, but there's not a lot of trading going on." Mr. Bakke described the climate as improving. "Remember," he said, "office is a lagging business behind the economy."

HEADLINE: THEATER: THE LOWS; 
Iffy Scores and a Shortage of Lust

 BODY:
 Ben Brantley and Bruce Weber saw innumerable productions last year, some of which they were eager to forget. In conversation, they recalled the worst of the lot.

BRANTLEY -- There was a lot of blood spilled this season -- not so much by the critics as by the productions themselves. It wasn't a boring season. There was a lot of energy, a lot of it misplaced, a lot of it diffuse. But there was something kind of fascinating about the spectacle. I was occasionally appalled, but I can't say I was ever bored.

WEBER -- It certainly seemed to be the busiest fall in years.

BRANTLEY -- Which says something about dubiously flush economic times. It's been a year that tested star power and its consequences at the box office: who's a star and who's not.

WEBER -- Antonio Banderas "Nine" is and John Stamos is not.

BRANTLEY -- Right.

WEBER -- The other thing -- and I think this has to do with the economic times -- is that there were a number of productions that showed up on Broadway that seemed to me to be quite cynical----

BRANTLEY -- I agree.

WEBER -- Put there to establish a pedigree that could then be taken out on the road, or taking advantage of an inexpensive production to try to make a quick killing. The Polly Bergen-Mark Hamill show "Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks" had no business even being in New York. It was community theater fare. I do not believe that producers are so blind as to say, "We have a Broadway-quality play." I think they very cynically say, "Put it up on Broadway and we can sell it on the road and call it the Broadway smash."

BRANTLEY -- In an odd way I found "The Retreat From Moscow" a cynical proposition. It is a minor domestic drama that doesn't say much but is encrusted with a lot of poetic quotations that make it seem more literary than it is. It's capitalizing on that Anglophile audience. And, yes, it does have the wonderful Eileen Atkins, but even she didn't hold my attention.
And what about the current impulse that a show isn't legit unless you move it to Broadway? An honorable kind of defeat -- if you can put it that way -- is "Anna in the Tropics." It would have been much better in a more intimate production in a smaller theater not on Broadway. Instead, the actors are lined up across the stage in order to fill the space and project it. You made a good case for seeing "I Am My Own Wife" again, now that it has moved to Broadway, but I think I'd still rather see it in a smaller house.

WEBER -- I've got to say the proscenium did wonders for it.

BRANTLEY -- I never thought "Avenue Q" would transfer as nicely as it did. It didn't get lost in the John Golden and the puppets, in fact, are not bigger. It was a big year for puppets.

WEBER -- What does that say about the state of the American theater?

BRANTLEY -- Blame Julie Taymor.

WEBER -- One of the most frightening things about theater today is that there is almost no contemporary music on Broadway.

BRANTLEY -- "Wicked."

WEBER -- But "Wicked" is a mediocre score from a composer who is still writing in the same style as he was in the 70's. People have been saying this for a long time, but there isn't any contemporary show music, or at least there's very little that makes it to the stage.

BRANTLEY -- It's almost all pastiche. That's the fascination about contemporary music now. Tony Kushner's healthy dose of medicine, "Caroline, or Change," has a very sophisticated score by Jeanine Tesori. It reflects patterns of thought; it's very disjunctive. You hear klezmer, Motown, Mozart -- it's basically a collage. There are strains of "Porgy and Bess" and Samuel Barber's "Knoxville: Summer of 1915."
In Jeanine Tesori's case, she's not just coasting on audience memories and associations. Her work is also about how received music shapes our world and perceptions. The problem is it's not emotionally compelling because it deliberately keeps averting itself by shifting gears. There's something very brave about it, as I think there is about the show. But you leave not humming anything because nothing is sustained long enough. 

WEBER -- The last original score that we had of any note was "Urinetown."

BRANTLEY -- I liked the score for "Avenue Q."

WEBER -- That's fair enough.

BRANTLEY -- Of the new musicals that opened this year, the only ones that made much of an impression on me for their scores are "Avenue Q" and "Caroline, or Change." "Caroline," I think, is pitched at a much older audience -- it's for guilty liberals of a certain age. But "Avenue Q" is very smart in pitching itself to an audience that is under 40 and grew up to "Sesame Street." I think one of the composers said something like, the songs from "Sesame Street" were our musicals when we were growing up and these are the tunes that stick in our heads. The show was very canny in addressing that.

WEBER -- I agree about the score. And I think that's precisely what Broadway needs -- some kind of musical freshness. You walk down the street and you see Jerome Kern and Boy George and Peter Allen. And you think, "What year is this?" Music and musicals are what sells Broadway today, and yet what's being sold is really old-fashioned. There is enough composing talent out there, and a number of shows are in the pipeline. But we'll have to see if any new music can actually find a home on Broadway or whether in the future it will be jukebox musicals featuring the songs of John Lennon and Elvis.

BRANTLEY -- If you go back and look: Jerome Kern played with operetta, Stephen Sondheim recycled a lot. In fact, we should pay a moment of tribute to Stephen Sondheim and "Bounce," which was, for me, probably the biggest disappointment of the year. Yet stack it up next to "The Boy From Oz" and it's a masterpiece. But it just never ignited. And for all that work from someone who is truly the god of the American musical----

WEBER -- Although it's not one of Sondheim's towering scores, it's quite a good score.

BRANTLEY -- It's a decent score. There just was no energy in the telling of it.

WEBER -- It's as though they never found the story they wanted to tell.

BRANTLEY -- I guess you can't call it the young generation anymore, but we did have two musicals from authors in the same generation as Jeanine Tesori: Michael John LaChiusa's "Little Fish" and Ricky Ian Gordon's "My Life With Albertine." Both of which were very ruminative scores and somehow didn't translate into real theatrical oomph. "My Life With Albertine" was just misconceived. It was reaching too high. "Little Fish" was engaging on its own terms, but it never made an impact somehow. It was a short story essentially, and adapted from a short story.

WEBER -- Another thing missing on Broadway is genuine sex appeal. Aside from Jimmy Smits and Daphne Rubin-Vega in "Anna in the Tropics," I can't think of any other hot couples. I just went to "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" and was disappointed. I would gladly watch Ashley Judd walk around in a slip any time, but she is not the picture of a smoldering, frustrated wife. And her co-star, Jason Patric, seems to go into a stupor whenever she's in the room. I went to "The Boy From Oz," having had everybody tell me that Hugh Jackman is the greatest thing since sliced bread. I saw a guy working his tail off, and I appreciated the performance, but he didn't do it for me.

BRANTLEY -- What impressed me most about Jackman's performance -- and I really hate the theater of dead celebrities as a general rule, where people do the most thorough impersonation they can -- is that without impersonating, he got a lot of what Allen projected on the stage: the loose shoulders, the gait and the idea of cruising the audience, which Allen would do. Peter Allen would have liked to look like Hugh Jackman -- in his dreams, of course. Nonetheless, Jackman made himself less attractive. To see him in the concert version of "Carousel" or in "Oklahoma!," he's a very virile Rodgers and Hammerstein hero. So it was a pretty interesting transformation.
In terms of transformations, John Patrick Shanley's "Dirty Story" -- the best topical play I saw Off Broadway -- was an ingenious way of dealing with something usually brought up in more conventional terms, like point-counterpoint debate. He presents the debate, but in such demonically subversive terms, you don't know what's going on until the end of the first act. And then it's as if you've been introduced to Israel and Palestine as the dysfunctional couple next door. It was very smart. But people didn't go see it.
"Omnium Gatherum" was a mess but I thought it worked because it was a mess -- it reflected the scramble of thoughts----

WEBER -- I'm still amazed at the people who were venomous about that play. I thought it was full of energy. All of us have had these conversations or worked them out in our heads -- and the play allowed us to see them in front of us in an instructive way. I'm disappointed that the show didn't find an audience.
BRANTLEY -- But the truly topical plays didn't. Most of what worked this year were charismatic performances in productions that didn't begin to measure up to them. So when you see a completely integrated ensemble, as in the revival of Lanford Wilson's "Fifth of July" by the Signature Theater Company or the current "Henry IV" by Lincoln Center Theater, the performers all give off so much energy -- they connect. They may not be at Kevin Kline's and Michael Hayden's level, but you feel they are in the same play. For me, honestly, that's so much better than any Shakespeare in the Park I've seen since George C. Wolfe's "Tempest." And you just think: this can be achieved. I saw a lot of good Shakespeare last summer in London. But this "Henry IV" was more compelling than even Nicholas Hytner's "Henry V."

WEBER -- I was very interested in the two David Edgar plays "Continental Divide" in Ashland, Ore. Just the whole idea of a British writer's take on American politics was absorbing. It was like watching election returns.

BRANTLEY -- That's a good way of putting it.

WEBER -- I don't think anyone is going to do it in New York.

BRANTLEY -- Not unless you've got Jim Carrey or Tom Hanks.
The most emotionally engaging Sept. 11 play I saw was "Make Love," in which Karen Finley presented herself as both Liza Minnelli and the spirit of New York. It wasn't an impersonation at all. She had 12 or so other men and women dressed up as Liza Minnelli on the stage. But it was a sense of New York City as a dancing lady who just kept getting knocked down and then getting up again. It had moments of real poetry almost in spite of itself, which wound up being very touching. 

WEBER -- I was disappointed in Boy George "Taboo" , who really can't sing anymore.

BRANTLEY -- But his was the only performance that got what was sinister about that world.

WEBER -- We did have Jackie Mason also.

BRANTLEY -- Yes, we did.

WEBER -- How does one say this? He exceeded? He under-ceeded?

BRANTLEY -- Transcended disappointment into its own category?

WEBER -- Thank you.
