HEADLINE: Rezoning, and Redefining, Park Slope 

BYLINE:  By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
TEN years ago, when Karen Brenner first moved to Park Slope, she settled in a rented one-bedroom floor-through on Third Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. In 2001 she moved again. She bought a two-bedroom apartment in a newly built 36-unit condominium called Park Slope Estates on Second Street between Fifth and Fourth Avenues. 
 To outsiders that might not seem like a big change. Geographically, it isn't. But Park Slope residents long believed that housing down the slope from Fifth Avenue was much less desirable than housing on the more easterly blocks off Sixth, Seventh and Eighth Avenues as far as Prospect Park West at the park itself. Fifth Avenue was dismal as a commercial street, and it was a psychological boundary from the standpoint of housing value. 
 In the last three years or so, this has changed. 
"Fifth Avenue is becoming the new trendy street, like Smith Street in Carroll Gardens," said Ms. Brenner, a television editor in her 30's. "In 1991 you wouldn't go there at night to find a hamburger. Now you can get a full meal any time of day."
You can also find new housing on the side streets, as Ms. Brenner did. For the striking phenomenon in Park Slope, especially though not exclusively between Fifth Avenue and Fourth Avenue, is the presence of new construction on large midblock parcels of the Lower Slope. 
Most of the buildings recently completed or in construction are on land that was formerly vacant or else occupied by commercial buildings.
Over the last year buyers have been paying about $335 to $440 a square foot for new apartments throughout Park Slope, based on 36 closings, said Peggy D. Aguayo of the firm of Aguayo & Huebener. Based on 43 sales now under contract, prices have risen to $368 to $535 a square foot, she said. Last month, for example, a buyer paid $369,985, or $406 a square foot, for a 910-square-foot two-bedroom two-bath condominium under construction on Sackett Street. Occupancy is to start in the spring.
Now a rezoning adopted in April has set in motion plans for new 12-story buildings along Fourth Avenue. The rezoning encompasses most of the blockfronts from Warren to 15th Street, on both sides of the street, excluding those with significant commercial or industrial activity. The rezoning also adjusts regulations between Fourth Avenue and Prospect Park West to assure the preservation of low-rise buildings. (Details of the rezoning, Page 7.)
"This was a perfect opportunity to balance preservation with growth," said Amanda Burden, chairwoman of the City Planning Commission. "We were beginning to see some sore-thumb buildings, while Fourth Avenue could accommodate apartment-house construction." Contextual rezoning was adopted for northern Park Slope blocks in 1992, but the new rezoning extends the concept to a far larger area.
The city councilmen from Park Slope -- David Yassky and Bill de Blasio -- expressed satisfaction about the new zoning in general but disappointment in its failure to require builders to provide a certain amount of moderate-income housing in exchange for the right to build taller structures on Fourth Avenue. "We're concerned about the need to maintain economic integration," Mr. Yassky said.
Mr. de Blasio noted that the Bloomberg administration had agreed to make funds available to create 133 units of moderate-income housing within the new zoning district in the next five years.
As broadly defined by brokers marketing real estate there, Park Slope runs all the way from Flatbush Avenue on the north to the Prospect Park Expressway on the south, and from Prospect Park and Prospect Park West to Fourth Avenue on the east. The April rezoning actually goes as far as Third Avenue on some blocks, and only to 15th Street on the south.
While census tracts do not precisely coincide with these boundaries, the area had an approximate population of 62,200 in 2000, and there were 29,800 housing units. Over 20 years, the population has declined but the number of housing units has increased. The 1980 census showed a population of 65,200 and 29,000 housing units. 
The population decline reflects the influx of younger people replacing older households, bringing a drop in average household size. "There's been an influx of a lot of singles and people living with roommates," said Joseph Salvo, director of the population division of the Department of City Planning.
Concurrently, the new arrivals have raised the proportion of college graduates in Park Slope. They were 60 percent of the people over the age of 25 in 2000, census figures show. In 1990 they were 49.5 percent.
HISTORICALLY, the most desirable blocks, with the highest housing prices, have been along the park and on the park-bounded side streets from President Street perhaps as far as Sixth Street, brokers say. Typical sales prices last year for one- and two-family homes ranged from $1.3 million to $2 million, and occasionally more. The Park Slope Historic District overlaps some blocks of this area and extends beyond it to the north and east.
The slope of Park Slope descends gradually from northeast to southwest, leading to the terminology North Slope (from Flatbush Avenue to Union Street), Center Slope (from the south side of Union Street to Fifth or Sixth Streets) and South Slope beyond that. Residents of the southeastern part of the slope, near Prospect Park Southwest, know it as Windsor Terrace.
"Originally, everything south of Ninth Street was just 'South Brooklyn,' " said Billy Stephens, senior vice president in the Brooklyn office of the Corcoran Group. "In the mid-70's Park Slope went as far as 15th Street. As time went on, the whole South Slope became 'Park Slope.' "
Prices for existing housing in Park Slope typically diminish farther down the slope and farther from the park. Most houses have at least one rental. Resales prices for two-families distant from the park in the South Slope, for example, would probably be in a range of $700,000 to $800,000, brokers say. A two-bedroom floor-through condominium in the Center Slope between Sixth Avenue and Seventh Avenue might sell in the range of $550,000 to $650,000.
Native Brooklynites would be surprised to hear any of the blocks below Fifth Avenue defined as Park Slope at all. But the name seemed justified to Jean Miele, a landscape photographer who grew up in Park Slope and now lives in the Park Slope Estates condominium on Second Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues.
Mr. Miele and his wife, Carol Guasti, were living the Chelsea section of Manhattan when they decided to move. Now they and their daughter, Cally, 12, live in an 1,800-square-foot duplex. "We needed more space and we're close to a great middle school -- M.S. 51," said Mr. Miele, who is president of his condominium's board. 
The man whose development work has been primarily responsible for expanding the concept of Park Slope to reach Fourth Avenue is Isaac Katan, the developer of Park Slope Estates. Either on its own or in partnerships, Katan Developers has put into construction 260 apartments in the area, mainly on side streets in attached four-story elevator buildings with eight units each. And Katan is in the design phase for about 400 more. 
"We cultivated the edge of the neighborhood at a time when nobody wanted to move there," Mr. Katan said. New projects now in construction or design on or near Fourth Avenue will have a sales value of about $350 million, he said, and will transform parts of Fourth Avenue into "the Park Avenue of Brooklyn." 
Park Slope Estates, with 38 condominium apartments in six buildings, was the first project of its kind in the area. Mr. Katan's partners in the project were Boymelgreen Developers of Brooklyn, which did the construction, and the Fatato family, prior owners of the land. Bricolage Designs of Borough Park was the architect of record, and Ken Yesmont of Manhattan was the design architect.
Other projects in construction for occupancy next year are City View Gardens, 46 units in five buildings on Second and Third Streets, plus 75 rental apartments in a 12-story building bordering Fourth Avenue; Park Slope Terrace, with 38 condominiums in a five-story elevator building on Sackett Street; and Park Slope Gardens, 30 condominiumsin three five-story elevator buildings on Second and Third Streets. Two unnamed projects - on Dean Street, between Fourth and Fifth Avenues, and on Bergen Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues - will have a total of 36 condominiums in three four- and five-story elevator buildings.
"We will have 225 condominiums to sell in the spring," Mr. Katan said.
The sales agent for this inventory is Aguayo & Huebener Realty Group. In 65 sales of new housing for the Katan group and other builders in the last two years, Ms. Aguayo said, 40 to 50 percent of the buyers have come from outside Park Slope. 
"Most are couples with a child already or planning a family," she said. The local schools have a high reputation among buyers, she said.
Katan partnerships are designing 10 additional developments on or near Fourth Avenue, Mr. Katan said. They will produce close to 600 housing units. Six of them will have frontages on Fourth Avenue, with residential entrances on a side street, and some will have 100 apartments or more. As the new zoning provides, the typical Fourth Avenue building will rise in a street wall of 80 or 85 feet -- eight floors -- and then set back for a four-story element. It is too early to report the precise sites, Mr. Katan said.
Mr. Yesmont, the design architect for most of the low-rise projects, said he tried to fulfill the goal of transporting Park Slope charm to the area with the use of copper mansard roofs, limestone arches at the entrances, smaller arches at the parapet level where the roof starts, and curved railings on the outdoor terraces.
"The colors of brick reflect the colors of surrounding buildings," Mr. Yesmont said. 
Bricolage Designs of Borough Park has been the architect of record for many of the current projects in Park Slope and elsewhere in Brooklyn. Henry Radusky, the principal in the firm, said that over the next 12 to 18 months the eight that are recently completed or in construction by developers other than Mr. Katan would bring 200 new housing units to the market. 
Several of these projects are single buildings that are higher than would be allowed under the April rezoning. For example, there is a seven-story two-building project on the southeast corner of Fourth Avenue and President Street, nearing completion, that would be two stories too high in its President Street element, but conforming along Fourth Avenue if it had been designed under the new zoning rules. The builder is Zoriano Inc. of Brooklyn.
Another builder is the Goldmedal Group, in which Mendel Goldshmid is a principal. Goldmedal is in midconstruction on a five-story 30-unit condominium on 15th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, with occupancy expected next summer. There will be three entrances to three connected elevator buildings. It will have a landscaped backyard of 4,000 square feet. 
At 101 Prospect Park Southwest, a new 15-unit six-story building shaped like the Flatiron Building in Manhattan, caused local controversy as a view blocker before construction. Nearing completion, the condominiums sold out at an average price of $400 a square foot, the developer, Manny Reiner, said. 
NOT all has gone smoothly in the new construction. At Park Slope Estates on Second Street, Mr. Miele, the president of the condominium association, spoke of excessive delay in fixing roof leaks that have been persistent for more than a year. "It's been a struggle, and it's still not quite complete," he said.
The builders, meanwhile, are trying to attract buyers from Manhattan. Representative of these buyers in recent weeks were Lara Eshkenazi and James Matheson, a couple who were living in cramped space on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. They have gone into contract on a two-bedroom three-bath apartment with 1,500 square feet of space on Sackett Street, for occupancy early next year. Its price is $590,000.
"We couldn't get the same space for that money in Manhattan," said Ms. Eshkenazi, a lawyer who works downtown. "And we have friends who settled in the neighborhood. They love it."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
New Luxury Hotels Lead A Revival in Miami

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: MIAMI 

 BODY:
MINIMALIST chic may have been the prevailing formula among the boutique hotels that thrived in South Beach in the 1990's, but the latest trend, fueled by a growing number of business travelers jetting in from this country and Latin America, is unabashed luxury.
 Mandarin Oriental, Four Seasons and Ritz-Carlton all opened their first properties here in the last three years, and more top-shelf hotels are due in the coming months. Most were in the works well before the 2001 terrorist attacks hobbled South Florida's tourism trade, and while the industry has yet to recover fully, tourism officials are touting the new crop of luxury hotels as proof of Miami's rising stature as not just a beach resort, but a cosmopolitan center. 
 In particular, the officials say, the increasingly upscale lodging choices on and around Brickell Avenue, the heart of Miami's financial district, demonstrate the city's popularity as an international business destination. 
 The luxury hotels are opening as Miami is trying mightily to revitalize its long-blighted downtown. A $344 million performing arts center is rising on Biscayne Boulevard, with a 2,400-seat opera house and a 2,200-seat concert hall, scheduled to open in 2006. And voters have approved a proposal to build new homes for the Miami Museum of Science and the Miami Art Museum in a waterfront park that will abut a planned luxury condominium complex called Ten Museum Park. 
 Eight new hotels have opened in the Greater Miami area since September 2001, of which three -- the Ritz-Carlton in Coconut Grove, the Four Seasons, and the Trump Ocean Grande Resort Hotel in Sunny Isles -- are in the luxury category. 
 David Whitaker, senior vice president for marketing and tourism at the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau, said that while the number of international visitors to Miami was nowhere near what it had been before the terrorist attacks, overall tourism was slowly climbing. 
 According to statistics from Smith Travel Research, hotel occupancy in Miami-Dade County through the first nine months of 2003 was 64 percent, compared with 66 percent for the same period in 2001, and 62.2 percent for all of last year. The average room rate for the first 10 months of 2003 was $107.30 compared with $110.20 in 2001 and $103.99 last year. 
 "We still have a ways to go," Mr. Whitaker said, "but we are narrowing the gap while absorbing a whole new category of properties." 
 Mr. Whitaker also said that luxury hotels were generally better suited to weathering the storm of a bad economy than lower-priced hotels because the huge, hardy companies that own them can continue to pour in resources. 
 Mandarin Oriental, the Japanese chain, was a pioneer of the luxury trend here when it opened a 329-room hotel on Brickell Key, a residential island adjacent to the downtown business district, in November 2000. Two new Ritz-Carltons followed: a 450-room hotel, spa and meeting center on Key Biscayne in July 2001, and a 115-room branch, also with spa and meeting space, in Coconut Grove last year.
 Another Ritz-Carlton was to open last Wednesday in South Beach, in a 1950's Art Moderne building that once housed the DiLido Hotel. The oceanfront hotel's 375 rooms are designed to resemble staterooms on a luxury yacht, and artwork by Joan Miro, among others, will decorate the lobby, pool area and 13,000-square-foot spa. 
 The Four Seasons Hotel Miami, with 221 rooms, 14,210 square feet of meeting space and a 45,000-square-foot spa, opened in a 70-story tower downtown on Brickell Avenue in October.
 Like several luxury hotels still on the drawing board, the Four Seasons is in a building that also offers condominiums for sale. That configuration, tourism officials say, makes such properties more palatable to investors wary of a glut of luxury hotel rooms. Similar properties include a 203-room Conrad Hilton -- only the second in this country -- scheduled to open in the spring in a 36-story residential building on Brickell Avenue, and the Setai, owned by General Hotel Management of Singapore, expected to open late next year in South Beach.
 Further down the road, two luxury hotels are planned for Watson Island, an artificial island connecting Miami and South Beach, until now largely a thoroughfare. The developers, Flagstone Properties, are trying to differentiate their properties by stressing that their plans include a marina for large yachts, a shopping and dining complex, a maritime museum, a spa and gardens. 
 Mr. Whitaker said that while he and other tourism officials worried that there would not be sufficient demand for the spate of luxury hotels, experience has proved them wrong. 
 "We are back in an era of big opulence again," he said, "and competition is the best way for improvement and reinvestment to take place."
 Sure enough, 50's-era resort properties like the Eden Roc and the Fontainebleau Hilton, the luxury hotels of their day in Miami Beach, have made or are making extensive renovations. The Eden Roc added a lavish spa and a climbing wall, while the Fontainebleau put in a 7,000-square-foot water park and is adding condominiums and luxury suites.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Cape Town

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES; MICHAEL WINES is chief of the Johannesburg bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
 The Portuguese navigator Bartholomeu Dias, on a mission from King Joao II to find a way around the southern tip of Africa, discovered the Cape of Good Hope in 1488, and for the next 400 years, most people save sailors and South Africans pretty much forgot about it. But in the last five years that has begun to change: well-heeled Germans, British and Italians are snapping up land on sheer promontories and pristine beachfronts along the 30-mile finger of Cape territory, and its hub, Cape Town, has sprouted luxury hotels and classy shops like Whack-a-Mole games sprout moles. Unavoidable, for the world is rediscovering South Africa now that apartheid has been gone for a decade. But too bad, in a way: before long, this loveliest of African cities will be a genuine Riviera, with all that implies. 
 Already, the town crawls with film stars and their crews, drawn by the jaw-dropping scenery, California way of life and low production costs. Traffic along trendy Camps Bay, nicknamed the Riviera, is constant, and there are too many Ferraris for the average person's comfort. 
 Because the rich-poor gap here is so yawning, one should be sensibly vigilant against crime -- mostly pickpockets and purse-snatchers, though violence also has risen sharply since apartheid's end. 
 On the other hand, Cape Town is bustling, never a bad thing in a nation where unemployment exceeds 40 percent. And this city, so long ostracized by the outside world, retains an almost mystical blend of European high style and African high culture. In art, crafts, architecture and lifestyle, it is a hybrid that even an invasion of chain stores, beautiful people and fusion cuisine has failed to overwhelm. Yet. 

Events
 It's summer here, which is to say that the Cape is rife with outdoor music festivals, generally in spectacular settings with great South African wine and food. On the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront, the Standard Bank Jazzathon showcases South African talent in 40 afternoon and evening performances from Jan. 8 to 11; Jan. 9 is an all-women performers day. Admission is free; the crowds are huge. Information: www.jazzathon.co.za. 
 Far more bucolic and intimate is the Savanna Up-the-Creek Music Festival, (27-21) 671-4360, www.upthecreek.mweb.co.za, a parade of music, live comedy and art exhibitions Feb. 6 to 8 on the banks of the Breede River near Swellendam, down the Cape two and a half hours by car from downtown. The organizers bill it as an upscale festival for postgraduate adults, meaning one needs a tent to stay all three days, but the camping facilities are clean and pleasant. The crowd is small, about 750 people. One can eschew the tent and attend on Saturday, from noon to midnight. Tickets are $55, at 6.5 South African rand to $1, by phone or Computicket, www.computicket.com. 
 Then there is festival luxe: the Spier Summer Arts Festival, (27-21) 809-1177, www.spier.co.za, at the Village at Spier, a 155-room hotel and country estate near Stellenbosch, a 30-minute drive east of Cape Town. Stellenbosch, South Africa's second-oldest town, is a museum piece by itself. The festival's late-summer fare, staged by the South African Opera Company Dimpho Di Kopane, ranges from the sublime ("The Beggar's Opera," intermittently from Feb. 12 to 25) to the ridiculous ("The Rocky Horror Show," Jan. 31 through Feb. 28). One night at the Spier for two, with dinner, breakfast, show tickets and a free bottle of wine, is $98 a person by phone at the hotel or through www.computicket.com. 
 Oenophiles can drop by Cape Town's main Holiday Inn, downtown at Strand and Adderly Streets, on Feb. 24 for a wine-tasting prequel to the internationally famous Nederburg Wine Auction, in April. Tickets, $10, include snacks and a chance to sample vintages bound for the auction block and can be reserved through www.computicket.com.
 The Iziko-SA National Gallery, (27-21) 467-4660, www.museums.org.za/iziko/izihome, Government Avenue, Gardens, houses South Africa's national art collection, an impressive assemblage of works reflecting the nation's tumultuous history. Through January, the museum draws on the collection for "Coexistence," an exhibition of professional artists' and rural craftsmen's interpretations of South African life. Through Feb. 4 is "AIDS in South Africa," a joint exhibition with Wellesley College featuring artists' views of the pandemic. Closed Mondays; 75 cents.

Sightseeing
 Cape Town is an adventurer's paradise: hikers and rock climbers abound in the mountains rimming the city, and parasailers soar in the thermals off Lion's Head, the peak overlooking Camps Bay. Scuba divers can explore shipwrecks or, if nervy enough, even arrange caged encounters with sharks. The adrenalin-challenged can take the daily cable car to the 3,560-foot top of Table Mountain (touristy, sure, but breathtaking). Tickets are, in summer, $16 round trip at the station on Tafelberg Road; call ahead, (27-21) 424-8181, or visit www.tablemountain.net, to ensure that the blustery weather allows the trip. A drive south to the Cape of Good Hope takes travelers past picturesque cliffside villages, vineyards and often-wild scenery. 
 Robben Island, (27-21) 413-4200, www.robben-island.org.za, the 2.2-square-mile home of the maximum-security prison where Nelson Mandela spent 27 years before gaining freedom and leading South Africa to democratic rule, is now a World Heritage Site. The island and its prison are open daily to visitors, who arrive by half-hour ferry (it leaves from the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront); a museum and interactive exhibits place the island and its grisly history in context. Booking should be made at least three days in advance, $23. 
 More broadly, visitors can revisit South Africans' trek from slavery to oppression to liberty by taking the Footsteps to Freedom walking tour, 5 Church Square, (27-21) 465-2032, www.footstepstofreedom.co.za. The three-hour guided tour passes through a former slave market, the moving District Six Museum memorializing the bulldozing of the homes of 66,000 Cape Town nonwhites in the 1970's, and the broad square where Mr. Mandela, newly released from prison, addressed thousands of celebrators in February 1990. Group tours, booked at the Cape Town Visitor Information Center, (27-21) 426-4260, are $15. 

Where to Stay
 One place popular with the Hollywood set -- film crews, not stars -- is Victoria Junction, corner of Somerset and Ebeneezer Roads, (27-21) 418-1234, fax (27-21) 418-5678; www.proteahotels.com/victoriajunction. In the city's bohemian Green Point neighborhood not far from downtown, it is modeled after Manhattan lofts, with lots of glass blocks, exposed brick and stainless steel. The 172 rooms are meticulously kept and artfully designed, if somewhat cramped. The ground-floor restaurant is superb, and reasonable. Standard double, $192.
 The Cape Castle Hotel, 3 Main Road, (27-21) 439-1016, fax (27-21) 439-1019, www.proteahotels.com/capecastle, has 68 pleasant if spartan rooms with kitchen facilities. Some have a separate anteroom with a foldout sofa. Waterfront attractions are across a broad and busy street, but a crossing is nearby. Like all Protea hotels, it's tidy and well-run. A double is $144.
 Budget: The Cape Town Lodge is on downtown's edge, 101 Buitengracht Street, (27-21) 422-0030, fax (27-21) 422-0090; www.capetownlodge.co.za. A onetime technical college, it has been dramatically renovated. The 114 rooms are often oddly shaped and appointed, but huge, well-kept and comfortable with simple modern furnishings. A small rooftop pool is shared with a clutch of upper-floor private lofts. A standard double is about $140; specials are often posted on a sign outside. 
 The 208 rooms at City Lodge, (27-21) 419-9450, fax (27-21) 419-0460, www.citylodge.co.za, Dock and Alfred Roads, directly across from the waterfront and near downtown, are appointed with tasteful furnishings; in a few rooms a bathroom wall slides down, allowing bathers to watch TV in the main room. There is no room service, and the dining room, while offering a full breakfast, skimps on other meals. The pool is the size of a pool table, but the price -- $122 for a double -- is right, and drops Friday through Sunday to $90. 
Luxury: The Table Bay Hotel, Victoria and Alfred Waterfront, (27-21) 406-5000, fax (27-21) 406-5767, has 329 rooms in a seven-year-old Victorian reincarnation fronting the Atlantic on Cape Town's colorful harbor. All polished wood and butter-yellow decor, the hotel abounds with thoughtful touches, from internationalized electrical outlets to a combination personal fax and laptop printer that doubles as a hotel message center in each room. There is no room without a view, and the sight of Table Mountain from the glass-walled Conservatory bar is splendid. A double costs $415, and looks it. 
 Considerably more laid-back, but also plush, is the new 182-room Radisson Hotel Waterfront, Beach Road, Granger Bay, (27-21) 418-5729, fax (27-21) 418-5717, a four-story, Mediterranean-white affair directly on the ocean breakwater perhaps a half-mile from the Table Bay. Airy and bright, with canvas-roofed atria throughout, the hotel has a California feel; it's a frequent stop for film stars. Guests can watch dolphins and the occasional whale at the outdoor oceanfront cafe. Families will want the two-bedroom suites, with kitchenettes and spacious living rooms with fold-out sofas. Doubles, $345. 

Where to Eat
 The guard and his metal-detecting wand at Balducci's, www.balduccis.co.za, Victoria Wharf lower level, (27-21) 421-6002, are off-putting, but inside, the ostrich fillet, crayfish, blackened kingclip and duck confit are elegantly served in a sophisticated-casual atmosphere of cherry furniture and artsy photos of nudes. Dinner for two, with wine, $40. 
 Mama Africa, 178 Long Street, (27-21) 424-8634, has wildly painted furniture and an imposing chandelier constructed of Coke bottles. The food is eye-catching, too. Try the smoked kudu and avocado salad, grilled butternut squash, vegetable samoosas (stuffed Indian pastry) and potjiekos, a wild-game stew. There's an African band evening. The neighborhood is a bit dicey at night, so reserve a return taxi. Dinner and wine for two is $40. 
 Riviera, Second Floor Promenade, Victoria Road, Camps Bay, (27-21) 438-7333, serves Mediterranean fare on a second-story overhang with a view of trendy Camps Bay beach and its beautiful-people sunbathers. The Moroccan spiced chicken salad is good; there are hot and cold tapas, paella and Lebanese char-grilled chicken, too. Dinner for two with wine starts at about $45. 
 La Med, (27-21) 438-5600, Glen Country Club, Victoria Road, Clifton, is a restaurant and club in a young-at-heart beach enclave perched on a peninsula about four miles southwest of downtown. Inventive pizzas (bacon, brie and avocado, for example) and the usual burgers, calamari and salads highlight a limited menu. Dinner for two with wine is about $23. Open daily.
 Theo's, 163 Beach Road, Mouille Point, (27-21) 439-3494, serves above-average burgers, steak rolls and game like ostrich and grilled crocodile here and at two other locations. Dinner and wine for two, $30.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Elizabeth Weber, Daniel Handwerker

 BODY:
Elizabeth Anna Weber and Daniel Abraham Handwerker are to be married today in East Rockaway, N.Y. Rabbi Stuart L. Kelman is to officiate at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center.
 The couple are doctoral students at the University of California, she in economics at the Berkeley campus and he in bioengineering at Berkeley and San Francisco. 
 The bride, 27, worked in 2000 and 2001 as a research assistant at the Council of Economic Advisers in Washington. She graduated from Swarthmore College. She is a daughter of Jane Weber and Dr. Jonathan Weber of Nashua, N.H. Her father is a senior electro-optical engineer in Nashua in the information and electronic warfare systems group of BAE Systems, the British military and aerospace equipment maker. Her mother is a social studies curriculum specialist for the Nashua school district. 
The bridegroom, 25, graduated from Johns Hopkins University. He is a son of Dr. Sara Handwerker and Dr. David Handwerker of Baldwin, N.Y. His mother is a staff physician at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens, specializing in high-risk pregnancies. His father is an obstetrician and gynecologist at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn.
Ms. Weber and Mr. Handwerker met in August 2001 at a Sabbath dinner for graduate students at Berkeley and became friends. "By November, we were e-mailing each other dozens of articles from the Web site of a newspaper we both liked," Ms. Weber said. So in tune were they, Mr. Handwerker said, that often "we sent each other the same article simultaneously." 
Then they discovered they tied their shoelaces the same way. "I still routinely tie my shoes with a double loop," Ms. Weber said, adding that her mother always made fun of her for it. "I've never met anyone else who does it like that."
"It was then," Mr. Handwerker said with a laugh, "that we decided ours was a match made in heaven."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
How Internet Banks Have Inched Ahead on Rates

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIMELMAN

 BODY:
RICHARD REINMAN, a retiree in Albuquerque, knows what investment experts mean when they say, "Cash is trash." He has watched in recent years as falling interest rates have eroded the returns that he and his wife, Marilyn, receive from the cash in their investment portfolio.
 But while many investors are resigned to getting 0.7 percent or 1 percent a year on a money market fund tied to a brokerage account, Mr. Reinman, 74, went shopping for a better rate. And he found it not at a brokerage firm or a mutual fund house, but at a "branchless" commercial bank that does business over the phone and the Internet. 
 Mr. Reinman and his wife are now receiving 2.2 percent a year on close to $100,000 in money market deposits at the Bank of Internet USA, a bank in Del Mar, Calif., with a single, 6,000-square-foot office and only 20 employees. 
 "This is paying me three times what I might make on a typical money market mutual fund," he said, adding that the investment is also insured through the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "That's a world of difference."
 Some financial advisers contend that it is hardly worth the effort to build a relationship with one more financial institution just to eke out an extra percent or so a year in returns. But others beg to differ. With inflation running at close to 2 percent, investors who can earn that much on their cash are at least keeping up with the cost of living.
 "That's a difference worth the added effort, " said Greg McBride, a senior financial analyst at BankRate.com in North Palm Beach, Fla.
 Michael Karstens, a certified financial planner in Omaha, agreed, saying that the added returns justified the effort for all but relatively small accounts. "If you have $100,000 invested in a money market fund and you are earning only 0.75 percent a year, you will be making $750," he said. "If you are earning 2.2 percent, you are making $2,200 a year. That's a $1,450 difference before income tax." 
 By contrast, an investor with only $20,000 or $30,000 in short-term money might question the need to shop for better rates, said Lewis M. Wallensky, a financial planner in Los Angeles. If investors are receiving no more than $200 or $300 a year of additional income for their effort, he said, they might just forgo some luxury expense to make up for it.
 But for those who feel that the extra return makes the effort worthwhile, commercial banks are a good place to start. Once scorned for not keeping up with money market mutual funds in their returns, certain banks now offer the best rates. 
 This year through Dec. 19, a net $435 billion has flowed into bank money market and savings accounts, raising total assets to $3.2 trillion, according to BanxQuote.com in Scarsdale, N.Y. By contrast, there has been a net outflow of $111 billion from retail money market mutual funds, reducing their total assets to $817 billion.
 NOT surprisingly, some of the most competitive banks are also beating their rivals in the rates they pay on certificates of deposit. Unlike money market deposits, which can be liquidated at any time, money in C.D.'s cannot be withdrawn without penalty for, say, one, three or five years. 
 But because the best one-year C.D.'s pay only slightly more than the best money market rates, investors see little value in them. There has been an outflow of $86.2 billion from consumer C.D.'s in the past year, lowering total assets to $808 billion as of Dec. 19, according to BanxQuote.
 The average money market return at commercial banks and mutual fund companies is similar -- about a half-percent a year -- but the best bank rates are higher than the best rates offered by fund companies. 
 That difference can be explained by the economic forces that shape these rival industries. Money market funds run by mutual fund houses and large securities firms invest in similar short-term securities, including Treasury bills, repurchase agreements and commercial paper issued by companies. So there is not much they can do to increase interest rates for customers, other than lower or waive management fees.
 "These money market funds are all fishing from the same investment pond," said Mr. McBride, the financial analyst, "so most of the disparity in returns is attributed to different management expense ratios rather than the investment performance." 
 By contrast, banks rely on deposits for the money they lend. So certain banks in need of added deposits may be willing to raise the rates for them if they expect to lend at higher rates. "Some banks simply want your deposits more than others do," says Norbert Mehl, the president of the Banx Corporation, the operator of BanxQuote. 
 Traditionally, banks in small communities have often offered some of the highest rates on money market deposits and C.D.'s, to try to keep up with loan demand. But the emergence of the Internet has led to the rise of branchless banks, which benefit from low overhead to offer better rates on deposits, also backed by the F.D.I.C. 
 Indeed, the three banks that now advertise the best rates are not found on neighborhood streets, according to Bankrate.com. They are the Bank of Internet USA, Virtual Bank and National InterBank. 
 The Internet banks do not tend to lower their rates abruptly, Mr. McBride said. "The institutions that are competitive tend to be competitive over time." BankRate rewards banks that keep rates high with a "top tier award."
 Some small traditional banks are willing to offer better rates to local depositors than those advertised on the Web. "These deals are hard to track on a national basis because they are often offered in the local market and they tend to come and go," Mr. Mehl of Banx said. 
 For example, Mr. Karstens, the Omaha financial planner, learned from one client that the Exchange Bank, a small community bank in Gibbon, Neb., was paying close to 3 percent a year for money market deposits. "I called them and asked if I could send additional money from customers who weren't clients at their bank already," he said. The bank said he could, but it lowered the rate later in the year. 
 Pat Meyer, an assistant vice president at Exchange Bank, confirmed that it was offering consumer money market rates ranging from 2.6 percent to 2.9 percent in June. "But we got the deposits we needed," she said, "so we lowered the rate."
 TO attract customers, some banks are willing to do more than just raise rates. Daniel Dektar, chief investment officer at Smith Breeden Associates, a money manager in Chapel Hill, N.C., specializing in fixed-income investments, found that out when he checked local banks to learn their C.D. rates. His goal was to find good investments for his workers, family members and friends -- not his clients, who have little use for bank C.D.'s. 
 Not only did he find rates that were better than the national averages, but he also discovered that some banks were willing to improve the terms to make the C.D.'s more attractive when rates rise. The Federal Reserve, which held short-term rates steady at its last meeting, is expected to begin raising them soon. 
 Mr. Dektar learned that two local North Carolina banks were willing to reset the interest rate once if rates rose during the life of the investment. Another bank would charge only three months' interest as a penalty if an investor liquidated the investment.
 "Both of these types of C.D.'s have features that limit your opportunity cost should rates rise, while starting out with higher income," Mr. Dektar said. 
 But Mr. Mehl contends that most investors should stick with simpler deposit products they can compare easily, not ones laden with too many bells and whistles.
 "It's better to find a straightforward product that is paying a good rate," he said.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Those Year-End Bonuses Aren't Always Green

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
JESSICA VARGA received no year-end bonus check this year. Not a share of stock or even a gift check from her employer, DVC Worldwide, a marketing firm in Morristown, N.J. Yet Ms. Varga, an assistant account executive who has never received a bonus, does not seem to mind: she was given her very first office -- in fact, a coveted corner one.
 She won the use of an office for all of 2004 as a prize at DVC's year-end party, held at a hotel in nearby Madison. Ms. Varga, 23, participated in a drawing to reward the company's less-senior staff. Each employee received 10 raffle tickets to place in various boxes for prizes like dinner certificates, a dedicated spot in the front row of the company's parking lot or the corner office. 
 Ms. Varga put all her tickets in the "corner office" box, and after her name was pulled out as the winner, the crowd cheered loudly. "I figured it would take me 10 years to get an office," said Ms. Varga, who has been with DVC for only 18 months. "It was the last thing I expected to be rewarded with." 
 Sue Furlong, president and chief operating officer of DVC, said that some executives continued to receive annual cash bonuses this year but that the noncash awards for everyone else had been extremely popular. "They're something that you can't buy," she said. "They're pretty meaningful."
 They are also far less expensive to give than cash or other forms of financial compensation. 
 Many other companies, large and small, seem to agree. They have been doling out far less in cash bonuses this year, at least for their rank-and-file employees, according to compensation experts. 
 "When it comes to end-of-year bonuses, cash is no longer king," said Laura Sejen, national practice director for strategic awards at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, the human resources consulting firm.
 About one-third of companies planned to give holiday bonuses this year anyway -- about the same fraction as in 2002 -- but fewer companies were giving them in cash, according to a study of 435 American companies conducted in November by Hewitt Associates, another human resources consulting firm. 
 Only 28 percent planned to give cash this year, compared with 39 percent last year. The remainder were giving mainly gift certificates or food products -- hams, turkeys and, yes, fruitcakes -- the survey found. A majority of the companies in the survey budgeted less than 1 percent of payroll expenses for these awards.
 Noncash awards are not given just around the holidays. In a recent study by Mercer Human Resource Consulting, 72 percent of the corporate executives surveyed indicated that they give noncash awards to employees all year.
 More employers, meanwhile, are replacing standard bonuses with pay-for-performance plans in which a worker's total compensation is tied to performance or revenue goals. Nearly 80 percent of companies have these plans in place for some of their employees, up from around 50 percent in 1991, according to Hewitt Associates.
 Ken Bosch, a Hewitt consultant, said that these awards could better help employees "focus on the key drivers of the business."
 "The primary criticism companies have with holiday bonuses is that there tends to be a loose link between someone's performance and the fact that they got a ham," he said. Pay-for-performance plans, he said, "avoid the entitlement mentality that exists with holiday rewards." 
 With performance-related plans, "workers aren't saying, 'It's holiday time, where's my reward?' no matter how well or how poorly they performed," he said.
 Ms. Sejen of Watson Wyatt says the move away from cash began as the economy began to sour more than three years ago. Companies that were struggling to meet earnings expectations started experimenting with less expensive awards, like theater tickets, dinner certificates or gift cards, for employees who were not executives. A rising unemployment rate also meant that fewer employers had to shower big bonuses on workers to keep them.
 Now, even with the economy improving, these companies are finding that "they're getting more bang for their buck" with noncash awards, Ms. Sejen said. 
 Such awards can backfire, however, if they are used as a replacement for large cash bonuses. 
 "If you're accustomed to getting a $5,000 bonus and you're now getting a $25 gift certificate, you're going to think your company is a little bit chintzy," said Carroll Lachnit, editor of Workforce Management, a human resources publication.
 Many companies, of course, continue to give hefty cash bonuses to their senior executives. And the financial services industry also continues to give out mounds of cash. 
 According to Alan G. Hevesi, the New York State comptroller, Wall Street firms alone will pay $10.7 billion in bonuses in 2003, up from $8.6 billion in 2002. 
 But Ms. Lachnit says that companies in many other industries have been eager to change an employee mind-set that annual bonuses should be a guaranteed part of their compensation. "People just factor the money in as part of their annual salary expectations," she said. 
 Rewards like gift certificates, she said, are often viewed differently by employees, "because they're usually something that someone wouldn't spend on themselves."
 "So they're seen as more special," she added.
 RICK JOHNSON, president of Quantum Media, a software development company in San Diego, says he rewards his 25 employees at the end of the year by letting them select merchandise through a barter organization of which his company is a member. Mr. Johnson says he gives each employee an amount they can spend, usually from $500 to $2,000, and has them select gifts from a catalog, such as leather coats or mountain bikes.
 "When you give people cash, they spend it on an insurance bill or a doctor bill and then forget about it," he said. "This is much more exciting."
 Dr. Chris Kammer, president and owner of the Center for Cosmetic Dentistry in Madison, Wis., is also banking that the holiday reward for his employees this year will generate some excitement.
 Dr. Kammer says he previously gave employees $50 checks at the company's annual potluck holiday party. "It became sort of expected," he said. 
 At this year's party, Dr. Kammer had a surprise for his staff of 25. When the employees finished eating, he asked them to wait a few minutes. Then two stretch limousines, driven by chauffeurs in Santa outfits, pulled up to the curb outside the company. The staff was invited to climb into the limos and drink Champagne, eat bonbons and sing along to a holiday CD that Dr. Kammer himself had burned.
 The employees were whisked to a local mall, where he presented each of them with a $100 bill and gave them an hour to spend it all. Whatever money they didn't spend in that time, they had to return.
 While the main reward was still money, Dr. Kammer said he believed that the experience surrounding it would be more fondly remembered than the cash of years past. 
 "The money alone was drab," he said. "This is something they're never going to forget."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
N.F.L. Ownership, on the Installment Plan

BYLINE:  By GREGORY JORDAN

 BODY:
ART MODELL, owner of the Baltimore Ravens, often refers to the owners of competing teams in the National Football League as partners. Now, Mr. Modell is at a turning point in a partnership that has been crucial for his team. 
 At the end of the football season, Mr. Modell will hand over control of the Ravens, which he has owned since 1961 when they were the Cleveland Browns, to Stephen Bisciotti, the founder of Allegis Group, a recruiting and staffing company in Hanover, Md. 
 The two men have structured the transition as a lengthy collaboration that is unusual in professional sports -- and hardly more common in other businesses.
 The sale of the team was born of financial necessity. Mr. Modell took on debt in the 1990's for repairs to the antiquated Cleveland Municipal Stadium and for other business expenses. In addition, he had to buy out the share of a former partner, Alfred Lerner. Shortly before the sale to Mr. Bisciotti, Mr. Modell had to take on $185 million in debt, a sum so large he needed league approval.
 The impending management change is on track to be much smoother. Mr. Modell, who bought the team for $4.6 million in 1961, handpicked Mr. Bisciotti to buy the team from among several potential suitors in 2000. Mr. Bisciotti then paid $275 million for 49 percent of the team and will pay an additional $325 million after this season for the remainder. 
 The four-year transition has been an apprenticeship of sorts for Mr. Bisciotti, 43, who has spent the time learning about professional sports management from Mr. Modell and his son David, the team's president. After Art Modell, 78, hands over control of the team, he will stay on as a consultant with an office next to the new owner's.
 The arrangement has been fruitful from the start. The Ravens won their first Super Bowl in January 2001. And during the transition, Mr. Bisciotti has gained access to other team owners and has begun developing relationships with them. "Steve was a success in business but knew little about the operation of a professional sports team," said Ron Shapiro, a Baltimore sports agent. "Art realized he could tap Steve's business skills, and Steve recognized an opportunity to learn the sports business and tap Art's decades of experience in football."
 Mr. Modell said he and Mr. Bisciotti had planned the changeover to benefit the team as well.
 "We staged this transaction to give Steve a chance to learn this business and to give the franchise a less abrupt change," Mr. Modell said. "And we developed new financial strength. It was a novel way to do it, but Steve paid a very handsome price even with this slow buy-in period built in." 
 During the transition, Mr. Bisciotti said, he has focused on learning about league governance and economic matters from Art Modell and about team marketing and finance from David. The new owner has also adopted the Modell buzzword.
 "Art helped build this league with partners," Mr. Bisciotti said. "The new breed of owners are successful at business, but few admit we are coming into an entirely new business. You almost never acquire a company so different from your own, so you don't come into the N.F.L. with a lot of knowledge. I like to think I recognized this and gained that knowledge from Art."
 A LENGTHY ownership transition carries both benefits and risks, said Mitchell H. Ziets, president and chief executive of the sports investment bank MZ Sports. 
 "The good thing about that structure is it allows the new owner to have a very orderly transition, to learn the personnel and the potential problems in a direct way," he said. "But the exiting owner could start cutting long-term deals that put a new owner in a situation where his hands are tied." That has not happened with the Ravens, Mr. Ziets said, because Mr. Modell and Mr. Bisciotti have worked so closely on all aspects of the team's business.
 But by extending the official change in leadership, the two men may have also prolonged the ill will that surrounded the team's move from Cleveland in 1996, said Kenneth Shropshire, a professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
 Cleveland fans, who had loyally followed the Browns, felt betrayed by the decision to leave, even if the move was to a city that itself had been abandoned by its longtime franchise, the Colts. They later used that anger to lobby the league to locate a new franchise in Cleveland in 1999 under the Browns name.
 Sports business experts say that the Modell-Bisciotti transition is a rare one because a new owner seldom acknowledges needing a period of apprenticeship. A team tends to be handed down within a family or sold to very wealthy individuals who want immediate control. 
 And there is also a substantial record of owners battling for control of teams. The football teams owned under partnerships that had to be dissolved because of bitter disputes include the Miami Dolphins in the 1960's, and later the Oakland Raiders and the Minnesota Vikings. 
 This pattern makes the collaborative approach to the Ravens' sale and ownership transition stand out, sports business experts say. 
 Mr. Modell's management approach with his staff is also collaborative, particularly for the world of sports. He has usually promoted from within the organization and has chosen minority candidates for prominent positions. 
 Ozzie Newsome, a former Cleveland Browns tight end who is now the team's general manager, said Mr. Modell's management style stood out. "Art runs a franchise with a deep commitment to its people," said Mr. Newsome, who in 2002 became the first black general manager in the N.F.L. "His approach to personnel management is reflected in the long tenure of so many people at all levels around here."
 Mr. Bisciotti said he would keep Mr. Modell's management team. "There has been less turnover in Art's organization than any team I know of," Mr. Bisciotti said. "You look at most sports executives and they have three or four teams on their resume. I spent the last four years learning from people I want to keep. I knew within a year of buying the business I wasn't going to have any turnover."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Art Modell, left, at the training camp of the Baltimore Ravens in May with Stephen Bisciotti, who is buying the team from him. (Photo by Phil Hoffmann)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Year-End Is Crucial For Alcohol Sales, Too

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
TIME for a little holiday libation? 
 Like their retailing cousins, the companies that make beer, wine and liquor rely on healthy fourth-quarter sales for a good chunk of their annual profits. 
 Last year, alcohol sales in the United States totaled $137.5 billion, according to Impact Databank. Beer has had a tough year in 2003, but wine and spirits sales are up. 
 Bryan Spillane, a beverage analyst at Banc of America Securities, took some time last week to talk about the industry, and whether the stocks are overpriced. 
 Following are excerpts from the conversation:

Q. Is there a lot of seasonality to sales of beer, wine and spirits?

A. The fourth quarter is important for wine and spirits sales, because there are more parties and they are also given as gifts. The end of the year is probably about as important to them as the fourth quarter is to the retailers.

Q. Nevertheless, isn't it fair to say that demand for these products is fairly inelastic?

A. Yes, it is fairly inelastic. When the economy is good or improving, you tend to have more trading up to better brands.
 This year, we have seen the return of the luxury consumer, and volume growth has accelerated from 2 percent to 3 percent in spirits like whiskeys and vodkas.

Q. Have wine sales been helped by reports that wine drinking is good for your heart?

A. On a volume basis, the wine industry will grow 6 percent this year, after growing at a 3 percent rate over the previous two to three years. The idea that a glass of wine is healthy is part of the appeal.
 Also, to a 50-year-old baby boomer looking for more luxury items, wine fits the bill. So there is a good demographic opportunity. And since you still have relatively low per capita consumption among younger people, there is an opportunity for growth.

Q. Americans spend more money on beer -- $67 billion last year -- than on either wine or spirits. But 2003 hasn't been a good year for the brewers, has it?

A. This year the beer industry, including imports, will probably see volumes decline by about 1 percent. Over the last five years, it has grown at about a 1 percent rate.
 Unfavorable weather over the first half of the year is at least part of the reason why it has been a tough year. Also, I think some beer drinkers may have migrated to spirits. And a slowdown in bar and restaurant traffic didn't help. 
 But I expect you will see some improvement in beer industry volumes in 2004. Some of that is due to easy year-over-year comparisons. 
 Over the last couple of months we have liked Anheuser-Busch. It's a stock that has lagged the market. When the beer industry stagnates, Anheuser does, too, irrespective of its own performance. But it has 50 percent of the beer market.

Q. A lot of these stocks have done well this year. Constellation Brands, for instance, is up more than 30 percent. Brown-Forman is up more than 40 percent. Is it realistic to think that they can continue to outperform?

A. It really depends on the stock.
We like Diageo, which is up more than 20 percent this year but is still relatively undervalued. 
 This is a company whose brands include Johnnie Walker whiskeys, Smirnoff vodka, Jose Cuervo tequila and Tanqueray gin. 
 Over the course of the last five years they have made a lot of acquisitions that forced a lot of change. When they came out of it as a spirits company, they set pretty high sales and earnings targets. The missed their numbers a couple of times in the second half of 2002 and the first half of this year. 
 I don't think there is anything fundamentally wrong with the company. They are just at the beginning of being able to leverage their market share in the U.S., which is the biggest of any spirits company. This is a company that can pretty consistently deliver 10 percent earnings-per-share growth and operating income growth of 6 percent to 7 percent. It also has a dividend yield of about 3.6 percent.

Q. Do you like any of the others?

A. Constellation Brands, which brews Corona beer, has an Australian vineyard and two California vineyards and makes Fleischmann's vodka, among other brands, is a stock we like.
 The stock is trading at about 11.5 times next year's earnings, so it is still reasonably priced. The key with this stock is Banrock Station, the Australian vineyard. Australian wines are growing at a 50 percent clip in the U.S. right now. 
 Brown-Forman Corporation is a great company. Jack Daniel's, which they make, is a great brand in terms of pricing power. And it is a very shareholder-friendly company. Over the course of 2003, they did a share repurchase, announced plans to split the stock and have increased the dividend. 
 You should think of these stocks as being like most other big, consumer staples companies. Over time, the real concern is not if they are going to generate cash, but how they are going to spend it.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 4, 2004

 CORRECTION:
The Market Insight column last Sunday, about investing in makers of alcoholic beverages, misidentified the brewer of Corona beer. It is Grupo Modelo of Mexico. (Constellation Brands is the parent of Barton Beers, which distributes Corona in the western United States.)

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
Old Cars Can Become Good Deeds

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN the auto dealer told me that he would give me only $5,000 as a trade-in on my 1997 minivan, I made two decisions. One, I was going to keep my old, but perfectly sound, van and not take the new all-wheel-drive version I had come to the showroom to buy. And, two, I would eventually give the van to charity instead of accepting the dealer's low offer.
 Donating an old vehicle to a charity has long been a popular option. The charity makes money by reselling the car, and the owners get a tax break and the satisfaction that they're doing some good. Many charities accept old vehicles. The Polly Klaas Foundation and the California Council of the Blind say they receive most of their income this way. 
 Just last month, the National Automobile Dealers Association announced a donation program that lets owners choose a charity from a list of 200 (www.nadaguides.com or 800792-2095). The dealers work with the Vehicle Donation Processing Center in Monrovia, Calif., which runs the donation programs for these groups. 
 The American Cancer Society runs its own donation program (888227-5500 or www.cancer.org). The group says it receives about 18,000 cars a year, raising about $5 million. Richard Riehl, vice president of the society's vehicle donation program, says that as of now, it usually doesn't accept cars from 1987 or earlier. The Vehicle Donation Processing Center says it generally will not take nonrunning domestic cars that are more than 15 years old.
 "This is a fund-raising exercise, so we only want cars that we believe will have a net profit," said Harvard E. Palmer Jr., vice president of the processing center. 
 Many of the organizations make donating incredibly easy. They mail the paperwork to the owner, who signs over the title and mails everything back. Usually within days, a tow-truck operator calls to make an appointment to haul the car away.
 Dianna L. Shattuck, 39, a veterinarian from Stamford, Conn., said she needed a total of only about 15 minutes for the phone calls and paperwork to donate a 1992 Oldsmobile to the cancer society this year. Mary Bettinson, 52, a marketing consultant from Costa Mesa, Calif., said her 1994 Thunderbird was gone 12 days after she started the donation process last month through the dealers association.
 The hardest part is coming up with the fair market value for the Internal Revenue Service. The agency makes it clear that checking a used-car pricing guide is only the first step. You must adjust the value depending on the car's condition, mileage and options. (Check with car dealers or repair shops.) The I.R.S. also requires an appraisal if the car is valued at more than $5,000. And keep in mind that the General Accounting Office released a report this month on car donations, noting that the amounts that donors claimed as deductions were often much higher than what the charities received for the cars. So changes may be coming.
 The dealers association helps assign value on its Web site. It said that my vehicle should sell for about $8,000 because it has low mileage, but I'm sure it's worth less because the body is dented and scraped. It is an ugly van, but it runs great.
 That prompted another thought: Instead of giving my van to a charity that probably won't get its full value, why not give it to a group that can actually use it? I would have to find that group and do the paperwork myself, but the satisfaction would be greater. And the tax deduction wouldn't be any less.
 So I called the Food Bank of Lower Fairfield County in Stamford, which picks up food in my neighborhood. Kate Lombardo, the executive director, said that she would love to have the van but was concerned about insurance costs. "Moving another vehicle in would take us over budget," she said.
 I also called my church, First Presbyterian in Stamford. My pastor, the Rev. Blair Moffett, was also hesitant."The downside is you take on a car that you need to insure and to repair," he said. "It's not a freebie."
 I WAS becoming discouraged. But then he said that if someone in the congregation desperately needed a car and couldn't afford one, the church could pass it on. The Good News Garage (877-448-3288 or www.goodnewsgarage.com), a car donation plan run by Lutheran Social Services of New England, has a program like that. The group usually doesn't resell the cars but it gives them to people who need them for work. 
 Frankly, the idea of getting the van to someone who could actually use it is attractive to me. And if I donated it to my church, there might be another financial benefit.
 I asked my pastor if I could subtract the van's value from my annual pledge. "I would hope not," he said, sounding surprised.
 Hey, I was just asking.

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB; 
Thanks, Boss. Next Time, Make It a Lump of Coal.

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
The holidays are a time for giving. Nobody ever said that choosing an appropriate gift is easy, but sometimes holidays in the workplace seem to lack a generous spirit.
 As some people put it, "What goes around comes around." But let Norma Tavis of Vancouver, Wash., tell her own story. 
 "I was a legal secretary my entire working life, mostly in Lower Manhattan," she writes. "I was able to take dictation, person to person, for hours at a time without discomfort, and then transcribe my notes, without error. I was good!
 "One year, one of my employers gave me $10 as a Christmas bonus. I was so insulted that I purchased a gift certificate for that amount and gave it to him." 
 Mrs. Tavis knew whom she was dealing with. "That was Scrooge in person," she writes.
 Not long afterward, she quit. 
 Once upon a time, with college and the Navy behind him, Sanford Teller of New York, now the owner of a public relations business, was eager to begin his career in that field.
 "I landed what appeared to be a promising job in New York with a recently formed trade association established to promote West German cameras and optical equipment in the American market," he writes. "Until I joined the staff, it had been a two-person operation, run by an executive and his secretary. Now there were three of us sharing one large, open space.
 "My boss was very formal, in his appearance as well as his demeanor. Always wore a bow tie and almost never took off his suit jacket."
 He also says that while he and the secretary had always addressed each other by their first names, his boss insisted on being addressed with the title "Mr."
 "And each time he planned a trip to the association's headquarters in Cologne, he called it 'a state visit,"' he says.
 Mr. Teller had been working there 10 months, when, on the last workday before Christmas, the boss asked him to stay late because he had something he wanted to say to him.
 Visions of sugarplums danced in Mr. Teller's head. "Having been highly complimented on my performance on many occasions, and knowing that the association had presented several industry reporters with gifts ranging from Leica cameras to fine leather briefcases, I eagerly anticipated going home with a great Christmas gift," he says.
 Mr. Teller says the boss praised his work, then smiled and said, "You've been here almost a year, and you've become a valuable member of my team, Sandy."
 From now on, he said the boss told him, he could call him by just his first name.
 And that was Mr. Teller's Christmas gift.
 Nevertheless, it was better than what Dick Villari received. "I can't say that I ever received a gift that I didn't appreciate, but I did receive a Christmastime phone call that required a lot of thought," he writes from Buffalo, where he is a consultant for a health insurance company. 
 "I had been with a previous employer as the chief executive of a division for six months when my secretary, who was also new to the company, received a phone call from the division president's secretary."
 Her message, he says, was this: The president's policy was that he was to receive a Christmas gift from each person, like Mr. Villari, who reported to him directly, and that each of those gifts should cost about $100.
 Mr. Villari checked with several of his peers. Yes, it was true, they said. This was the president's policy, and it had been his policy for as long as they had been with the company.
 Mr. Villari writes: "I asked what would happen if someone did not give him a gift." He was told that no one knew, because no one had been either brave enough or dumb enough to refuse.
 "So I bought him a suitable gift," Mr. Villari says.
 In return, he received a thank-you card.
 But no gift.
 Is no gift at all worse than a thoughtless, inappropriate gift?
 Consider the case of Tessa Craib-Cox, now the director of development at the Theater School at DePaul University in Chicago. "I was working in retail for a cutting-edge design company that had built its business and reputation on creative and focused customer service," she writes. "I still have the schedule somewhere to prove that I did not have a single day off from Thanksgiving to the New Year.
 "My husband had very recently and painfully recognized his alcoholism and gone through treatment. We were struggling to survive financially, put the family together again and make many adjustments to create a new and different way of life."
 The company where Mrs. Craib-Cox was working as a store manager 20 years ago was then a relatively small concern, and the upheaval in her life had not gone unnoticed.
 Right before Christmas, when the holiday gifts were distributed, Ms. Craib-Cox was given a willow basket. Inside, in gratitude for all the extra hours of holiday merchandising she had contributed, were six bottles of wine. "My gut reaction was, of course, horror, and not the expected rapture," she writes. "Even worse, I was made by superiors to feel really guilty at my lack of appropriate appreciation."
 Not long afterward, Mrs. Craib-Cox found a new job. "The family survived, and the episode now seems sadly inept rather than malicious," she writes. She still has the willow basket to remind her to be attentive to signs that it is time to move on.
 A few years ago, when Dorothy T. Wass of Topsfield, Mass., was working as a teaching aide at aregional junior high school, she and other members of the staff were presented with a Christmas gift of poinsettias. But they came with a condition.
 "We were to return the plants in time for the annual Christmas concert," Mrs. Wass writes. "They were to be used as decorations for the stage during the performance. 
 "We were able to retrieve the plants after the concert, but we decided that we would have a little fun with our gifts."
 The months passed, and now it was June, a time for the end-of-the-school-year party for the faculty and staff, when one attendee is singled out for a tongue-and-cheek award named for the hind end of a horse.
 The recipient was the principal. The award was the dead poinsettias.
 Mrs. Wass writes, "I must say that he accepted his gifts very graciously."

PERSON: James R. Olson 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Interpreter for Toyota's Growth

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
AS Washington lobbyist for the Toyota Motor Corporation, James R. Olson spent years developing relationships on Capitol Hill and in the White House. But in 1995, he thought that his political world had come to an end. That May, Mr. Olson watched in dismay as the Clinton administration threatened to place a 100 percent tariff on sales of Japanese luxury cars in the United States, part of a trade war with Japan over American companies gaining access to its market.
 The dispute was resolved a month later, but not before Mr. Olson vowed to expand Toyota's leverage in the United States. He figured that the Japanese company's clout would be much greater if it had factories in more than just one state: Kentucky. 
 Toyota now has five American plants -- in Alabama, Indiana, Kentucky and West Virginia -- and one under construction in Texas. When Mr. Olson retired this month after 18 years as Toyota's field general in the American political and economic wars, he was pretty confident that the automaker was finally safe from Detroit's protectionist volleys. 
 "We've got 35,000 employees and $14 billion invested" in dealerships, development centers and factories across the United States, said Mr. Olson, 62, who joined Toyota in 1985, after working for the Ford Motor Company.
 In an interview, Mr. Olson said the political environment had changed greatly during his tenure: "What are you going to do, blow up our plants? We have countless political allies that like Toyota and would be willing to stand up for us." 
 "We're too embedded here now" to be threatened by protectionism, he concluded.
 Toyota, whose biggest market is the United States, has said that its intent was to build vehicles close to its customers. But Mr. Olson bluntly acknowledged another factor. "There is a business reason, but there is also a political reason," he said.
 He defends his willingness to leverage Toyota's economic capital by pointing to the tactics of Detroit companies, longtime powerhouses on the Washington scene. "The Big Three have used government affairs as an offensive weapon for years," he said. "They know how to use their political networks and do so superbly." 
 Such forthrightness has made Mr. Olson one of the most visible and controversial figures in the American automobile industry in the last two decades. He is fond of pink dress shirts and navy pinstriped suits, has a cackling laugh that can be heard a block away and has a gutsy pragmatism about the automotive game.
 Mr. Olson and his wife, Mary Ann, who have a grown son, Cameron, divide their time between New York and a sprawling post-and-beam house, which Mr. Olson helped design, in North Carolina.
He expects to remain a consultant to Toyota, where he was an interpreter of American ways for a succession of Japanese executives who were initially skittish about having too large a profile in the United States. One who listened most closely was Toyota's chairman, Shoichiro Toyoda, an architect of its American expansion plans. Mr. Olson met Mr. Toyoda in November 1985, when the diminutive Mr. Toyoda traveled to inaugurate Toyota's plant in Georgetown, Ky. 
 Mr. Olson, much taller, feared that a regular-sized American lectern might make Mr. Toyoda seem even shorter. So he called friends at a parts supplier and ordered a motorized lectern that could be adjusted for height. Arriving for the ceremony, Mr. Olson discovered that Mr. Toyoda's assistants had set the lectern for his height, then taped the controls shut. While Mr. Toyoda and the lectern were in harmony, the shortened stand made Mr. Olson look like Quasimodo by comparison, he recalled, laughing.
 Always concerned about appearances, Mr. Olson regularly conducted market research to gauge how Americans felt about buying cars from a Japanese company.
 The latest surveys, taken this fall, showed that 75 percent of Americans did not consider a company's nationality in choosing a car, Mr. Olson said. That is up from 63 percent just after the September 2001 terrorist attacks. And it is 15 percentage points higher than equivalent surveys showed in 1992, which Mr. Olson considers a turning point for foreign auto companies in the United States.
 Public opinion, as measured by the surveys, began to shift in the wake of the 1992 trip to Japan by the first President George Bush, accompanied by Chrysler's former chief executive, Lee A. Iacocca, and other Detroit automobile executives, he said.
 Mr. Olson speculated that American consumers were disillusioned by seeing Mr. Bush, who famously fell ill at a banquet, lobby the Japanese government on Detroit's behalf. "That really backfired on the Big Three," Mr. Olson said.
 But as one of the first Americans to join a Japanese company, Mr. Olson has felt Detroit's bite. On the day he resigned from Ford's public relations department, he said, he was given an hour to pack his things and was escorted out of Ford's headquarters by security workers. With one exception, none of his co-workers said farewell. 
 "The only person who had the class to say goodbye was Edsel," Mr. Olson said, referring to Edsel B. Ford II, a company director and Henry Ford's great-grandson.
 MR. OLSON said he never regretted switching sides. Even in his 18 years at Ford, its engineers recognized the quality of Toyota's cars and its manufacturing expertise, he said. Detroit's bosses were a different story. 
 "I sometimes think top management may have underestimated us," Mr. Olson said.
 Not anymore. In August, Toyota outsold the Chrysler Group, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, in cars and trucks, not including the Mercedes luxury brand, in the United States, though Chrysler has surpassed it narrowly each month since. Toyota, meanwhile, passed Ford in global sales for the third quarter, to become the world's second-largest auto company, behind General Motors. 
 Toyota's chief executive, Fujio Cho, is pushing the company to capture 15 percent of the global market by 2010, similar to what G.M. has now.
 Mr. Olson, however, is not underestimating Detroit's ability to rally. "I've seen the Big Three time and time again come back from the brink of death," he said. "If they hit a lot of doubles, triples and home runs, they could bounce right back."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Weak Dollar Has Put U.S. Assets On Sale

BYLINE:  By DANIEL GROSS; Daniel Gross writes the Moneybox column for Slate.com.

 BODY:
IF currencies were basketball teams, the dollar could be this year's version of the New York Knicks, who have lost about two-thirds of their games this season. With each passing week, the once-mighty franchise slips further in a league increasingly populated by European andAsian talent. 
 In 2003, the American dollar has fallen about 19 percent against the euro, and around 10 percent against the British pound. And the dollar has not fared much better against other currencies of major trading partners like Japan and Canada. 
 Bond market analysts worry that a weak dollar and low interest rates will encourage foreign investors -- particularly Asian and European investors who finance so much of our government debt -- to invest elsewhere. 
 That would be disastrous. With the overall trade deficit widening, securities are among the most significant American exports.
 But selling government bonds is just one of many ways we repatriate capital. The dollars we send into temporary exile come home in the wallets of British tourists at Disney World, or through stock purchases by European pension funds. Dollars also return when Japanese golfers buy villas in Hawaii or when German companies snap up American competitors. And with the dollar significantly weakened, all these assets are effectively on sale.
 Some indicators point to an increase in cross-border investment of late. For 2003, European companies announced acquisitions of American companies worth $13 billion, compared with $44 billion in 2002, according to Thomson First Call. But nearly 40 percent of the year's total -- or $5.1 billion -- came in the fourth quarter, more than double the pace of the third quarter. 
 Many deals have occurred this month. Henkel, the German consumer products company, agreed to buy the Dial Corporation for $2.9 billion, and announced last week that it was buying the hair care company Advanced Research Laboratories for an undisclosed price. Also last week, a federal bankruptcy court judge approved the sale of assets of Rouge Industries to the Russian steel maker Severstal. 
 Rebecca McCaughrin, an economist at Morgan Stanley, suggests that these deals are a harbinger for 2004.
 "We've seen domestic mergers and acquisitions activity rise, and that generally leads to spillover in cross-border deals," Ms. McCaughrin said. 
 The strength of foreign currencies is also having a salutary impact on tourism. Now that the euro goes much farther at the Venetian resort in Las Vegas than it does in Venice, European tourists, who account for 45 percent of all overseas arrivals and spent about $22 billion in 2002, are returning to the United States. Last week, the Commerce Department reported that there were 2 percent more visitors from Western Europe in September than in September 2002. There were 5 percent more visitors from Britain, 13 percent more from Italy and 15 percent more from Spain. For 2004, the Commerce Department projects a 6 percent increase in visitors from Europe. 
 "The weak dollar couldn't have come at a better time," said Andrea Stokes, director of marketing and international research at the Travel Industry Association of America, a trade group in Washington. 
 IT makes sense that tourists would flock to areas where their domestic currency packs the greatest punch. But when it travels around the globe, money does not always behave so rationally. 
 When the dollar falls, foreigners might be expected to dump fixed-income assets like bonds and buy stocks -- especially now that stock markets are strengthening. But in the third quarter, according to the Securities Industry Association, foreigners bought $155.9 billion worth of American bonds while selling $2.6 billion in American equities. Over all, foreign acquisitions of American securities in the first nine months of 2003 totaled $539.9 billion, just short of the record $547.5 billion for all of 2002. In other words, as the dollar skidded, cash flowed into American markets at a healthy rate this year. 
 But the stream of foreign investments was counterintuitively channeled into safe government bonds, not stocks.
 What gives? Perhaps European shoppers simply aren't as accustomed to discount shopping as we are. What's more, when it comes to buying stocks, European investors, who piled into American stocks at the height of the market, have proved to be lousy market timers. 
 "They've pared back their stock investment very significantly in the past two years, and they haven't returned to the market," Ms. McCaughrin of Morgan Stanley said. "They largely missed out on the rally of the past six months."
