HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Want to Pump New Life Into a Fund? Change Its Name

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
INVESTORS apparently pay much attention to mutual funds' names. Funds that change names often receive a significant increase in inflows, even when they have not altered their investment strategies.
 Though this behavior appears irrational, it is widespread, according to a recent study conducted by three finance professors, Michael J. Cooper and P.Raghavendra Rau, both of Purdue University, and Huseyin Gulen of Virginia Tech. They examined 296 stock mutual funds in the United States that changed their names from April 1994 to July 2001 by adding or deleting the words "value," "growth," "small" or "large." The professors' study is online at papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract--id=423989. 
 The researchers found that the bulk of these funds changed their names either to remove any association with a lagging investment style or to create an association with a strong style. In the late 1990's, for example, most changes involved eliminating the words "small cap" and "value" or adding the words "large cap" and "growth."
 The researchers found that these funds had a significant increase in new investments after the name changes. Using a complex statistical technique, they estimated how much the funds' net assets would have grown in one year without the name changes. On average, the funds' actual total assets were 22 percent greater than the estimates a year after the name changes.
 The average fund in the study had $299 million in net assets when it changed its name. The findings mean that one year later, the average fund had $65 million more assets than if it would have had by keeping its old name. Across all 296 funds in the sample, that translates into a total shift of more than $19 billion.
 The increased inflows do not necessarily mean that investors were responding to name changes alone. Some funds might have altered their investment strategies at the same time they changed their names, so investors might have been reacting to those new strategies, too.
 But while some renamed funds did change their investment approaches, the researchers found that many others did not. And the assets of both types grew at similar rates after the name changes.
 The researchers also looked at the possible role of advertising but found further evidence that investors were reacting primarily to the name changes alone. Though funds that increased their ad budgets had higher inflows, so did funds that did not increase their advertising, as well as those with no advertising budget at all. 
 Of course, if funds improved their performance after the name changes, they could argue that the changes were more than cosmetic. But the researchers found just the opposite, on average. They compared each fund with a control group of funds that owned similar stocks, as indicated by factors like market capitalization and the ratio of price to book value. They found that the average renamed fund lagged behind its control group by 2.3 percent over the year after its name change.
 The new study shows that many investors are choosing mutual funds based on factors having nothing to do with the funds' actual performance or strategies. Professor Cooper says he believes that investors would be better served by using objective criteria like past performance, turnover rates and expenses in deciding among funds.
 IN January 2001, the Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a rule that prohibits mutual funds from using misleading names. The rule was adopted six months before the end of the period analyzed by the researchers, so the study sheds little light on whether the rule will be effective in reducing the number of funds that make purely cosmetic name changes.
 But the researchers doubt that it will. They note that the S.E.C.'s new rule puts no restrictions on funds' use of the words "growth" and "value." Further, funds whose names include "small cap" or "large cap" are restricted in the kind of stocks they own only if they have defined such terms themselves. If they have not, the new S.E.C. rule leaves them free to use those terms in any way they wish.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "What's in a Name?"After the MFS Equity Income fund changed its name to MFS Value, money flows into the fund increased sharply. Graph tracks MFS Value Fund (monthly net inflows) from 2000 to 2001 and since name change in 2001. (Source by Michael J. Cooper, Huseyin Gulen and P. Raghavendra Rau)

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
So, There May Be Jobs After All

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
 So your child goes off to college, you hover at the doorway of her room for a year or two, then finally, stealthily, move in some books, the extra computer, perhaps an easy chair. Then -- surprise! -- four years later she moves right back in. 
"Sorry, Dad, no jobs." And farewell empty nest. 
 Not to worry, says Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm. Yes, many jobs are taking a fast freighter to China, but the aging of the baby boomers -- yes, you with the creaky knees -- will help set off "a surge in job creation next year," says John A. Challenger, the firm's chief executive. Some jobs, like financial planner and physical therapist, simply can't be exported. Thats the theory, anyway. HUBERT B. HERRING

HEADLINE: Where U.S. Translates As Freedom 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN; Maureen Dowd is on vacation.

DATELINE: WARSAW 

 BODY:
I found the cure.
 I found the cure to anti-Americanism: Come to Poland. 
 After two years of traveling almost exclusively to Western Europe and the Middle East, Poland feels like a geopolitical spa. I visited here for just three days and got two years of anti-American bruises massaged out of me. Get this: people here actually tell you they like America -- without whispering. What has gotten into these people? Have all their subscriptions to Le Monde Diplomatique expired? Haven't they gotten the word from Berlin and Paris? No, they haven't. In fact, Poland is the antidote to European anti-Americanism. Poland is to France what Advil is to a pain in the neck. Or as Michael Mandelbaum, the Johns Hopkins foreign affairs specialist, remarked after visiting Poland: "Poland is the most pro-American country in the world -- including the United States." 
What's this all about? It starts with history and geography. There's nothing like living between Germany and Russia -- which at different times have trampled Poland off the map -- to make Poles the biggest advocates of a permanent U.S. military presence in Europe. Said Ewa Swiderska, 25, a Warsaw University student: "We are the small kid in school who is really happy to have the big guy be his friend -- it's a nice feeling."
Indeed, all the history and geography that Western European youth have forgotten, having grown up in a postmodern European Union, are still central to Polish consciousness -- well after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. "We still remember many things," said Jan Miroslaw, 22, also a Warsaw University student. "We are more eager to cooperate with America rather than just say 'no.' The West Europeans just don't remember many things -- like the wars. They live too-comfortable lives."
No wonder then when young Poles think of America, they think of the word "freedom." They think of generations of U.S. presidents railing against their communist oppressors. There is a huge message in this bottle. In the Arab world, because of a long history of U.S. support for Arab autocrats, who kept their people down but their oil flowing to us, America was a synonym for hypocrisy. In Poland, where we have consistently trumpeted freedom, America means freedom. We need to remember that. We are what we stand for.
Poland's becoming a member of the E.U. will give the U.S. an important friend within that body -- a counterweight to those E.U. forces that would like to use anti-Americanism as the glue to bind the expanding alliance and that would like to see the E.U. forge its identity as the great Uncola to America's Coca-Cola.
But as powerful as Poland's bond to America is these days, we dare not take it for granted. Poland has some 2,400 troops in Iraq. That's the good news. The bad news is that roughly 75 percent of Poles oppose their deployment. Polish officials will tell you Poland sent troops to Iraq to help keep the Americans in Europe. But the public doesn't make such connections, and most people don't understand what their boys are doing there or what Poland is getting out of it. (How about a few extra visas for Poles?) If the U.S. ends up in a mess in Iraq, so will Poland. Many "old" Europeans will then laugh at Warsaw, and that would be highly corrosive for Polish-U.S. relations.
At the same time, once Poland is fully ensconced in the E.U., its young people will grow up in that postmodern E.U. nirvana, where anti-Americanism is in the drinking water. Sadly, many education and public diplomacy programs the U.S. directed at Eastern Europe after the fall of communism have been cut or redirected to the Muslim world. Bad timing.
There is now a competition between the United States of America and the United States of Europe for the next generation of Poles -- who don't all have their parents' emotional ties to the U.S. -- "and the U.S. is losing this competition," says a Polish foreign policy expert, Grzegorz Kostrzewa-Zorbas. "The new generation in Poland likes American pop culture, but it has less contact with American high culture -- like education. It is so much easier for young Poles to go to university in Germany or France."
Given Poland's geography and history, there's a limit to how far it will drift from America. Poland will never be France. But we shouldn't assume it will remain the Poland of 1989 forever, either, and if it doesn't, that could have real consequences for America's standing in Europe.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
On Farm of Pampered Cows, Couple Cringes at the Mention of Mad Ones

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES

DATELINE: LAFAYETTE, N.J. 

 BODY:
ANY doubt about who is really in charge at Ken and Julie Bechtold's dairy farm along a rustic ribbon of road is dispelled at the stockade fence out front. There, outside a weathered barn, a yellow sign urges visitors to yield with a simple message: "Moo Cow Xing."
 "You have a happy cow, you get good cheese," Mrs. Bechtold said Friday, explaining the care -- she unapologetically calls it pampering -- lavished on the 20 or so "moo cows" here who have lived their entire lives in something of a cattle-based bubble. "We have what's called a closed herd. All our cows were born here on this farm. We've never brought cows in. When you do, your disease level goes up, you don't know where that cow came from, how it was treated." 
 The answers to those kinds of questions became all the more important last week when agriculture officials announced that a dairy cow from a farm near Seattle had tested positive for bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. It was the nation's first reported case of the disease, which can be fatal to people who eat infected beef.
As beef exporters grappled with a widening ban on United States meat, and as agriculture and public health officials tried to determine how the Washington State Holstein contracted the illness, farmers like the Bechtolds wait and hang on every report.
"I heard on CNN they've quarantined more cows," Mrs. Bechtold said, referring to the isolation of thousands of cows under way at two Washington farms. "I hope they can retrace where this cow came from."
The Bechtolds said they had no reason to fear for the health of their cows. Besides being far from the Washington case, the Bechtolds said the closed-herd upbringing of their cows provided another layer of insulation. "We're lucky in that respect," Mr. Bechtold said.
But even as they brush aside fear for themselves, the Bechtolds wonder about the effects of the disease's discovery on their fellow farmers and on the future of agriculture in general and farming in the region in particular.
"This is going to hurt a lot of people," Mr. Bechtold said, standing near an old barrel-shaped butter churn while his wife arranged wrapped wedges of Colby and cheddar cheeses that they sell out of the barn on their 140-acre farm. "You really wonder about the financial impact."
Already, Mr. Bechtold said, in a quarter-century or so of milking cows and making cheese, he has watched the number of fellow farmers dwindle. While thousands of dairy farms once dotted the state, he said, now there are slightly more than a hundred.
"It's kind of sad to see the farms disappearing," he said. "It's discouraging what's been happening to some farms. Especially in New Jersey."
Part of the change can be attributed to the spread of development across the state. Part can be traced to the changing economic forces that have been at play for years on farms in New Jersey and across the nation.
"It's not easy doing business here," he said. "The taxes -- believe me, we're not in this for the money."
And it is with an emphasis on the economical that the Bechtolds run their place, called Stoney Croft Farm. The cheeses that the couple produce are as well known for their high quality as for their low cost, with customers regularly driving to the farm in Sussex County, about 20 miles from New Jersey's northernmost point.
THE cows -- of the Jersey breed, of course -- meander about the farm between sunup and sundown milkings and chew cud at the edge of a fence, with yellow ID tags affixed to their ears. Walking across a muddy, haystrewn path on Friday, Mrs. Bechtold seemed to dote on the animals as she would on her three children.
"They all have names," she said, referring to the cows (her children do, too: Jennifer, Kenny and Kate).
Partly to keep costs down and partly out of respect for tradition, the Bechtolds have largely done without modern farming equipment. "My oldest tractor is a 1948," Mr. Bechtold said. "My new one is a 1978."
Besides the cheeses they produce, the Bechtolds have a small garden where they grow vegetables for themselves.
As Mrs. Bechtold sees it, "We figured we've got the manure, why not use it?"

HEADLINE: Two-Front Battle in Puerto Rico: Crime and Apathy 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R. 

 BODY:
It was a long autumn for Nestor Muniz, and the winter, he guesses, will be longer still. A stray bullet killed his daughter Nicole as she drove past a housing project here one August night, a month before her 17th birthday.
 She was among more than 750 people killed this year in Puerto Rico, a small island (only twice the size of Rhode Island) with a homicide rate more than three times the United States average. More murders per capita take place here than in any American state, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
 Since Nicole's death,which was widely covered by the news media here, Mr. Muniz has made lowering crime on the island his mission. He has organized a march with other relatives of murder victims, lobbied politicians and worked to inspire a collective sense of responsibility among Puerto Ricans -- the most crucial step, he says, toward abating the problem. 
"It's going to take a big, big change," Mr. Muniz said, taking a break at the furniture shop he manages in San Juan, where 1.5 million of the island's nearly 4 million residents live and where most of the island's violent deaths take place. "People here have been like, 'If it didn't happen to me, I don't care.' " 
Nicole's killing commanded more attention than most because of its randomness, but the outpouring of concern did not slow the homicide rate, which the police attribute largely to the drug trade. Three superintendents of the Puerto Rico Police Department have quit in two years; the latest, Victor Rivera Gonzalez, is leaving Jan. 6. In an interview, he said that even a last-minute offer to raise his $107,000 salary by $20,000 did not sway him.
Superintendent Rivera said the root problem was insufficient staffing: Puerto Rico has 21,000 police officers, and by his reckoning, the force should grow by at least 4,000. He said he envied New York City's police force, but in fact the ratio there is about the same: 40,000 officers for a population of 8 million.
As of Dec. 14, New York had 569 murders this year, according to the New York police. Puerto Rico had 752 by Dec. 17. Last year there were 774 murders on the island, up from 744 in 2001, the F.B.I. said. 
The island's major newspapers keep a running tab of the deaths, with graphic articles about shootings, stabbings and carjackings almost daily. This month alone, there have been articles about a quadruple homicide outside a San Juan disco and the shooting death of a nursery school teacher in Juncos who was hunted down in her home by a gang seeking revenge on her brother. 
After Nicole's death, Superintendent Rivera announced a new war on street crime that doubled police patrols from 4 p.m. Friday to 4 a.m. Monday, sent frequent helicopter patrols over known drug-dealing areas and dispatched K-9 units to sniff out guns at nightclubs, where many shootings have taken place.
The police have also tried to reduce an estimated 1,500 drug puntos, or distribution spots, with frequent raids, Superintendent Rivera said. And the department has shortened the initial training time for recruits, to get them on the streets faster.
Because of its 270 miles of coastline, much of it isolated, and its location between South America and the United States, Puerto Rico has long been a way station for shipments of cocaine and marijuana. About 75 percent of the drugs move on to Miami, New York and other points north, Superintendent Rivera said.
Young men peddle the drugs that remain here, often in the housing projects of San Juan, he said. The competition among dealers is fierce and often fatal. 
Murders of drug dealers and their associates are by far the most common kind, which leads some Puerto Ricans to play down the problem.
"It's not a good idea to be on the street or in the discotheque at 3 or 4 in the morning," said Freddy Van, a cabdriver in San Juan. "But if you go early or don't go at all, you don't have a problem." 
Superintendent Rivera says he wants a law requiring bars and nightclubs to close at 2 a.m. A Puerto Rican legislator proposed such a bill after the quadruple murder outside the disco, but the island's powerful tourism industry is fighting it. 
Another proposed law would increase penalties for killings by stray gunfire, which are on the rise. But some legislators said creating laws would not help, pointing to a strict gun-control law passed in 2000 that they said had done nothing to diminish a huge illegal gun trade. 
"We have enough laws on the books," said Iris Miriam Ruiz, a minority leader in the Puerto Rico House of Representatives. "We need to enforce the existing laws better and deal with the economic problems of Puerto Rico." 
Ms. Ruiz said it would also help to find a police superintendent who would stay on the job, because the department was "a difficult bureaucracy" and new superintendents needed time to win the loyalty of the force. Ms. Ruiz, like other members of the minority political party, the New Progressive Party, said Gov. Sila Calderon was too soft on crime and Puerto Rico needed a return to mano dura, or strong hand tactics.
Ms. Calderon's predecessor, Pedro Rosello, used that approach in his two terms in the 1990's, when the murder rate dropped after the number reached a high of 995 in 1994. Now Mr. Rosello is running for governor again and promising to bring back mano dura, an approach that involved, among other things, having the National Guard swoop down on housing projects.
Like Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's anticrime tactics in New York, Mr. Rosello's drew complaints of civil rights violations. 
Superintendent Rivera said that the news media had exaggerated the crime problem and that most categories of crime, including robbery, rape, aggravated assault and car theft, were down this year. He said it would be hard to adopt New York's intensive crime-fighting tactics without sharply raising police salaries, which he said start at about $21,300. In New York, the entry-level police salary is $34,500.
One point on which Superintendent Rivera and his critics agree is that Puerto Rico's bail laws need overhauling. The island's Constitution does not allow judges to deny bail and gives them wide discretion in setting it, so many accused killers go free while awaiting trial.
In one high-profile case, a man accused of killing a teenage trumpet player turned out to have been out on bail after being charged in another killing months earlier.
Mr. Muniz said that bail reform would help but that the biggest change had to be in the apathetic attitude he says has engulfed the island.
When a convoy of police vehicles descended on a drug punto in the Vista Hermosa housing project one recent Friday night, a crowd that had gathered for an outdoor party watched impassively as the police arrested a teenage boy and an older man, seizing bags of crack cocaine and marijuana from their pockets. 
A woman in a Santa Claus hat had been selling rolling papers at a table on the sidewalk and seemed to barely notice the disruption.
Mr. Muniz, who said he was never involved in politics or crime fighting before Nicole's death, said that his best consciousness-raising effort to date had been a march on Oct. 5, Nicole's 17th birthday. As many as 1,000 relatives of murder victims participated, he said, many carrying photos of their dead.
Next year, billboards will go up around San Juan with a picture of Nicole, who had hoped to study fashion design at Boston University, and a line from an essay she wrote shortly before her death: "I only wish that violence comes to an end." Mr. Muniz hopes people will notice.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 1, 2004

HEADLINE: Despite Warnings, Industry Resisted Safeguards 

BYLINE:  This article is by Christopher Drew, Elizabeth Becker and Sandra Blakeslee.

 BODY:
During a House debate last summer over a possible ban on using sick and injured cows for meat, Representative Gary L. Ackerman, a Democrat from New York, held up a photo of a crippled cow and cautioned that such "downer animals" carried the highest risk for mad cow disease.
 But Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a powerful Texas Democrat and a rancher, countered that the government's screening program was tight enough to prevent any problems. 
 "The picture the gentleman is showing, that sick animal, will never find its way into the food chain," Mr. Stenholmsaid. "Period."
But now that a downer cow has the first confirmed case of mad cow disease in the United States, critics are assailing the beef industry and federal regulators for not taking greater precautions since the disease exploded overseas in the mid-1980's. 
Though some scientists had long warned that mad cow disease would eventually appear in the United States, cattle owners and meatpackers repeatedly resisted calls for a more substantial program to test for the disease, and the Agriculture Department went along with them. Congress came close three times to banning the sale of meat from downer cows -- ones that are too sick or hurt to amble into slaughterhouses -- only to see the industry's allies block each of the bills at the last moment. And proposals for systems to track which farms produced sickened cattle -- now required in Europe, Canada and Japan -- also languished for years here.
"This is one of these times when unrealistic optimism triumphed over responsibility to the public," said Carol Tucker Foreman, a consumer advocate who ran the Agriculture Department's food-safety programs in the Carter administration.
If a number of countries stick with hastily announced plans to ban American beef, she added, "I think the damage to the American meat industry costs infinitely more than anything U.S. cattlemen would have had to pay to do this thing right."
Each year at least 200,000 cattle -- and perhaps many more -- are downers, and some of these animals could have mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy, which can destroy an animal's brain and central nervous system and lead to similar ailments in humans who eat diseased meat.
That is only a small fraction of the 104 million cattle in the United States and the 35 million slaughtered each year, suggesting that the industry may have taken a disproportionate risk in continuing to sell meat from the downers.
Government officials and packinghouse executives are now rethinking their positions and promising at least to consider many of the proposed changes they once rejected. They still say it did not make sense to do more earlier, given how expensive it would have been to guard against a disease that was not yet visible.
Many industry and government officials say they also believe that the disease and the damage from it can be contained, and that view was bolstered yesterday by the news that the Holstein cow that had the disease in Washington State was imported from Canada. The cow, which was slaughtered on Dec. 9, had not shown any signs of mad cow disease, but was considered a downer because it had been injured in giving birth to a large calf. The first North American case of mad cow disease was discovered last May in a downer cow in Wanham, Alberta. 
"We're looking at what Europe is doing, what Canada is doing," Alisa Harrison, the press secretary for Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman, said in an interview Friday. "Yes, we're looking at the whole system, we're looking at all options."
But a close look at how the crisis developed also reveals broader problems that could complicate efforts to restore consumer confidence and to ensure that no other tainted meat enters the food supply.
The nation's meat inspection system has undergone sweeping changes, with the government shifting much of the responsibility for safety to meat companies. 
Beef production has also become increasingly concentrated and industrialized. Many packing plants now use advanced systems to extract more meat close to the animals' bones and spinal cords, increasing the chances that possibly risky tissue from their central nervous systems could end up in hamburgers and other processed meat.
And some scientists question whether government officials, even now, appreciate the full extent of the dangers. In some ways, the Agriculture Department still "believes its own propaganda," said Dr. Stanley Prusiner, a Nobel Prize-winning neurologist at the University of California in San Francisco and an authority on these types of diseases.
In Britain, more than 4.5 million animals have been killed since the disease was discovered in 1986. A related brain-wasting disease has killed 137 people, mostly in Britain.
The United States banned imports of live British cattle, and in 1997, the Food and Drug Administration, which oversees what animals eat, drafted a regulation: no more feeding bits of cows and other ruminants back to cows.
But critics say the regulation leaves glaring loopholes. Rendered cattle can be fed to pigs and chickens, which can then be fed back to cows. Cow blood, which cannot be guaranteed free of disease, is widely fed to calves as a "milk replacer." Deer that may be infected with disease can be rendered into cattle feed. Enforcement of the regulation, they say, has been lax.
Dr. Stephen Sundlof, an F.D.A. veterinarian, said that "with any new rule there is a period of time that compliance is not 100 percent -- and then it gets better." 
But Dr. Prusiner said the cow, whether born in the United States or Canada, "probably didn't get sick by eating anything."
He said regulators in both countries believed that mad cow illness was akin to a viral disease that "comes from the outside" and can be stopped by putting animals into quarantine. But given his suspicions that mad cow disease is endemic in both countries in low levels, it is more likely that the one or both cows had a spontaneous homegrown form of the disease and not the British version. He also said that using cow blood as a milk replacer is "a really stupid idea."
Food-safety experts said that slaughter and meatpacking procedures also may have to change.
Several major restaurant chains -- including McDonald's, Wendy's and Burger King -- have long refused to serve meat from downer animals to avoid health problems.
But powerful lobbies representing big ranchers and dairy farmers have stopped efforts in Congress in each of the last three years to prohibit slaughtering these animals for meat sold elsewhere.
Chandler Keyes, the Washington lobbyist for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, said that because some downer animals merely have injuries like broken legs, his group would continue to resist efforts to declare all downer animals unfit for human consumption. That is a decision, he said, that is best left to federal veterinarians who inspect cows as they enter the nation's slaughterhouses.
But trusting federal veterinarians to find mad cow disease may be a mistake, an inspector at a Midwest meatpacking firm said. The inspector said that in his two years overseeing the killing of 600 downer cows, the veterinarian at his plant tested the central nervous tissue of only one of the animals. "All we tested downer cows for was antibiotic residue," said the inspector, who insisted on anonymity to protect his job.
Wayne Pacelle, the chief lobbyist for the Humane Society of the United States, said the economic devastation wrought by the nation's first confirmed case of mad cow disease was already changing the minds of some politicians who previously had been unmoved by arguments about public health and animal husbandry.
"Now the public realizes there is no firewall between B.S.E. and the American consumer," Mr. Pacelle said. 
Last year, the Agriculture Department tested processed products from plants that use advanced meat recovery systems, which are meant to strip the last bits of meat from close to an animal's bone and spinal column, and found that 35 percent of the meat tested positive for central nervous system tissue.
Caroline Smith DeWaal of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer group, said the Agriculture Department still considered the presence of such tissue in meat to be more a labeling than a safety issue. Felicia Nestor, the food safety director at the Government Accountability Project, another advocacy group, added that given the possible dangers of eating such tissues, "it's just unacceptable that the American public should be put in this position." 
Computerized systems for tracing food have also grown overseas. Outbreaks can be blocked early if an animal's history can be quickly obtained.
After waging their own battles with mad cow disease, Europe, Canada and Japan instituted government-regulated mandatory systems to trace animals from their birth to the grocery. They also require extensive testing of cattle herds, not the small risk assessment used in the United States that tests 20,000 to 30,000 cows or about 0.03 percent of the herds.
The United States does not require or have such records. But Agriculture Department officials said they would now speed up a project to create a national database for tracing animals. The system would be voluntary; farmers and ranchers could decide whether to register their animals in the data bank.
"At some point this could become mandatory," Ms. Harrison said.
In an industrialized agriculture system like the United States, where animals can be shipped thousands of miles in the course of being birthed, fed, slaughtered and packaged, the possibility of an uncontrolled outbreak has increased exponentially, the officials say.
"We need to be able to instantaneously track the history of a sick animal," said Mr. Stenholm, the Texas lawmaker, who also said he was ready to work on ways to keep sick animals out of the food system.
Dr. Prusiner and others say the only hope is better testing. Neither the United States nor Canada has ever carried out surveillance efforts beyond testing small numbers of downer cows, based on the notion that if mad cow disease were to appear, it would most likely show up in older animals showing signs of illness. By contrast, Western European countries tested 10 million cows last year, and Japan tested each of the 1.2 million cows it slaughtered.
Some experts say advances in the tests making them cheaper and quicker to conduct could make it easier to expand their use here and provide an answer to the crisis.
Representative Rosa DeLauro, Democrat of Connecticut and cochairwoman of the House Food Safety Caucus, said, "In this new age, where most cattle in the United States don't eat grass in open pastures, where they're crammed into feedlots most of their lives, and where we don't know where our meat comes from, I think it's time we take our safety precautions into the modern era."

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP 

BYLINE:  By Joseph P. Fried

 BODY:
Still Making Deals At a Different Table
 Years back, Theodore W. Kheel helped settle so many big and bitter labor disputes in New York and around the country that he was widely regarded as the maestro of mediation. 
 These days, he still uses his talent for bringing people together, though for ends other than soothing passions at the bargaining table. 
Mr. Kheel, a lawyer who specialized in seeking consensus in union-management wars, was most often spotlighted as a mediator and union adviser in the 1960's and 70's, when he helped settle transit and newspaper strikes in New York as well as labor clashes in the railroad, airline and waterfront industries nationally.
In the 1980's, Mr. Kheel, then in his 70's, was called on to help in fewer conflicts. Old friends among union leaders died or retired, he lacked the same ties with their successors, and he and Edward I. Koch, the mayor, had an antagonistic relationship.
But phasing out of labor strife did not mean a slower life. "I'm as active now as I ever was," Mr. Kheel, now 89, said by phone from the office of Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, the law firm in Manhattan with which he is affiliated. 
He has long been involved in environmental protection campaigns and groups, including Earth Pledge, a nonprofit group he founded in 1991. 
He represented the artists Christo and Jeanne-Claude in negotiations that led to the city's approval last January of their proposal to decorate Central Park's walkways for two weeks in February 2005 with gates topped by translucent saffron-colored fabric. Profits from selling products based on the project will go entirely to environmental and arts causes.
On the business side, Mr. Kheel is chairman of Grupo Punta Cana, a company that has turned a 30-square-mile stretch of coastal jungle in the Dominican Republic into a tourist and vacation-home resort. 
The company sponsors a foundation for environmental research in the area, which is consistent with the outlook Mr. Kheel expressed. "We want both to protect the environment and encourage economic development," he said, ever the mediator.

In Brooklyn, a Name Is Looking for a Home
Whither BoCoCa?
TriBeCa has stuck, a 1970's name for a Lower Manhattan area thought of as a triangle below Canal Street. So too SoHo, 1960's coinage for an area south of Houston Street. NoLIta (north of Little Italy) and Dumbo in Brooklyn (down under the Manhattan Bridge overpass), both of more recent vintage, seem to have a foothold. Not so LoBro, minted in the 80's for a stretch of Lower Broadway in Manhattan but not much heard today.
BoCoCa is an umbrella coinage for three adjacent Brooklyn areas, Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens. Christopher Branstetter, a Web site designer, says he and Sandra Paez, who owns a women's clothing shop called Frida's Closet on increasingly trendy Smith Street running through Carroll Gardens and Boerum Hill, came up with BoCoCa three years ago for a local shopping guide.
Travel and other magazines and NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors' bureau, have cited the name.
On and around Smith Street last week, of six local residents stopped at random, four knew of BoCoCa but said they considered themselves residents of Carroll Gardens, while two said they had never heard of BoCoCa. It is safe to say there is a way to go before we know whether BoCoCa will catch on or be a no go like LoBro.

HEADLINE: In Lieu of Flowers: Remembering 17 Who Made a Difference 

BYLINE:  By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER

 BODY:
Long Island First
 Frank Tracy Jr.'s motive was simple. He wanted Long Islanders to know that they lived in a special place. 
 "Frank had this vision that we needed an organization that would raise awareness about all the riches we have on Long Island," said Brian R. McCaffrey, president of Promote Long Island, the not-for-profit organization that Mr. Tracy founded a decade ago. 
 A tireless cheerleader who earned the nicknames Mr. Long Island and Mayor of Long Island, Mr. Tracy never stopped pushing his mission statement: "To foster and promote public awareness and appreciation of Long Island, particularly the benefits of living on Long Island and Long Island's parks, beaches, cultural, educational, recreational and tourist activities," it began. He also championed the regional economy and activities designed to rally Long Island spirit and pride.
 In spite of objections from the post office, Mr. Tracy lobbied local businesses to put Long Island, or at least the abbreviation, L.I., in their addresses -- as in Melville, L.I. N.Y., where he lived. 
 "We just aren't a suburb of New York," Mr. McCaffrey said. "We are Long Island."
 The son of a military man, Mr. Tracy graduated from Sewanhaka High School but spent much of his youth moving from military base to military base before his family finally settled in Floral Park. 
 "His biggest thing was he wanted to have the rest of the United States and world to know about Long Island," said Yolanka Tracy, his wife of 46 years. "He was for Long Island." 
 Mr. Tracy had a home improvement company, Long Island Cnstrctn Inc., when in the late 1980's he started attending meetings of different Long Island organizations like the Hauppauge Industrial Association looking for people to support his cause. 
 "He was quite unstoppable," said Stephanie Tracy, one of his five children. 
 Mr. Tracy networked endlessly, setting up Promote Long Island kiosks at local events, handing out free I Love Long Island pins when someone joined his organization. His car was covered in Promote Long Island stickers and even his license plate revealed his loyalty: Lng Ilnd. 
 Mr. Tracy died on Jan. 9 of lung disease. He was 69.

A Trailblazer in Blue
 When Thomas S. Gulotta, then the Nassau county executive, told William Willett that he was going to recommend him as the next police commissioner in Nassau County, Mr. Willett struggled to fight back tears. 
 "He said to me, 'I never thought I'd be police commissioner,"' Mr. Gulotta said, recalling that moment in 2000. "'You made a dream of a lifetime for me and for my family come true."'
 Mr. Gulotta said that Mr. Willett, the county's first African-American police commissioner, was the consummate professional law enforcement officer.
 "He earned the respect of the members of the department as well as the residents of the community," Mr. Gulotta said. "He treated everyone with dignity and respect and with fairness. He knew law enforcement and the operation of the Nassau County Police Department inside and out, as thoroughly as anyone could." 
 The Police Benevolent Association president, Gary DelaRaba, said Mr. Willett had compassion for police officers. "He knew what cops went through on the street," Mr. DelaRaba said. "He instilled a pride into the police officer. It wasn't about having the job. It was about doing the job." 
 Mr. Willett was born in Glen Cove and lived in Westbury. When he joined the police department in 1953 after serving in the Navy during the Korean War, there were only 18 blacks in the department. 
 He never planned to be a police officer, said Floretta Willett, his wife for 47 years. He took the civil service test because he couldn't find another job and joined the police force as a patrolman. 
 Mr. Willett once recalled that the first accident he responded to as a rookie took place when a white driver noticed him standing on a street corner with a gun. Startled, the driver backed her car into the one behind her. 
 He spent evenings studying for career advancement exams that propelled him through the ranks. "He knew he had to be 110 percent," Mrs. Willett said. 
 He became the first black patrol supervisor and the first black precinct commander. He was first deputy commissioner for seven years before being named commissioner of a department with a $520 million budget. He served as commissioner only 14 months before reaching the mandatory retirement age of 70.
 Mrs. Willett said that her husband's father, Marston, would tease him, saying, "How are you going to be a police officer? They don't take people with flat feet."
 Years later, she said, her husband would respond, "See, Pop, those flat feet brought me a long way." 
 Mr. Willett died on April 12 of lung cancer. He was 71.

An Oyster Bay Guardian
 Dorothy Horton McGee was more than the historian for the Town of Oyster Bay. With her wide-brimmed hats and the parasol she carried on hot, sunny days, she seemed to become part of the very history she wrote and recorded. 
 "Ms. McGee was someone who went well beyond keeping records and telling you on what date something happened," said John Venditto, the town supervisor. "She made the history of this town relevant to today."
 Ms. McGee, who took on the historian's job in 1982 for $1,500 a year, had a North Shore patrician's genteel, guarded manners and regal bearing. But she knew her stuff, and didn't hesitate to speak out. When a group approached Mr. Venditto and asked the town to accept the wooden sailing vessel Regina Maris, the supervisor figured it was worthwhile but deferred to Ms. McGee's judgment. 
 "Ms. McGee in her inimitable style let us all have it," Mr. Venditto recalled. "She pointed out the folly of the town getting involved in an undertaking of this vessel."
 Some time later, the city of Glen Cove agreed to park the ship along its waterfront. It sank at the dock, becoming a political and governmental quagmire. 
 "She had done her homework and understood the problems," Mr. Venditto said. "She did not want to see anything adverse happening to the town."
 Michael Spinelli, an architect, worked with Ms. McGee on the town Landmarks Preservation Commission, which she helped found and had headed since 1990, landmarking 40 buildings. 
 "If a notable person lived there or a significant historical event took place or if the building had architectural significance, Dorothy would speak to all three," Mr. Spinelli said. He recalled that she pulled out photographs of Theodore Roosevelt speaking to residents from the back of a train in her effort have the Oyster Bay railroad station landmarked. 
 Ms. McGee was the historian for Matinecock and, during the 1950's, an assistant historian for Roslyn. She wrote books about the signers of the Declaration of Independence, the framers of the Constitution, Herbert Hoover and Alexander Hamilton, and edited the first three editions of "Landmarks of Long Island," a guide for the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, where she was a trustee. 
 She also was director of the Raynham Hall Museum, the spy house that belonged to the Townsend family in Oyster Bay. But the story Ms. McGee told in the book, "Sally Townsend: Patriot" (1952, Dodd, Mead) about the uncovering of the Benedict Arnold plot to betray West Point, raised eyebrows. "It's not a version accepted by Long Island historians, but it made a very good story," said Richard Evers, the Hicksville library historian. 
 Ms. McGee, who lived in Locust Valley, died on Oct. 12. She was 89. 

A Star in the Firmament
 George Plimpton, the literary journalist, editor of The Paris Review, amateur athlete and patrician about town, was the author of more than 30 books and a cameo actor in multiple movies. But on the East End of Long Island, Mr. Plimpton was best known for his penchant for pyrotechnics.
 For boaters anchored in Three Mile Harbor and thousands of spectators on shore, Mr. Plimpton was the voice of the Boys and Girls Harbor fireworks fund-raiser held on Bastille Day for nearly three decades. 
 "The Boys Harbor party celebration was synonymous with George Plimpton," said Felix Grucci Jr., the fireworks impresario and former congressman. "George had a deep passion and a love for fireworks. He always referred to them as the eighth wonder of the world."
 On his way to the South Fork where he summered, Mr. Plimpton often stopped by the Grucci fireworks factory in Bellport, where he struck up a friendship with Felix Grucci Sr. On one of his early trips, Mr. Grucci gave him a care package of sparklers, spinning wheels and Roman candles. That Fourth of July, Mr. Plimpton lit them in his East Hampton backyard.
 After the fireworks got Mr. Plimpton into trouble with the local police, he looked around for a new venue. Tony Duke, a longtime friend, asked Mr. Plimpton if he could do the fireworks as a benefit at Boys and Girls Harbor, a 30-acre summer camp on the East End for disadvantaged youth. 
 "George turned the tables," Mr. Duke recalled. "He said to me, 'I had been wishing that you, particularly with Boys Harbor, would come along and ask me to do the fireworks. Would you do me the great honor?' He made me feel I was doing him a favor and it was just the opposite." 
 That first year the fireworks show, put on with the Gruccis, raised $10,000. Last summer's 27th event brought in more than half a million dollars, Mr. Duke said, figuring that Mr. Plimpton raised $5 million to $7 million for the camp. 
 Mr. Grucci said, "The creativity that George had and the ability that George had to portray this passion that he had for the youth, for the community, for the East End and for fireworks, he rolled that all into one to create this magical and mystical night." 
 Mr. Plimpton died on Sept. 26. He was 76.

In Her Own Right
 The Nobel prize-winning author John Steinbeck wrote "The Winter of Our Discontent" and "Travels With Charley" in the waterfront studio of the Sag Harbor bungalow he shared with his wife, Elaine, until his death in 1968. But it was at Sag Harbor's Bay Street Theater that Elaine Steinbeck found her own spotlight. 
 Theater had been her passion since childhood. In the 1940's, she was one of the trailblazing women who worked as stage managers with "Oklahoma!" on Broadway and the national tour of "Othello" with Paul Robeson. But after she married Steinbeck in 1950 -- her first marriage to the actor Zachary Scott ended in divorce -- she backed away from show business. 
 When the Bay Street Theater opened in 1992, Mrs. Steinbeck's interest was aroused. Sybil Christopher, the co-artistic director and one of the founders of Bay Street, recalled being advised to contact Mrs. Steinbeck. 
 "We said, 'We don't know her,"' Ms. Christopher said. But while the theater staff was out to lunch one day, Mrs. Steinbeck dropped off a letter thanking them for starting the theater, promising to help and including "a really big check," Ms. Christopher said.
 They met the next day. 
 "She was phenomenal; she just understood," Ms. Christopher said. "She was always supportive. From Bay Street's point of view, she was such a treasure." 
 With Mrs. Steinbeck's help, the theater took off. She joined the board of directors and came to all the opening nights, readings and children's theater productions. In 1998, the main stage was officially named the Elaine Steinbeck Stage at Bay Street Theater with a gala salute that included the playwrights Terrence McNally and Edward Albee and the actor Gary Sinise. Bruce Springsteen sang "Oh, What a Beautiful Morning." 
 Mrs. Steinbeck donated her husband's first-edition books to the theater's benefit auctions. She also was co-chairwoman of the annual book and author fair at Southampton College of Long Island University. The event, named for her husband, raises scholarship funds for the school's writing program and helps maintain the John Steinbeck writer's room on campus. 
 "I want theater in my life till the day I die," she once said. "I think my friendship with the Bay Street means that I will."
 Mrs. Steinbeck died on April 27. She was 88. 

Working With Light
 Thirty-four synagogues, churches and libraries on Long Island are bathed in the light that passes through stained-glass windows created by Paul Wood. A prolific artist who ran an art school for adults out of his Port Washington studio for more than half a century, Mr. Wood used bits of glass to recreate biblical scenes and create a sense of spirituality. He also adorned the houses of worship with tapestries and mosaics. 
 "Great art comes from simple things done exquisitely well," Mr. Wood was known to say. Some of his stained-glass windows grace Young Israel of West Hempstead and Young Israel of Long Beach. His mosaics are installed at his own church, Our Lady of Fatima in Manorhaven, and at the public library in Port Washington, where he long headed the local art council. In 1996, he designed the sanctuary at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck. It also houses a permanent exhibition of his work, including watercolors and oils that are musings on the themes of family, faith and love. 
 Mr. Wood was a portrait painter when he joined Albert Wood and Five Sons, his father's Port Washington furniture and architectural business, which specialized in church interiors. While his brothers carved altars and doors, Paul Wood designed stained glass. When church work dwindled, he concentrated on synagogues. 
 Mr. Wood died on Aug. 24 of Parkinson's disease. He was 81.

In Honor of Athletes
 In the late 1980's, a handful of guys tossed around the concept of a Long Island Sports Hall of Fame. Nassau County had its own small display at the Nassau Coliseum. So Arthur Figliozzi, along with Guy (Butch) Dellacave and Jack Foley, decided to create a Suffolk Sports Hall of Fame. 
 In 1990, it began inducting local athletes, sportswriters, coaches, sports administrators and special Olympians. Among those honored that first year were the baseball player Carl Yastrzemski and the football player Boomer Esiason.
 Mr. Figliozzi, a Commack resident, was superintendent of the Wyandanch school district for about 14 years, then led the Eastport school district until he retired in 1988. But he earned his 1997 induction into his own hall of fame after a 30-year career as a basketball coach, referee and rules official.
 "When there would be a problem, whether it was with the officials' association or the Hall of Fame, he was able to get people together, to get them to work together," Mr. Foley recalled. "He was a team builder."
 Mr. Figliozzi remained the Hall of Fame's president until last December. His dedication paid off. With $750,000 raised to build a museum, library, sports research and educational center, the conversion of a former bank building on South Ocean Avenue in Patchogue are scheduled to begin shortly, said Edward J. Morris, the Hall of Fame's executive director. The museum is scheduled to be open by next summer. 
 Mr. Figliozzi died on Jan. 31 of an aneuryism. He was 75.

A Medical Love Affair
 When there was a thunderstorm and the lights went out at Michael Maffetone's Setauket home, the first thing the former director and chief executive officer of Stony Brook University Hospital did was open the front door and make sure the lights at his hospital, visible through the trees, were still on. 
 "He felt that the hospital belonged to him," said Dawn Maffetone, his widow, recalling how she teased him about his inability to delegate. "Everything about it he felt reflected on him."
 He grew up in Bethpage and earned a doctorate of arts in medical technology from Catholic University in Washington. He started his career at the Community Hospital of Glen Cove and Syosset Hospital, then worked in Baltimore and Chicago before coming to Stony Brook in 1994. Wearing his sunglasses and signature fedoras -- black or brown in winter depending on his suit, straw with changing hatbands that matched his tie in summer -- Dr. Maffetone went to work placing the hospital among the top teaching hospitals in the nation. 
 He made it the first in the United States to voluntarily extend maternity length-of-stay, allowing regular maternity patients to stay two days and women who had had Caesarian sections to spend four days.
 "He knew what he was doing was right," Mrs. Maffetone said, adding that it was later mandated that health insurance had to pay for that length of stay. "He said, 'I'm doing it."' 
 Dr. Shirley Strum Kenny, president of Stony Brook University, said: "He was bright, energetic, witty, creative, and determined to make our hospital the best. He made us laugh, but he made us think too. He cared deeply about people and worked hard to make sure that everyone who came to the hospital had not only the best of medical care but also the sense of caring that people need when they are sick or injured."
 Dr. Maffetone helped bring the Carol M. Baldwin Breast Cancer Research Fund Inc. to the university and served as its president. The fund raised more than $1 million earmarked for breast cancer research at the hospital. 
 He died of a degenerative nerve disease on Jan. 19. He was 52. 

A Fighter for Hofstra
 A big-hearted entrepreneur, Allan Tod Gittleson directed his philanthropy toward Hofstra University. Mr. Gittleson, who was known as Tod, was a trustee and chairman of the board at Hofstra for 30 years. 
 "Hofstra's success is in large part due to his generosity and his leadership," said Stuart Rabinowitz, Hofstra's president.
 In 1987, Mr. Gittleson, the son of a coal miner, set up a distinguished academic scholarship with millions of his own money, offering full tuition for four years. Additionally, he supported university programs for minorities and the disabled. He also helped found the Hofstra School of Law.
 "His goal was to make it the finest university on Long Island and make sure that anybody who was worthy was able to come to it whether they had the money or not," said Maurice Deane, who served with Mr. Gittleson on the board and is also a former chairman.
 Mr. Gittleson's involvement was also hands on. He founded the Hofstra Health Dome, a $1.2 million fitness center that heralded the university's entry into the field of preventive sports medicine and was a departure from traditional curriculum. The center, which he ran as chief executive officer from 1981 to 1997, tailored fitness programs to individual need, stress testing and weight loss through behavior modification, and would help people develop a healthy lifestyle and stick with it. 
 "It takes a rare person," Mr. Gittleson said at the time, "to sustain the discipline to keep fit without structure and supervision." The profits from the fitness center went back into scholarship funds. 
 In the greenhouse of his Old Westbury home, Mr. Gittleson loved to fiddle with new varieties of plants. He always donated his best pumpkin to the fitness center, recalled a daughter, June Gittleson. Friends and neighbors were always invited to share in the garden's surplus bounty. 
 Mr. Gittleson died of Alzheimer's on Aug. 12. He was 86.

Breast Cancer Warrior
 Statuesque and vivacious, Diane Sackett Nannery was always the leader of the women in the rolling support group known as the "Breast Cancer Victory Train," an annual two-hour Long Island Rail Road ride from Penn Station in Manhattan to Port Jefferson. During one such journey to a breast cancer pep rally at John T. Mather Hospital, one of many events that Ms. Nannery organized as a breast cancer activist, hundreds of survivors and women who were still battling breast cancer traded war stories. Every day, Ms. Nannery told them, was a victory. 
 "I've always been a strong person," Ms. Nannery said in an interview during the 1998 ride. "I'm not a better person, because I was a nice person without breast cancer. I didn't need breast cancer to be a better person. But I'm different." 
 When Ms. Nannery, a postal worker, learned she had breast cancer in 1993, she immersed herself in learning about the disease and became one of the Island's most outspoken breast cancer activists. 
 "I feel like I've found my mission in life," she once said. 
 She launched a successful campaign for the nation's first breast cancer stamp, started the first Postal Workers Breast Cancer Coalition and helped create a check-off box on New York State tax returns for contributions to breast cancer research. 
 "She focused like a laser beam not only on researching the disease and its treatments, but also on putting into motion trailblazing initiatives that she thought, accurately, would benefit untold numbers of women," said Joan Swirsky, who wrote the book "Coping With Lymphedema" with Ms. Nannery. 
 When Ms. Nannery began crusading for the stamp in 1994, her request to the United States Postal Service was denied 27 times over 17 months. She persisted and the 32-cent stamp was issued in 1996. 
 "I had to do something, and I chose this," she said at the time. "The Postal Service is in a unique position to use stamps as public service announcements. They are a great awareness tool." 
 Even as she underwent chemotherapy treatments, Ms. Nannery reached out to other breast cancer patients, holding their hands and accompanying them to the hospital. She gave powerful and influential speeches on lymphedema to such institutions as the National Cancer Institute and the American Cancer Society. But when her activism led her to appear in television ads in Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's 1998 campaign, she was criticized for endorsing a political candidate. 
 "None of us as individuals have the power to get the money we need," she said. "But we do have the power to raise our voices to elect officials who will help our cause. I wish breast cancer wasn't political, but the reality is, it is." 
 Ms. Nannery died of breast cancer on Nov. 19. She was 51.

Helping Rockville Centre
 When William Harry Lister, known as Harry, successfully ran for mayor of the village of Rockville Centre on the independent home rule party ticket in 1945, his platform was giving the village government back to the people. Elected time and again, he did more than that as mayor for 22 years. The secret to his success in creating a vibrant downtown was parking lots.
 "During his early years he condemned a lot of property and bought a lot of property for the village in the business district and built parking lots behind the stores," said Eugene J. Murray, the current mayor. "If he hadn't done that we wouldn't have a business district today." 
 For much of his tenure Mr. Lister ran the village from his Buick dealership. As the village grew, he expanded its power plant and water system, drawing on his training as an engineer.
 "As a result the Rockville Centre area prospered in those days and today it is still growing strong," Mr. Murray said. 
 Mr. Lister turned a marshy area into baseball fields, now Lister Park, and oversaw a 15-block urban renewal project that used federal money to transform the western end of town into a vibrant commercial area with low-income housing.
 "That was a very old area of Rockville Centre and not known as one of the better areas, and now it's as nice as can be," said William Lister Jr., of Huntington Bay, one of his three children. 
 He modernized the police department, adding more officers and a fleet of motorcycles, and built the first village-owned headquarters for its volunteer firefighters. 
 Mr. Lister served as president of the New York State Conference of Mayors and led the state's Municipal Electric Utilities Association. During the A. Holly Patterson administration, he served as commissioner of welfare for Nassau County. Mr. Lister died on Oct. 10 at age 102.

A Mover at Adelphi
 Timothy W. Costello, then the president of Adelphi University, sat in his wood-paneled office on the Garden City campus one morning in 1983 and he explained why, after a decade of steady growth past the 11,000-student mark, the 7 percent plunge in Adelphi's enrollment was "probably the best thing that has happened to Adelphi in 15 years." 
 "In times of easy growth, colleges had grown fat and lazy," Dr. Costello said. "Now Adelphi is responding by sharpening its mission."
 Under Dr. Costello's leadership from 1972 to 1985, Adelphi established several new departments, launched its adult degree program, added the Gordon F. Derner Institute for Advanced Psychological Studies, expanded the Swirbul Library and built new facilities including the Olmsted Theater and a new home for the School of Social Work. 
 "He did everything in his power to make it flourish," said Harry Davies, now chairman of the art and art history department and the dean of Adelphi's College of Arts and Sciences under Dr. Costello. "He was a builder." 
 After World War II, Dr. Costello, a psychologist and the author of several books, taught psychology and management at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration. He worked as New York City deputy mayor under Mayor John Lindsay before returning to academia at Adelphi. "He liked the idea of being able to have a broad impact on organizations," said Peter Costello, a communications professor at Adelphi and one of his six children. 
 Dr. Costello was credited with creating a collegial campus culture at Adelphi. Under his administration, the adult baccalaureate program was started, high school juniors and seniors were allowed to take Adelphi courses for college credit, and a program bringing guest scholars to the university was instituted. To attract the best and the brightest, he instituted a merit-based scholarship, reducing tuition by one-third to students in the top 10 percent of their high school class. 
 "Places like Harvard, Yale and Stanford get the cream of the crop, so they don't have to worry about the quality of their student body," Dr. Costello once said. "Adelphi is a fine institution, but it's not Harvard. If we want to attract good students, we need to let them know that we'll help them come here."
 Dr. Costello died on Oct. 20. He was 87.

Mr. Long Beach
 Ed Buscemi used to say that Long Beach was the jewel of the South Shore. A big guy with a big heart, Mr. Buscemi helped make it that way. During more than 50 years of community service, he kept watch over the oceanfront city as lifeguard, police commissioner, city council president and executive director of the Chamber of Commerce. 
 "He came to be known as Mr. Long Beach," said his son, Vincent, a Long Beach police lieutenant. 
 Mr. Buscemi was a member of the City Council for 13 years, including a two-year stint as president. Before that, he rose from patrolman through the ranks of the local police. After retiring, he worked full time as a volunteer doing public relations for the local chamber of commerce, helping grow it to one of the Island's largest. He was named the Long Beach chamber's Man of the Year for 2001.
 "He was always touting Long Beach to people who didn't know it," Vincent Buscemi said, recalling his father's pride in the city's renaissance in the 1980's after two decades of blight. "He wanted to impress on other people that Long Beach had changed." 
 Assemblyman Harvey Weisenberg was Ed Buscemi's lifelong friend. "He was a champion for all the people in our city," Mr. Weisenberg said. "He was a people person who appreciated differences and saw differences within our community as the strength of our community and advocated for the diverse population that we have."
 Mr. Buscemi lobbied for the local senior citizen center, to fix the recreation hall, stem erosion on the beach and for bayfront development.
 "He thought he could make Long Beach a better place," Vincent Buscemi said. "He was very into proper planning and the proper use of space." Before running for the city council, Ed Buscemi, a former Marine, studied towards a master's degree in suburban planning at Adelphi University.
 Mr. Buscemi was born in the Bronx but summered in Long Beach as a child, moving full time in 1948 with his widowed mother. 
 Mr. Buscemi died on Feb. 13. He was 74.

Devoted to the Union
 When William H. Harrison, a union leader, ordered a nighttime shutdown of bus service in 1970, disrupting Nassau bus lines, the move worked. With the help of $60,000 from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, theft-proof exact-fare coin boxes were installed in the buses, making it unnecessary for drivers to carry change. 
 "When New York City installed the exact-fare system on its buses, we became sitting ducks," Mr. Harrison said at the time. After a driver was robbed and beaten in Inwood, he even followed the buses in his own car at night to make sure drivers on certain routes didn't get hurt. 
 "We've been knocked off six times since then, and we've had enough of it," Mr. Harrison said. "We want these dope addicts and thieves off our backs." Other private bus lines followed suit and soon passengers all over the county were depositing exact fare into a locked box when they boarded the bus. 
 Mr. Harrison's transportation career included being a mechanic and driver. But as president and business agent for Local 1061 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, he represented more than 1,000 bus drivers and mechanics in Nassau from 1968 to 1979. 
 "He was a strong union personality," said Robert Harrison, a son, recalling that his father succeeded even though he only had an eighth-grade education. "He was passionate about his men and his unions." 
 He usually got what he wanted. In 1972, Mr. Harrison took his drivers out on strike to protest plans by the Jerusalem Avenue Bus Lines to fire five drivers and drop two runs. The strike knocked out service for 3,500 daily riders. The following year, Mr. Harrison worked out a deal guaranteeing job security to drivers affected by the county's takeover of private bus lines. 
 When the union failed to win changes in a pension fund during a 1974 labor dispute, Mr. Harrison claimed the county's offer and timing were unacceptable. He told his drivers not to put in their customary overtime. 
 "This is no job action," Mr. Harrison said at the time. "This is only taking advantage of our God-given, union-won right to two days off." He later worked in labor relations for the New York City Transit Authority.
 Mr. Harrison was born and lived in Hempstead his entire life. He died on May 13 of cancer. He was 83.

A Caring Heart
 When Agnes and John Funk retired and moved to Flower Hill in 1970, two years after they married, they decided to devote their lives to charitable activities even if that meant giving away more than their $25,000 a year in investment income.
 "We were trying to show people by example you don't have to have money to give," said Mrs. Funk, now of Upper Brookville. "Give time. When you have money, you'll give."
 Last month, the Funks were honored by the Association of Fundraising Professionals' Long Island chapter as the outstanding philanthropists of the year. 
 John Funk delivered Meals on Wheels for 20 years. With his wife, he was involved with the National Center for Disability Services in Albertson, St. Mary's Children and Family Services in Syosset and St. Christopher-Ottilie Services for Children and Families in Sea Cliff. He was a trustee with the Children's Medical Fund at Schneider Children's Hospital and sponsored 12 children at about $5,000 each for heart surgery through the Gift of Life, an organization that brings needy children from around the world who need heart surgery to places like St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn. Mr. Funk often picked up the children when they arrived and brought them to his home. 
 The couple went to about 25 black-tie charity events a year. They bought tables, worked on committees and sold tons of raffles. After bidding $5,500 at a gala auction to conduct the Long Island Philharmonic, he wore a white tuxedo and tails for his debut. 
 "If it weren't for volunteers, there would be a lot of places folding," Mrs. Funk said. 
 He worked in management at United Parcel Service until he retired 35 years ago. In recent years, he helped raise Nicole, 7, the daughter of their former cleaning woman, and took care of a neighbor's son who was ill. 
 "He was always doing," Mrs. Funk said. "He was always helping. He never objected to anything." 
 Mr. Funk died on Sept. 10. He was 94.

Helping the Disabled
 Kathleen O'Callaghan Maul's dream was a Universal Access Center, a facility that took into account the needs of individuals with a wide variety of visual, hearing and mobility impairments and disabilities. Ms. Maul's vision included a new school, diagnostic and treatment clinics and a health and fitness center with accessible locker rooms, swimming pools and a gym. As the executive director of United Cerebral Palsy of Greater Suffolk, she turned that concept into plans for a two-story, 104,000-square-foot structure on 10 acres in Central Islip. Construction is scheduled to begin next year. 
 "As an agency everything that we are is due to her," said Stephen Friedman, who succeeded Ms. Maul as executive director of United Cerebral Palsy of Suffolk, one of the Island's largest not-for-profit organizations with about 1,000 employees serving more than 4,000 individuals each year. 
 Under Ms. Maul's leadership for the last 12 years, U.C.P.-Suffolk expanded to include a children's center, adult day programs and a diagnostic and treatment center with numerous clinics throughout Suffolk. It also built 23 family-style residences for people with disabilities and a 12-unit apartment complex in Central Islip for independently functioning individuals. 
 Ms. Maul was soft-spoken, but when she was advocating for individuals with disabilities, hers was a strong voice. One moment she was the business executive, the next she was on the floor hugging a child, Mr. Friedman recalled. 
 "Her heart was huge," Mr. Friedman recalled. "Whether it was children or adults, it didn't matter. It didn't matter what disability. For her everybody was the most important."
 George Maul, her husband of 28 years, said his wife's motto was "whatever it takes to get the job done," adding, "She ran the house and me the same way." 
 Ms. Maul, who lived in Huntington Station, was also a soccer mom who raced home on the first day of school each year to bake chocolate chip cookies for her children, Brehan, now 26, Meaghan, 22 and Katharine, 18. She loved to read and to go to the beach in Montauk and at Robert Moses State Park. 
 Ms. Maul died on April 5 of lung cancer. She was 52.

Backing Black Studies
 The abolitionist Frederick Douglass's words, "without struggle there is no progress," were at the core of William McAdoo's beliefs, said his wife, Joy Mahabir, of South Setauket. Dr. McAdoo was chairman of the Africana Studies department at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. 
 When he came to Stony Brook in 1978, Africana studies were a program, not a department. When black studies were being phased out at universities across the country in the 1990's, Dr. McAdoo mobilized faculty and students and bucked a trend.
 "He transformed it from a marginal program to a really good department," said Aaron W. Godfrey, a senior lecturer in the department of European languages at the university. "He was a guy who was in your face but always about the right thing. It wasn't about him. It was about racial justice. It was about people getting along with each other. It was about equity." Africana studies became a department in 1998. 
 The son of a Jewish mother and an African-American father who were labor organizers in Michigan, Dr. McAdoo was also a civil rights activist, writer and musician. In his quest for social justice, he was a bit of a curmudgeon, skilled at pricking peoples' consciences and saying exactly what he thought, regardless of whom he offended. In 2002, when Candace De Russy, a SUNY trustee, unsuccessfully tried to have African-American studies phased out, saying they had been incorporated into history departments and were "flabby, feel-good programs that carry an anti-American bias," Dr. McAdoo fought back. In letters to the editor and an article in Black Issues in Higher Education, Dr. McAdoo contended that to call such programs irrelevant was to disregard the history of the United States and the history of slavery and racism. 
 "Her statements are racist," Dr. McAdoo wrote at the time. "To say that most black studies programs are un-American smacks of McCarthyism, smacks of the whole fascist kinds of repression that took place in the 1950's in the U.S."
 During the civil rights movement, Dr. McAdoo composed and recorded an album of protest songs, "Bill McAdoo Sings," with Pete Seeger on the banjo. 
 After six years together, Dr. McAdoo married Dr. Mahabir last August. He died on Nov. 6 of leukemia at age 67.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
How Much Is That Monkey in the Window?

BYLINE:  By JESSICA BRUDER

DATELINE: MOUNT HOLLY 

 BODY:
THREE of Mount Holly's monkeys went missing last month. 
 "Historic Mount Holly Monkey" was the first to go. The little fiberglass chimp covered in decoupaged photographs was supposed to raise people's holiday spirits, not their larcenous ones. But it disappeared, leaving residents baffled. 
 "We're not going to let anyone spoil our fun," said Lynne Lemyre, a community organizer who helped bring 14 monkey sculptures decorated by Burlington County artists to downtown streets here to help celebrate the new year. 
 In fact, two of the monkeys have been recovered and Ms. Lemyre has posted a reward of $200.40 for the return of the third. The amount of the bounty is reference to the New Year, as are the monkeys: according to the Chinese calendar, the Year of the Monkey begins on Jan. 22. 
 The monkey project was devised by Main Street Mount Holly, a downtown revitalization group powered by more than 100 volunteers that is fighting to restore an intimate neighborhood feel to downtown Mount Holly, in contrast with the wave of Wal-Marts, strip malls and asphalt lapping at the town's edge. Ms. Lemyre, who keeps a poster bearing the Japanese word "karoshi" -- meaning "death from overwork" - tacked above her desk in a tiny office downtown, is the group's executive director; she says she graduated to the organization's only paid position through "excessive volunteerism." 
 Main Street Mount Holly projects have included town festivals like Fire and Ice, an annual chili-cooking and ice-sculpting competition, along with efforts to retain local businesses and promote public art.
 The primate project began with an extensive search for a manufacturer who could supply 14 identical, unpainted monkey sculptures.
 "Out in Chicago, they had a mold that was particularly sensitive-looking, and sweet," Ms. Lemyre said. The figure, almost life-size at two and a half feet tall, had one drawback, though -- it wasn't quite a monkey. 
 "They're actually chimpanzees," Ms. Lemyre said conspiratorially. "They're primates." Close enough.
 When the chimps had been decorated by local artists, they were bolted to barrels that were in turn bolted to cement blocks intended to keep the barrels in place. 
 On Nov. 10, the monkey sculptures were installed on sidewalks in downtown Mount Holly. Within a few hours, "Historic Mount Holly Monkey" had vanished. "So Rousseau" and "Monkey Business" were the next to go. 
 For the volunteers of Main Street Mount Holly, the loss was frustrating. Each sculpture was an original piece, from the trompe d'oeil of "Brass Monkey" -- "he's not really brass, he's just painted to look brass," explained Ms. Lemyre -- to the Dadaism of "Chocolate Chimp," which was meant to resemble a large, monkey-shaped chocolate chip cookie. "Monkey Business," a sculpture in which Mount Holly's mayor, Donald Scattergood, saw a suggestion of his own likeness, was even dressed in a simian-sized business suit and spectacles.
 "Monkeys are touchable," said Irvane Spracklin, a retired social worker and a 40-year resident of Mount Holly who tried to make sense of the theft. "It's like taking home a stuffed animal, only this was a fiberglass animal." 
 She is the creator of "Historic Mount Holly Monkey," which she painstakingly covered in a decoupage of sepia-toned digital photographs depicting historic town landmarks. Of the three stolen sculptures, her monkey was the first to disappear and the only one that remains missing. 
 "I have no sympathy for those who stole them," Ms. Spracklin said, "but I understand why they would have wanted them. I got very fond of mine." Convinced that there was little hope of recovering the original, she recently completed a copy of "Historic Mount Holly Monkey." 
 To protect the remaining monkeys, Ms. Lemyre moved them to indoor display sites where they will remain until Jan. 24, when they will be auctioned off to benefit Main Street Mount Holly and the individual artists. The auction is planned as part of the Monkeys' Ball at Rancocas Valley Regional High School, which will feature the East River Ensemble from Chinatown in New York City performing traditional percussion and the dance of the Monkey King. 
 Though he is pleased that the remaining monkeys are secure, William Carrig, the public safety director of Mount Holly, says his detectives haven't abandoned their efforts to find "Historic Mount Holly Monkey." 
 And the town is pressing criminal charges against 22-year-old Brandon Bilyard, the man accused of taking "So Rousseau" and "Monkey Business." According to Mr. Carrig, Mr. Bilyard lives with his parents, who were taking boxes of Christmas ornaments down from the attic of their Pearl Street home on Nov. 28 when they came across the two monkeys.
 James Bilyard hauled both monkeys and his son down to the police station, Mr. Carrig said, adding that the town would prosecute because the primates were pricey. According to Ms. Lemyre, the monkeys have an estimated value of $650 apiece. "That's $1,300 worth of monkeys," she lamented.
 Brandon Bilyard has been charged with two counts of theft and criminal mischief. His trial date is pending. Mr. Carrig noted that, while Mr. Bilyard seemed "very remorseful," no one had been able to establish a motive for the theft. So on a recent December evening, a reporter paid a call to Mr. Bilyard to hear his side of the story.
 Standing outside on his family's porch in the winter chill, Mr. Bilyard seemed embarrassed and shy. Was he honestly the cause of Mount Holly's holiday headache? Did he take those monkeys?
"Yeah," Mr. Bilyard said. He hesitated and added, "I was just being a jerk." Then his mother emerged from the house. She shooed him back inside, slamming the door behind them.
