HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
A View of Outer Space? No, It's Just of Jersey City.

BYLINE:  By BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

DATELINE: Jersey City 

 BODY:
VARGAS-SUAREZ UNIVERSAL'S matrix of lines and kaleidoscopic array of shapes at the Jersey City Museum is a monster. At 28 1/2 by 16 feet, it climbs up and around the staircase at the entrance to the museum. It is bold and intriguing, looming above you like some colossal ruin or a distant, mountainous urban sprawl. It reminded me of the view flying into La Paz, Bolivia. 
 In fact, the drawing, "Space Station: Jersey," presents a vision of Jersey City as urban space debris. The artist worked from satellite views of the city, images of the Hudson River waterfront and architectural plans of historic Jersey City buildings. He created the drawing freehand with permanent ink and then finished it with black latex paint. It took six weeks to complete. 
 If you try to link the title of the drawing to its specific imagery, there is a good chance you will blow a fuse in your head. Perhaps that is Mr. Vargas-Suarez's intention, to make us think for ourselves about what it means. My take is that it is a spectacularly eccentric project, the artist hoisting our eyes skyward to behold a quirky visual puzzle. It is just like looking at the stars.
 What I like about this drawing is the way it distills something sad, something alien about the ultra-urban American landscape. I often feel it in New Jersey, especially when motoring at night past acres of factories and warehouses. This is not a world for people, but for machines and automatons. 
 According to the press release, the drawing presents an exploration of the dynamics of urban space. Just how it does that is unclear, although the intersecting spears of light and profuse linear forms (moving over and into one another in constant, repeated movements) are meant to mimic flows of people and the constant growth and development of urban environments. Or so the press release says.
 Mr. Vargas-Suarez studied art history and astronomy, not studio art. No doubt his interest in astronomy accounts for the drawing's extra terrestrial setting. It might also account for the limited color scheme, with everything reduced to black or white, light or dark, positive or negative space.
 There is nothing beyond a perfunctory wall label to help viewers understand the drawing and explain why the museum chose it as its first semi-permanent installation. But its visual powers are lure enough.
 "Space Station: Jersey" is at the Jersey City Museum, 350 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, through August 2005. Information: (201)413-0303.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Ode to Commuting

BYLINE:  By ANDREA HONORE; Andrea Honore is an arts administrator at Johnson & Johnson and lives in Princeton.

 BODY:
I DRIVE to work alone in my car. This fact brings me into the blood brotherhood of New Jersey residents, as census figures show that three-quarters of us drive to work alone in our cars each day. The data also show that the average commute in New Jersey takes 30 minutes and is the third longest in the country. My commute, from Princeton to New Brunswick, takes 45 minutes, door to door. I wonder if other commuters in New Jersey, and throughout the nation, share the same mixture of affection and disgust for their commute that I have for mine. 
 In the mornings, particularly, I appreciate the buffer between home and work that is provided by my commute. It's a chance to savor my coffee and take in the change of seasons. Some days, it's the only chunk of time that I really have to myself. I always listen to the radio, and this is usually news on public radio. Owing to this radio habit, certain stretches of road have taken on the ability to unleash sudden but brief emotions related to September 11th, the recount in Florida or, more incongruously, Monica Lewinsky. But for the most part, my commute is a restful, thinking part of the day. I have scores of illegible notes scattered throughout the car, with the names of songs and recording artists, books and movies that I heard reviewed, and cryptic notes related to brilliant ideas that I tried to scribble down without taking my eyes off the road for too long. 
 When you drive the same route so often, certain landmarks take on a peculiar significance. There is a large dead tree along my route that is the favorite haunt of turkey vultures. I think this is because of the proximity of a quail farm that, in combination with a sudden sharp turn in the road, supplies a desirable yield of road-kill. Ten or twelve huge vultures will sit in this tree at one time, sometimes with their wings squared out to the sides. Around Halloween one year, I drove my children up to see it, but, of course, the tree was vulture-less. Thankfully, there is a habitually overdecorated house a bit farther along in my route (another landmark), and the fake hearse, tombstones and guillotine proved equally drive-worthy that day.
 Commuting is not all quiet meditation and autumn leaves drifting down upon the roadway, however. It is often quite dangerous. There have been the near misses when I almost didn't see the deer crossing, and angry fists brandished when I didn't push the light hard enough. Once I kind of fell asleep at the wheel and "came to," still driving, on a road I didn't recognize. There was also the time when a duck flew up from the side of the road and squished straight into my windshield. Swerving or even braking at that moment would have cost my life, instead of the duck's. Nonetheless, I cried most of the way to work and was terrorized by the sight of ducklings that I imagined as motherless for the next few weeks.
 Owing to the hundreds of hours that I have spent in my car listening to news radio, I am remarkably well informed about the negative impact of my commute on the larger world: the dangers of ozone layer destruction, the political ramifications of our reliance on fossil fuels and the effects of automotive pollution on both weather patterns and long-term health.
 The quality, availability and cost of public transportation are partly to blame. The end points on my commute are unusually well connected. Still, it is both more time-consuming and more expensive for me to commute by train. The last time that I tried to take the train home, it was unaccountably delayed and spent a very irritable hour and half locating and riding a bus home down Route 27.
 For many of us in New Jersey, public transportation isn't even an option. There are tens of thousands of desks just in the 18 miles between Princeton and New Brunswick that are completely inaccessible by public transport. Small wonder that Route 1 was voted the worst road in New Jersey by drivers who responded to the "Keep New Jersey Moving" Web site poll. And most foreseeable development in the area affirms rather than punishes our reliance on cars. 
 Given the economic and environmental ramifications of my commute, in fact, it's too bad that it isn't more uncomfortable or more costly. We are all admittedly creatures of comfort and, like all objects in nature, keep to the path of least resistance. So as long as my car has heated seats, a coffee holder and decent radio reception, I will guiltily, but comfortably, maintain my status quo among New Jersey residents and drive at least 30 minutes to work, in a car, alone.

HEADLINE: THE YEARS AHEAD: STYLE; 
If Beauties Multiply, They'll Be Plain to See

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
THE American fascination with self-improvement, inside and out, has been documented in many variations. But the ardor for physical and aesthetic enhancement was best captured this year by "Extreme Makeover," an ABC reality program. In it, middle-class Americans -- a police officer, a waitress, a local radio D.J. -- were transformed by plastic surgery, sometimes several procedures at a time, from plain Janes and Johns into coiffed, glossed movie-star lookalikes.
 Along with the approval of Botox for wrinkle reduction in 2002, the popular neurotoxin that has conquered wrinkles, the show drew attention to the increasingly popular notion that plastic surgery is not just for the vain or the wealthy. 
 If cosmetic plastic surgery is available to the average consumer -- thanks in part to lending agencies that specialize in financing cosmetic procedures -- and no longer bears the stigma of vanity, the question arises: Are we on our way to becoming a nation of the surgically enhanced? If looking beautiful becomes as easy as buying a car or a dress, will beauty -- or an imitation of it -- become so commonplace as to be meaningless?
 The American Society of Aesthetic Plastic Surgery reports that the overall number of cosmetic procedures has increased 228 percent since 1997. The numbers are likely to rise as the population ages, prices drop, younger patients seek out surgery, technology and genetic engineering generate new techniques, and more doctors from various fields offer cosmetic surgical procedures. 
 Surgical procedures will inevitably become less expensive, said Dr. Lloyd M. Krieger, a plastic surgeon who also has an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago, in part because procedures that 10 years ago took place in a hospital operating room and required expensive overnight stays now take place in a doctor's office.
 And, like any consumer product, as it becomes more popular, the laws of economics dictate that the price will come down. "Usually that does not apply to health care, which is bound up with insurance issues, but in the case of cosmetic surgery, people are using their own money so the typical health-insurance restrictions don't apply," Dr. Krieger said. Consumers approach cosmetic surgery as a retail decision, "as if they were buying a cruise, a vacation, a car."
 For a while at least, the distance between those who can afford to maintain a youthful-looking appearance, increasingly a sign of privilege, and the merely plain, the unretouched have-nots, will likely widen.
 New technologies will soon be available to draw in well-off patients who might never have thought of cosmetic enhancement. Dr. Steven A. Teitelbaum, a plastic surgeon in Santa Monica, Calif., predicted that the next milestone would be the control of tissue formation, whether to reduce scarring or grow new tissues.
 When surgeons can selectively grow tissue in the breast, Dr. Teitelbaum said, patients may face less risk than if they, for example, receive breast implants, which can rupture and cause complications and must also be replaced every few years. "When we can control scarring we can do operations we don't even think of now because of the massive scar formation," he said.
 Surely, a backlash against the artificial beauties will erupt. Not a chance, Dr. Teitelbaum said. Surgical work, when well done, is now subtle. "Most people aren't getting those bad face lifts anymore, where the eyes, lips and cheeks are distorted," he said. "If everyone getting plastic surgery looked like that, there would be a backlash."
 The aesthetically altered future would surely flummox Darwin. One New York surgeon, Dr. Michelle Copeland, suggested that cosmetically altered couplings could create some surprises. Say a man with a big nose and receding chin has a nose job and a chin implant. With his new profile he manages to marry a beautiful woman, who, by the by, had already had her ears pinned back, her sleepy-looking eyes lifted and her thin lips augmented. Their child might well be a surprise package with the big nose, the Dumbo ears, receding chin, saggy lids and thin lips. 
 "Well, then the child will simply have to start doing all the things his or her parents did," Dr. Copeland said with a sigh. "I've already seen it happen."

HEADLINE: Page Two: BUZZWORDS; 
What We Said And What We Meant, A to Z

BYLINE:  By TOM KUNTZ

 BODY:
IN a sense, we are what we speak. Good thing the English language, the world's largest at some 650,000 words and growing, is eminently adaptable to the way people change.
 This year, adapt it did -- quickly and often with wit -- to modern war, economic uncertainty, technological progress, social change, you name it. 
 Herewith, an alphabet soup of coinages that came on the radar screen in 2003. Many 
 appeared in this newspaper; others were noted on wordspy.com, a Web site by Paul McFedries, a Toronto writer and linguaphile. 
 Some words are not new but took on new meanings, while others simply attracted unusual attention or gained wider currency.
 A is for augments -- people with implants that increase sensory capacity, like hearing, or change appearance, like breast implants.
 B is for bling-bling, the hip-hop term for diamonds and other jangly ostentation -- a word now so common that, according to news reports this year, the editors of the Oxford English Dictionary were considering adding it to their next edition. B is also for blogosphere -- the realm of bloggers, those who maintain Web logs of frequently updated entries on particular topics.
 C is for celebreality -- a TV show format in which one or more celebrities participate in real-life situations. (Think Paris Hilton on "The Simple Life.")
 D is for dramality -- a television show or series with elements of both drama and reality programming. (As in "AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL, a Dramality Series to Determine The Nation's Next Supermodel," -- PRNewswire, Jan. 12, 2003.)
 E is for embed -- a journalist placed in a military unit during the American takeover of Iraq to cover its activities.
 F is for flash mob -- a large group of people who gather in one location, usually organized in advance via e-mail or cellphone, to perform some brief action and then quickly disperse. ("In Sao Paulo, Brazil, people took off their shoes and banged them on the street. In one of New York's six flash mobs, the crowd dutifully followed instructions to mimic bird calls in Central Park for 20 seconds." -- The Week in Review, Aug. 17.)
 G is for globesity -- the worldwide epidemic of obesity, a term coined by the World Health Organization in 2001 that this year became huge.
 H is for ham -- an ordinary e-mail message blocked because it includes one or more keywords common to spam, or unsolicited junk e-mail. (As in, "one person's spam is another person's 'ham,' hacker-speak for desirable e-mail." -- The Associated Press, Jan. 17, quoting a scientist.)
 I is for imperial overstretch -- the extension of an empire beyond its abilities. (As in: "Might Washington, like Rome, fall victim to imperial overstretch?" -- The Sunday Mail of London, Oct. 12.)
 J is for job-loss recovery -- a form of economic growth in which the total number of jobs in the economy decreases. Related to, but not to be confused with, a jobless recovery, which simply fails to create new jobs.
 K is for knee-mail -- religion's computer-age, tongue-in-cheek word for prayer, often seen on signs outside churches: God answers knee-mail.
 L is for latex -- one of numerous words that some would consider benign but that nevertheless sets off Internet pornography blockers.
 M is for masstige -- a term combining mass and prestige and describing consumer products that are comparatively low-priced with a prestigious brand name. M is also for metrosexual, an urban male who spends a great deal of time and money on his appearance (likely to engage in manscaping, the artful shaving and trimming of a man's body hair).
 N is for nicotini -- a nicotine-laced martini that some restaurants introduced after they were forced to ban smoking.
 O is for odortype -- the genetically determined smell unique to each person. Government scientists are studying odortype as a possible identification tool in the war on terror.
 P is for pococurante -- meaning indifferent, a word that Sai R. Gunturi of Dallas spelled correctly to win this year's Scripps-Howard National Spelling Bee.
 Q is for quirkyalone -- a person who enjoys being single and who'd rather wait for the right person to come along than date indiscriminately. Q is also for quagmire, an old word that some think now has new life in Iraq.
 R is for rumint (ROOM-int) -- intelligence based on rumors rather than facts, which some believe led to faulty conclusions about Iraqi weapons programs.
 S is for shock and awe -- a term used by the American military to describe its strategy in Iraq, unleashing swift and overwhelming force early in a conflict to defeat the enemy quickly. S is also for slog, to plod one's way perseveringly, especially against difficulty (perhaps when caught in a quagmire; see Q above). And spider hole, a term popularized during the Vietnam War, but now used to describe Saddam Hussein's last hiding place.
 T is for tell-some -- a memoir revealing private or sensitive information, but only up to a point. (As in "'Living History,' Hillary Clinton's political 'tell-some' book." -- The San Jose Mercury News, June 10.)
 U is for unilateral -- an independent journalist, a war correspondent covering the Iraq war who was not officially sanctioned by the military. (See E is for embed).
 V is for video pill -- a camera the size of a pill that, when ingested, transmits images from a person's stomach and intestinal tract.
 W is for Wal-Mart effect -- the economic impact of the retail chain, from forcing smaller competitors out of business and driving down wages to keeping goods cheap, inflation low and productivity high.
 X is for xenozoonosis (zee-noh-zoh-AWN-uh-sis) -- a disease transmitted from an animal to a human after the transplantation of an animal organ.
 Y is for yottabyte -- or a million trillion megabytes, a term likely to become more popular as online data and computer memories expand in coming years to fill that amount of storage space.
 Z is for zorbing -- a new sport much noted this year, from New Zealand. In zorbing, a person is strapped inside a large sphere, which is itself held inside a larger sphere by a cushion of air (the whole thing's called a zorb) and then rolled along the ground or, better yet, downhill.
 Which, it can only be hoped, is not where the English language is headed in 2004.

HEADLINE: THE YEARS AHEAD: ECONOMICS; 
Questioning The Age Of Wal-Mart

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
WAL-MART, it seems, is the corporate Pied Piper of modern global capitalism, leading the way toward an economic future of admirable efficiency and low prices but also painful change for many workers and communities. And 2003 was the year the "Wal-Martization of the economy" really came into view. The retailing powerhouse toppled more rivals and became the target of lawsuits for unpaid overtime and a federal investigation into its use of poorly paid illegal immigrants as janitors. 
 The Wal-Mart formula extends far beyond the retail business. It has been a pioneer in using the tools of information technology to track every purchase, every shipment of supplies, every cost of doing business, minute by minute, around the world. If a Chinese factory can supply a toy for a few cents cheaper than a domestic plant, the business goes offshore in a heartbeat. 
 The spread of the Internet has brought the Wal-Mart model to all kinds of businesses, especially service jobs, like computer programming and back office work, that once seemed immune to foreign competition. The Indian programmer, paid one-fourth his American counterpart, is now just a mouse-click away. The fear of a swift migration of high-paid white-collar jobs abroad is stirring political concerns and protectionist sympathies in the United States.
 Has the economy been permanently prodded into some new shape, and what does it mean? 
 To critics, the global search for efficiency and low prices that Wal-Mart symbolizes -- squeezing domestic suppliers, offshore outsourcing and paying pinch-penny wages at home -- portends a grim future. They foresee growing wage gaps between the affluent and the working poor, as living standards for millions are sacrificed to market forces run amok. Friedrich von Hayek, they suggest, needs to be updated, and today his "road to serfdom" runs through Bentonville, Ark., Wal-Mart's hometown.
 If such pessimism becomes mainstream, the odds of a backlash rise. If protectionist or regulatory steps come, they will bejustified with much talk of creating a "level playing field" for domestic producers and local retailers, and to keep even more jobs from moving overseas. 
 A dissenting perspective comes from what might be called the Wal-Mart globalists. Wal-Mart, they say, is big, successful and an innovator. And innovation, they add, is always disruptive. Electricity, automobiles, personal computers and the Internet have all displaced workers, but also created new opportunities. The lesson of the American experience, they say, has been to bet on the benefits of that disruptive dynamism -- lower costs for consumers, higher productivity and more job creation than any other developed nation. 
 Still, the macroeconomic joy brings little comfort to the worker whose job is lost to the relentless evolution of global capitalism. Most workers find new jobs, but not always ones with comparable rewards. A study by the Institute for International Economics, examining manufacturing job losses from 1979 to 1999, found that a fourth of factory workers who were re-employed took pay cuts of 25 percent or more.
 Even some Wal-Mart globalists argue for some wage insurance to soften the blow of lost wages. How much would that cost? Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, estimates that paying workers half the money they lost in wages after they were laid off and took a lower-paying jobe, if limited to two years, would total $4 billion to $6 billion a year. "The only humane and economically sensible thing to do is ease the adjustment," Mr. Litan said.

HEADLINE: THE YEARS AHEAD: WAR; 
The Weak Will Try To Shift The Battle

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE American military has now fought two wars in two years, earning two dramatically swift battlefield victories that are already changing the face of future warfare.
 It seems clear that the American military will have few worries any time soon about rivals in technical proficiency and the reach of its power. So the next thing to expect is for the weak to change the way they struggle against it. 
 Thus, bands of guerrillas in Iraq have been trying to undermine the morale of the world's best-equipped combat units and the political will of the voters who sent them there. Terrorist groups are reported to have sought nuclear material for dirty bombs, or worse. Even some allies, feeling powerless and after America decided to go to war in Iraq with or without them, have found diplomatic and economic ways to thumb their noses at Washington. France, Germany and Russia have said, in effect: "You broke it, you bought it."
 While war itself remains an unpredictable enterprise, the American military this year proved it needs far smaller forces than ever before when it wants to reach around the globe and grab the throat of an adversary. In Iraq, as in Afghanistan the year before, it marched to the enemy's capital with a loss of life far below Pentagon projections.
 Nevertheless, victory in both Afghanistan and Iraq has been incomplete so far, and the Pentagon is looking at mistakes it might have made in the planning for postwar stabilization, to assure that in future conflicts it can secure the peace after winning the war.
 The march to Baghdad in particular exemplified the commanding American superiority in 21st-century warfare: swift, agile and decisive, employing overpowering technology to focus relentless violence all at once all across an enemy's territory.
 For example, in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, only 9 percent of the weapons dropped were precision-guided; in the war in Iraq this year,the figure reached 68 percent. And as the proportion of precision-guided munitions increased, the actual number of bombs dropped decreased, resulting in fewer unintended casualties and less damage to civilian buildings.
 In some ways, the technical superiority is a matter of complexity: no adversary can launch a radar-evading bomber from the safety of its own soil, refuel over an ocean, drop precision ordnance nearly a dozen time zones away, refuel again and return home without ever asking to land on foreign soil.
 In other ways, it is a matter of small devices. No adversary can yet challenge the American soldier's ownership of the night, although in this case the cheapness of electronics can pose a problem: Pentagon officials are concerned that over-the-counter light-enhancing goggles are whittling away at this monopoly.
 Meanwhile, innovation still counts. A new generation of surveillance methods -- pilotless aircraft, spy planes and satellites -- were used by only one side in Afghanistan and Iraq, feeding round-the-clock intelligence back through darkness, smoke and storms.
 The American advantage was not solely a matter of smart bombs, but also of smarter troops with better training and a higher level of commitment.
 Even so, adversaries committed to a low-technology guerrilla conflict and to "asymmetrical" terrorist attacks have proved remarkably stubborn and resilient.
 And the Bush administration, which espouses new strategies of pre-emption and "regime change," is also aware that it needs to give greater thought to what happens after military offensives are over and a regime has been changed.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Middlemen in the Low-Wage Economy

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
AFTER federal agents raided 60 Wal-Mart stores in October and found more than 200 illegal immigrants in the cleaning crews, the world's largest retailer was quick to defend itself from this enormous embarrassment. Wal-Mart's officers said they had no idea those workers were illegal, insisting they knew next to nothing about the workers from Mexico, Mongolia, Russia and elsewhere because they were employed by contractors. Nor did Wal-Mart know, its spokesmen said, that the contractors were cutting corners by not paying overtime or Social Security taxes or by flouting other labor laws, as the investigators claimed.
 Like Wal-Mart, thousands of American enterprises rely on labor contractors to help hold down costs, and those industries -- from New York apparel makers to California's vegetable growers -- have given similar "I had no idea" responses when their contractors have been accused of cutting corners. 
 But American companies are facing increasing legal challenges to hold them accountable for their contractors' practices. 
 Just this month, New York State settled with a supermarket chain to redress minimum-wage law violations involving a contractor's deliverymen; a lawsuit in California against three grocery chains over the treatment of late-night janitors survived a challenge; and a union sued a contractor used by United Parcel Service, accusing it of breaking numerous laws in its treatment of immigrant janitors.
 Critics of business-contractor ties insist that companies know exactly what they are getting when they hire outsiders to supply them with labor.
 "They're doing it for the same reason they've always done it, to save money," said Della Bahan, a lawyer who helped bring the suit against the California supermarket chains on behalf of hundreds of janitors from Mexico. "These companies are pretending they're not the employer. The contractor is willing to work people seven days a week, not pay payroll taxes, not pay workers-comp taxes. The companies don't want to do that themselves, but they're willing to look the other way when their contractors do it."
 Contracting out is steadily increasing, business experts say. Some supermarkets turn to outside contractors to help deliver groceries and run cash registers, as well as to clean floors. Many hotels use them to handle laundry, catering and housekeeping. Real estate companies rely on contractors for cleaning and security, while the forestry industry uses them to plant seedlings.
 Historians say labor contractors were first used in Philadelphia in the 19th century when builders needed more workers and turned to some enterprising Italian-Americans who knew where to find newly arrived countrymen. Those contractors, like the Mexican immigrants of today who are farm labor contractors in California and Florida, also used their language skills to manage their work crews. In the late 19th century, garment manufacturers often turned to smaller jobbers to help with production. The contractors often submitted low bids and then violated wage and other laws to squeeze costs, helping to create sweatshops.
 Today, using contractors makes sense, business strategists say, because it allows managers to concentrate on doing what they do best, instead of worrying about cleaning bathrooms. Companies frequently save money by using contractors, who often do not provide fringe benefits, like health insurance and pensions, that companies usually offer direct hires. And labor has difficulty unionizing contractors' employees because many are temporary hires, and legal disputes often develop over who their employer is.
 Probably the loudest complaints involve farm labor contractors, who are being used increasingly as illegal immigration has soared. Often, they provide dilapidated housing, do not pay overtime and make migrant workers pay for their tools and rides to work. Over the past three years, five contractors in Florida have been convicted of enslaving farm workers.
 Phillip Martin, a professor of agricultural economics at the University of California at Davis, said using contractors gives employers the ability to deny knowledge that people working for them were illegal immigrants or were not paid overtime. "Increasingly the purpose of contractors is to be risk absorbers," he said.
 But Jasper Hempel, executive vice president of the Western Growers Association, a group of 3,000 fruit and vegetable growers, said contractors were good for growers and workers alike. "A cherry crop is grown and harvested in a month's time, and artichokes and asparagus are grown in a very short period," he said. "There's no way a farmer of these crops can have a full-year work force. Farm labor contractors can provide farmers with workers for two weeks or two months, and by moving workers from farmer to farmer, these labor contractors can give workers fairly stable, year-round work."
 Still, problems are reported in many sectors. Some contractors trick immigrant workers into believing they are not covered by minimum-wage laws, telling these workers that they are independent contractors, not regular employees. A contractor working for a Manhattan grocery chain was accused of using this rationale to try to justify paying just $2 an hour to African immigrants who delivered groceries. The federal minimum is $5.15. Two weeks ago, the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, announced a $3.2 million settlement in which the chain, Gristede's, agreed to compensate the deliverymen for the contractor's minimum-wage and overtime violations. Gristede's had maintained it was not the employer and was thus not responsible for the violations.
 There is a growing effort to make companies responsible when their contractors skirt the law. A California law now makes apparel companies that use contractors joint employers. In Florida, farm worker advocates recently sought a law to make orange and tomato growers liable whenever labor contractors violated minimum-wage laws, but the growers blocked it.
 "A lot of these abuses are not going to happen if employers know that they're the people ultimately responsible," said Rob Williams, director of the Migrant Farm Workers Justice Project for Florida Legal Services.
 But Ralph DeLeon, a labor contractor who employs 450 citrus and avocado workers in California and Arizona, asserted that only a small fraction of contractors break the law. 
 "Unfortunately," he said, "the good labor contractor who complies with the law, you're never going to hear about."

HEADLINE: Legacies of Notable Lives 

 BODY:
IN lieu of flowers, many obituary notices say, the family requests . . .
 What follows may be a suggestion for a donation to a cause supported by the person who died: a college scholarship fund, a soup kitchen, a symphony, a shelter that saves abandoned pets. Or perhaps the family wants to direct contributions to an organization seeking a cure for the disease that caused the death. Then again, the money could go toward a more tangible monument: the planting of trees, land preserved for a park, a stained-glass glass window in a house of worship. 
 In every case, the impulse is the same: to remember the friend or family member who died and to remind those who survive why that life mattered. 
 Much the same impulse governs this annual collection of articles summing up the lives of notable Westchester County and Putnam County residents -- some already well known, all worth knowing. Lynne Ames researched and wrote the obituaries chosen for the year 2003.

Social Justice Personified
 Christopher Fairfield Edley met his wife, Zaida Coles Edley, when they were in the fifth grade. In their 52 years of marriage, Mrs. Edley saw more in her man than his public achievements, impressive as they were: president for 18 years of the United Negro College Fund, a prominent Harvard- trained civil rights lawyer, a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. 
 "He really did have an incredible dedication to doing good things," Mrs. Edley said. "It's an interesting thing to think about. Is this something you are born with, or is it nurtured by a caring environment? In my husband's case, I would surely say both."
 He was also a calculating charmer, at least when it came to winning the girl he wanted. "He was a friend of my brother," she said. "He later confessed it was his strategy to get close to my brother in order to get close to me."
 Mr. Edley grew up in Lynchburg, Va., where his divorced mother supported him and two other children by working on the housekeeping staff of a local college. During his high school years, he worked part-time to help with family expenses. 
 He and his wife attended Howard University in the District of Columbia. He then went to Harvard Law School, where, in the early 1950's, he was "one of less than a handful of blacks on the law school campus," according to his literature handed out at his memorial service in Shiloh Baptist Church in New Rochelle, where Mr. and Mrs. Edley lived. 
 After researching the demographics of American cities, Mr. Edley chose Philadelphia as a good starting place for a young African-American lawyer. He eventually became the appeals chief in the district attorney's office, then a partner in the firm Moore, Lightfoot & Edley. Later he worked for the United States Commission on Civil Rights, then in 1963 joined the Ford Foundation, becoming its first African-American program officer. 
 In 1973 Mr. Edley succeeded Vernon F. Jordan as president of the United Negro College Fund. This came a year after the Advertising Council, a public service organization, helped coin the phrase "A mind is a terrible thing to waste," which became the fund's durable signature. Mr. Edley built upon the slogan, mounting huge advertising campaigns and setting up a government affairs unit to lobby for the fund's member colleges and universities. In 1979, he started the fund's annual telethon with the singer Lou Rawls as the host, an event that has raised more than $100 million. 
 By 1991, when the fund's current president, William H. Gray III, succeeded him, Mr. Edley had overseen the flow of more than $550 million in direct aid to 41 private historically black colleges and universities, and the awarding of a thousand individual scholarships a year. 
 Although diabetes and heart problems forced his retirement from the fund at 63, Mr. Edley remained active in many causes. He was on dozens of public interest boards and commissions, including the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., and received honorary degrees from 16 colleges and universities .
 Mr. Edley died on May 5. He was 75.

Adventurous Storyteller
 Her friends knew how Bonnie Page lived: with flair, drama and creativity. But many others knew her because of the way she died, news that made headlines throughout the country.
 On May 16, Mrs. Page was attacked in the kitchen of her Cortlandt Manor home by a pit bull that she had recently adopted. The wounds to her face and head were so severe that she bled to death on the way to the hospital.
 Mrs. Page was born Bonnie Lou Barker in 1927 in Peekskill, where she lived most of her life. After graduating from Hendrick Hudson High School, she attended the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in Manhattan. She appeared in Off Broadway plays and worked as a model.
 After a marriage that ended in divorce, she worked for AT&T and raised her two children. Faced with financially rough times, she stayed briefly at the local Y.W.C.A. By 1977, things had improved so much that she not only was living in her own apartment, but she had also become president of that Y.W.C.A.
 In her late 50's, she started working on a semiautobiographical account of her life, said Emily Hanlon, a professional writer and leader of a writing workshop in Ossining. 
 "She was one of the most wildly creative students I've ever had," Ms. Hanlon said. 
 "She was giving birth to creative thoughts all over the place. Much to her credit, she stuck with it and finally finished her novel. She was just at the point of beginning to rewrite when she died. She had become a truly good writer."
 The novel, loosely autobiographical, was about an actress, said Mrs. Page's daughter, Dr. B. Starr McMullen, chairman of the economics department at Oregon State University in Corvallis. The sense of artistic adventure mirrored her mother's spirit, Dr. McMullen said, adding, "She was very dramatic. she loved to tell a story." 
 After her mother's cremation, Ms. McMullen sent some of the ashes to Ms. Hanlon so the writing group could hold a memorial service. 
 "We were devastated," Ms. Hanlon said. "We planted a rose bush and put her ashes there."
 Mrs. Page died May 16. She was 76.

Entrepreneurial Father
 Plenty of shoppers know the name "Sau-Sea Shrimp Cocktails" and the product that goes with them: curved glass jars filled with tiny shrimp and tangy red sauce. 
 The man behind the brand was a longtime Greenburgh resident, Abraham Kaplan. He founded Sau-Sea Foods in Yonkers in 1948, after borrowing $1,500 from his brother Sidney and another $1,500 from a friend, Ernest Schoenbrun, who was his business partner. The two rented a tiny warehouse space on School Street in Yonkers and went to Fulton Street Fish Market to buy shrimp.
 After packaging their product, the partners took it to stores, suggesting a retail sales price of 50 cents.
 Success was virtually immediate. Sau-Sea shrimp cocktails were distributed nationwide out of the Yonkers building.
 Antonio Estadella, the husband of Mr. Kaplan's daughter Ronnie, became head of the company. Mr. Kaplan bought Mr. Schoenbrun's share in 1980. 
 In 1965, Sau-Sea moved to a plant at 1000 Saw Mill River Road. There it employed 70 people and processed 10 tons of shrimp a day. Then in 1993 it moved the bulk of its operations to South Carolina, which is home to many seafood processors.
 Administrative offices are now in Tarrytown. Sidney Kaplan, who worked for the company in its early years, recalled: "We deveined, cooked and put shrimp in jars, all by hand. Now that's all done by machinery." 
 Recalling the company's early days, and her father's generous, gregarious personality, Ronnie Estadella said: "He loved to entertain and to feed people. Of course, all our guests got shrimp. But the immediate family probably got the best deal of all. When the sauce was first made at the plant, it was really spicy, the horseradish was really fresh. Those were the shrimp cocktails he brought home to us -- the first ones of every batch, the ones that made your nasal passages sting and brought tears to your eyes."
 Mr. Kaplan died on May 2. He was 84.

Educator and Family Man
 Clayton L. Akin of Larchmont was the superintendent of Rye Neck Schools from 1974 to 1989. He viewed education as a mission, a moral obligation to young people, said his widow, Carol Bradshaw Akin, a teacher at the Hommocks School.
 But, she said, he was equally devoted to her and their children during their 27-year marriage.
 When they met -- in the First Church of Christ Scientist in Mamaroneck -- he was divorced, and 30 years her senior. But that proved no obstacle.
 "He was honest, he was brilliant; we started off as good, good friends and then the relationship grew," Mrs. Akin recalled.
 When he finally did propose, it was on Christmas afternoon. "He gave me this big, carefully wrapped box, and inside it was another beautifully wrapped box and inside that another and well, you can guess what was in the smallest one -- -- a diamond engagement ring." 
 His legacy in education was large and original. He decided to eliminate the position of principal in Rye Neck's elementary, middle, and high school, instituting instead teams of teachers who oversaw guidance of 8 to 10 students per team, and curriculum coordinators who oversaw instruction. The result, Mrs. Akin said, was more personalized learning. 
 "Clayton was a humanitarian," she said. "He was a good administrator but he sometimes called that end of it 'administrivia.' What he really loved was dealing with people."
 Mr. Akin died on April 27. He was 79.

Collector Extraordinaire
 John Boker of Scarsdale had the kind of resume that sounds like something out of the movies: C.I.A. intelligence officer and collector of rare stamps.
 "It was tough as a teenager having a professional interrogator for a father," his daughter, Pamela Boker of Armonk, said jokingly. "His style was understated, polite, nonchalant, but he never forgot a detail. He had this photographic memory. He could see someone once and remember everything about them."
 Mr. Boker, born in Manhattan, graduated from Yale in 1933. In World War II he was a private, then a major, and became fluent in German. During the war he also worked with British intelligence, recruiting double agents. Soon he attracted the attention of the United States Central Intelligence Agency. 
 After the war, when suddenly the Soviet Union went from the status of ally to cold war enemy, Mr. Boker was asked to cultivate Reinhard Gehlen, a Nazi spymaster who had been captured by the British. His subtle, courteous handling of Gehlen gained the German's trust, and he began sharing information about the Soviet Union that he said had been gathered by the Nazis. 
 "I've read letters from Gehlen telling my Dad he was the only one he trusted," Ms. Boker said. In 1990 Mr. Boker was named to the Military Intelligence Hall of Fame.
 Stamps were her father's "other life," Ms. Boker said. He built his collection slowly and painstakingly, interested more in aesthetics than monetary value. Among his most prized specimens were a group of misprints: five-cent stamps that were accidentally printed as two-cent stamps. Other favorites included stamps that had been designed by a New Hampshire man who carved little pictures of people, animals and tools on wine corks, then transferred the artwork to government stamps.
 "I believe my father collected every one of that group" Ms. Boker said. "As in everything else, he was thorough and caring."
Mr. Boker died on April 12. He was 90.

Big Leaguer, Everywhere
 Jim Gordon changed hats many times: play-by-play broadcaster for the New York Giants football team, radio newscaster and chairman of the Putnam County legislature, among other political jobs. 
 "Jim focused on issues rather than political affiliations," said the Putnam County executive, Robert Bondi of Mr. Gordon's years on the Board of Legislators from 1989 to 1997. 
 Mr. Gordon, who lived in Putnam Valley, was probably best known politically for his tenacious role in securing a watershed agreement in 1995 that took two years to negotiate. The agreement stipulates that Putnam County would form a partnership with New York City to protect the quality of the water used by people in New York City, Westchester and Putnam. Another major political achievement was his work in helping defeat a proposed landfill in 1989. 
 Mr. Gordon began his career in 1955 at Madison Square Garden, where he broadcast New York Knicks games, New York Rangers games, and college sports. He later worked as a news director at WINS and WNEW radio stations, while still working as a freelance sportscaster.
 Although his work kept him busy and often on the road with teams, he also found time for volunteer firefighting with the Putnam County Fire Department. At the time of his death, he had logged hundreds of fire calls, very nearly reaching his goal of 1,000 calls.
 Mr. Gordon died on Feb. 17. He was 76.

Congeniality, on Bass
 Aaron Bell "never knew a stranger," his widow, DeLores, said. By that she meant that the tall, affable, jazz bass player made friends with just about everyone he met. "He'd meet someone and right away they were talking and telling each other things about their lives," she said. "We'd be on an airplane and by the end of the trip, Aaron knew the life story of the person next to him."
 Mr. Bell of Mount Vernon was also known for his versatility as a musician. He excelled at drums, piano and tuba before landing on bass, which became his trademark instrument. During World War II, he played with Navy bands. Later he was a bassist with the Andy Kirk Orchestra, Lester Young and Miles Davis. He also played for several years with the Duke Ellington Orchestra and in 1963 he conducted a 14-piece orchestra in the premiere of his composition "Memorial Suite for Duke" in a program at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan to commemorate Ellington's birth.
 His career also included performances on Broadway with Cy Coleman and Sammy Davis Jr.; composing and playing background music for films; leading his own group, the Aaron Bell Trio; being musical director for the La Mama Theater in Manhattan; and lecturing on jazz at colleges.
 Less than 24 hours before his death from lung cancer, Mr. Bell was wheeled into the dayroom of the hospice, and played piano. "After that," Mrs. Bell said, " after he got too tired to play, they took him back to his room, and soon after that, the priest was administering last rites."
 Mr. Bell died July 28. He was 82.

With People at Heart
 John E. Flynn was one of those people to whom the phrase "humble beginnings" applies perfectly. 
 "He had ahard life at first," his daughter, Joan Natoli, said. "He grew up in north Yonkers in a home with no indoor plumbing. They used an outhouse. To shower, they went to the local Y. His parents were immigrants from Ireland and from their experiences, and his own, he developed a feeling for people in trouble."
 That feeling eventually led Mr. Flynn to politics.
 A Republican, he was the mayor of Yonkers for three terms, beginning in 1961, and then a state senator, serving Yonkers, Greenburgh and parts of Mount Vernon and the North Bronx for 10 terms. 
 Before going into politics, Mr. Flynn went to New York University and Columbia University. Later, he worked at the Alexander Smith and Sons carpet company in Yonkers. 
 "He was always in motion, always busy, always trying to help people," she said. "He was even able to march in the St. Patrick's Day parade this year" about six months before his death. "I said, 'Dad, it will be too much for you' and he said, 'Oh no, I'm going to do it.' It was a cold day but he refused to wear a coat, and do you know what, it did not make him sick."
 One of Mr. Flynn's primary concerns was the welfare of the disabled and the elderly. He sponsored bills in the State Senate to provide for wheelchair ramps and other means of accessibility. He also "spoke, really talked and listened to" older people who were worried about living on fixed incomes in a county as costly as Westchester. One of the first housing developments for the elderly in Yonkers, Flynn Manor, was named for him. 
 He was also responsible for another first for the city. As mayor, he created its original youth board, which later became the Youth Services Agency. He also set up the city's Human Rights Commission. As state senator in 1975, he was able to procure enough state money so the financially beleaguered city could avoid default.
 Many people knew Mr. Flynn by his nickname, Chippie. Although he was a life-long Republican, he nonetheless played on a baseball team affiliated with the Yonkers Democrats -- the Chippewa Club. Thus, the nickhame. 
 Mr. Flynn died on Sept 23. He was 91.

Art as a Life's Work
 Even as he mourns, Leon Wolfe can joke about his second wife, Rita Rapaport. "She was the only WASP Jew I've ever known," he said. "Her parents were in real estate. She could, in fact trace her ancestry in America almost as far back to colonial times."
 But Ms. Rapaport (who had also been been married once before) defined herself not by her ancestry but by her art. Despite her very secular ancestry and upbringing, her painting and sculpture focused largely on the Holocaust, and the atrocities that defied all the usual questions of why and how it could have occurred.
 Perhaps one of her best-known pieces is "The Gates of Remembrance," a bronze sculpture on Martine Avenue in downtown White Plains that evokes the horror of the Holocaust. Of the 1968 sculpture, she wrote: "'The Gate of Remembrance':" two posts, blown by the wind, evoking fire, crematoria, the chimneys. Vav -- the sixth letter of the Hebrew alphabet for the six days of creation the six million dead.
 "And the gate itself -- a gate to heaven? The gate to hell" Or Yom Kippur's gate of forgiveness that closes at the end of the Holy Days? Do the gates come to freedom -- or close us in?"
 Mr. Wolfe, a native of Poland who was imprisoned in three concentration camps, met Ms. Rapaport when he was curator at the museum at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, whose exhibits often have Jewish themes. Ms. Rapaport visited the museum in 1986, and Mr. Wolfe, who is now 87, said: "Things just, how do you say, clicked between us." They married a year later.
 Ms. Rapaport died on Nov. 29. She was 85.

HEADLINE: The Smoking Ban: Clear Air, Murky Economics 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU; Ann Farmer contributed reporting for this article.

 BODY:
When New York City banned smoking in its bars and restaurants last March, opponents warned that the tough new law would drive away customers and devastate businesses. Supporters insisted that New Yorkers would quickly adjust.
 Nine months later, the impact is hardly so clear cut. An examination of government data, public polls, private surveys and interviews with customers, employees and owners of more than three dozen bars and restaurants around the city shows the law having an impact on some businesses, but certainly not on all. 
 Many bar owners and managers say the smoking ban has hurt business, eroding profits and, in some cases, forcing them to cut back hours or lay off workers. Others say they have seen virtually no effect. 
Some restaurants and bars say that business is fine -- even thriving, as the economy improves -- particularly in places where food is a main draw. Further, a vast majority of New Yorkers have said in recent polls that they are happy with the new law. One survey shows that many regular restaurantgoers see a smoke-free environment as an attraction.
That does not mean, though, that some city night spots are not hurt by the ban. Happy-hour sales on Friday nights at the Whiskey Ward on the Lower East Side have dropped to barely $100, from $600, a co-owner says, and regulars have disappeared along with the ashtrays. 
A co-owner of Patroon, a steakhouse in Midtown, says he no longer sees much of a cigar-puffing, after-dinner crowd. And in the meatpacking district, the owner of Hogs & Heifers, where Julia Roberts was once enticed to dance on the bar, says she is considering laying off four employees.
Then there are the many nuisances wrought by the smoking ban, which bar owners and bartenders say just makes it harder to scrape out a living in an already tough business.
"It's harder to keep track of everybody going in and out," said Chuck Zeilfelder, a bartender at Bourbon Street in Bayside, Queens, who opposes the ban. "It's common for people to leave money on the bar, and that becomes an issue -- how much they left. Also, people leave their drinks on the bar and go out. The drinks get thrown out, and then you have to buy them another round on the house."
It is unclear whether the complaints about the smoking ban are anything more than growing pains, as a city that prides itself on its night life adjusts to the far-reaching new law. Certainly, where the city goes from here is of great interest to other places around the world, like Ireland, Norway and Lexington, Ky., which are debating their own versions of the law.
The early evidence, however, is that many businesses are unharmed. In fact, though rumors swirl in an environment where every bit of news is trumpeted by the side it favors, a reporter could not verify that one bar, restaurant or club, of the more than 20,000 in the city, had closed solely because of the smoking ban.
In contrast, the owner-chef at Gotham Bar and Grill, Alfred Portale, says more people are dining at the pink granite bar, where the food is served on black lacquer trays. The bar at the Jazz Standard on East 27th Street remains packed every night, its owner says. And the line only grows longer outside McSorley's Old Ale House on East Seventh Street, the "wonderful saloon" chronicled by the writer Joseph Mitchell, though some patrons have grumbled that they miss having a Marlboro with their house ale.
"Believe it or not, it may be helping us because it's driving people to drink," said McSorley's owner, Matthew Maher.
The city's antismoking law was championed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who saw it as a health initiative to protect restaurant and bar workers from being exposed to secondhand smoke. In July, the state followed with an even tougher smoking ban.
Even if the city were to repeal its ban, the state's would remain in effect -- something that has not seemed to make much difference to the smokers and businesses who continue to blame the mayor for their woes and lobby to have the city's law amended.
The ban does not appear to have deterred businesses from opening in New York City. The New York State Liquor Authority, which issues licenses to establishments that serve alcohol, received 127 applications from city businesses last month, compared to 126 in November 2002. The number of licenses granted by the authority in that same period rose to 106 last month, from 75 the year before.
The city's Health Department, which enforces the smoking ban, has also analyzed monthly employment numbers and found no overall job loss in the food service and drinking industry. Critics have countered that such findings are politically motivated, and cannot show when establishments cut back shifts and absorb revenue losses. But many restaurants and bars refuse to divulge their finances, making it difficult to gauge the validity of their complaints.
Polls back the city's contention that New Yorkers have welcomed the ban. A New York Times poll in June showed that 56 percent of the 962 respondents said they approved of the smoking ban. A Quinnipiac University poll in October found that 62 percent supported the ban.
Tim Zagat, the publisher of restaurant guides, surveyed more than 29,000 of his volunteer reviewers this year and found that 96 percent said they would eat out as much, if not more, with the smoking ban. Only 4 percent said they would eat out less. "I don't care how you cut it," Mr. Zagat said. "I think it's long-term good for business."
The industry counters with its own surveys, some of which depend on voluntary responses. Pollsters say such surveys are deceptive because those most prone to complain are also most prone to respond. 
The city chapters of the New York State Restaurant Association mailed out a survey to more than 900 members and found that 88 of the 115 city businesses that responded said they had a decline in bar sales since the smoking ban, and 58 said they had a decline in food sales. In addition, 76 reported that their employees had an unfavorable reaction to the ban, while 18 reported a favorable reaction.
Similarly, an October study commissioned by the Vintners Federation of Ireland interviewed 300 bars and nightclubs in the New York region and found that 66 percent reported fewer customers since the smoking ban, while 15 percent reported more. In all, 78 percent said the impact of the ban on their businesses had been negative. 
"The nightclub and bar industry are the collateral damage in the admittedly noble fight to get people to stop smoking," said David Rabin, co-owner of Union Bar and Lotus in Manhattan and president of the New York Nightlife Association.
Sales representatives for wine and liquor companies say the impact has trickled down to them.
They say business has dropped between 20 percent and 40 percent since the smoking ban. Similarly, an association for operators of jukeboxes, pinball machines and other games says that revenues have fallen between 10 and 25 percent at bars and nightclubs in New York City. 
"If the people are outside smoking, they're not inside drinking, and they're not inside playing my machines," said Kenneth Goldberg, vice president of the Amusement Music Operators Association.
Indeed, a check by a reporter on two blocks of Bell Boulevard in Bayside and three blocks of Northern Boulevard in Little Neck, both thriving night life strips in Queens, showed some impact from the ban, but more in terms of subtle economic and social changes than closings and layoffs.
Owners and employees reported selling fewer drinks and losing customers before dessert. They complained of the need to watch over drinks and money left on the bar and seats left unoccupied by patrons heading out for a smoke. And bartenders said that tips were down, as were overall tabs, and that longtime customers were resorting to alternatives -- hotel rooms, private homes and parks -- to indulge their smoking and drinking.
But Danny Meyer, who owns a half-dozen restaurants and night spots in Manhattan, including Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern, said his businesses had seen no impact. He banned smoking in some of his restaurants in 1990, and they have grown more popular, he said.
Mr. Meyer said that he no longer had to worry about his waiters and customers coughing from the smoke or the nightly squabbles between smoking and nonsmoking tables. One of his best customers, Roger W. Straus, a publisher with Farrar Straus & Giroux, had complained when Mr. Meyer started his ban about being separated from his cigarettes, but later credited the restaurant with helping him to give up smoking, Mr. Meyer said. 
"New Yorkers will adapt to almost anything," Mr. Meyer said. "They're not going to quit going to great restaurants just because they can't smoke."
Many bars and nightclubs have adopted coping strategies, with varying degrees of success. At the popular China Club near Times Square, smokers are now directed to a 2,000-square-foot terrace. 
"It hasn't impacted us that much," said the owner, Danny Fried, of the ban. 
O'Neill's Bar and Restaurant in Midtown laid off three people in April and resorted to novelty events like trivia contests and election-night vigils for races in Ireland. Ciaran Staunton, the owner, says he sees his regulars pass by on the street, toting six-packs of beer to drink at home. 
Other bars and taverns, like Broadway Dive on the Upper West Side, are placing new emphasis on their food now that they are selling fewer drinks. Since the ban began, alcoholic beverage sales at the Broadway Dive have fallen about one-third, or between $1,500 and $2,000 a week, its owner said. 
Amy Sacco, owner of Lot 61 and Bungalow 8 in West Chelsea, said she had to hire an extra security guard just to make sure the smoking crowd outside does not become unruly. 
"It makes the job very unhappy," Ms. Sacco said. "Next thing you know, it's prohibition for cocktails. We're all responsible for policing it. It's such a drag."
"It's just a big headache in a job that had enough headaches to start with," she said.
