HEADLINE: Legacies of Notable Lives; 
From Politicians to Teachers to Dedicated Members of a Community

 BODY:
IN lieu of flowers, many obituary notices say, "the family requests ..." 
 What follows may be a suggestion for a donation to a cause supported by the person who died: a college scholarship fund, a soup kitchen, a symphony, a shelter for abandoned pets. Or perhaps the family wants to direct contributions to an organization seeking a cure for a disease. Then again, the money could go toward a more tangible monument: the planting of trees, land preserved for a park, a stained-glass window in a house of worship. 
 In every case, the impulse is the same: to remember the friend or family member who died and to remind those who survive why that life mattered. 
Much the same impulse governs this annual collection of articles summing up the lives of notable Connecticut residents -- some already well known, all worth knowing. Dick Ahles researched and wrote the profiles chosen for the year 2003.

A Presence in Baseball
Joseph Buzas opened the 1945 baseball season at shortstop for the New York Yankees, but then the return from World War II of another Yankee shortstop named Phil Rizutto and a serious shoulder injury combined to end Mr. Buzas's big league career after only 30 games.
Although his time in the majors was brief, it was followed by a lifetime in the minor leagues as a manager and owner.
During a span of nearly 50 years, Mr. Buzas owned 60 minor league teams, including, the Boston Red Sox farm teams that played first in Bristol and then in New Britain. 
He was a successful owner in a difficult business, so successful that he was able to sell a Reading, Pa., franchise he had bought for $1 in 1977 for $1 million plus $1 a decade later. 
Mr. Buzas will long be remembered in Connecticut as the man who saved minor league baseball for New Britain when he refused to bow to pressure from the Red Sox to move his team to Springfield, Mass. Instead, he ended a 38-year association with Boston and turned the New Britain franchise into a farm team for the Minnesota Twins. 
Mr. Buzas had moved the team from Bristol to New Britain in 1983, the year the promising young pitcher Roger Clemens led the Class AA team to an Eastern League pennant. The team was popular in New Britain but by 1994, Dan Duquette, the Red Sox general manager, wanted to have a minor league team in western Massachusetts.
Mr. Buzas was tempted to move to the larger city deeper in Red Sox country but appeals by hundreds of New Britain fans persuaded him to keep the team in Connecticut, a decision he dramatically announced from home plate before a game. 
The Red Sox moved, but minor league baseball stayed in New Britain where it continues today as the New Britain Rock Cats.
Mr. Buzas sold the team in 2000 for $6.5 million. He had paid $250,000 for the franchise in 1956 when it was in Allentown, Pa.
Mr. Buzas died in Salt Lake City on March 20. He was 83. 

Fighter, Artist, Survivor
As a young man, Maurice Jean-Henri Ghnassia was a French Resistance fighter with the code name "Spartacus." Then he became the host of a jazz program on a radio station in Paris where he was known as "Mr. Blues." 
Later, he was a United Nations and Washington correspondent for several European publications, a novelist, a professor at the University of Hartford and the translator of eight volumes of "Peanuts" cartoons into French.
Mr. Ghnassia was a 20-year-old student at the Sorbonne when the Nazis occupied Paris in 1940. He helped organize a Resistance cell that harassed Nazi troops and French collaborators until its members were ambushed near a River Seine bridge. Mr. Ghnassia was facing execution when he escaped to the south of France. There, he was once again arrested and condemned to death for Resistance activities, and once again he escaped.
When France was liberated, Mr. Ghnassia joined a French paratroop unit that was attached to the U.S. 101st Airborne Division. 
In a 1989 interview, Mr. Ghnassia recalled: "I have been arrested. I have been condemned to death. Everything you can imagine in a movie happened to me. But it happened to many. I fought because I was angry. I fought for my friends."
Mr. Ghnassia resumed his studies after the war and as Mr. Blues he conducted radio interviews with celebrated jazz performers like Louis Armstrong, Bessie Smith and Billie Holliday. He moved to the United States in 1955 and for more than two decades was a journalist in New York and Washington, where he reported for a Paris radio station and several European newspapers and magazines, interviewing many of the 20th-century's most notable figures, among them Dwight D. Eisenhower, Adlai Stevenson, John F. Kennedy and Fidel Castro.
Mr. Ghnassia lived in New Hartford for a decade in the 1980's and 1990's before moving to Windsor. For several years, while writing novels and poetry and translating Charles Shultz's "Peanuts" comic strips into French, he was also an adjunct professor at the University of Hartford, teaching western civilization and French literature. 
Mr. Ghnassia died Jan. 4 at his retirement home in Cullowhee, N.C. He was 82. 

In Football, a 'Block of Granite'
Football took Harry Jacunski from New Britain High School to Fordham, to the Green Bay Packers, to Notre Dame, Harvard and Yale. 
Mr. Jacunski was an All-State center at New Britain High School in 1934 and good enough to be recruited by one of the era's great college football teams, Fordham, where he played with Vince Lombardi on the legendary defensive line known as "The Seven Blocks of Granite." The team, with Mr. Jacunski as an end, lost only two games in three seasons.
Mr. Jacunski would have ended his football career at Fordham but there were few jobs available for Depression-era college graduates and, after playing a College All-Star Game, he joined the Packers. He played six seasons at Green Bay and was a member of its National Football League champion teams in 1939 and 1944.
After his playing days ended, Mr. Jacunski became an assistant coach at Notre Dame and Harvard before joining the Yale coaching staff in 1947. He served under four head coaches at Yale: Herman Hickman, Jordan Olivar, John Pont and Carmine Cozza, coaching at various times, the ends, guards and centers and scouting opponents. 
In 1965, Mr. Jacunski became freshman coach. During 16 seasons, his teams had a record of 59-37-3 and he worked with nine players who went on to the National Football League, including Calvin Hill, Brian Dowling and Don Martin. He retired in 1980.
Mr. Jacunski died Feb. 20. He was 87. 

Broadway and Prime Time
Anne Burr McDermott made theatrical history in her 1941 Broadway debut when she became the first white actress to perform opposite a black leading man. 
The play was Orson Welles's production of Richard Wright's "Native Son" and Ms. McDermott's leading man was Canada Lee, according to her daughter Maggie McDermott.
Known professionally as Anne Burr, Ms. McDermott spent part of her childhood in Hartford where she attended the Oxford School, now known as Kingswood-Oxford. While working in New York and Hollywood, she spent many summers in Old Lyme and made the town her permanent home in 1986. 
Ms. McDermott appeared in many successful Broadway plays in the 1940's. She played opposite Ralph Bellamy in "Detective Story" and Richard Basehart in "The Hasty Heart." In the early 1950's, Ms. McDermott was one of dozens of actors, writers, directors and others blacklisted for a time following allegations of communist influence in the entertainment industry. 
After she was removed from the blacklist, Ms. McDermott became one of television's first soap opera stars, performing in "As the World Turns" on CBS from 1955 to 1959. She then moved to Hollywood with her husband, Tom McDermott, the producer of successful television shows like "Father Knows Best," "Wanted, Dead or Alive" and "The Big Valley." Ms. McDermott joined the actors Dick Powell, Charles Boyer and David Niven in the Four Star Television production company, which had as many as 11 shows playing in prime time during the 1960's.
Ms. McDermott was active politically, especially in the presidential campaigns of Adlai Stevenson and John F. Kennedy. She was also involved with Recording for the Blind and Dyslexic, an educational service for those with reading disabilities.
Ms. McDermott died Feb. 1 at her home in Old Lyme. She was 84. 

A Reshaping of New Haven
No one in New Haven's 365-year history was mayor longer than Richard C. Lee, who served eight terms from 1954 to 1969. He was also, in the view of the Yale political scientist Douglas Rae, "the most important figure in New Haven's 20th century."
Dick Lee was born and raised in the city's working class Newhallville neighborhood. He never went to college but learned much about the city and its politics while working as a city hall reporter for the old New Haven Journal Courier and as an alderman and a director of the Yale News Bureau.
Elected in 1953 at age 37, Mr. Lee was the city's youngest mayor. He defeated a Republican incumbent to begin a string of consecutive Democratic victories in mayoral elections that has reached the 50-year mark. 
Joined by a staff of like-minded urban reformers and social services professionals like Edward Logue, a redevelopment director, and Mitchell Svirdoff, who headed the city's anti-poverty agency, Mr. Lee set out to change the face of New Haven by clearing its slums and revitalizing its downtown. His dream was to transform New Haven into a model city, a city without poverty. 
The dream was never realized but New Haven under Richard Lee "came closest to our dream of a slumless city," said Robert Weaver, the Federal Housing administrator. 
Mr. Lee replaced blocks of slum housing with new public housing and new schools. He razed three city blocks to make way for two major department stores and a downtown shopping mall and routed the new interstate highways so that they provided easy access to the downtown area.
To achieve all of this, the mayor worked closely with the Democratic administrations of Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. His efforts resulted in more than $430 million in federal funds being funneled to New Haven, along with millions more in foundation grants for social programs. New Haven's Community Progress Incorporated created many job training, education, housing and child care programs that would become the models for President Johnson's "War on Poverty" programs of the 1960's. 
Mr. Lee died Feb. 2 at age 86. He was buried in New Haven's historic Grove Street Cemetery, not far from the graves of some earlier New Haven luminaries, including Eli Whitney, Noah Webster and the city's first mayor and a signer of the Declaration of Independence, Roger Sherman. 

Fond of Square Dancing
Ed Thrall liked square dancing so much that he built a dance hall on his land in East Windsor and started a 20-year fight with the town and the state for the right to hold dances there.
It was quite a dance hall, built with scrap materials that Mr. Thrall found in Hartford and surrounding towns. There was brownstone from the old Heublein Hotel, stones from the former Y.M.C.A. and posts from the demolished Chauncey Harris School. He built a dance floor of multicolored tiles salvaged from various places and cushioned the floor with used truck tires. 
"I worked like a goldurn jackass and built that building practically by myself," Mr. Thrall recalled in an interview five years ago.
The job took Mr. Thrall nearly 10 years and when the dance hall was finally finished in 1978, he was told he couldn't hold square dances because the property wasn't zoned for dance halls. Denied a certificate of occupancy from the state, Mr. Thrall held his square dances anyway, at least until the police arrived. 
Mr. Thrall refused to give in to the authorities and on several occasions he defended his hall and his dances with his shotgun, wearing a tri-cornered hat in the manner of the Minutemen. Then, by way of showing there were no truly hard feelings, Mr. Thrall's wife, Flicka, would arrange for a temporary truce and serve doughnuts to the police.
But there were also several arrests, angry courtroom confrontations and Mr. Thrall spent some time in jail, including six months after a 1995 standoff. Since he couldn't use the hall, Mr. Thrall refused to pay taxes on it and the town finally foreclosed after the unpaid tax bill reached $67,000. The land was auctioned off but when Mr. Thrall's neighbors declined to bid, the town bought the dance hall and 22 acres of Mr. Thrall's land.
Despite what the former police chief Thomas Laufer called "the foolish things" Mr. Thrall did, the town had a grudging respect for his grit and the townspeople concluded that the building should go back to the Thrall family. In 1998, a town meeting voted 115 to 11 to sell the dance hall to Mr. Thrall's daughter and her husband for $100,000. The motion to sell the building was made by Steven Knibloe, a police lieutenant Mr. Thrall once took a shot at during a dance hall siege, according to The Hartford Courant. 
Mr. Thrall died April 20. He was 84. 

Committed to Glastonbury
When Nat Sestero, a Glastonbury correspondent for The Hartford Times, joined the Navy and went to war in 1943, his wife, Norma, replaced him and kept the job for the next 22 years. 
As many of the young reporters assigned to Glastonbury by The Hartford Courant during those years would quickly discover, Norma Sestero was a formidable competitor who knew everyone and everything about her town. 
She won the loyalty of Glastonbury residents early in her career by writing and editing a monthly newsletter, "The Home Town News," which was sent to nearly 1,000 Glastonbury men and women serving in the armed forces all over the world in World War II. When they returned to their home town in 1946, the veterans honored Ms. Sestero at a victory celebration, and 46 years later, the veterans did it again, naming Ms. Sestero honorary marshal of the town's 1992 Veterans Day parade.
As a reporter, Ms. Sestero covered the town's transition from the traditional board of selectmen to the town manager form of government and she saw Glastonbury grow from 6,000 residents to 30,000. Ms. Sestero was involved in many town organizations, serving as a life member of the Glastonbury Historical Society and as a member of the Friends of the Welles-Turner Memorial Library and the libraries in East and South Glastonbury. She established a trust with the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving in 1988 for the benefit of the region's cultural, educational and health agencies. 
Although her husband, Nat, didn't get his Glastonbury job back after World War II, he did return to The Hartford Times and rose to managing editor. Ms. Sestero served as the official hostess for the national convention of the Associated Press Managing Editors when the meeting was held in Hartford in 1969.
Ms. Sestero died April 23 in Hartford Hospital. She was 92.

Legislator and Advocate
When Nancy Pilver first learned she had breast cancer eight years ago, she became an advocate for victims of the disease.
As legislative chairwoman for the Connecticut Breast Cancer Coalition, Ms. Pilver lobbied the Connecticut General Assembly to pass legislation that ended what were known as "drive-through mastectomies" at hospitals in the state.
Connecticut insurance companies must now pay for 48-hour hospital stays after mastectomies.
Ms. Pilver was involved in many other community groups in her home town of Manchester, including the Library Board, the Historical Society, the Center Congregational Church, the Manchester Hospital Women's Auxiliary and the Pride in Manchester Week Committee.
She was also active in the Republican Party, serving on the Town Committee and the Republican Women's Club.
Last year, she ran for state representative but was not successful and during the campaign, she discovered that the cancer that had twice gone into remission had returned. 
Ms. Pilver died May 10. She was 69. 

Pioneer for Space Program
Henry Clay Osborn III was a space pioneer who helped develop the fuel cells used on both the Apollo and Gemini missions as a Pratt & Whitney engineer. His contributions to the space program are recorded in the archives of the Air and Space Institute in Washington.
Mr. Osborn received engineering degrees from the University of Rhode Island and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and served as an Army officer during World War II before joining Pratt & Whitney.
He was a man with many interests. Although trained as an engineer, his love of history prompted him to pursue a master's degree in the subject at the University of Connecticut and he used his knowledge of history to collect and restore antiques. Also an avid horticulturist, Mr. Osborn was certified as a master gardener by the UConn Agricultural Extension Service and he was co-founder of the Connecticut Chapter of the Rhododendron Society. 
He lived in Hebron for 53 years and was chairman of the Hebron Republican Town Committee for 25 years. In addition, he served his town as chairman of the building committee for Rham High School.
Mr. Osborn died Jan. 22 in a fire in his historic home, which he had carefully restored over many years. He was 84. Mr. Osborn would have been pleased that his family asked those who wished to remember him to contribute to the Hebron Volunteer Fire Department to help restore its antique fire truck. 

Father Figure in Norwich
Dan O'Leary liked to help people.
As president of the Norwich-Quinnebaug Unit of the American Cancer Society and the fund-raising chairman of the statewide Cancer Society, he raised tens of thousands of dollars to fight the disease. He was also involved in raising funds for the Haitian Health Council, which provides poverty-stricken Haitians with medical and dental treatment.
Mr. O'Leary and his wife, Carolyn, helped relocate hundreds Laotian refugees from camps in Thailand to permanent homes in Connecticut. To the 500 men, women and children in the Laotian community in northeastern Connecticut, Mr. O'Leary was known as Papa. 
Mr. O'Leary died May 4 at his home in Danielson. He was 64. 

An Officer and Reporter
Albert Cotter enlisted in the army as a private in 1942 and retired as a major general in the Connecticut National Guard 34 years later. 
As a civilian, he was a newspaperman, first with the weekly Farmington Valley Herald and then with The Hartford Times, which he served as both city hall reporter and military editor from 1947 to 1963.
When the Connecticut-based 43rd Infantry Division was called to active duty during the Korean War, The Hartford Times assigned Mr. Cotter to cover the division for the two years it was attached to NATO in Germany.
Mr. Cotter, a graduate of Georgetown University, was an army sergeant in 1943 when he was sent to officer candidate school and commissioned a second lieutenant. He spent two years as a platoon leader and battery commander in the European theater and received the Soldier's Medal, the highest Army decoration for valor involving an act of heroism in a non-combat situation, for risking his life to save a member of his anti-aircraft battery in France in 1945. 
When he was discharged as a captain in 1946, Mr. Cotter joined the Connecticut-based 76th Infantry Army Reserve Division and later transferred to the Connecticut National Guard. During the administrations of Gov. Abraham Ribicoff and Gov. John Dempsey, he was the senior officer on the governor's military staff. He also commanded the Guard's officer candidate school at Camp Dempsey in Niantic in 1967. By the time he retired in 1976, he was a major general.
Mr. Cotter died March 8. He was 83. 

Dedicated to Teaching
Helen Ely Brill believed the most meaningful period of her life was the year she taught at the Manzanar War Relocation Center, a California internment camp in which the United States government confined Japanese Americans during World War II.
At Manzanar, she met a conscientious objector named Robert Brill, who was doing alternate military service as a firefighter in the mountains near the camp. 
Ms. Brill joined the Religious Society of Friends, more familiarly known as the Quakers, while in her 20's. She was a founder of the Buffalo, N.Y., meeting and held many local, regional and national positions with the Society. 
She and her husband also founded the Connecticut Chapter of the Parents and Friends of Lesbians and Gays.
Ms. Brill, a longtime history teacher at Enfield High School, died April 14 of an injury caused by a fall in her Bloomfield home that day. She was 88. Her family noted that her last day was a joy-filled one spent visiting the Peabody Museum in New Haven.

Columnist Called 'Pop'
John Weaver-Bey was known as Pop, an appropriate designation for the father of 8, grandfather of 19, great grandfather of 29 and great-great grandfather of 5.
But he was also a surrogate parent and mentor to many Hartford residents, including the city's first African-American mayor, Thirman Milner. Mr. Milner's father died when he was 12, and he said Mr. Weaver-Bey always referred to him as "son."
Mr. Weaver-Bey worked for many years as a carpenter and as an oil deliveryman, but he was widely known for the column he wrote for the last two decades in the Northend Agent's, a weekly newspaper serving Hartford's black community.
Mr. Milner said that Mr. Weaver-Bey could still read small news print without glasses in his 90's. Until he became ill early in 2003, he drove copy to the newspaper's printer in Willimantic.
John Allen, the Northend Agent's publisher, said Mr. Weaver-Bey also served as the small paper's office manager, sold ads and "he was our good will ambassador. We told him he had a job with the paper for life and he did."
Mr. Weaver-Bey died in his Hartford home July 4. He was 93. 

Political Longevity
No woman served longer in the Connecticut General Assembly than M. Adela Eads.
Dell Eads was a legislator for 24 years, four of them in the House and 20 in the Senate. She was also the first and only woman elected president pro tem of the Senate.
A Republican and a fiscal conservative, Ms. Eads held moderate to liberal views on many social issues. She was credited with playing a major role in the creation of the state's Office of Child Advocate and the passage of the Education Enhancement Act, which provided higher wages for the state's teachers in the 1980's. 
She supported abortion rights and voted against a ban on the procedure that its opponents call partial birth abortions in 1999. On that occasion, according to The Hartford Courant, she "chided her male colleagues on the Senate floor by asking them how many women had called to voice support for the abortion ban. 'This is the end of the 90's. Get with it,' Eads told the male senators."
Despite her occasional differences with the party, Ms. Eads had an otherwise solid Republican voting record and wasa recipient of the party's highest honor, the Prescott Bush Award, named for the late Connecticut United States senator who was father and grandfather to Republican presidents. Whenever she made a summertime announcement that she would seek another term, Ms. Eads would be honored at a fund-raiser at the home of Kent's most prominent resident Republican, Henry Kissinger, the former secretary of state.
Though considered a quintessential Connecticut Yankee, Ms. Eads was born Mary Adela Diaz in Brooklyn, N.Y., to parents who spoke fluent Spanish and English. She moved to Kent in 1950 with her husband, Vernon Eads, with whom she worked as a partner in a family owned business that bought and sold used equipment. Mr. Eads died in 2001.
At the time of her death, The Lakeville Journal noted the "many remembrances throughout the Northwest Corner of the diminutive Eads," among them a building at the Torrington Branch of the University of Connecticut, the reading room at Housatonic Valley Regional High School and a red flowering maple on the lawn of Kent's town hall.
Ms. Eads died July 8. She was 83. 

Grande Dame of G.O.P.
The political rivals John G. Rowland and Lowell Weicker rarely agree on much, but they do share an admiration for Emma Lincoln.
To Governor Rowland, Ms. Lincoln was "not only a great Republican but a great contributor to all of her causes. She had an extroardinary life and we will miss her."
To Weicker, a former governor and former Republican, Ms. Lincoln was "one of the grande dames of the Republican Party."
That she was.
Ms. Lincoln was the longtime chairwoman of the New London Republican Town Committee and was a state central committeewoman.
"For some five decades she carried the Republican Party banner in New London with enthusiasm and pride," The Day of New London said. "That she did so in a city where Democrats held an overwhelming majority and regularly inflicted heavy casualties on G.O.P. candidates was a testament to her persistence, her ironclad belief in Republican principles and her love of politics."
Ms. Lincoln had another distinction. From 1944 to 1976, she owned and operated Lincoln Auto Body in New London. During that period, she operated an auto body repair shop, an unusual job for a woman. 
Ms. Lincoln died London June 10. She was 89.

A Model Citizen
You could tell the kind of citizen Olga Mele was by the awards she received. 
In 1977, she was given the Jefferson Award from the American Institute for Public Service in Washington for her community work in Hartford. 
Three years later, President Carter presented her with a Special Distinction Award at the White House and in 1985, Pope John Paul II awarded her the Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice Medal for her outstanding contributions to her church and society.
Ms. Mele was born in Guayama, P.R., and moved to Hartford in 1941. For many years, she was a job counselor with Hartford's Community Renewal Team but her involvement in the Hartford community and especially its Hispanic neighborhoods went far beyond her job.
She assisted the elderly of the city through her participation as a member of the Larabee Foundation of the Commission on Aging and as a member of St. Peter's Church she took part in many of its outreach programs through the Ladies Auxiliary and Prayer Group.
Among the many other honors cited by Ms. Mele's family were the Marcus Garvey Award, the La Casa de Puerto Rico community service award and the Maria Sanchez Award for community service named for a legendary leader of Hartford's Puerto Rican community and the first Puerto Rican member of Hartford's Board of Education. Ms. Mele was a mentor to Ms. Sanchez.
Ms. Mele died July 20. She was 86. 

Politician and Music Lover
State Representative Anthony Tercyak was on the telephone, discussing President Bush's June 12 visit to New Britain, when he collapsed and died on June 11, The Hartford Courant reported. 
On his desk, Mr. Tercyak's family found a note he had just written to a former student, apologizing for missing the student's recent recital. Mr. Tercyak had been a music teacher and coordinator of the New Britain schools' Gifted and Talented Program before retiring and running for office. He promised to attend the student's next recital. 
Mr. Tercyak was elected to the state House of Representatives in 1994 and was serving his fifth term at the time of his death. According to his family, he was proud to have been the first Republican elected to the House from the heavily Democratic New Britain and proud of the Democratic and independent votes that returned him to office. He was highly regarded by both parties and the Democrats joked that he was an honorary member of their caucus.
Robert Ward, the leader of the Republican minority in the House, recalled that when Mr. Tercyak was first elected, he gave up his Wednesday night orchestra seats to the Metropolitan Opera so that he would not miss any evening sessions of the House.
Mr. Tercyak was born and raised in a largely Polish neighborhood in New Britain known as "The Hill" and was a lifelong member of the city's Holy Cross Church that has a predominantly Polish congregation.
"They used to call him the most popular man in town," said Mayor Lucian Pawlak. "He earned that title. He deeply loved his community."
Mr. Tercyak was 79 when he died. As expected, a Democrat was elected to succeed him. The Democrat is Mr. Tercyak's son Peter.

Stalwart of Education
Theodore Powell was one of the founders of Connecticut's community college system in the 1960's and an early chancellor of the colleges.
Mr. Powell lived in Manchester for many years and played a prominent role in the town's political life as a member of the Manchester board of directors and as deputy mayor.
"He was a voice of liberalism and had the courage to express his feelings, no matter the odds," said Ted Cummings, Manchester's Democratic town chairman who worked closely with Mr. Powell.
He persuaded Manchester leaders to establish the Manchester Community College in 1963 and received an honorary degree from the college in 2000. Andew McKirdy, who succeeded Mr. Powell as chancellor of the community college system, called Mr. Powell "a man who was deeply committed to the extension of educational opportunities to people who wouldn't otherwise have them. He could be extremely feisty in advancing his causes. That was part of the strength of his commitment." 
Eleanor Coltman, an associate of Mr. Powell in establishing the Manchester college, agreed with Mr. McKirdy's description of Mr. Powell's feistiness, saying that he had very strong opinions "but he was always very gentlemanly about it."
Mr. Powell, a combat veteran of World War II, was educated at Colgate University and received a master's degree in political science from Johns Hopkins University and a doctorate in public law and government from Columbia. He was the author of two books, "The Long Rescue," an account of a Navy arctic expedition in the 19th century, and "The School Bus Law," about a bitter battle in the Connecticut General Assembly in the 1950's over providing bus service to parochial school students.
Mr. Powell left Connecticut in 1968 to become a professor and then the president of Fenger-Southeast Community College in Chicago. He later taught at community colleges in New York. 
Mr. Powell died May 13 in California. He was 84. 

Painter of Presidents
Herbert Abrams painted portraits of presidents.
He also painted other famous people, like governors, a first lady, a general, an astronaut and a playwright. The presidents were George H.W. Bush and Jimmy Carter. The first lady was Barbara Bush. His three governors were from Connecticut: Thomas Meskill, Ella Grasso and Lowell Weicker. The general was William Westmoreland, the astronaut, Edwin (Buzz) Aldrin and the playwright, Arthur Miller.
Mr. Abrams wasn't always a painter of portraits. As a young artist fresh out of Norwich Art School, he painted camouflage for the United States Air Force during World War II. He also became a pilot and was the designer of aircraft insignia. Later, he taught art at the United States Military Academy at West Point.
After the war, Mr. Abrams studied at the Pratt Institute and Art Students League in New York. He wasn't an immediate success as an artist, once recalling that he considered himself fortunate to sell his paintings for as much as $35 from a park bench in Greenwich Village. But he did find success as a portrait artist, painting more than 400 portraits in a 40-year career.
Mr. Abrams's wife, Lois, who served as his public relations aide and scheduler, told The Hartford Courant that her husband insisted on getting to know each subject before beginning to paint. She said it was important to him to not be in awe of the people he painted and that they not worry "about the artist who was going to portray him or her for posterity." 
To prepare for the Carter portrait, Mr. Abrams went to church with the president and attended the Sunday school Mr. Carter conducted in his home town of Plains, Ga. With Mr. Bush, Mr. Abrams discussed mutually pleasant things like their interest in fly fishing and the Boston Red Sox. 
Both presidents and their families liked their portraits, Ms. Abrams said. Mr. Carter's mother, Miss Lillian Carter, had warned the artist that she wouldn't like the portrait "unless it's just like him." When she saw her son's likeness, she agreed it was just like him and said, "I do like it."
When the Bush portrait was unveiled in 1995, Mr. Bush looked at the painting of him standing in his office with his elbow resting on a globe and said, "I'm inclined to think it's pretty darned good."
Mr. Abrams, who lived in Warren for many years, died Aug. 29. He was 82.

Service as Prosecutor
Politics was in Jack Bailey's blood but he was never elected to anything other than Democratic town chairman of Colchester. Instead, he chose a career in public service as a prosecutor, an appointed office in Connecticut.
John Michael Bailey was the son of John Moran Bailey, one of the most powerful political leaders Connecticut has produced. As the only son of the longtime Democratic state chairman and national chairman in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, the younger Mr. Bailey for a time seemed likely to become involved in his father's profession. But his ambitions ran head on into those of another heir to a Connecticut political dynasty, Christopher Dodd, the son of the United States Senator Thomas Dodd. The two met in a Congressional primary in 1974 and Mr. Dodd won.
Mr. Bailey's older sister, Barbara Kennelly, did choose the family business, running successfully for secretary of the state and serving 17 years in Congress beforerunning for governor, and losing, in 1994.
When Jack Bailey died, Mr. Dodd, now Connecticut's senior senator, said, "He had a strong understanding of Connecticut's history because his family has been such an important part of that history."
Mr. Bailey served as a White House intern during the Johnson Administration and worked at the 1964 and 1968 Democratic conventions. After graduating from Ashland College and Catholic University's law school in 1972, he joined his father's Hartford law firm, Bailey and Wechsler. He left the firm after losing the Congressional nomination to become a prosecutor. After four years as an assistant state's attorney in Manchester, he became Hartford's state's attorney at age 35. 
Mr. Bailey was prosecutor in Hartford for 14 years before being promoted to chief state's attorney, a post he held until health problems forced him into early retirement in 2002. 
As chief state's attorney, Mr. Bailey went before the General Assembly several times seeking investigative subpoena power for his prosecutors. Without such power, Mr. Bailey argued, state prosecutors had to rely on federal prosecutors to conduct more serious and complex investigations. 
Mr. Bailey stepped down as chief state's attorney after he was told by doctors that he had progressive bulbar palsy, a rare disorder in which talking and swallowing become increasingly difficult. There is no known cause or cure for the disease, a variation of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly referred to as Lou Gehrig's disease. For the last year of his life, Mr. Bailey was unable to speak and he could not respond to the 2000 people who attended a tribute to him in Southington 11 months ago.
"For a man so engaging not to be able to speak for the last months of his life must have been excruciating," said Richard Palmer, the state Supreme Court Justice, who presided at the Southington dinner. "But he handled it with aplomb and communicated without speaking." 
Mr. Bailey died Sept. 23. He was 59. 

A Star and 'Local Girl'
Katharine Hepburn grew up in Hartford at 138 Hawthorne Street, near Mark Twain's home, and also at 201 Bloomfield Avenue in West Hartford.
But the Connecticut community in which Ms. Hepburn lived most of her long life was Fenwick, the borough within Old Saybrook at the mouth of the Connecticut River. Dr. Thomas Hepburn and his wife, Katharine, first brought their young family to the affluent shoreline enclave in 1913, when Katharine was 6.
"Mother and dad were perfect parents," Ms. Hepburn wrote in "Me," her 1991 autobiography. "They brought us up with a feeling of freedom. There were no rules. There were simply certain things which we did -- and certain things which we didn't do because they would hurt others."
Dr. Hepburn was a surgeon and an early advocate of informing the public about venereal disease and his wife was a crusader for women's suffrage and birth control.
"In Hartford," Ms. Hepburn would remember years later, "that made her a wicked woman. When I was a small child, we'd be out walking and we'd meet a neighbor on the street and my mother would say, 'good morning,' and the neighbor would look right through us as if nobody was there."
Ms. Hepburn attended Hartford's West Middle School and the private Oxford School and in 1924, she enrolled in Bryn Mawr College near Philadelphia. She left college to pursue her legendary, 60-year career in Hollywood but in many ways, she never left Connecticut.
"Well, it's home to me," she wrote. "I've been stuck in the snow. I've lost a house in a hurricane. I've tennised, I've golfed. It's been fun. I've lived there and I'll be buried there."
The house lost in a hurricane was the first family home at Fenwick. Ms. Hepburn was visiting there before making the movie "The Philadelphia Story" when, on Sept. 21, 1938, the most ferocious hurricane to hit Connecticut in more than a century struck the coastline without warning. Ms. Hepburn, her mother, her brother Robert, a family friend and the cook fled from the house just minutes before it floated off its foundation and disappeared into Long Island Sound.
Dr. Hepburn would build a larger home to which Ms. Hepburn would retreat throughout her career. "I'm like the girl who never grew up, you see," she told an interviewer in 1989. "I just never really left home, so to speak. I always went back there almost every weekend of my life when I wasn't filming. I kept my life there, my roots."
To underscore her Connecticut roots, Ms. Hepburn left her autograph with those of other famous performers on a backstage wall in Hartford's Bushnell Auditorium. Under her name, she wrote, "local girl."
Ms. Hepburn died at her Fenwick home on June 29 and was buried in the family plot at the Cedar Hill Cemetery in Hartford. She was 96. 

Dependable and Dedicated
The slogan on the five red tow trucks that Charles Matties operated out of his two West Hartford service stations was this: "Stuck -- Call Chuck."
Those words could have applied just as well to Mr. Matties's long service to West Hartford as a councilman, state representative and mayor because Mr. Matties, a Republican, was more concerned with solving community problems than with ideology or partisan politics. The town responded by electing him councilman nine times and to one term as mayor. He also served four terms in the Legislature. (Another measure of longevity: he operated Matties Service Stations on Park Road and Farmington Avenue in West Hartford for 48 years.) 
Senator Kevin Sullivan, president pro tem of the State Senate and a Democrat, defeated Mr. Matties for the seat he now holds in 1986. "He was not a partisan," Mr. Sullivan of his rival. "He was a good guy."
Mr. Matties died July 29 at the John Dempsey-UConn Medical Center in Farmington. He was 79.

Stickler for the Law
Clarence Jackson, a 24-year-old black man from Hamden, had made an expensive mistake. He had failed to redeem a winning $5.8 million dollar state lottery ticket within a year, as required by state law, turning it in three days late.
There was an outpouring of sympathy for the young man from every corner of the state. Among those moved by Mr. Jackson's plight were members of the House of Representatives, who voted to declare him the winner and award him the millions. It looked as if the State Senate would do the same, until Senator Alvin Penn said no.
Mr. Penn, known as a tireless and tenacious fighter for minority groups and the urban poor he represented in Bridgeport, wanted to go along with the House. But as chairman of the public safety committee, which oversees the lottery, Mr. Penn concluded that he could not bend the rules. He blocked a Senate vote, thereby depriving Mr. Jackson of the money.
"Don't they know I'd love to give this kid a check? I'd love to help the brother out," Senator Penn told his press secretary, Dan Tapper. "But it's not mine to give. My job is to make tough decisions. I'm sorry but that's my job." 
Mr. Penn also considered it his job to end racial profiling by police after his car was stopped by the police in Trumbull for no reason. Three years after the episode, both houses passed a law that prohibitspolice officers from pulling over minority drivers who are not breaking any law. He also introduced legislation strengthening the state's witness protection program after an 8-year-old Bridgeport boy and his mother were shot and killed to keep them from testifying at a murder trial.
Mr. Penn was first elected to the Senate in 1983. From the start, he was seen as a relentless, even stubborn champion of his city's poor but he was not always successful in his quest for jobs and other opportunities for his constituents. In 1995, he tried to get the General Assembly to allow the construction of a casino in Bridgeport. He saw a casino as an economic cure for many of the city's problems but suburban residents objected to the traffic a casino would bring to the already clogged Interstate 95. The casino bill was defeated.
Mr. Penn was being treated for pancreatic cancer when he was elected to his sixth term in 2002. He died Feb. 14 at age 54.

Judging With Wit and Intellect
After learning that he had bone marrow cancer six years ago at age 75, David Shea, a retired state Supreme Court Justice, took his wife, Rosemary, through the Canadian Rockies hiking by helicopter.
Maura Shea Crowley, his daughter, recalled how concerned the family was as her parents crossed ravines on swaying rope bridges and hiked for hours at an altitude of 14,000 feet but the vacation was a success.
Mr. Shea was on the state Supreme Court for 11 years, stepping down upon reaching the mandatory retirement age of 70 in 1992, but continuing to sit as a trial court referee until last December.
Judge Shea wrote that the majority opinion in a celebrated case involving a conflict between property rights and free speech when he and a court majority determined the Westfarms shopping mall in West Hartford was not the 20th-century equivalent of a town green.
The opinion denied the National Organization for Women the right to circulate petitions in the mall, saying the state constitution protected the free speech rights of individuals against government interference but the property rights of the shopping mall owners could not be denied by the petitioners.
Mr. Shea died July 22. He was 81. 

Banker and Negotiator
In January 1981, Alexander Vagliano and 11 other American bankers negotiated the release of frozen Iranian assets in American banks in exchange for the 53 hostages taken by a mob from the United States embassy. One of the freed hostages was Mr. Vagliano's cousin, Moorehead Kennedy, an economics and development officer at the embassy.
A native of Paris, Mr. Vagliano came to the United States in 1940 at age 13 and became a citizen five years later after serving in the United States Army. He was a graduate of Harvard College and a cum laude graduate of Harvard Law School. 
During the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, Mr. Vagliano was director of the Office of Capital Development and Finance for the Near East and South Asia in the Agency for International Development. He also had a long career as a banker with J.P. Morgan and Company.
Shortly after Mr. Vagliano helped negotiate the release of the hostages in 1981, he ended his career with J.P. Morgan and became a sheep farmer in Norfolk. 
He continued to pursue the interests he had developed in banking and government as a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, a founding trustee of the French-American Foundation, a trustee of the Institute for French Studies at New York University, a governor of the Atlantic Institute for International Affairs and a trustee of the Council for Excellence in Government.
Mr. Vagliano died Nov. 13. He was 76.

Judging Through the Ranks
Judge Joseph Dannehy began his judicial career as a police court judge in Willimantic in 1949 when Connecticut cities and towns had their own courts to deal with traffic violations and other minor crimes. He retired as a justice of the state Supreme Court nearly 40 years later.
According to The Hartford Courant, he is believed to have been the only judge to serve on all five levels of the state's court system, including two that no longer exist: the town courts and the circuit courts that replaced them. 
"No judge revered the law more than Judge Dannehy," said Austin McGuigan, a former Chief State's Attorney. "And no judge was more demanding of excellence in the pursuit of justice."
Mr. McGuigan worked with Judge Dannehy on a one-person grand jury investigation of a botched police investigation of a hit and run death in New London in the 1970's.
On Christmas Eve 1973, a New London teenager named Kevin Showalter was struck and killed by a hit and run driver and Judge Dannehy's investigation ultimately concluded that "more probably than not" the hit-and-run driver was Harvey Mallove, a prominent New London jeweler and a former mayor. The judge's investigation, the longest and most expensive in Connecticut history up to that time, was criticized by Mr. Mallove's supporters for naming the former mayor on evidence that was probable but not conclusive. 
Judge Dannehy defended his findings, but said that Mr. Mallove could not be prosecuted because the police had lost or destroyed important evidence.
Judge Dannehy wrote in the grand jury report, "After Dec. 25, the New London Police Department did nothing to solve the hit and run death of Kevin B. Showalter."
Judge Dannehy was a lifelong resident of Willimantic, and after attending Boston College and Cornell University Law School, he returned to his home where he practiced law and served as a police court prosecutor, a Willimantic city attorney and the Windham town attorney before becoming a town court judge. He was one of the first judges appointed to the Circuit Court after it was established in 1961 and moved on to Superior Court and the Court of Appeals before becoming a Supreme Court justice.
Judge Dannehy died Dec. 17. He was 86.

Charting High School Sports
Bohdan Kolinsky started writing about high school sports for The Wethersfield Post when he was in high school and he never stopped. He was covering the state high school football playoffs days before his death two weeks ago.
Bo Kolinsky was eight months out of Wethersfield High School when he got a job in The Hartford Courant sports department in 1973. He was named the director of high school sports coverage four years later and probably saw more high school games than anyone in the state in his 30 years at the paper. As the assistant sports editor for high school sports, he was responsible for covering more than 100 sports programs.
"High school athletics will miss him greatly," said Charlie Sharos, a retired basketball and soccer coach from South Windsor. "He was an advocate for high school sports events and wanted high school athletes and teams to get their due in the paper." 
Mr. Kolinsky was a past president of the Connecticut Sports Writers Alliance and in 1989 he received the organization's Art McGinley Award for meritorious service to Connecticut sports. He was then 35 and the award's youngest recipient. 
Mr. Kolinsky died of a heart attack Dec. 14. He was 49.

 INTERNATIONAL 3-18

Death Toll Rises in Iran; Bodies Line the Streets
The death toll from Friday's earthquake in the Iranian city of Bam rose to 25,000, and the final toll could approach 40,000, according to the local governor, with estimates that 70 percent of the ancient city was destroyed. Many thousands more people were injured. Field hospitals were overwhelmed, and many of the injured and dead lined the streets. Volunteer and professional rescue workers began arriving. 1

Coordinated Attacks in Iraq
Insurgents staged three attacks, hitting military bases and the mayor's office in Karbala, part of the south that has been largely quiet. At least 13 people where killed, including four soldiers of the occupying forces. 1

Public opinion surveys of Americans show nearly 70 percent of those polled calling for greater United Nations activity in Iraq. But the United Nations is resisting. 16

Squatters in Baghdad occupy what they consider permanent homes, but American military officials say that the Iraqi transitional government will almost certainly want the buildings back for their own use, or at least will want to charge rent. 14

Brazil to Produce Uranium
Brazil expects to begin producing enriched uranium for exportation. But officials are balking at giving international inspectors unimpeded access to the plant that will produce the nuclear fuel. 4

Chinese Work to Seal Off Gas
Emergency crews poured sealant down a ruptured gas well to smother the toxic fumes that killed at least 198 people and forced 41,000 to flee. 11

Possible Chinese SARS Case
The Chinese government intensified health screenings of travelers and hospital patients after acknowledging the first suspected SARS case in mainland China since the disease caused panic early in the year. The patient remains in quarantine. 7

NATIONAL 20-26

Infected Cow's Origin May Have Been Canada
The Agriculture Department announced that a cow found to be infected with mad cow disease may have been imported from Canada. The infected animal, said Dr. Ron DeHaven, chief veterinarian for the Department of Agriculture, entered the country through Eastport, Idaho, before being transported to Washington State in October 2001. 1

Critics are assailing the beef industry and federal regulators for not taking greater precautions since mad cow disease exploded overseas in the mid-1980's. 25

That Spam? It's From Congress
Members of Congress are sending out hundreds of thousands of unsolicited messages to constituents although they unanimously approved a law aimed at reducing the flow of junk e-mail. The effort is aimed at attracting subscribers to the lawmakers' e-mail lists. 1

Anthrax Concerns Heightened
Administration officials say they have fresh concerns about the nation's vulnerability to attacks with anthrax. 20

Policy Aims to Shield Medicare
The Bush administration is proposing a new policy that would punish hospitals, drugstores and other health care providers that charge Medicare or Medicaid substantially more than their usual charges to private insurers. 24

Violence Surges in Puerto Rico
More than 750 people were killed this year in Puerto Rico, more murders per capita than in any state, according to the F.B.I. Now there is a growing call for change in law enforcement. 20

Mudslide Victims Recovered
Search-and-rescue teams found the bodies of two more people caught by a mudslide that struck a church camp in the San Bernardino Mountains, officials said. Seven bodies have been recovered, and seven people remain missing. 20

The ban on smoking enacted early this year is having an impact on some businesses, but not on all, according to an examination of government data, public polls, private surveys and interviews. 1

HEADLINE: Faster and More Furious, With Cash Back 

BYLINE:  By JAMES G. COBB

 BODY:
WHAT kind of year was 2003, automotively speaking?
 It was the year of the deal, with car sales propped up in a queasy economy by no-interest loans, no-money-down deals and generous rebates. 
 It was the year of the truck. Through November, light trucks -- including pickups, S.U.V.'s and minivans -- were handily outselling passenger cars once again. And consider this: last month, Porsche, a company built on fast sports cars, sold more trucks than automobiles. 
 It was the year of Toyota, which passed Ford in worldwide sales for six months this year to become, at least temporarily, the world's No. 2 automaker. 
 It was a year of horsepower, with several new cars -- including the Porsche Carrera GT and Mercedes-Benz SLR McLaren -- offering 600-plus, and Volkswagen's Bugatti subsidiary claiming 987 for its ultraexclusive Veyron. (You may recall that just two years ago, the BMW M5 seemed outlandishly overpowered with just 400.) 
 It was the year of the Hummer, whose H2 had quasi-military street swagger as war sabers were being rattled. What's more, the celebrity most associated with all things Hummer moved into the governor's office in California, the state that has done the most to regulate, downscale and electrify the auto industry.
 It was a year of cars and sex. Buick moved to rename its new LaCrosse in Canada, after learning that the word is slang in Quebec for a sex act. Dodge generated controversy with a commercial for its enlarged Durango that featured men standing at urinals making double entendres about the size of an unidentified object. And, under pressure, Dodge backed off from its plan to sponsor the Lingerie Bowl, a cable TV event that was originally promoted as a football game between teams of female models in underwear.
 It was also, of course, a year of cars and trucks -- good, bad and sometimes ugly. Here are a dozen of the better efforts, in the admittedly subjective view of this writer:

AUDI A8L: Imagine this "Gremlins" sequel: electronic poltergeists inhabit the complex electronic systems of European luxury cars, tormenting owners with system failures and plaguing service managers with elusive bugs. This year, Audi offered a remedy with its MMI user interface, which restores a bit of intuitiveness to these overachiever dashboards. While there is no guarantee that the big Audi won't have troubles, too, at least the interface is easier to use. And beyond that, this $70,000 aluminum sedan is smooth and spacious.

CADILLAC SRX: Of all the auto divisions in Detroit, only Cadillac seems to have figured out what it stands for - quite a turnaround for a brand that until recently seemed ready for the old folks' home. The SRX sport wagon is a lively alternative to high-end imports. Yes, the price is steep, at $39,000 to nearly $60,000, but the SRX is, on balance, a credible first effort in an arena where G.M. had never dared to compete.

CADILLAC XLR: Bold, brash and unabashedly American, this Corvette-based luxury roadster is also fast, stylish and thoroughly original. FORD F-150: These are dire financial times for Ford, whose very survival may depend on the success of its new bread-and-butter pickup, which is also the nation's best-selling vehicle. Mission accomplished: the rock-solid 2004 F-150 melds big-city polish with Big Sky toughness to reclaim first place among full-size trucks.

FORD FOCUS PZEV: The Focus's initial promise was undone by quality and mechanical glitches. With those problems presumably behind it, the Focus family is again one of Ford's bright lights; the high-performance Focus SVT is one of the best cars ever to wear the blue oval. This year, Ford earned some green stripes by offering partial-zero-emission versions of the Focus nationwide, proof that environmentally friendlier cars can also be peppy and economical, at a cost barely higher than much more polluting versions.

INFINITI FX35/FX45: Suppose the Porsche Cayenne Turbo cost half as much and looked twice as good? It would be more like this pair of crossover speedwagons, which got a double dose of sport (sports car plus S.U.V.) at the expense of utility (the sleek roofline compromises cargo capacity). Yes, the ride can be harsh on those huge wheels, and the people who designed the unintuitive controls should be sent home in an Acura. But the FX's are highly entertaining, both to drive and to look at.

LEXUS RX330: While other sport utilities tried to outdo one another with menacing grilles and contrived body cladding, Lexus got in touch with its feminine side. The second-generation RX is plush and polished, with carlike manners, a silky ride and a high-heeled view of the road. While the RX is not exactly my cup of mocha frappucino, it seems to be just what what many suburbanites, especially women, are looking for.

MAZDA RX-8: After a period of austerity, Mazda is again turning out some of the best-driving cars around. For the reborn RX, it revamped the small but powerful rotary engine that it shares with no other company, matched to a crisp six-speed gearbox. Small rear doors and a usable back seat make this a slick sports car for the entire family.

NISSAN TITAN: This mammoth, in-your-face truck is Japan's first truly serious challenge to the Big Three's last remaining stronghold: the huge market for full-size pickups. With a powerful engine of modern design, Incredible Hulk nonstyling and ingenious touches (like adjustable cargo latches and a lockable outside storage drawer), the Titan demands respect. The truck isn't subtle, but it's too impressive to ignore.

RANGE ROVER: One of the best things under the Ford Motor umbrella is this British adoptee fathered by Germans. The latest Range Rover, developed in the brief period when BMW owned Land Rover, is an aristocratic redefinition of the definitive S.U.V. In a luxury utility segment full of pretenders, this is the real thing.

TOYOTA PRIUS: Some see this second-generation gas-electric hybrid as a paradigm of fuel efficiency. Others (especially the competition) see it as an overhyped pretender with complicated mechanical systems, unproven reliability and real-world mileage that falls far short of official estimates. The truth, no doubt, lies in between. The Prius's driving dynamics are inferior to other Toyotas' and its mileage isn't a lot better than that of some efficient gas-only cars. But the Prius is cleverly designed and shrewdly marketed, and it has Americans lining up to vote for the sorts of green vehicles that Detroit keeps promising but never delivers.

TOYOTA SIENNA: This cleverly redesigned minivan jumps over the Honda Odyssey for best-van honors, and along with the new, more stylish Nissan Quest, it may give a lift to this 20-year-old segment. One other thing: the Sienna makes a dandy New York City taxicab.

Other Cars of the Year
 Here are some reflections on other vehicles from the 2003 test fleet:

ACURA TSX: A plush version of the shorter foreign-market Honda Accord, the bland TSX does everything well. Sowell, in fact, that it's hard to remember having driven it.

BMW 530i: The old 5 Series was perhaps the best all-round sedan in the world, and the new version is every bit as exciting to drive. But like the 7 Series and the Z4 roadster, the new 5, with its electronic gadgets and flame-broiled styling, seems colder, more distant and less endearing.

BMW X3: The 325xi wagon, a terrific all-wheel-drive car, weighs 3,594 pounds. The new X3 sport utility is over 4,000, with a higher center of gravity. Is it any wonder that the X3 is slower, harsher and less pleasant?

CHEVROLET MALIBU: The good news is that G.M. seems to have finally made a serious commitment to the midsize family sedan, and the '04 Malibu is a big leap over its Hertz-special predecessor. But Chevy continues to aim too low with its yawn-inducing styling.

CHEVROLET SSR: I fell headlamps over tailgate in love with the original concept version of this roadster pickup, but the production version arrived at a porky 4,760 pounds and a hefty $42,000 -- a heavyweight date.

CHRYSLER CROSSFIRE: Aside from making use of available Mercedes components, what was the point of this ultraclaustrophobic, none-too-fun $35,000 coupe?

CHRYSLER PACIFICA: Overhyped and overpriced when introduced, this big wagon was supposed to be the next big thing. It isn't yet.

GMC ENVOY XUV: The retracting cargo roof is handy if you have a pet giraffe. With the test truck carrying a sticker of $45,390, I'd make him walk.

HONDA ELEMENT: If this box on wheels was supposed to appeal to young people, why do you mostly see old people driving them?

JAGUAR S-TYPE R: I find the S-Type more lovely as time goes by, and the high-performance R version is dressed in subtle but striking jewelry. Too bad the illusion vanishes when you start to drive and realize that this disconnected-feeling car is no competition to its poised rivals from BMW and Mercedes.

JAGUAR XJR: The new aluminum body is a crowd-pleaser, and the supercharged V-8 has jet-engine thrust. Still, I wish Jaguar had done a redesign that was a little less retro and a little more forward-looking.

LINCOLN AVIATOR: My test version of this overstuffed Explorer, with a sticker of $48,370, is a strong contender for the title of most overpriced test vehicle of 2003.

MITSUBISHI LANCER EVOLUTION: Driving this ferociously fun rally car was, along with time in the competitive Subaru WRX STi, one of the highlights of the year.

NISSAN MAXIMA: Nissan's respected flagship sedan found itself in an uncomfortable position, squeezed between a bigger, better Altima and its fancy Infiniti cousins. In trying to move upscale, the new Maxima comes off as just another, somewhat odd contender in the supercompetitive market for $30,000 sedans.

NISSAN PATHFINDER ARMADA: Since S.U.V.'s are now nearly as big as houses, why not make them look like three-bedroom Colonials? The side windows of this Brobdingnagian S.U.V. form a peak, inviting calls from aluminum-siding salesmen.

PONTIAC GRAND PRIX: Despite a mild redesign, this unrefined old-tech car feels two decades behind the times, with one of the poorest interiors I've seen in years.

PORSCHE CAYENNE TURBO: It is homely, it can cost nearly $100,000 and it requires a change of tires to go off road. It is closely related to the Volkswagen Touareg , which does nearly everything just as well for half the price. Coming soon: a V-6 version for the people who always lusted for a slow Porsche.

SAAB 9-3: Those who fear for Saab's future as part of G.M. have reason to fret. There will soon be Saab-arus and thinly disguised GMC S.U.V.'s in the lineup. The nice-driving 9-3 sedan preserves a bit of Saab appeal, but I spent my time in the car wondering where they got the flimsy, fragile plastic controls.

SATURN ION: A key difference between the "old" G.M. and the new one: nowadays, when the company rushes cars to market that aren't ready for prime time, it comes back to clean up its mistakes. Both the sad-sack Saturn Vue and Ion have received engineers' attention, and at least the new version of the Vue, with a Honda engine, is much improved.

SCION xB: What can you say, really, about a tiny youth-oriented box with a killer stereo that lets you choose interior lighting from a menu that includes "tangerine" and "amethyst"?

VOLKSWAGEN TOUAREG: The Touareg is a good, handsome and rather expensive S.U.V. that, like many others, is too bulky for its own good.

VOLVO XC90: The antirollover system is an innovation, but there is little else about this pricey S.U.V. that rises above the competition.

SECTION: Section 10; Column 1; Job Market; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 724 words

HEADLINE: Home Front; 
Tenant Advocacy Group Faces Eviction

BYLINE:  By Colin Moynihan; This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Fifteen years ago, when a nonprofit tenants advocacy group called Good Old Lower East Side set up shop in a storefront at 525 East Sixth Street, between Avenues A and B, the area was filled with rubble-strewn lots and derelict tenements. Arson was common, and sidewalk drug bazaars operated around the clock. 
 Today, however, as restaurants and boutiques have opened and as rents have risen to record levels, the landscape of the East Village has changed dramatically. And for a group called Good Old Lower East Side, which has existed since 1977 and is known locally as Goles, that transformation is turning out to be a big problem. The lease on the storefront expires at year's end, and the building's management agency has told the advocates that the $1,200 monthly rent for the storefront will at least double in the new year. Now the group that has sought to defend tenants from eviction for 26 years may itself be sent packing by a landlord. 
 The neighborhood may be gentrified, but that doesn't mean there is no longer a constituency for Goles, said Margaret Hughes, the group's executive director. "There are still people who need our help," Ms. Hughes said on a recent afternoon. "They aren't as visible as they used to be, but they're still here."
 Howard Cohen, the president of 14K Management, which began running the low-income co-op building at the end of 2001, said the increase was necessary. The co-op, he said, has only eight apartments and depends on income from the storefront to pay bills. "The building is not wealthy," he said. "They need a fair rental from the storefront."
 Ms. Hughes spoke about the group's history of organizing rent strikes, working with the police and residents to limit drug dealing, and helping persuade landlords to retain tenants who receive public assistance. But she also spoke about what had drawn her to the arduous and sometimes thankless role of tenant advocate.
 One of her earliest memories, she said, is of bathing in front of a coal-burning stove in Belfast, where her family moved from Brooklyn after her birth 40 years ago. She remembers marching in funeral processions that often turned into angry political demonstrations, Ms. Hughes said, and watching her father, a freelance television cameraman, film confrontations between mourners and riot police.
 "I grew up with a sense that everyone should have a voice," Ms. Hughes said. "And the best way to get justice was to be in the street, be visible and use that voice."
 In 1972, when Ms. Hughes was 9, her family moved back to New York City, and as she grew up she was convinced that she wanted to pursue work assisting the needy. She earned a bachelor's degree in literature from Fordham University and a master's degree in social work from Columbia. Along the way, she said, she counseled teenagers in a group home in Fresno, Calif., and taught high school in Kenya. But she also organized tenants in Manhattan and Brooklyn before joining Goles in 1998.
 At times, Ms. Hughes said, work in the nonprofit world has been wearing. "There are so many times you think that a battle simply can't be won." she said. Still, she could not help beaming as she described how in 1987, she and others lobbied successfully to prevent the razing of seven Upper East Side tenements that had cracks in their facades caused by construction work next door. She said she still remembered her sense of elation on learning that the buildings would remain standing.
 "When you win there's a feeling that people can overcome the system," she said. 
 GOLES staff members are still hoping for such an experience at 525 East Sixth Street. Ms. Hughes said she was talking to residents and to members of the co-op board about the possibility of staying. At the same time, she said, she was looking into new spaces. Goles has a thrift shop with four employees at the corner of Avenue B and East Third Street and a two-person office at Avenue B and East 10th Street for which they are given a break in the rent. But neither, she said, could accommodate the entire paid staff of 13. She added that the group, which is financed by grants and donations, was determined to somehow stay on the Lower East Side.
 "We will remain in this community and we will continue our services," Ms. Hughes said. "The trick will be figuring out how to do that and also pay the rent."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Margaret Hughes, left, director of Good Old Lower East Side, with Maizie Torres and Damaris Reyes and a client, Madlynn Bologna at the group's storefront. (Photo by Lucian Read for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 3; THEATER: THE HIGHS

LENGTH: 884 words

HEADLINE: The Plays And Players Of the Year

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:

BRUCE WEBER

1. THE CLASSICAL THEATER OF HARLEM Three adventurous productions this year put it on the map as a company to follow and relish. The standout was a raucous, audience-challenging revival of ''The Blacks,'' Jean Genets surreal take on race.

2. JEFFERSON MAYS The star of ''I Am My Own Wife,'' heretofore unknown, gave the tour-de-force performance of the year, a testament to an actors commitment to a role and a play.

3. 'THE BEARD OF AVON' Amy Freed's smart and witty treatment of the Shakespeare author-ship question was presented all over the country, before a fun-loving production directed by Doug Hughes opened at New York Theater Workshop. Another reminder that New York is not necessarily on the leading edge of American theater.

4. 'THE MOONLIGHT ROOM' This first play by Tristine Skyler is a rarity from a young writer in this age of shocking subject matter and episodic, film-fluenced scripts: it's a realistic drama with both intelligence and a crowd-pleasing heart. The subject, teenagers and their single parents, is neither sensational nor frivolous. A careful production by the Worth Street Theater Company (directed by Jeff Cohen) announced a promising talent.

5. FLOW In this flawed but fascinating one-man show about neighborhood storytellers in the Bronx (presented at the New York City Hip-Hop Theater Festival and later at New York Theater Workshop), Will Power gave a tantalizing glimpse of how hip-hop culture is likely to influence theater art and vice versa.

6. THE DAUGHTER-IN-LAW The Mint Theater Company, which is devoted to unearthing forgotten but worthy works, has had an uneven track record, but its production of this powerful early drama by D. H. Lawrence was proof that theater history is worth excavating.

7. 'HUMBLE BOY' Not Charlotte Jones's over-wrought homage to ''Hamlet,'' but Tim Hatley's magnificent set for it. Mr. Hatley created a wild garden, complete with long grasses, hillocks, wildflowers and pathways, that turned the underground stage at the Manhattan Theater Club into a thrilling terrarium, a reminder that in any production, any of the myriad collaborators may leave a brilliant mark.

8. JULIE WHITE In two irresistibly charming performances as a harried wife in Daniel Stern's wispy comedy ''Barbras Wedding,'' and as a harried single woman in Theresa Rebeck's one-woman show ''Bad Dates'' - Ms. White earned this year's award for the performer who out-shines her material.

9. RESIDENT THEATERS From the Alley Theater's side-by-side productions of Edward Albee's ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ''The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?'' in Houston, to the Old Globe's ''Julius Caesar'' in San Diego, to the coproduction by the Berkeley Rep and the Oregon Shakespeare Festival of David Edgar's two-play political opus, ''Continental Divide,'' to Arena Stage's compact ''South Pacific'' in Washington, D.C., the notable productions of the year stretched from coast to coast. A collective nod to the nonprofit theaters around the country that make quality theater virtually impossible to escape.

BEN BRANTLEY

1. VANESSA REDGRAVE, 'LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT' As the morphine-addicted mother in Eugene O'Neill's masterpiece, she went way out on a limb and took us all with her.

2. DONNA MURPHY, 'WONDERFUL TOWN' Absolute blissful perfection.

3. KEVIN KLINE, 'HENRY IV' With his fine-grained portrait of Falstaff in the superb Lincoln Center Theater revival, he found far more than ham in Shakespeare's porcine hedonist.

4. BERNADETTE PETERS, 'GYPSY' Redefining both a classic character (Mama Rose) and her own adorable image, she gave the gutsiest musical performance of the year.

5. TONYA PINKINS, 'CAROLINE, OR CHANGE' As a Southern maid in 1963 in this musical economics lesson from Tony Kushner and Jeanine Tesori, she finds a dazzling ferocity in self-repression.

6. EDDIE IZZARD, 'A DAY IN THE DEATH OF JOE EGG' The year's No. 1 crossover performance by a cross-dresser. Mr. Izzard, who wore fishnet stockings for ''Sexie,'' his scintillating one-man show, proved himself equally at home in trousers as the attention-hungry schoolteacher in the revival of Peter Nichols's wrenching drama.

7. NED BEATTY, 'CAT ON A HOT TIN ROOF' Let others debate his offstage etiquette. As Tennessee Williams's Big Daddy, he is a life-affirming expert in bad manners.

8. KRISTIN CHENOWETH, WICKED Her skill, sparkle and high-sheen soprano gave depth and contours to the years most superficial heroine, Glinda the Good Witch.

9. HUGH JACKMAN, 'THE BOY FROM OZ' As the singer Peter Allen in this bathetic bio-musical, he drew blood from papier-mch and confirmed his status as a serious musical star.

10. DENIS O'HARE, 'TAKE ME OUT' As an accountant in love with baseball in Richard Greenberg's Tony-winning play, this actor's actor infected even nonsports fans with his character's galloping enthusiasm.

11. AIDAN GILLEN, 'THE CARETAKER' Making his Broadway debut in the smallest role in this lukewarm revival, he demonstrated that silence in Pinterland is worth a thousand spoken threats and snatched the show from his more famous co-stars (Patrick Stewart, Kyle MacLachlan).

12. MELANIE GRIFFITH, 'CHICAGO' Taking over the role of the narcissistic Roxie Hart, she proved you don't have to be able to sing or dance to dominate a musical. Let's just hope this isn't a trend.
