HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED; 
Crossing Class Lines

BYLINE:  By Diane McWhorter; Diane McWhorter is the author of "Carry Me Home."

 BODY:
 Ivan Allen Jr. b. 1911, Maynard H. Jackson Jr. b. 1938
The South can be a magical place, conjuring gracious illusions out of jagged reality. No Southern city has been better at performing sleights of image than Atlanta. The metropolis that finessed "Gone With the Wind" from slavery has also owned the modern South's most beguiling myth: the triumphal transition from segregation to integration. Only days apart last summer came the deaths of two protagonists of that redemption story. Ivan Allen Jr., who died at 92 on July 2, was the white savior, the noble aristocrat who steered the segregationists into the light as Atlanta's mayor during the darkest 1960's. Maynard H. Jackson Jr., who died nine days earlier at 65, was the black messiah, the great-grandson of slaves who fulfilled Allen's vision by becoming, in 1974, the urban South's first African-American mayor. (Incredibly, the nemesis in this drama, Lester Maddox, died at 87 two days after Jackson. The classic "cracker" demagogue, Maddox won the Georgia governor's office in 1967 after doing little more than waving a pistol at blacks hoping to eat at his famed Atlanta restaurant, the Pickrick. )
 Beneath these romantic archetypes of the civil rights era is an unsentimental story of class and money that is in its way no less heroic. Historically, the South's power elite encouraged racial friction between poor whites and blacks so that those have-nots wouldn't gang up on them. Atlanta's genius was to invert the race-baiting ruses that had safeguarded the Southern economy and pioneer a new gimmick of civic boosterism: racial harmony. Allen and Jackson were very much vehicles of the Chamber of Commerce's mission. But it was the thrilling ways in which they transcended their own bourgeois backgrounds that accounted for their success and exposed the shaded contradictions of class underneath the black-and-white surface. 
Allen's story -- that of the reconstructed white Southerner -- is a reconciliation narrative dear to the new New South creed of prosperity. A second-generation office-supply magnate, Allen broke with his Piedmont Driving Club peerage and stooped to politics. In 1961, he ran for mayor on a Realpolitik platform of racial moderation, beating Maddox to succeed the legendary William Hartsfield, who had put the money in harmony by fashioning Atlanta as "the City Too Busy to Hate." Beginning with his elocutionary switch from "nigra" to "knee-grow," Allen promoted integration just enough to enforce business climate mandated by home office of Coca-Cola. 
Atlanta's most famous son, Martin Luther King Jr., had to go across the state line to Birmingham to make his mark fighting segregation. After King's school-age marchers faced off against that city's fire hoses in 1963, President John F. Kennedy asked Allen to appear at hearings on his civil rights bill to abolish legalized racism. Withstanding a tongue-lashing from the segregationist -- at least publicly -- Senator Strom Thurmond (who died a week before Allen), the mayor of Atlanta became the first white elected official in the Deep South to testify against segregation, calling it "the stepchild of slavery." That trip to Washington clinched Allen's conversion from an opportunistic integrationist to a sincere one.
At the Piedmont Driving Club, no less, Allen hectored Atlanta's nabobs into bankrolling a biracial dinner to celebrate King's Nobel Peace Prize in 1964 and predicted witheringly that they would be "out of town or sick" on the appointed night. "Don't let it worry you, though," he told them. "The mayor will be there." By the time Allen escorted Coretta Scott King to the Atlanta airport to catch a plane to Memphis on the evening of April 4, 1968, it was the clear that beneath the gray silk suit beat a desegregated heart.
A few days later -- in a scene recounted in Gary Pomerantz's marvelous epic of Atlanta, "Where Peachtree Meets Sweet Auburn" -- Mayor Allen watched out of a window at city hall as Gov. Lester Maddox stood in front of the Capitol trying to hoist up the flag flying at half-staff in deference to the slain King. Allen then joined the marchers behind King's mule-drawn coffin. Among the mourners was another prince of Atlanta royalty, Maynard Jackson Jr.
Jackson was the fussed-over son of a prominent Baptist minister and a teacher with a Ph.D. in French from the University of Toulouse. His maternal grandfather was John Wesley Dobbs, a postal worker whose position as the grand master of Georgia's Negro Masons made him, prophetically, the city's unofficial "black mayor." Though grandiose with destiny (and with sheer heft as well), Jackson was a renegade, professing a contempt for "the vapid, jejune trappings of American middle-classness" somewhat undercut by his alligator boots. When Jackson ran for mayor in 1973, he was considered too pushy by Atlanta's go-along-get-along black leaders, who had also discouraged King from upsetting the racial status quo. 
The 35-year-old lawyer prevailed to become the self-advertised "youngest, fattest, blackest mayor in America." Jackson aggressively challenged white financial privilege, redistributing the wealth through that shrine to Atlanta's New South supremacy, the Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. The muscular affirmative action program he enacted to award contracts for the facility's $400 million expansion became a model nationwide. In 1982, the Peachtree mandarins failed to extend the departing mayor a partnership in one of the silk-stocking law offices. Jackson bided his time with a Chicago firm and reclaimed City Hall in 1990. Then he pushed Dixie's city on a hill to its highest mountaintop yet. Atlanta was selected the host of the 1996 Olympics.
Even from such heights, the New South is forever drawn back to old battles. When Lester Maddox died in June, Georgia's governor, Sonny Perdue -- elected on a pledge to rehabilitate the Confederate flag -- kept official flags lowered for three days. A racial skirmish ensued over the slighting of Jackson with only one half-staff day, and a black campaign to rename the airport after Jackson met white resistance. In the true Atlanta spirit, harmony was restored through the compromise "Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport," yet another nifty civic trick of integration and redemption.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
A Year's Debacles, From Comic to Epic

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
AFTER three stormy years, the sun finally came out on Wall Street this year. But while investors savored rising stock prices, scandal continued to cast a long shadow over corporate America.
 Reports of corporate chicanery have come all too regularly since the discovery of arcane and esoteric accounting schemes at Enron more than two years ago. But this year, the misdeeds went distressingly mainstream, with revelations that some mutual fund managers were not satisfied with their enormous advisory fees and chose to pick their investors' pockets -- a breathtaking betrayal. 
 The top dramas of the year were mostly depressing, but occasional comic relief came from L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chairman of Tyco International, whose trial began in September on charges that he had looted the company. A highlight was the videotape of the birthday party that Mr. Kozlowski had in Sardinia for his wife; the event proved that no matter the price tag, tacky is tacky. 
 But Mr. Kozlowski was not the only star of 2003. Others who played prize-winning roles during the year should not be forgotten.
 And so it is time, again, to grant the Augustus Melmotte Memorial Prizes, named for the schemer at the heart of Anthony Trollope's brilliant Victorian novel, "The Way We Live Now." Mr. Melmotte, a financier who reached the heights of London society by standing on his wallet, crashed when he was discovered to be a swindler. 
 Following are this year's prizes and their winners:

THE DIOGENES AWARD -- To Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, who searches high and low for an honest man in the financial world, but finds so many of the other persuasion. Last year, he prosecuted Wall Street for duplicitous research; this year, he identified a mountain of mutual fund malfeasance. Detractors like to say that Mr. Spitzer is hunting down financial scoundrels only because the headlines will help him become governor of New York. But that begs a question: If this man can come up with blockbuster cases while he is holding down one big job and running for another, what are the other regulators' excuses for inaction?

THE PRIDE GOETH BEFORE A FALL AWARD -- To Matthew P. Fink, president of the Investment Company Institute, and Paul G. Haaga Jr., its chairman, who throughout the bear market had been congratulating the mutual fund industry they represent for being free of the scandals that tainted Wall Street. Of course, neither man has been implicated in the fund debacle. But just three months before the fund scandal erupted, Mr. Haaga said in a speech to the group's members: "Trust is the reason why our relationship with investors has not been broken by the bear market of the past three years. Our shareholders trust that their mutual funds are being managed with their best interests in mind." Whoops!

THE WHY DIDN'T I THINK OF THAT? AWARD -- To Ralph Nader, for calling on the Federal Bureau of Investigation to include corporate crime statistics in its annual crime report.
 "Because the F.B.I. does not collect data on corporate crime," Mr. Nader wrote in a letter to John Ashcroft, the attorney general, last November, "both the American public and the law enforcement community lack good information on what has become a pressing national problem -- a corporate crime wave." Mr. Nader is right. Investors need a scorecard.

THE MEA CULPA IS ME AWARD -- To Philip J. Purcell, chief executive of Morgan Stanley, who had to apologize twice last year for his own or his firm's actions.
 The first apology came on May Day, when Mr. Purcell advised William H. Donaldson, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that he had deep regret for public comments he made that played down Morgan Stanley's conduct in the Wall Street research scandal. The second was in November, as the firm settled a regulatory case in which its brokers had been promoting certain mutual funds over others to generate higher commissions but had failed to advise their clients of the extra fees. In a statement, Mr. Purcell said, "I regret that some of our sales and disclosure practices have been found inadequate." 
 Taking some pain out of his contrition was a handsome bit of remuneration Mr. Purcell received at the end of November. The firm awarded him restricted stock valued at $4.1 million, or 35 percent more than the restricted stock he received last year.

THE WILL THEY EVER GET IT? AWARD -- To Mr. Purcell's Morgan Stanley, which was fined $10,000 a day by an NASD arbitration panel for refusing to produce documents in a suit filed against it by an investor who bought its mutual funds. Because the arbitration is not yet final, it is unclear how much Morgan Stanley ultimately paid. And $10,000 a day is not even a rounding error to a firm of that size. But congratulations to the NASD panel for standing up to the stonewall.

THE BE CAREFUL WHAT YOU WISH FOR AWARD -- To Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. As its spokesman, Mr. Grasso did a superlative job promoting it as something as American as Mom and apple pie. But when his $140 million in pay came to light, a compensation package he had angled for, Mr. Grasso lost the thing he loved best: his job as casino greeter.

THE THAT'S MY STORY AND I'M STICKING TO IT AWARD -- To Silicon Valley executives who even now refuse to recognize that stock options are an employee cost and should be accounted for as such on company financial statements. New rules from the Financial Accounting Standards Board, requiring options to be deducted from a company's income, will go into effect in 2005, but technology types are still agitating against them.
 John F. Gifford, the chairman of Maxim Integrated Products, a maker of integrated circuits, spoke for the California contingent when he said last April: "The potential damaging long-term effect on our nation's economy and our lifestyle that would result from the forced expensing of stock options should be taken seriously." Who knew that high-tech executives' lifestyles had become a public policy issue?

THE BEST SECOND ACT AWARD -- To Henry Blodget, the former Internet analyst at Merrill Lynch who left Wall Street in 2001 and recently resurfaced as a reporter for Slate, covering the Martha Stewart trial. His debut was a brilliant piece, full of self-deprecation and sympathy for the embattled Ms. Stewart.

MOST TONE-DEAF EXECUTIVE AWARD -- To Donald J. Carty, the former chairman of AMR, parent of American Airlines. Last April, as American was negotiating significant wage and benefit concessions with its employees to keep it out of bankruptcy court, the company disclosed that it had recently given top executives lucrative retention bonuses and set aside $41 million to protect the pensions of 45 executives, including Mr. Carty, if the company filed for bankruptcy. Truly a let-them-eat-cake moment in corporate history.

HEADLINE: Mexico Adrift 

 BODY:
Ten years after entering into a North American Free Trade Agreement, and three years after putting an end to the asphyxiating seven-decade reign of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, Mexico has yet to fully capitalize on these auspicious developments. The government's failure to deliver on high public expectations could unleash a reaction that would jeopardize the country's political and economic modernization.
 President Vicente Fox, at the midpoint of his six-year term, already looks like a lame duck. It would be hard to overstate the personal popularity and moral authority that Mr. Fox had upon assuming office. But he has failed to turn that into a governing mandate. That's partly because his party does not control a majority in the Congress, where the PRI retains the largest voting bloc. 
 Mr. Fox's administration has also suffered from self-inflicted wounds. Its clumsy approach to negotiating with Congress, the constant infighting within his cabinet, and even his wife's political activism have strengthened opponents who argue that there is more to be gained from obstructing Mr. Fox than there is in working with him.
The PRI, suffering from an identity crisis, is split between a faction that wants to work with Mr. Fox and a more traditionalist one. Many PRI lawmakers joined with the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party last weekend to once again deny Mr. Fox a long-overdue package of fiscal reforms. 
Mexico's tax receipts amount to the equivalent of only 12 percent of its gross domestic product -- a dangerously low amount by any standard -- and President Fox had been trying to overhaul the tax code to add to public resources. 
America's economic slowdown and the Bush administration's cold shoulder on immigration reform have added to Mr. Fox's woes. What makes his predicament tragic is that the country is in dire need of what he is peddling. The lack of government spending on education amounts to a costly failure to invest in the nation's human capital at a time when the country's competitiveness is eroding. This year, China is expected to surpass Mexico as the second-largest exporter to the United States. 
Nafta has been a boon for Mexico, though the benefits derived from access to the American market would be far greater if the country invested more in its people, strengthened its public institutions (the courts, for starters) and upgraded its transportation and energy sectors. 
The inefficient state-owned oil and electric industries -- public piggy banks in the absence of sufficient tax revenues -- are in desperate need of private investment, which President Fox would like to allow, but so-called dinosaurs within the PRI and the PRD opposition persist in mustering tired populist rhetoric to preserve the status quo. 
The real danger, if Mr. Fox doesn't find a way soon to break the current impasse, is that the opposition's message from the past will become a road map to the future.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: HOUSING; 
Below Market. River View. Many Rooms. Expected Term of Occupancy: Day-to-Day

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 27 

 BODY:
Below market is not an adequate phrase to describe this deluxe apartment on the east bank of the Tigris River. 
 Outfitted for a senior official in the government of Saddam Hussein, it has a river view with a balcony, floor-to-ceiling windows and a spiral staircase. 
 The rent is exactly zero dinars a month. 
At least that is what Sajeda Hassen Ali and her family pay. They began squatting here in May after the American-led forces ousted Mr. Hussein. The building's former residents, all government officials, had fled for their lives and a free-for-all had ensued for the plush quarters. 
Ms. Ali's son and her nephew stumbled across this place, and everything soon worked out for the impoverished family, or so they thought. The question is whether it will continue. 
Ms. Ali and her husband listen every day for an ominous knock on the door, for someone from the ruling authorities to walk up and tell them that the family has to move out because the government wants the building back. 
"Maybe they will take it and give it to government workers again," she said as she sat on the floor of her living room, patting small meat pastries called koba. She stared down at her 4-day-old daughter in a basket and added: "But I pray to God not to kick us out, not to leave us on the street. We have no place to go." 
Ms. Ali and the 1,800 or so squatters in this corner of Baghdad are living in a purgatory of their own making. Though they occupy what they consider permanent homes along a row of 23 apartment buildings on the Tigris near downtown Baghdad, many are worried that officials from the new government or the military will come knocking at their doors and evict them. 
Their fears seem justified: American military officials say that although they have allowed squatters to remain in public buildings throughout the city, the Iraqi transitional government that will take power on July 1 will almost certainly want the buildings back for their own use, or at least will want to charge rent. 
The population of Baghdad has boomed since the Americans took control in Iraq, with many rural migrants coming to seek jobs, causing a housing shortage, military officials said. 
Because the nationwide jobless rate is about 25 percent, many families cannot afford to pay rent. But what allows the squatters to move in is that most of the real estate in Baghdad was owned by Mr. Hussein's government, rather than by private companies or individuals. The old government is not around to protect the properties, and the new government is not in a position to take action. 
"The Iraqi government and the coalition forces are only establishing control of buildings that we have the ability to control," said Col. Paul L. Aswell, who oversees matters concerning Iraqi public property. "We can't kick out people just because they're not supposed to be there. Where am I going to put thousands of displaced people? You can't just throw them out on the streets." 
But the transitional government will probably try to sell much of the city's public property, since there is no need to hold on to it, Colonel Aswell said. It is likely that officials will assign private management companies those buildings it does not sell, or the officials may use them for work space or employee housing. 
How the transitional government will deal with the problem of squatters becoming homeless families is a daunting challenge. "It's an insurmountable problem," Colonel Aswell said. "There just isn't any place in Baghdad to send hundreds of families." 
No one has done a count, but Colonel Aswell said every inhabitable building that was empty after the invasion probably has squatters in it. The largest centers have well over a thousand people. The 23 buildings on the west bank of the Tigris, constructed with yellow clay bricks, make up one of those areas. 
Collectively called the Abi Nuwas project, named for the riverside street on which the three-story buildings sit, they were built in the 1980's to be one of the most progressive housing works in the country. 
A British company with Iraqi architects designed it for upper-middle-class residents and planned for the buildings to use solar energy, said Ghada Razzouqi al-Siliq, an assistant professor of architecture at Baghdad University. Mr. Hussein eventually rented the apartments for a nominal fee to the top administrators in his government. 
The buildings were looted after April 9, with windows broken and furniture stolen. Squatters rushed in and did what they could to renovate the housing. Professor Siliq said they felt they had a right to be there, to take their share of the country's wealth after being economically deprived for so long. 
Nada Khalif, 28, lives with her family next door to Ms. Ali. "When we moved in here," she said, "we saw how unfair the system was. The people living in this house, they were not educated, they did nothing for the country. They were just Baathists. But we're educated, we have degrees and we can help our country. We deserve to live in this apartment." 
Ms. Khalif was serving sweet tea to a visitor in her family's living room. The family had decorated the room with large potted plants, a plush green rug and Russian nesting dolls arranged on a wooden shelf beneath a TV and a VCR. The homey quality was typical of many of the eight units in this building. 
Soldiers have sprayed numbers on the front wall of every building. Ms. Ali and Ms. Khalif live in No. 31. Graffiti on the outer wall reads, "This building is inhabited," to deter other squatters or looters. At the rear, dozens of children play soccer in a small lot. 
Safi Abbas Khalif, Nada's father, said he had found this building after wandering around Baghdad for more than a week last May looking for a place to live. He had taken to the streets because the landlord of his old house was raising the rent $25, he said, and his only employed son, an army conscript, was killed by the American-led invasion forces. Mr. Khalif said he could not work because he was undergoing a series of operations for a brain illness. 
The original residents of the apartment, Iraqis loyal to Mr. Hussein, returned after three months in hiding, but let the 13 members of Mr. Khalif's family keep the apartment because they sympathized with the family's plight, Mr. Khalif said. 
"We hope the new government will be more merciful than Saddam's regime," Zaineb Khalif, the eldest daughter, said. "We have no place to go if we're kicked out. I have no land, no houses, nothing. I just have God." 
The Khalif family and the rest of the building's squatters are Shiite Muslims, generally much poorer than Sunni Arabs. The Sunnis were favored first by British colonialists in the early 20th century, then by Mr. Hussein, himself a Sunni from the north. Mr. Hussein's government persecuted the Shiites and Kurds, often torturing and killing large groups of them. 
One family with a Sunni father does live in the building and has done so for 12 years. They are from Tikrit, Mr. Hussein's hometown, and fled there during the invasion of Baghdad. They returned in May. 
Just as the American military has no policy for addressing the squatter issue, it also does not have a way of dealing with Baathist officials still living in residences given to them as gifts. Some of those quarters were forcibly taken from owners, who could try to get them back. "It'll be a very difficult property reconciliation process," Colonel Aswell said. 
In this building, most of the squatters shun the family from Tikrit. They warned a reporter not to approach the apartment. The mother of the household, Fatim Khadim, opened the door on the reporter's third try to see the family. 
She invited the visitor in. Over tea, this woman, who cried in despair the day Mr. Hussein was captured, talked about how the squatters had stolen the surrounding apartments. They deserve to be evicted, she said. 
"People betrayed each other," she said. "People didn't stand up for each other. They stole each other's things."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2616 words

HEADLINE: Hard Times In Star Part Of the State Economy 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

 BODY:
MERCK & COMPANY has long been the crown jewel of New Jersey's rich pharmaceutical industry. The company was the first to commercialize penicillin in the 1940's. In 1987, it introduced the breakthrough cholesterol drug Mevacor. A pioneer in H.I.V.-AIDS treatments, the company is workingon a promising vaccine to stop the killer that is ravaging Africa.
 Yet despite its proud past, Merck, the world's third-largest drug company, which has its headquarters in Whitehouse Station, now faces its own ills. 
 Merck's top-selling drug, Zocor, for cholesterol, is about to lose patent protection, which could wipe out a huge chunk of the $5.6 billion in sales that the medicine brings in, about a quarter of the company's total revenue. 
 At the same time, Merck has failed to come up with blockbuster new drugs to replace the revenue from Zocor, and has canceled two drugs for depression and diabetes that were in late-stage development. 
 In addition, the company's stock is in a slump and Merck is laying off 4,400 workers, or 7 percent of its global workforce, to save $250 million to $300 million a year.
 Merck is not the only New Jersey drug maker facing significant erosion to previously healthy sales growth. In addition, drug companies are battling image problems as political debate simmers over the cost of prescription drugs.
 "The pharmaceutical industry is running into more challenges now than at any time in my 30 years in the industry," said Fred Hassan, chief executive of Schering-Plough. 
 Schering-Plough, which is based in Kenilworth, is cutting employment costs by 10 percent through a combination of layoffs and an early-retirement package.
 Another giant in the pharmaceutical industry, Johnson & Johnson, recently laid off nearly 500 employees at a plant in North Brunswick and will shed more jobs by combining administrative work at subsidiaries in New Jersey.
 The retrenchment is all the more difficult because it comes after four years, from 1999 through 2002, when pharmaceutical employment in the state rose 17 percent. In 2003, for the first time in more than a decade, pharmaceutical employment in New Jersey appears to have remained flat at just over 69,000 people, according to the HealthCare Institute of New Jersey, a statewide industry trade group. 
 Besides internal problems like the dearth of new products to replace high-profit blockbusters, the drug industry finds itself in an unhappily prominent spot in political debates. Both members of Congress and candidates for president have seized on the issue of drug costs. 
 "Especially in the last two election cycles it has gotten caught in the cross-fire of politicians as a way to make themselves more visible," Mr. Hassan said. "It's a very negative climate."
 The health of the drug industry is vital to New Jersey, where it is the single largest manufacturing business. About $30 billion in pharmaceuticals were made here in 1997, the most recent census data available, for about a third of the state total of all manufactured goods.
 The industry contributes $22.7 billion to the state economy, including $6.8 billion in salaries, as well as charitable contributions of $45 million. The average salary in the industry was $80,439 in 2002, according to the HealthCare Institute.
 Drug companies based in New Jersey account for more than 40 percent of the industry's total global sales of $400 billion. World headquarters for nine major pharmaceutical companies are in New Jersey, and 11 others have based their North American operations in the state.
 "The decisions that manage the industry throughout the entire world are made here," said William Healey, executive vice president of the HealthCare Institute.

Still, a Lucrative Industry
 To be sure, the pharmaceutical industry is a long way from the critical list. It is among the world's most lucrative businesses, with a profit margin of 18.5 percent, according to FamiliesUSA, a patient advocacy group.
 Growth in sales, however, is slowing. The rate was 7 percent for the 12 months ended in September 2003, compared with 8 percent growth in 2002 and 12 percent in 2001, according to IMS Health, which tracks drug sales.
 In part, that is because patents are expiring on a number of big-selling products. When a drug loses patent protection it becomes open to generic competition, which typically drives the price of a product down by as much as 80 percent.
 "Patent expirations are having a greater impact than in years past because there is a trend to move to generics very quickly and aggressively, which is fueled by the overall managed-care juggernaut," said John Colaizzi, dean of the Ernest Mario School of Pharmacy at Rutgers University. The 111-year-old school of pharmacy offers degree programs in medicinal chemistry, pharmaceutical science, pharmacology and toxicology.
 In addition, despite hopes within the drug industry that breakthroughs in gene research would result in an explosion of new therapies, few new drugs are in the pipeline. In 1996, federal regulators approved 53 new drugs, but in 2002 the number of approvals dropped to 17. In part, that is because some diseases are proving to be difficult to crack.
 "Some of the breakthroughs we've had in the past were taking advantage of what might be called low-hanging fruit," Mr. Colaizzi said. "Cancer is not a simple thing, like finding an antibiotic. We're making progress, but it's slow and extremely costly."
 In addition to internal problems, the industry faces pressure from consumers, insurers and politicians for its pricing policies.
 For years, the industry had fought against a Medicare drug benefit, fearing that it would result in price controls by giving the federal government massive buying power. But Raymond Gilmartin, the chief executive of Merck, said the industry was satisfied with provisions of the law that was signed by President Bush on Dec. 8.
 "Medicare will provide benefits based on choice and competition modeled after the private market, which is very supportive of pharmaceutical innovation and does not include price controls," Mr. Gilmartin said.

Part of the Political Debate
 Even with Medicare legislation completed, the industry is expected to remain a focus of electoral campaigns while more than 40 million Americans have no insurance coverage. 
"Issues around health care in general," Mr. Gilmartin said, "and the fact that we're still faced with the uninsured is likely to be part of the political debate."
 Another flashpoint is the issue of re-importation of drugs from Canada and other countries where they are cheaper largely because those nations have national healthcare programs that buy drugs in bulk at lower prices than they are sold for in the United States.
 "People look at the price in Canada and say, 'Why can't we have that too?"' Mr. Colaizzi of Rutgers said.
 "If that continues to grow in momentum," he said, "it's going to affect the economics of these pharmaceutical companies. Either they will have to raise prices in Canada or lower them in the United States. It seems to me one of those outcomes is going to have to happen at some point."
 Merck is an acute example of the problems confronting the entire industry.
 The company's biggest seller, Zocor, is expected to lose patent protection in 2006, and there is little to replace it in the near future. Since February Merck has scrapped four highly anticipated drugs because of concern that they would not win regulatory approval, even though they had made it into mid- to late-stage development.
 Merck is being punished, in part, for taking the high road, said Hemant Shah, an independent industry analyst at HKS & Company in Warren.
 He said that Merck had largely resisted a strategy embraced by other companies in which they slightly modify a rival company's breakthrough treatment and then market this so-called me-too drug.
 "Merck is a company that has never depended on gimmicks," Mr. Shah said.
 Mr. Gilmartin said that the ability to make easy profits on me-too drugs was eroding as health insurers, including managed-care companies, refuse to pay for drugs that do not add a significant benefit for patients.
 "The value of a true advance, a novel mechanism that really represents a different health outcome for the patient, has even greater value now and going forward than in the early 90's," he said.
 Merck has also resisted the industry trend toward mergers.
 Pfizer Inc. has grown to become the world's largest drug company, with sales of $32 billion in 2002, largely through acquisitions. Two of its largest purchases were Pharmacia and Warner Lambert, which both had extensive operations in New Jersey.
 "The consolidation in the industry is inevitable and Merck will almost certainly be a part of it," Mr. Shah said. "In the future you will see fewer companies in New Jersey than there are now."
 Mergers allow companies to increase profits by combining operations and cutting redundant employees and costs. A merger may also add promising drugs to an otherwise empty pipeline.
 Mr. Gilmartin said many of the mega-mergers had not been successful. He says Merck will remain independent.
 "Mergers create, at best, a short-term boost in your profits but at an expensive long-term cost that's not an appropriate," he said.
 Merck is, however, adopting one strategy that has been widespread in the industry. The company is speeding up the pace of alliances with other drug companies and smaller biotechnology companies to beef up its pipeline. 
 In 1999 the company had only 10 of these cooperative ventures. This year, Merck completed 40 deals and is actively reviewing 80 more.
 Mr. Gilmartin said the company was changing its strategy because the biotech industry had evolved and now provides new drug discovery tools to help Merck in its own development work.
 "There are more and more opportunities for external alliances," he said.
 In addition to large pharmaceutical companies, New Jersey is home to 120 biotechnology companies with revenue of $1 billion, up 53 percent since 2000, according to the Biotechnology Council of New Jersey. These companies employ nearly 8,000 workers in the state and are expected to hire, on average, 10 employees each in 2004, the council says.
 Merck's most visible alliance is reflected in its plan to sell a new cholesterol therapy combining Zocor with Zetia, from Schering-Plough. The two companies applied for F.D.A. approval of Zocor-Zetia in November and expect it to be on the market in late 2004 or early 2005.

Troubles at Schering-Plough
 Schering-Plough has suffered after the 2002 loss of patent protection on its $3 billion blockbuster, Claritin, the allergy medicine, which accounted for a third of the company's sales. 
 The company is also in a battle with the Federal Trade Commission over allegations that it used anti-competitive practices to block generic versions of its K-Dur potassium-chloride supplement.
 Earlier this month, Schering-Plough announced an early retirement package and said that it would also lay off an unspecified number of employees to reduce costs by $200 million, or 10 percent. Of Schering-Plough's 12,000 employees, 7,200 are based in New Jersey.
 Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, has been trimming back, too. It plans to combine finance, human resources and information management to cut costs at some of its five pharmaceutical subsidiaries, which employ a total of 10,000 people worldwide.
 Four of the subsidiaries are based in New Jersey. Johnson & Johnson has not said how many jobs will be eliminated but has called the cuts "modest."
 The company's Ortho-McNeil subsidiary disclosed on Dec. 12 that it had received a subpoena from the United States Attorney's Office in Boston, requesting information about the marketing of Topamax, an epilepsy medication. 
 Bristol-Myers Squibb, which has 8,500 employees at various plants in New Jersey, has had its own set of problems, including patent expirations and the failure of a promising new drug, along with a $1 billion accounting scandal and a troubled relationship with the biotechnology company that has been at the root of Martha Stewart's problems on Wall Street.
 And in July, Bristol-Myers Squibb set aside $600 million to settle claims by state attorneys general that the company had illegally blocked generic competition to its drugs Taxol, for cancer, and BuSpar, for anxiety.
But Mr. Shah says Bristol-Myers Squibb is beginning to pull out of a very rough period, and, in fact, he said, "In my opinion Bristol Myers probably has the strongest position." 
 The company is hopeful that the Food and Drug Administration will soon approve the cancer drug Erbitux for sale based on new data submitted by Bristol-Myers. The F.D.A. had rejected clinical trial data submitted by Bristol-Myers's partner in developing that drug, ImClone Systems Inc. ImClone's founder, Samuel D. Waksal, is serving a seven-year prison term after pleading guilty to securities fraud and other charges in connection with insider trading of ImClone stock at the time of the F.D.A. decision. 
 Many other drug makers, including Aventis, Wyeth and Roche, have kept employment stable or announced slight cuts. 
 In fact, Roche is building a $155 million diagnostics manufacturing plant in Somerset County that will consolidate 440 jobs at different locations around the state and employ a total of 800 when it is finished.
 The state recently missed out on two pharmaceutical projects.
 Merck decided to build a $300 million vaccine plant in North Carolina, without seeking proposals from its home state. 
 "Unfortunately we didn't get a chance to work with them," said Juliet Johnson, a spokeswoman for Governor McGreevey. She also said that the state had recently revised its business incentive programs to generate more pharmaceutical and high-technology jobs.
 New Jersey also lost out in a recent decision by the Swiss drug maker Novartis, which has its United States base in East Hanover. The company chose to retrofit a former candy factory in Cambridge, Mass., as a laboratory for cutting-edge research rather than build a suburban campus in New Jersey.
 "We wanted our scientists to be within the campus of Harvard and M.I.T.," said Paul Herrling, head of global research at Novartis.
 "If you live in a science culture," Mr. Herrling said, "the closer the people are -- to have coffee and go to the cinema and stay out at night -- the more efficient is the interaction, the creativity, and the transfer of knowledge."
 Despite the current downturn, the drug industry is expected to rise again.
 "Inthe long term, this is still a very good industry," Mr. Hassan, the Schering-Plough executive, said. "I still see this as a sunrise industry."
 Pharmaceutical employment in the state is expected to grow to 80,000 by the end of the decade, said Mr. Healey of the HealthCare Institute of New Jersey.

Optimism at Merck
 Mr. Gilmartin said Merck had cycled through tough times before, most recently in the early 1990's. The company followed that up with a string of hits, including Zocor, in the mid- to-late 1990's before its recent slide. 
 Mr. Gilmartin said Merck would begin growing again next year. He also said that the company was about to submit applications for regulatory approval of a pain medicine, Arcoxia, and three new vaccines, including one that could block a virus linked to cervical cancer.
 Analysts are optimistic, too.
 "We will see another wave of consolidation that will give the industry four to five or six years of breathing room," Mr. Shah said. "They're just beginning to understand these complex diseases and fine-tune their efforts. It's going to take another five to 10 years before this massive effort will be realized with new breakthrough products."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
In Pakistan, a Leader Has More Enemies and Fewer Friends

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
ANYONE taking time to ponder the fate of the predecessors of President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan over the last three decades would not find the facts very reassuring. One was hanged, another died in a suspicious plane crash, and two were ousted from power and remain in exile.
 Now, after four years of ruling Pakistan with a wily determination, General Musharraf has earned himself a long list of enemies, any one of whom might wish him dead. They include generals he has sidelined, myriad opposition parties, a range of organized criminal gangs dealing in arms and drugs, the country's jihad-obsessed religious factions and, of course, India, with which Pakistan has fought three wars. 
 When two suicide bombers plowed their vehicles into General Musharraf's motorcade on Christmas Day, making the second unsuccessful attempt on his life in less than two weeks, suspicions immediately focused on Al Qaeda and its allies. American officials shared that assessment, though they noted that in Pakistan very little intelligence is dependable.
 "It's never easy to follow the situation in Pakistan, because reality keeps shifting," said an administration official with long experience in studying the region. "You can never be sure about the reliability of your information."
 A violent change in power in Pakistan is especially frightening to American policy makers and others who fear that the country's nuclear weapons could get into the hands of those waging war against the West. Experts often declare Pakistan one of the most dangerous places in the world and also one of the most difficult places in which to figure out who America's friends are.
 General Musharraf, for example, is accused by Islamic militants in Pakistan of cracking down too hard on Al Qaeda, but is suspected in Washington of looking the other way while Osama bin Laden roams freely along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. Both perceptions are rooted in reality.
 American officials say they are impressed that in recent years, for example, the general has spent money on roads and other benefits in the mountainous tribal areas of that part of Pakistan, seeking to curry favor with the Pashtuns who have always rebelled against central rule. It is there that Pakistan has said it is determined to help the United States find Mr. bin Laden. But no American official is entirely convinced that President Musharraf is trying as hard as he might.
 "The image we get in Washington is that there are a lot of negotiations going on," an American official said. "It's certainly not force majeure."
 Administration officials say they take at face value General Musharraf's promise not to transmit nuclear weapons information or materials to other countries, especially Iran and North Korea. Last week, Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage said the general had pledged not to make such transfers "and I believe him."
 The United States is pushing Pakistan to move back toward democracy, but its appeals are tempered by the knowledge that the few elections held in recent years have shown the growing strength of religious parties that revile American influence in their country. The elected local governments of the Northwest Frontier province are among the most militant.
 The day before he survived his latest assassination attempt, General Musharraf made a deal with several hard-line Islamist opposition parties to step down as army chief while remaining the nation's president. In return, the parties agreed to constitutional changes he had been seeking that would solidify the power of the presidency and the armed forces in political life.
 All the feuding among factions in Pakistan, and the rampant trafficking in arms, drugs and smuggled goods, have persuaded American policy makers over the years to put their faith in the military. The country has been under its rule for most of the time since independence in 1947, and the military is today the most powerful force in society.
 Blunt force, once again, only partly explains the role of military influence. The army's tentacles extend throughout the economy. The army or groups alliedwith it own many enterprises, and many retired military officers can expect to serve as heads of private businesses. Along with ruthlessness and intimidation, the army brings discipline, consistency and sophistication to many parts of Pakistani life.
 But history also shows that military rule sows the seeds of its own downfall. The last general to rule Pakistan, Mohammed Zia ul-Haq, died in 1988 at the height of his power, in a plane crash that has never been explained. His death ushered in a cycle of democracy, coupled with instability and corruption, that culminated in General Musharraf's coup of 1999.
 If the past is a guide, General Musharraf faces future instability, with the Americans hoping he can cling to power long enough to keep protecting American interests.

HEADLINE: Dismay in Waterbury Over Governor's Problems 

BYLINE:  By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
WATERBURY residents have watched local boy John G. Rowland make headlines since he got out of college and rose from the State Legislature to the United States Congress. When he became governor in 1994, he didn't forget his hometown, helping send millions of dollars to the city in state grants.
 But news about Mr. Rowland these days is almost all sour, and while some are sympathetic to his plight, many people in this city are tired of the words "I'm sorry" from their leaders. After a decade of corruption investigations and a child molestation scandal from their last mayor, those words are starting to ring a little hollow. 
 "It must be something about Waterbury," said Donna Yorker as she walked to a bus stop this month. "Child molesters and thieves." 
Across the street, Robert Thompson, also waiting for a bus, vented his frustration.
"It'll all come out. They all do things and then try to move on and take the focus off of them," he said, referring to politicians in the state. "It's about doing the right thing. That's what's important."
It's hard to blame them for being jaded. Three consecutive Waterbury mayors have been indicted for various acts of corruption, the most recent of which was arguably the worst. Philip A. Giordano is serving 37 years in prison for sexually abusing two children.
So forgive Waterbury residents. They've heard their share of half-hearted apologies, half-truths and outright lies. And with unemployment here at almost 8 percent as of November and the poverty rate at 16 percent as of 2000, Mr. Rowland's false statements about gifts he received for his vacation cottage, including a hot tub, aren't getting a good reception.
"He's using state contractors to do the work," said Blerim Zhuta, who owns a hair salon in a strip mall on Wolcott Street. "If you're going to do something, pay for it out of your own pocket. A lot of people can't afford to live on a lake."
Eric Gibson, a state corrections officer who was at the shop for a haircut, said he thought he could be seeing more of Mr. Rowland soon at his place of employment.
"If he's on the track he's on, he'll need to see one of us sooner or later," Mr. Gibson said. "People in public positions, we look up to them. They're actually playing directly into the stereotype of a politician."
Even at the governor's high school, students viewed their vaunted alumnus with a certain disdain. Two of the three previous mayors to face indictment, the only two to serve prison time, went to Holy Cross High School, where Mr. Rowland graduated almost 30 years ago.
"Every political figure that goes to Holy Cross, something happens to them," said Chris Readel, 16. "It's just funny." He said the misdeeds of public officials who went to Holy Cross have become a running joke among students at the school.
When he went to Holy Cross, Mr. Rowland was the captain of the wrestling team and the president of the senior class. His family, which has a long and rich history in the city, lived about four miles away in the Overlook neighborhood. Mr. Rowland's grandfather, Sherwood L. Rowland, gained renown for fighting municipal corruption in Waterbury after he became the city controller in 1937. Mr. Rowland's father, Sherwood, also served as city controller.
But Mr. Rowland's father has since passed away, and his mother, Cerie, moved out of the city this year, selling the house on Randolph Street to an Orthodox Jewish family. The only remnant of the family's belongings still in the two-story yellow home is the wallpaper in the upstairs bathroom, which pays homage to America's founding fathers, the Declaration of Independence and Betsy Ross. The neighborhood has indeed changed since Mr. Rowland was a boy, as a new yeshiva has brought a number of Orthodox families to Randolph Street.
One of the few families left from Mr. Rowland's childhood are the Cotters of Euclid Avenue. In a recent telephone interview, Mary Cotter said she remembered watching Mr. Rowland, whom she has known since he was 5 years old, cut lawns as a child. He was always ambitious and hardworking, she said. She was upset about the governor's current situation and thinks he's getting a bad rap.
"I just feel that any normal individual, if a friend offers to give them something, they thank them and move on," she said. "I don't think John had any evil intentions. He just made a mistake. Everyone's entitled to a mistake."
After graduating from high school, Mr. Rowland went on to Villanova University. In 1980, Mr. Rowland won his first political seat in Connecticut, representing Waterbury in the state House. In 1984, Mr. Rowland was elected to Congress, where he served three terms.
His first run for the governorship, in 1990, ended in failure. But, four years later, Mr. Rowland won his first of three terms. If he finishes out his third term, he will be the longest-serving Connecticut governor since colonial times.
And even though Waterbury has almost three times as many registered Democrats as Republicans, he received more than 60 percent of the city's votes in the last election.
While Waterbury long thrived because of its brass business, the city declined in the 1960's and 70's. Previous governors virtually forgot about the struggling city, said the current mayor, Michael J. Jarjura, but Mr. Rowland has paid special attention to his hometown.
"In Waterbury there's a particular sense that for many years other governors passed over the city," Mr. Jarjura said. "Since we got a governor from our city it's been more fair," 
Mr. Rowland has helped steer about $153 million in Urban Act money to the city, Mr. Jarjura said. Waterbury built a new courthouse about two years ago and was chosen as the site for a brand-new University of Connecticut branch, which opened this year. A new middle and high school devoted to the arts is scheduled to open next fall. It will connect to the Palace Theater, which was built in 1920 and is undergoing a $30 million renovation.
State investment has also led to more private investment in the city, Mr. Jarjura added.
Since Mr. Jarjura took office to replace Mr. Giordano in 2001, he has helped write new ethics guidelines and restore the city's ethics commission, as well as revamping its purchasing and procurement laws. Past administrations had used a competitive bidding process, but then undermined it by spending millions on change orders, he said.
But the misdeeds of the last decade have left residents wary of politicians with big plans, Mr. Jarjura said.
"Given what the people in Waterbury have been through, it's so hard to restore their confidence," Mr. Jarjura said. "They're under the impression that everybody's on the take."
That's not to say the governor doesn't have a strong base of support here. At Gahan's Eating and Drinking Saloon downtown, customers said they were tired of the recent spate of governor-bashing.
"I think there's nothing wrong with accepting a favor from your friends," said John Sullivan, a bartender who has known the governor since he started in politics. "You know the old saying: 'Let he who is without sin cast the first stone."'

HEADLINE: TELEVISION: THE HIGHS; 
The Programs of the Year

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
 1. 'THE DAILY SHOW WITH JON STEWART' -- Comedy Central has the best late night talk show -- better than Leno, Letterman or Conan O'Brien. Mr. Stewart, who is acidly funny about everything, describes Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman as the candidate for "people who want to vote for Bush but don't think he is Jewish enough."

2. TED KOPPEL'S WAR COVERAGE -- ABC's graying anchorman was the most authoritative of the embedded correspondents covering the invasion of Iraq. He brought his cameras in as close as any other reporter storming across the desert with United States troops, but never lost his cool detachment.

3. 'THE OFFICE' -- It's the best comedy on television, even if it can be seen only on BBC America, a digital-tier cable station. The deadpan mockumentary about a group of listless employees of a paper company in the dreary English suburb of Slough has no laugh track, slapstick or obvious punch lines, just infectious social satire.

4. 'HOPE AND FAITH' -- This ABC show has the laugh track, slapstick and obvious punch lines that weigh down most network sitcoms, but Kelly Ripa is surprisingly amusing as a narcissistic, unemployed soap opera star forced to move in with her prim, suburban sister (Faith Ford). Together they are a "Laverne and Shirley" for the Botox generation.

5. 'THE PRACTICE' -- ABC's wilting legal drama underwent an extreme makeover: its creator, David E. Kelley, replaced half the cast with James Spader and made the show twice as good.

6. 'THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW' -- The former standup comedian and sitcom star turns out to be a charming and unobtrusively witty talk show host. Her show is a refreshing throwback to the days of Merv Griffin and Mike Douglas, when talk show hosts actually made conversation.

7. 'THE O.C.' -- Fox's nighttime soap opera about rich, pampered teenagers in Southern California may not be uplifting or groundbreaking, but it amply fills the teen angst vacuum left by "Beverly Hills, 90210" and "Dawson's Creek."

8. HBO DOCUMENTARIES -- "Born Rich," a look at what it is like to inherit wealth, directed by one who knows -- Jamie Johnson, an heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune -- was an unusual, sidelong glance at one of the only remaining closed circles in American society. "Terror in Moscow," a documentary about the taking of 700 hostages in a Moscow theater by Chechen rebels, was an astonishingly intimate portrait of terrorism.

9. 'ANGELS IN AMERICA' -- It redefined the term "made-for-television movie." Mike Nichols's six-hour adaptation, for HBO, of Tony Kushner's epic two-part play about AIDS in the 1980's was exhilarating -- artsy television that didn't make viewers antsy.

10. 'QUEER EYE FOR THE STRAIGHT GUY' -- Bravo's makeover masterpiece was the best new reality show. In each episode, five seraphic gay stylists transform a lumpish heterosexual with a new haircut, new clothes, new furniture, new recipes and better table manners. They are the real angels in America.

HEADLINE: The White-Collar Blues 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
I am surprised at how passive American workers have become.
 A couple of million factory positions have disappeared in the short time since we raised our glasses to toast the incoming century. And now the white-collar jobs are following the blue-collar jobs overseas. 
 Americans are working harder and have become ever more productive -- astonishingly productive -- but are not sharing in the benefits of their increased effort. If you think in terms of wages, benefits and the creation of good jobs, the employment landscape is grim. 
The economy is going great guns, we're told, but nearly nine million Americans are officially unemployed, and the real tally of the jobless is much higher. Even as the Bush administration and the media celebrate the blossoming of statistics that supposedly show how well we're doing, the lines at food banks and soup kitchens are lengthening. They're swollen in many cases by the children of men and women who are working but not making enough to house and feed their families.
I.B.M. has crafted plans to send thousands of upscale jobs from the U.S. to lower-paid workers in China, India and elsewhere. Anyone who doesn't believe this is the wave of the future should listen to comments made last spring by an I.B.M. executivenamed Harry Newman:
"I think probably the biggest impact to employee relations and to the H.R. field is this concept of globalization. It is rapidly accelerating, and it means shifting a lot of jobs, opening a lot of locations in places we had never dreamt of before, going where there's low-cost labor, low-cost competition, shifting jobs offshore."
An executive at Microsoft, the ultimate American success story, told his department heads last year to "Think India," and to "pick something to move offshore today."
These matters should be among the hottest topics of our national conversation. We've already witnessed the carnage in manufacturing jobs. Now, with white-collar jobs at stake, we've got executives at I.B.M. and Microsoft exchanging high-fives at the prospect of getting "two heads for the price of one" in India.
It might be a good idea to throw a brighter spotlight on some of these trends and explore the implications for the long-term economy and the American standard of living.
"If you take this to its logical extreme, the implications for the entire middle-class wage structure in the United States are terrifying," said Thea Lee, an economist with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Now is the time to start thinking about policy solutions."
But that's exactly what we're not thinking about. Government policy at the moment is focused primarily on what's best for the corporations. From that perspective, job destruction and wage compression are good things -- as long as they don't get too much high-profile attention.
"This is a significant problem, much greater than we believed it was even a year ago," said Marcus Courtney, president of the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, an affiliate of the Communication Workers of America.
Accurate data on the number of jobs already lost are all but impossible to come by. But there is no disputing the direction of the trend, or the fact that it is accelerating. Allowing this movement to continue unchecked will eventually mean economic suicide for hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of American families.
Globalization may be a fact of life. But that does not mean that its destructive impact on American families can't be mitigated. The best thing workers can do, including white-collar and professional workers, is to organize. At the same time, the exportation of jobs and the effect that is having on the standard of living here should be relentlessly monitored by the government, the civic sector and the media. The public has a right to know what's really going on.
Trade agreements and tax policies should be examined and updated to encourage the creation of employment that enhances the quality of life here at home. Corporate leaders may not feel an obligation to contribute to the long-term well-being of local communities or the nation as a whole, but that shouldn't be the case with the rest of us. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Seminole Casino Plan Inspires Hope and Fear 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 28 

 BODY:
It was here, on a run-down stretch of State Road 7, that the multibillion-dollar Indian gambling industry had its humble beginnings. Today, the Seminoles' original high-stakes bingo hall still stands, but it seems a relic from the past.
 Just down the road, the tribe sees its future: a Las Vegas-style complex, the Seminole Hard Rock Hotel and Casino, now under construction. 
 There are big dreams, great expectations. Tribal leaders hope this casino and a complex in Tampa will more than triple annual gambling revenues to around $1 billion when they open early next year. But some members fear that the tribe is overreaching and that its rags-to-riches story might end in ruin. 
The tribe has taken on $410 million in debt to finance the Hard Rock casino project. James Billie, the Seminoles' leader from 1979 to 2001 and the man who built their gambling empire, was ousted after reports of multimillion-dollar spending sprees.
Some Seminoles say the quest for wealth has blinded the tribe's leaders to the needs of its people.
"We have a severe housing shortage, infrastructure that needs to be updated," Gloria Wilson, a tribe member, said, adding that the casino project and its accompanying debt were "too ambitious for our coffers." 
The Hollywood complex, the bigger of the two casinos, will have 130,000 square feet of casino space, a Hard Rock Cafe, a bar with 42 plasma-screen televisions, a spa and a 6,000-seat arena for concerts, among other features. It will also have 300,000 square feet of retail space and restaurants.
James Allen, the Seminoles' chief executive for gambling, said the hotel had tentative commitments for 60,000 room bookings, enough to fill it for four months.
The two Seminole complexes are expected to draw more than 20,000 visitors a day, bring in $700 million in annual revenue and create 6,000 full-time jobs, tribal officials said. "It's going to be a pure economic engine," said Max Osceola, the Hollywood representative on the tribal council.
The tribe sold $410 million in 30-year bonds to build the two complexes, Mr. Allen said. The Hard Rock Cafe's parent company, the Rank Group, bought $25 million of the bonds. The tribe has only a licensing deal to use Hard Rock's name, so the restaurant chain will not manage the complex. Hard Rock officials declined to comment.
"Some of them were upset, saying: '410 million? That's a lot of money,' " Mr. Osceola said of tribe members. "And that is a lot of money. But what do they say? You've got to spend money to make money." 
There is no doubt that gambling money made the Seminole Tribe of Florida rich. Each of its roughly 3,000 members receives $42,000 a year and free health care and college tuition. Tribal leaders say that figure will probably go up after the Hard Rocks open in April.
The empire Mr. Billie started with the bingo hall in 1979 led other tribes to turn to gambling. The Indian gambling industry had $14.5 billion in revenues last year, according to the National Indian Gaming Commission, a federal agency.
But for the Seminoles, wealth has also invited legal troubles and accusations of greed. Mr. Billie and other leaders have admitted that they went on spending binges. Only Mr. Billie was ousted from leadership.
Tribal lawyers have acknowledged that federal officials are still investigating whether Seminole leaders paid millions of dollars in required taxes on gifts. The lawyers denied any wrongdoing by the tribe. Internal Revenue Service officials declined to comment.
Mr. Billie says the current leadership is spending too much on the Hard Rock casinos and ruining his legacy as chief. "When I was there they made close to $3 billion," he said. "None of these guys will be able to achieve that."

HEADLINE: Dominican Republic in Crisis 

 BODY:
In the late 1990's, the Dominican Republic had the fastest-growing economy in Latin America. Fueled by tourism, manufacturing and money sent home by Dominicans abroad -- many of them in New York -- the economy grew nearly 7 percent a year. Today that economy is in collapse. Protests are common, and at least eight people were killed during a strike in November. Extraordinary as it sounds, the troubles are largely due to a single bank collapse and its aftermath, a meltdown due to cronyism, corruption, lax regulation and secrecy. 
 Until April, Banco Intercontinental, known as Baninter, was the country's second-largest private bank, and its president, Ramon Baez Figueroa, was Santa Claus. Mr. Baez Figueroa gave away millions of dollars to popular causes and politicians. He gave two S.U.V.'s to President Hipolito Mejia. His generosity served to shield the bank from regulators who might have discovered that hundreds of millions of dollars had disappeared. 
 When Baninter collapsed in April, the government -- against the advice of the International Monetary Fund -- guaranteed all deposits, even those held in the Cayman Islands. Three-quarters of the payments went to 80 very wealthy individuals.
The bailout has cost Dominicans $2.2 billion -- two-thirds of the government's budget for the year -- leading to inflation and a sharp devaluation of the peso. Electricity is highly subsidized, even for the rich, and the state is too broke to pay anyone to generate it, so blackouts last for hours. Recently the government bought two private electricity distribution companies. The move was popular, but it has not led to service improvements and cost the treasury the suspiciously large sum of $350 million. The deal led the I.M.F. to suspend a loan in progress.
The Dominican Republic needs to buy electricity and lessen people's suffering and the risk of social violence. But the I.M.F. and other lenders are right to condition larger loans on reforms like better banking supervision, more transparency and reform of the electricity sector to focus subsidies on the poor. The government has reluctantly made some improvements, but its policies and style remain cronyism as usual -- and are worsening as May elections approach. President Mejia, who had pledged not to run again, is doing so, a move so unpopular that his party is in rebellion. Dominicans would be better served if instead he spent his remaining months working to strengthen his country's institutions.

HEADLINE: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE RETIRED GENERAL; 
With Tour, Clark Focuses on Southern Votes

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 28 

 BODY:
The New Hampshire primary is less than a month away, but Gen. Wesley K. Clark will spend the waning days of 2003 far from the North. Instead, he will barnstorm across eight Southern states, even though most of them do not hold their primary elections until well into March and many Democrats expect their presidential nominee to have been chosen by then.
 The unusual campaign swing is meant to demonstrate what General Clark's campaign says is his strength in a region where Democrats have not fared too well in recent national elections and thus to portray him as the best alternative to another candidate, Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont. 
 The decision to look ahead to the general election in November before a single vote has been cast in the primaries is a calculated risk by the Clark campaign, which has been briskly raising money over the last three months and attracting growing crowds at recent stops in Wisconsin and South Carolina. 
General Clark is trying to show the party that his national security credentials and experience leading a well-integrated institution make him the most qualified candidate to go toe-to-toe with President Bush in the fall. With five Senate seats being vacated by Democrats in the South, General Clark is also trying to demonstrate that for Southern office-seekers, he would be a strong presence at the top of the ticket.
"The message we're trying to send is beyond the specific states we will visit," Paul Johnson, the Clark campaign manager, said in an interview. "In part the plan is to make the statement that General Clark has a broad base of appeal in all 50 states."
The swing, called the True Grits Tour, will begin Monday at General Clark's campaign headquarters here in Arkansas, then travel over two days to Jackson, Miss.; New Orleans and Baton Rouge, La.; Birmingham, Ala.; Pensacola, Fla.; Memphis and Nashville; Garden City, Ga.; and Mount Pleasant, S.C.
South Carolina has a primary on Feb. 3 and Tennessee on Feb. 10. The other states on the tour hold primaries later, however, with Georgia voting on March 2 and Mississippi, Louisiana and Florida voting on March 9. The Arkansas primary is scheduled for May 18 and the Alabama primary for June 1.
General Clark has also been attracting growing crowds at campaign stops in New Hampshire, where he spent most of his time during the fall after deciding to skip the Iowa caucuses. The crowds are still much smaller than those for Howard Dean, who sometimes draws 1,000 people or more. But as a rookie campaigner, General Clark says that he feels more comfortable in small town-hall settings than behind a lectern, and the campaign has purposely chosen smaller venues for his appearances. 
Mr. Johnson said that during the Southern tour, General Clark's message would be aimed at military families. Many of them are undergoing long separations because of the fighting in Afghanistan and Iraq.
In addition, General Clark is expected to highlight his experience with affirmative action in the military, something he refers to repeatedly on the campaign trail in areas with large minority populations. Though much of the tour will focus on General Clark's plans for the economy, the environment and health care, in Birmingham he will give an address focused on civil rights, campaign officials said. 
The issue came up during a recent visit to Oklahoma City, when the campaign's only public event was a town hall meeting at Stell's, a soul-food restaurant near the state Capitol. Of about 60 people at the meeting, nearly all were African-American, and one person asked General Clark whether he practiced what he preached when hiring campaign workers.
General Clark asked his staff members to raise their hands. "I've got all kinds of people who mirror America," he said, pointing out that about half of the workers were minorities. 
Gwen Tabor, who attended the Oklahoma City event, said she believed General Clark "knows how to talk to people and deal with the problems of the world."
"He knows we have to live together and talk together," Ms. Tabor said. "We need somebody who can lead, which General Clark can do and George Bush has never done."
Some Southern politicians appear to believe in General Clark's ability to attract voters that other candidates might not. On Sunday, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans quoted Representative Chris John, a Democrat and potentially a candidate for the Senate seat being vacated by John B. Breaux, saying that he would be more comfortable campaigning alongside Mr. Clark than any other candidate.
General Clark is clearly having fun these days. Recently, when a contingent of supporters from Arkansas traveled to New Hampshire to show their support, General Clark joined them to "call the hogs," a ritual yelling of "Soooo-eeeeee!" that University of Arkansas fans use to rally their team. Instead of invoking the Razorbacks at the end of the cheer, as is customary, the group ended with "Clark!" which brought a hearty laugh from the general.
