HEADLINE: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE GENERAL; 
In Southern Stop, Clark Promises to Enforce Voting Rights

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 29 

 BODY:
Forty years after four black girls were killed in a church bombing here, Gen. Wesley K. Clark visited the same church on Monday and said African-Americans were still in danger of having their votes go uncounted and their voices unheard.
 Speaking at the 16th Street Baptist Church on a two-day campaign visit to the South, General Clark said voting rights were a "very personal issue for me," as someone who had grown up in the South and who had supported affirmative action in the armed forces. 
 He said that if he became the Democratic presidential nominee he would appoint a legal team to monitor the 2004 elections to ensure that problems reported in the contested 2000 election in Florida would not be repeated. 
"If anyone is intimidated or turned away from the polls illegally, we will push to prosecute the perpetrators to the full extent of the law," he said.
General Clark, who is retired from the Army, cited complaints that black voters had been disenfranchised in Florida through rejected ballots or by being turned away at the polls.
His day was soggy and hectic as he traveled across the rainy South, making seven stops on what his campaign is calling the True Grits tour through eight states. 
The trip, which combines campaign events with fund-raisers asking $1,000 per plate of grits, is designed to highlight General Clark's Southern background and military credentials. He has made an effort to reach black voters, who are some of the Democratic Party's core supporters. He has also been seeking to appeal to party centrists who worry about whether Howard Dean, who is ahead in the polls in early primary states, can appeal to voters in the South.
At campaign stops in Jackson, Miss.; New Orleans; Baton Rouge, La.; and Pensacola, Fla., General Clark emphasized his Arkansas roots, telling supporters that he held dear the values of patriotism, faith, family and inclusiveness.
"What it all comes down to is that I am who I am because of what I learned right here in the South," he said, addressing about 100 people in the War Memorial Building in Jackson, in a room with exhibits on voting rights and the history of the United States flag.
The Clark campaign was also trying hard to send the message that the general's beliefs echoed those of another son of the South who talked about faith and family, former President Bill Clinton. The campaign on Monday began running a television advertisement in New Hampshire that features a clip of Mr. Clinton awarding the Presidential Medal of Freedom to General Clark in August 2000 for his work leading NATO forces in the war in Kosovo.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, has endorsed a candidate for the Democratic nomination, but General Clark said after entering the race that the Clintons had been encouraging of his candidacy. His advertisement was the first by a candidate this campaign season to feature a shot of the former president. 
As he campaigned on Monday, General Clark encountered a heckler who asked whether he supported the Confederate battle flag. His response -- "We stand for that American flag, not the Confederate flag" -- drew applause from a racially mixed crowd.
Despite passage of federal legislation in 2002 to overhaul the nation's voting procedures, General Clark said later in Birmingham, "The result is that today it's only one person, one vote if you live in the right county, and if you vote at the right machine and if your name happens to be on the rolls." 
He urged states to change laws that prevented felons from voting. He said that felons who had served their sentence and who remained out of trouble should be allowed to apply for the right to vote. 
Earlier this year, Gov. Bob Riley of Alabama, a Republican, vetoed a bill supported by black lawmakers in the state that would have allowed felons to regain voting rights. In the last few years, seven states have dropped or eased restrictions on voting by felons, according to the Sentencing Project, a group in Washington.
General Clark drew curious crowds and supporters. In Baton Rouge, the Rev. J. W. Crawford, pastor of Lighthouse Missionary Baptist Church, said he liked the candidate's agenda, including opposition to the war in Iraq, providing money directly to states to stimulate jobs and raising taxes on wealthy Americans to where they were before the Bush tax cuts.
"He can turn the country around economically for the so-called middle class, who I believe are being left out by the greedy rich," Mr. Crawford said.
Norman Pendergrass, a high school chemistry teacher who traveled to see General Clark in Baton Rouge from his home in nearby Denham Springs, said he was interested in the candidate's military background.
"My father is retired military, and that part of his resume attracts me," Mr. Pendergrass, 57, said of General Clark. "I'm a child of Vietnam, and that war affected me directly." 
He said he thought President Bush would have "learned a lesson from that conflict" before sending American troops into Iraq.
"That's why I'm here trying to find an alternative," Mr. Pendergrass said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 7, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 30 about Gen. Wesley K. Clark's support of voting rights in his campaign for the presidential nomination misstated the number of states that have eased barriers to voting by felons who have served their sentences. It is nine, not seven. The article also referred incompletely to Alabama's consideration of such a measure. Although Gov. Bob Riley vetoed it last June, he signed a similar bill three months later.

HEADLINE: Layers of Ownership Conceal Trouble in Italy 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: MILAN, Dec. 29 

 BODY:
After Enron and other corporate scandals erupted in the United States, Congress passed the Sarbanes-Oxley bill in an effort to prevent abuses. In much of Europe, regulations have been tightened in hopes of avoiding similar problems. 
 But Italy has reacted to its own business disasters in a different way. Led by Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, perhaps the nation's leading business executive as well, Italy has moved to remove criminal penalties for accounting fraud and, in the last week, has rewritten its bankruptcy laws to accommodate the failure of Parmalat, the giant dairy and food-processing company controlled by the Tanzi family. 
 Magistrates investigating Parmalat, which was declared insolvent on Saturday, say one factor that allowed the company to hide its problems for so long was a multilayered ownership structure all-too-common among Italy's leading corporations, including Mr. Berlusconi's media empire. 
The reliance on a so-called Chinese box of holdings within holdings invites abuse, critics say, and is compounded by the way Italy's big family-controlled companies are governed at the top, with lots of family members on the board and weak checks on their power.
"The typical structure of Italian capitalism, with family ownership, favors the continuity of companies and, at least in the past, transmitted a level of trust and stability," said Carlo Alberto Carnevale Maffe, a professor of industrial strategy at the Bocconi University Business School in Milan. "The fall of the Tanzi family sends a clear signal of the need for reform of family-controlled capitalism."
As the investigation of Parmalat continued, officials close to the inquiry said that magistrates questioning Parmalat executives and advisers privately told a judge in Milan that Calisto Tanzi, the founder and former chairman of the company, might have misappropriated as much as 800 million euros ($999 million).
The magistrates said Parmalat's total liabilities might be as much as 13 billion euros ($16.2 billion), far above the 8.2 billion euros in debt that the company held at the end of last year. The estimates, according to those close to the investigation, were contained in a document presented by the magistrates to a judge on Saturday when they sought an order for Mr. Tanzi to be detained.
The official questioning seems to be moving even faster than efforts by experts from PricewaterhouseCoopers and two investment banks, Mediobanca and Lazard, to disentangle the web through which Parmalat's finances flowed. Parmalat's new chairman, Enrico Bondi, who was appointed as bankruptcy administrator, met with the experts on Monday. 
Mr. Tanzi acknowledged to investigators on Monday that he funneled about 500 million euros ($624 million) away from Parmalat and into other companies, said one of his lawyers, Fabio Belloni, according to Reuters.
On Saturday, the magistrates said that executives from Italian branch of the auditing firm Grant Thornton had assisted Mr. Tanzi in setting up a Cayman Islands subsidiary of Parmalat. Grant Thornton remained responsible for the subsidiary's auditing even after Parmalat was forced by Italian laws in 1999 to rotate its accountants.
Two Grant Thornton executives who were named by the magistrates -- Lorenzo Penca, the chairman of the Italian unit, and a partner, Maurizio Bianchi -- released a statement on Monday saying they had volunteered to be questioned by the magistrates regarding their work with Parmalat.
In London, Grant Thornton International, the umbrella entity that unites the independently owned auditing firms that cooperate under the name, said that it had "limited powers to obtain information and documents from its independent member firms, who are all separate legal entities." Nonetheless, the statement added, it had "initiated an inquiry as authorized by its governance documents."
Mr. Tanzi, like many industrial patriarchs here, had done all the right things in his long rise to the peak of Italian society. The son of a small delicatessen owner, he built Parmalat painstakingly, currying contacts in the government, where he had close ties to the perennially ruling Christian Democrats before their collapse in the 1990's.
His Catholicism was such an important feature of his public persona that even after he was detained by the police on Saturday and confined in Milan's San Vittore Prison, Italian newspapers reported that he had attended Mass at the prison chapel on Sunday and received communion. That gives some sense of the forgiveness that has long been an important characteristic of Italian society.
"We are a Catholic country," Professor Carnevale Maffe said. "We tend to forgive failings, provided you do penance." 
But even as Mr. Tanzi prayed, a fair amount of soul-searching was going on elsewhere in Italy over what the scandal means for the nation's ability to compete in the global market.
In the race to attract foreign investment, Italy lags woefully behind many European neighbors. A report presented this month by the American Chamber of Commerce in Italy points out that as of the end of last year, about 2 percent of the total stock of American investment abroad was in Italy, Europe's third-largest economy behind Germany and France. That represents only a fifth the amount in the Netherlands and a tenth that in Britain.
"Italy is not taken into consideration by American investors at the same level in which they consider productive investments in other European countries," Enrico Sassoon, the chamber's managing director, wrote in an introduction to the report.
The storm that has engulfed Parmalat comes roughly a year after Cirio, another Italian food company, defaulted on more than $1 billion in bonds. Italians are also struggling to make sense of the long decline of Fiat, the nation's leading industrial conglomerate. 
So far, Mr. Berlusconi's government has reacted to the Parmalat scandal by enacting a decree that accelerated the process of protecting failed companies like Parmalat from creditors, so that its industrial operations can continue and jobs be saved.
Meanwhile, the government has pledged to overhaul the system of industrial and financial regulation, much of which lies now in the hands of the Bank of Italy, the central bank. The government's economic minister, Giulio Tremonti, has long sought to transfer such authority to a unified regulatory body; the spreading Parmalat scandal, with its implications for failures of banks, auditors and other overseers, may finally provide him the power to win that battle with the central bank.
But he still faces a considerable struggle because of the continuing hold that Italian family capitalism has on public policy. Italy's family companies have traditionally lacked good rules of corporate governance, Professor Carnevale Maffe said. At Parmalat, Mr. Tanzi, his brother Giovanni, his son Stefano and his niece Paola Visconti all had important positions on the board or in the group's management. 
Moreover, Italian families have steered their complex corporate structures in ways that ended up leveraging them, placing much of the burden on the units furthest from the family itself. 
"A lot of debt was put on the shoulders of operating companies," Professor Carnevale Maffe said, "which were the last branches of the tree."
Under the stress of Parmalat's failure, though, institutional creditors, including banks and bondholders, may finally force Italian companies to shift strategy, Professor Carnevale Maffe added. 
While outside forces may press for change, Mr. Berlusconi's government is not expected to act hastily to overhaul the regulatory system. For one thing, Mr. Berlusconi himself is the owner of Italy's biggest private media group, and much of his time has been taken up recently trying to win parliamentary approval for a bill that would overcome opposition from Italy's president, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, and allow him to expand his media holdings. 
Mr. Berlusconi's own companies, nestled in dozens of Chinese boxes like Mr. Tanzi's, have in the past faced accusations of accounting fraud. 
Last year, his government pushed through legislation relaxing the penalties for false accounting, which were reduced from criminal penalties to administrative sanctions.
The legislation, said Airs Accornero, a professor of industrial sociology at the University of Rome, "gave a profoundly bad lesson to the economic system."
And those failing, experts said, may still come back to haunt Italy's powerful family concerns.
"For major things," Professor Carnevale Maffe said, "you still go to hell."

HEADLINE: LIBYA'S ATOM BID IN EARLY PHASES 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 29 

 BODY:
The top United Nations nuclear inspector, Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, said Monday that Libya's nuclear program was years away from producing a nuclear weapon and that important pieces of equipment were now largely dismantled and stored in boxes.
 But Dr. ElBaradei, who spoke in Libya after visiting four previously undeclared sites where scientists had been working to perfect the enrichment of uranium, did express surprise that Libya had acquired a great deal of high-technology equipment needed to enrich uranium through black-market transactions that have yet to be disclosed. 
 It was "an eye opener to see how much material has been going from one country to the other" and "the extent of the black market network," Dr. ElBaradei, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, said at a news conference in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, The Associated Press reported. The existence of this shadowy network of middlemen who often circumvent national export controls, he said, proved that those controls were not working.
"What we have seen is a program in the very initial stages of development," Dr. ElBaradei said of the Libyan effort. 
"We haven't seen any industrial-scale facility to produce highly enriched uranium. We haven't seen any enriched uranium."
The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, met Dr. ElBaradei for about half an hour, during which the Libyan reiterated his pledge to rid the country of illicit weapons, an official traveling with Dr. ElBaradei said. Colonel Qaddafi also pledged to begin immediate compliance with the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, especially by submitting to unannounced inspectionsof any site.
"Libya committed today to act as if the protocol was in force," Dr. ElBaradei said, referring to the treaty requirement on inspections. The Libyans have also been asked to produce documentation about their nuclear program, officials with the atomic energy agency said. 
During the news conference, Dr. ElBaradei, a former Egyptian diplomat who last year directed the final inspections in Iraq along with his colleague Hans Blix, said it was his "gut feeling" that Libya was three to seven years away from producing a nuclear weapon. 
"We are now working with them to neutralize any activities, any programs that could have led to a nuclear weapon," he said.
On Sunday, Dr. ElBaradei's inspectors visited four previously unknown sites near Tripoli where nuclear weapons-related equipment was stored. A senior Bush administration official said all the sites had been inspected by British and American intelligence experts in October and early December as part of the secret diplomacy that led to Colonel Qaddafi's renunciation of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons on Dec. 19. 
Also over the weekend, Dr. ElBaradei's team met and debriefed Libyan scientists and senior government officials, including Prime Minister Shokri Ghanem and Matouq Muhammad Matouq, a Libyan deputy prime minister and head of the country's secret nuclear program.
Robert J. Einhorn, who was the top State Department official in charge of nonproliferation in the Clinton administration, said in an interview that while it is "very good to get Libya out of the nuclear weapons business, it could be even more important if this helps us to understand the black market in nuclear technology and roll up some of those sources of supply."
A senior official in the Bush administration said Dr. ElBaradei's visit was another reminder that the nuclear agency "missed the Libyan nuclear weapons program just like it missed so many others." A spokesman for Dr. ElBaradei said he responded to this assertion by pointing out that "no verification system would be able to detect the kind of low-level activities Libya was conducting short of sheer luck or some perfect intelligence tip." The spokesman said Dr. ElBaradei had long campaigned for a strengthening of the nuclear safeguard provisions of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
In an interview with CNN on Monday, Dr. ElBaradei said his visit to Libya demonstrated that "we have to go after supplies and the source of supply" of nuclear technologies, because the system of export controls has once again been proven ineffective in Libya. He also said the centrifuges that Libya had acquired for uranium enrichment were inactive.
"There was a very small cascade of tens of centrifuges that were developed years ago as a pilot and that has been dismantled now, and they haven't developed an industrial or large scale cascade, so there were in the experimental stage," he said.
The visit by the international team of inspectors led by Dr. ElBaradei was arranged hastily in the wake of the announcement on Dec. 19 by Britain and the United States that Libya would disclose and dismantle its programs that were intended to develop unconventional weapons in order to reach a new accord with the West.
The announcement followed nine months of intensive negotiations with British and American officials and secret visits by British and American intelligence experts.
The senior Bush administration official said a large contingent of British and American intelligence officials, along with experts from the Department of Energy, the Defense Department and the national laboratories are expected to return to Libya in January to pursue unanswered questions about acquisition activities over the past two decades.
This official said Colonel Qaddafi, facing a deteriorating economic and political climate at home, was motivated by concerns for "regime survival" in finally allowing foreign intelligence officials to see all of his secret weapons laboratories last fall. 
"In October there was an event involving a shipment that Qaddafi expected that did not show up, and after that, he finally said, 'O.K., you can send your teams in,' " the official said. 
President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair both praised Colonel Qaddafi's decision. Mr. Bush hinted that a full disarmament process in Libya could be followed by lifting of sanctions and normalizations of relations, steps that Congress would have to approve and that had seemed inconceivable after decades of vilification and recriminations over Libya's support for terrorism. 
Dr. ElBaradei's description of the Libyan nuclear program appeared more modest and less alarming than the descriptions by Mr. Bush and Mr. Blair when they disclosed that nine months of secret diplomacy had led to a breakthrough with Libya.
Dr. ElBaradei said most of Libya's illicit nuclear equipment was "quite dismantled" and still in boxes.
"Luckily, I think, we are here when they have not developed a full fledged capability, and luckily also they have announced that they are ready to eliminate all programs relevant to weapons of mass destruction," he said. 
At the same time, Dr. ElBaradei called on North Korea to follow Libya's example.
"If a country was to show transparency and active cooperation, that can open the doors" and allow for "a complete change of face," he said, adding, "It is a lesson for North Korea to observe."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
After 1,200 Meals, 'Check, Please'

BYLINE:  By William Grimes

 BODY:
NEW YORK, since the time it could truly be called a city, has been serious about food and not exactly shy about declaring itself to be the country's capital of fine dining. In 1828, when Delmonico's was still a rickety cafe selling pastries and coffee, a local guidebook assured visitors that "New York abounds beyond all other places in the universe, not excepting Paris, in consummate institutions for cultivating the noble science of gastronomy." 
 I'm not sure the claim was, in the strict sense of the word, true. But the sentiment has held steady for nearly 200 years, and at the moment, despite the economic downturn, the facts fit. New York diners have never had it so good. 
 After nearly five years of reviewing restaurants (some 438 reviews, based on more than 1,200 meals), I find myself in the position of the frog in the gradually warming pot of water. Because the temperature increases gradually, the frog fails to notice that he is being poached until it is too late. The same thing has happened to me, but with a delicious difference. In my time on the job, the culinary standards in the city's restaurants have risen across the board. In quality and diversity, dining has gotten better and better. 
When you eat out constantly, it is easy to take incremental improvements for granted. It is only when I stop and look back that I realize what has happened. A couple of degrees at a time, the pleasantly warm water has reached the boiling point.
Two telling indicators spring to mind immediately: desserts and cocktails. Ten years ago, pastry chefs operated fairly anonymously. Today, even modest bistros often print a separate dessert menu with the name of the pastry chef displayed prominently, and in most cases the desserts merit the attention. A new generation of bartenders, inspired by Dale DeGroff's work at the Rainbow Room in the 1980's, now collaborate with chefs to develop innovative cocktail lists attuned to a restaurant's cuisine. The before-meal aperitif and the postmeal sweet are, by definition, peripheral. I single them out because refinement at the margins radiates from the center. When a dining culture is truly vital, you see creativity in all departments.
A confluence of long-term and short-term trends conspired to make my tenure as restaurant critic an extended dream sequence of spectacular meals. Young American chefs poured out of the culinary schools, eager to make their marks and firmly committed to the principles laid down nearly 30 years ago at Chez Panisse, where all meals were based on local produce and fresh ingredients. 
The growing allure of New York as a place to live and work attracted top talent from Europe. French chefs in particular brought the classical training and fierce discipline that, like tannins in wine, give backbone and structure to the city's best menus. They also brought a creative restlessness, an eagerness to try new ideas in a city famously willing to receive them.
An increasing awareness of foreign cuisines and an improving system for delivering exotic ingredients to market changed the appetites and the ideas of chefs and diners alike. Fusion cuisine spawned a dozen fads, fancies and minitrends, like Pacific Rim and Nuevo Latino. Some disappeared virtually overnight. (Remember new-wave Belgian?) But the trend toward more internationalization has become a fact of life. No one blinks at shiitake mushrooms or lemon grass on a French menu. And well-traveled diners now expect restaurants to honor regional differences when presenting, say, Italian or Mexican cooking.
The city's rising fortunes translated into a real-estate boom that had profound effects on dining. New hotels, many of them aimed at a young, stylish clientele, opened the door to younger chefs ready to play a starring role, like Geoffrey Zakarian at Town and Rick Lakkonen at Ilo. They were part of a wider, profound generational shift. Gabriel Kreuther, a sous-chef at Jean Georges, moved a few blocks east and created a highly distinctive style of haute cuisine at the Ritz-Carlton. Another Jean Georges chef, Wylie Dufresne, singlehandedly made the Lower East Side a serious culinary destination with his groundbreaking 71 Clinton Fresh Food, opening up the neighborhoods to a host of small but ambitious restaurants like Alias, Suba, aKa Cafe, Chubo and WD-50, Mr. Dufresne's slightly bigger and much bolder sequel to 71 Clinton.
When I began reviewing, the Lower East Side did not exist asa restaurant neighborhood. Neither did the meatpacking district, NoLIta, the Upper West Side or Smith Street and Fifth Avenue in Brooklyn. Any serious dining map of the city would now have to include these newly colonized territories, opened up by the rising price of real estate in Manhattan and the changing demographics of neighborhoods that formerly made do with cafes and diners. The meatpacking district has never quite lived up to the hype. Pastis anchors the neighborhood, but it is more impressive as a stage set than as a restaurant. The Upper West Side, however, has been blessed. Tom Valenti endowed it with two brilliantly realized restaurants, one French, one Italian. Ouest and 'Cesca brought some badly needed style to a neighborhood that seemed stuck with two alternatives: Cafe des Artistes or takeout. 
The ill-fated Marika transformed itself into Compass and took hold, while Nice Matin and Aix showed that the neighborhood could mob more than one French brasserie at a time. Suddenly, it was no longer possible to joke about dining on the Upper West Side. 
Brooklyn, meanwhile, added one solid restaurant after another, like beads on a necklace. Al di la opened on Fifth Avenue, followed by Blue Ribbon, Moutarde and others, culminating in the shocker of the year when the Zagat Survey voted Grocery, on Smith Street, the seventh best restaurant in the city.
Some of the expected names continued to prosper. Jean-Georges Vongerichten added a Shanghai-inspired restaurant, 66, to his expanding portfolio. Daniel Boulud, after striking out on his own with Cafe Boulud, put all his cards on the table with Restaurant Daniel. After picking up four stars, he opened a snazzy bistro, DB Bistro Moderne, and set off the kind of dining war that could happen only in New York. His $27 hamburger of foie gras and short ribs set off a race toward the $100 barrier, which picked up steam when the Old Homestead created a $41 kobe beef burger, which inspired Alan Miguel Kaplan at Salon Mexico to put together a $45 filet mignon and truffle burrito. Mr. Boulud has come up with the reply valiant, a $50 upgrade of the now-classic DB Burger.
Joining Mr. Boulud and Mr. Vongerichten was another shrewd Frenchman, Alain Ducasse. He arrived spreading rose petals in his own path, and New York responded in the only possible way, with a big Bronx cheer. Alain Ducasse at the Essex House, the most expensive dining proposition the city had ever seen, took a ferocious drubbing in its early days, but Mr. Ducasse showed that he has the talent to match his towering ego. He persevered, and he, or rather his cooking, won me over. Like Mr. Boulud, Mr. Ducasse cashed in on the brasserie trend, although he skipped the hamburger and opted for macaroni and cheese. Mix in New York, with its almost incomprehensible mix-and-match menu format and strange dishware, solidified Mr. Ducasse's reputation in my mind as a maddening genius. I don't know what to do with him, but I'm glad he came. He's part of New York now. Americans were also in an expansionist mood. Sometimes it took a genealogist to keep track of the relationships. Danny Meyer of Union Square Cafe begat Gramercy Tavern, whose chef, Tom Colicchio, created Craft, which begat Craftbar, 'wichcraft and Hearth. Mario Batali, in partnership with Joseph Bastianich, parlayed his success at a tiny, one-syllable Italian restaurant, Po, into a small empire of idiosyncratic, stylish two-syllable restaurants, Lupa, Babbo, Esca and Otto. Stephen Hanson, known for big, loud seafood restaurants, opened another one, Blue Fin, but followed up with Fiamma Osteria, a medium-size Italian restaurant of exceptional quality. Terrance Brennan, the chef and owner of Picholine, decided that the cheese mania of his maitre fromageur, Max McCalman, should be universal. He created Artisanal, the city's first cheese-centric restaurant, and went on to establish a center for cheese maturing, the French art known as affinage, whose influence on New York restaurants could turn out to be profound. Jimmy Bradley scored a hit with the Red Cat, a new kind of all-American brasserie, and showed it was no fluke when he went on to open Harrison and the Mermaid Inn.
Sometimes, a restaurant, or a star chef, would come out of nowhere. Scott Conant, who toiled honorably on the Bowery at the now-closed City Eatery, came into his own in spectacular fashion at L'Impero in Tudor City. One day a colleague happened to drop a menu on my desk from a new Japanese restaurant near his apartment. I looked it over. My eyebrows shot up, and there they stayed, when I tasted my first deep-fried eel backbone at Sushi Yasuda, a restaurant that immediately took its rightful place among the city's finest sushi restaurants. Gary Robins, who cooked brilliantly, and briefly, at Mi, returned without warning to reach even greater heights at the Biltmore Room.
Like every other critic, I also ate mediocre meals. But more often I ate good meals, very good meals and outstanding meals. Sometimes the best came at the expected places, like Le Bernardin or Bouley. Sometimes it came at small but ambitious restaurants too numerous to mention, places like Wallse, Fleur de Sel, Tocqueville, Sumile and 36 Korean Bar and Barbecue. 
It is the sheer profusion and depth of these second-tier and third-tier restaurants that make New York great. In the end, it is not the four-star showplaces but the small neighborhood restaurants that tell you most about the quality of dining in a city. New York, to fall back on a sports metaphor, has a deep, deep bench.
I see no end to this. The new complex at the Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle will deliver half a dozen high-end restaurants in one fell swoop to a city ready and eager to eat. Mr. Batali has a British-style gastropub in the works. Marcus Samuelsson of Aquavit is set to open Riingo, a Japanese-inspired restaurant. Gray Kunz and Mr. Vongerichten are collaborating on Spice, a restaurant devoted to Asian street food, and Eric Ripert of Le Bernardin has joined forces with Michael Vernon, his former sous-chef, at Geisha on the Upper East Side. 
The coming year looks auspicious. I just hope I can get reservations.

ONLINE William Grimes narrates a retrospective of his tenure as the restaurant critic at nytimes.com/dining.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
A Festival Not Resting on Its Laurels

BYLINE:  By JOHN ROCKWELL 

 BODY:
This year's 21st annual installment of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival, which ended in mid-December, turned out to be one of the most interesting in years.
 Not because everything was wildly successful. Almost the opposite. Since the name the Next Wave implies taking risks, a succession of blandly applauded offerings would suggest few risks had been taken. 
 That happened in 2002. The 20th anniversary festival was not billed as a retrospective, either of the festival or of the years when it was programmed by Harvey Lichtenstein, the academy's former president. But that was what it looked like then, and now academy officials belatedly speak of it as what they intended all along.
In 1983, when the Next Wave began, the festival was a formalization of work that had been presented on its stages since the fall of 1981 and, in fact, intermittently back to 1967, when Mr. Lichtenstein took over the then-moribund complex.
The academy, and later the Next Wave, served to celebrate innovative work begun in Europe or in Manhattan lofts and museum spaces in the 60's. The festival offered American, mostly New York artists like Robert Wilson, Philip Glass, Merce Cunningham, Steve Reich, Bill T. Jones and Mark Morris, along with Europeans like Peter Brook, Pina Bausch and Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker. They got the chance to expand their work to a big stage or, for the foreigners, to be seen in the United States.
This was all very admirable, but when last year's festival presented most of these same names, it made some of us worry that the Next Wave had become a museum. Where was the daring? Maybe it had drained away either because Mr. Lichtenstein and his deputy and successor as artistic director, Joseph V. Melillo (Karen Brooks Hopkins took over the administrative part of Mr. Lichtenstein's job), were obsessed with these few artists, or because they now feared alienating their audience. This year's program allayed many of those fears, both because the artists were innovative and because Next Wave attendance did not drop off.
The 2003 festival did offer some familiar names; that seems understandable, both because familiar artists continue to do good work and because there needs to be some anchor in the innovative tempest.
There was Mr. Cunningham, collaborating with the young art-rock bands Radiohead and Sigur Ross. There was William Forsythe and the Frankfurt Ballet, from which he is soon unwillingly to depart. And there was Ms. De Keersmaeker, whose "Rain," to music by Mr. Reich, was widely hailed.
By this time Taiwan's exquisite Cloud Gate Dance Theater counts as a staple, as well, and perhaps also the American choreographer Susan Marshall. The semistaged production (looked at another way, this was an austere but fully staged version) of John Adams's opera about Middle Eastern terrorism, "The Death of Klinghoffer," may have looked familiar, but it was still controversial and hence worth championing. 
There was also a solid contingent of less well known foreigners: the U Theater from Taiwan, the Flamenco singer Enrique Morente singing songs of Leonard Cohen (improbably enough) and the Improbable Theater from London.
But the heart of the festival, and of Mr. Melillo's intentions, was the cultivation of a new crop of New York and American artists. Not all were unfamiliar, but here they were given the chance to stretch themselves or, as Mr. Melillo put it in a telephone interview the other day, "to be invited into the BAM sandbox."
Unfortunately, Osvaldo Golijov's new opera "Ainadamar" had to be canceled because of the soprano Dawn Upshaw's indisposition. But Bob McGrath of the Ridge Theater got a chance to shine in the "Klinghoffer" production, as did Ms. Marshall and the three founders of the familiar Bang on a Can concerts -- Michael Gordon, David Lang and Julia Wolfe -- and the long-admired Dayton Contemporary Dance Company from Ohio, with their "Flight Project."
By common agreement the least successful of Mr. Melillo's experiments was the production of "Henry IV, Part One," by the downtown director Richard Maxwell. I did not read one review that liked it, nor did I encounter one noncritic who had enjoyed it. But several at least appreciated the concept -- actors treating Shakespeare like ordinary, everyday conversation -- even if they lost interest once they got the point. But this was the best instance of a risk admirably taken, even if the result wasn't admirable. 
The two most admired examples of Mr. Melillo's fostering of local work were "bobrauschenbergamerica," a touching homage to the painter from the Siti Company, the playwright Charles L. Mee and the director Anne Bogart, and the dazzling multimedia "Alladeen." This last took the Aladdin myth as a jumping-off point for a consideration of unseen telemarketers in Bangalore, India, and the mysteries of cultural transformation. It was directed by Marianne Weems of the New York-based Builders Association in collaboration with motiroti, a London visual-arts collective.
In response to the recent recession and downturn in cultural philanthropy, Ms. Hopkins and the academy board cut this year's budget by $5 million, Mr. Melillo said. He made his cuts not in the Next Wave showcase but in the winter and spring seasons, principally in the (one hopes temporary) elimination of what has become an academy pattern, three staged operas in the spring. In 2004 it's down to one, a production of Handel's "Siroe" by the Venice Baroque Orchestra.
The good news is that Next Wave attendance held healthily steady, despite the programmatic risks. That meant 79 percent of capacity, which was almost exactly in line with projections. The 20th-anniversary Next Wave, full of familiar names, drew 80 percent.
Mr. Melillo stoutly defended his 2003 program -- even Mr. Maxwell, whom he conceded did not enjoy a success with the public, but who would have been better served, he argued, by a more intimate, 300-seat theater. Which, he hints, the academy hopes to obtain soon.
Although Mr. Melillo worked with Mr. Lichtenstein for years, in a sense this year's Next Wave represented his coming-out party. His artistic policy is hardly a transformation of Mr. Lichtenstein's, let alone a repudiation. But he is now his own man, and rightly proud of the risks he took and the festival he achieved.

(Photo by Stephanie Berger); Richard Maxwell's experimental version of Shakespeare's "Henry IV, Part One," was not a success, but some appreciated the concept. (Photo by Richard Termine)

HEADLINE: WINE TALK; 
Time to Put a Cork in '03 and Stick On a Label

BYLINE:  By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
THE year ending tonight was a good one for wine in America, and not just for the vintage, which, it so happens, wasn't bad. We will have drunk some 264 million cases of wine by midnight, about 14 million cases more than in 2002.
 Early this year, a lot of the surge had to do with price cutting brought on by the economic downturn. But by the end of the year, reluctant imbibers were returning to the wine shops, and prices began to creep up. 
 A good number of those 14 million cases were Two-Buck Chuck, which represents one of the more startling wine success stories ever. Actually, the wine goes by the name Charles F. Shaw. Two-Buck Chuck is a nickname reflecting the label and the wine's $2 price.
The wine is sold only in Trader Joe's food stores, most of which are in California. In fact, outside California, the wine costs $3.
Two-Buck Chuck is produced by Bronco Wine of Ceres, Calif. (A winery called Charles F. Shaw used to exist in the Napa Valley. It shut down a dozen or so years ago, and Bronco bought the name.) It is a phenomenon of the current California wine market, which is laboring to rid itself of an ocean of surplus wine brought on by the economic slump and by overplanting in the 1990's. Chuck appeared in 2002 and jumped to the East Coast earlier this year.
More than just being inexpensive, it gave consumers a chance to express their irritation at the continual rise in wine prices. Someone described it as a reverse cult wine, with people who ordinarily spend $20 or more for a bottle of wine buying 5, 10 or more cases of Two-Buck Chuck at a time. Along with the Australian line Yellow Tail, which ranges from $4.50 to $6 and is now the largest-selling import in the United States, Two-Buck Chuck showed that there is a considerable market for drinkable, very inexpensive wine. This was the year when cheap became chic in the wine world.
This was the year, too, when screw tops became more than a curiosity on wine bottles. Half a dozen New Zealand wineries are now using screw tops, and several California wineries, including Murphy-Goode in Sonoma, are putting them on some wines. Bonny Doon Vineyard near Santa Cruz, which started using them for part of its production several years ago, announced early this year that it would use them for all its wines, including Le Cigare Volant, one of its top labels.
Screw tops were once confined to inexpensive fortified and jug wines. Constant problems with corks have driven producers of fine wines to experiment with various stoppering devices. More and more are adopting the screw top.
This was not a memorable year for wine books. I sort of liked "Out of It: A Cultural History of Intoxication," by Stuart Walton (Three Rivers Press), and Leslie Sbrocco's "Wine for Women" (Morrow Cookbooks).
I still get occasional letters charging that, in recommending one wine or another, I am doing the Devil's work. In fact, anyone who writes about recreational drinking knows full well that the folly of overindulgence and the horrors of addiction are the other side of the coin. So I was intrigued by Mr. Walton's assertion that intoxication has always been with us and always will be -- if not from wine, spirits and tobacco, then from the vast cornucopia of drugs available, and even from old friends like caffeine.
Mr. Walton is British, and I found his foreigner's take on the Volstead Act and its aftermath highly entertaining. But I could not buy his ultimate and rather arch conclusion that intoxication is fundamentally harmless, often beneficial, and as such should be free of any legal or moral restraint. His orotund prose can be a bit wearing, too.
Ms. Sbrocco has produced a lighthearted how-to wine book that runs through the same basics as a hundred other books before it, but with an easier touch and the addition of tips on buying and serving that the author asserts might be particularly useful to a woman. Knowing many women who make wine, sell wine, promote wine and teach and (like Ms. Sbrocco) write about it, I got the feeling that singling them out for their very own wine book might be about 30 years late. 
Of course, there are always more women coming along, and some might prefer their wine knowledge to be gender-specific. They might be more comfortable with a text that, for example, likens the effect of acid on wine to a push-up bra. It lifts, Ms. Sbrocco writes, and separates.
Could this signal a trend? Why not "Wine for Male Dummies" and "Wine for Female Dummies"?
As for wine itself, this was the year when riesling finally began to make an impact on the American market. Not too long ago, famous producers along the Rhine and the Mosel in Germany were pulling out vines because no one was buying their wines. In a happy turn, that trend has been reversed, at least in part as a result of the American reaction to the overblown, high-alcohol, woody whites that have dominated the country's market for so long.
Riesling is an infinitely subtle wine that displays its charms reluctantly. At its best, it is a long-lived wine that takes time to come around. Cheap riesling can be drunk when very young, but wines from great producers like Ernst Loosen in Bernkastel and Rainer Lingenfelder in the Pfalz, both in Germany, and Laurence Faller at the Domaine Weinbach in Alsace make rieslings that often need three or four years of bottle age to reach their best.
(Perhaps the best American rieslings come from the Finger Lakes region in New York, especially from the Hermann J. Wiemer Vineyard on Seneca Lake. Mr. Wiemer, who grew up in Bernkastel, has made riesling New York's signature wine.)
If Americans are developing a taste for good riesling, it means their taste is improving. That's a good thing, and not just for 2003.

HEADLINE: Iran Thanks U.S. for Help, but Refrains From an Embrace 

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR; Steven R. Weisman contributed reporting from Washington for this article.

DATELINE: BAM, Iran, Dec. 30 

 BODY:
President Mohammad Khatami said Tuesday that the arrival of an American aid team in this earthquake-ravaged city was a welcome development but should be viewed as just that -- a humane gesture and not a harbinger of improving relations between the United States and the Islamic republic.
 "Humanitarian issues should not be intertwined with deep and chronic political problems," Mr. Khatami said at a news conference in Kerman, the provincial capital. "If we see a change both in the tone and behavior of the U.S. administration, then a new situation will develop in our relations." 
 In Washington, the Bush administration on Tuesday hailed the contacts between Iran and the United States on earthquake relief as one of several "positive developments" between the countries in recent months.
"We reached out to the Iranians," said J. Adam Ereli, a State Department spokesman. "We offered our assistance. That offer was accepted, and I don't think you can see that as anything but a positive development for the people of Iran."
Some policy experts said there was now room for maneuvering, a chance to transcend the "Axis of Evil" versus "Great Satan" labels that each country has stuck on the other. Mr. Khatami also said Tuesday that the death toll from the quake was likely to reach 30,000. A disaster of such scope can create an opportunity for conversations that otherwise may not have taken place, the experts said. 
"It could be interpreted as earthquake diplomacy," said Davoud Hermitas Bavand, a political scientist at Tehran University. "It could be used as a starting point for dialogue."
The brief transit of about 12 American aid workers through the damaged airport terminal here caused a frisson of excitement, with Iranian relief volunteers asking to have their pictures taken with the workers when they heard they were Americans. 
For their part, the Americans insisted that there was nothing political or particularly unusual in their presence. 
The last time a large group of Americans was in the country was in January 1981, when 52 American hostages were released from 444 days in captivity at the American Embassy in downtown Tehran. Relations, severed then, have never really improved.
When asked if he had any qualms about being here, Kevin Garvey, a medical technician from Boston, said "None whatsoever" and several men behind him echoed the thought. 
"This is what we do," added Mr. Garvey, part of a team expecting to establish a field hospital in Bam. "I am totally apolitical when it comes to doing my duties."
Two different teams of Americans are here, an urban search and rescue group from Fairfax, Va., and an international medical response group affiliated with Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Although the Bush administration dispatched the groups, the Iranians have gone to great lengths to paint them as volunteers.
Asked repeatedly about the issue at his news conference, President Khatami said the United States needed to assuage Iranian fears before relations could move forward. 
"They must attract our confidence, and that requires resolving our differences," he said. "They must respect our sovereignty. They keep on saying that they want to overthrow the Islamic Republic. We have not seen good intentions. We hope that the U.S. will change its behavior so that this wall of mistrust will break."
A group of Iranian doctors watching the arrival of the Americans at the Bam terminal said they distinguished between Washington -- with its threats of "regime change" and its long history of trying to enforce worldwide economic sanctions -- and ordinary citizens.
"We still have problems with the American government; there are no diplomatic relations," said Ali Gorbawi, an anesthesia nurse. "Humanitarian relations are fine, though. We welcome that."
Out of such small seeds, though, diplomatic saplings may spring, some policy experts said. 
"Every situation, every occasion, every incident, if used properly, could be used for constructive relations," said Mr. Bavand, the political scientist. "In politics there is no such thing as not using an opportunity."
A presidential adviser, Mohammad Shariati, conceded as much to the official Islamic Republic News Agency. 
"There is no doubt that the way countries behave at the time of trouble for other countries will affect decision making and will pave the way for other matters," he said. "But I do not think it is a very good time now to talk about change, unless we get a chance to bring up our demands as well."
Washington has swung in recent years between trying to engage Iran and continuing to treat it as an outcast. Iran recently agreed to more wide-ranging international inspection of its nuclear research facilities, which it insists are for peaceful purposes. Iran has also voiced support for the American-led overthrow of Saddam Hussein, who waged an eight-year war across the Iran-Iraq border. At the same time, Iran has urged a speedy United States withdrawal from Iraq, evidently nervous at the prospect of tens of thousands of American soldiers bivouacked next door. 
In reacting to the American group arriving at Bam, one official drew a distinct comparison. 
"You are talking about politics, but these are doctors," said Mohammad Akbari, Iran's deputy health minister. "They are not Mr. Bush or Mr. Rumsfeld coming to kill us."
Other countries that have recently had tense relations with Iran, especially regional neighbors like Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Jordan, were also sending in assistance, signaling a certain thaw.
There is, of course, a constituency within the Iranian government that acts as if maintaining hostility toward the United States and its allies is one of the pillars that keeps the Islamic revolution alive. After the quake, Iran announced that it would accept aid from all nations except Israel, and Tehran has long supported militant Palestinian fundamentalist groups. 
Similar predictions of thaws in the past have come to naught -- including one in 1990 after a private American relief plane landed in Tehran ferrying supplies to the victims of a devastating earthquake in the Caspian region. That year, though, Iran left the United States off its thank-you list. 
The Bush administration's comments on Tuesday were among several in recent months trying to take advantage of Iran's latest cooperation on its nuclear weapons program. But direct contacts with Iran would be resumed only if the government in Tehran made further progress in shutting down terrorist operatives based in Iranian territory, American officials have said.
On Tuesday, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, in an interview with The Washington Post, was quoted as saying that Iran's recent actions had been "encouraging" and that the United States was open to "the possibility of dialogue at an appropriate point in the future."
An openness to talking with Iran had been signaled in late October by Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage, who told a Congressional panel that the United States was not seeking "regime change" in Iran and said a future dialogue might be appropriate.
The change in the administration's tone occurred after senior envoys from France, Germany and Britain won agreement from Iran to accept new international inspections of some of its nuclear facilities and to suspend production of enriched uranium, a fuel for potential use in making weapons.

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 305 words

HEADLINE: The Budget Politics of Being Poor 

 BODY:
Quietly and painfully, most states are choosing to crimp the health-care safety net for their poorest and most politically defenseless residents. An ominous new study shows that up to 1.6 million impoverished and working-poor Americans -- at least a third of them children -- have been deliberately knocked from publicly financed health care programs in the last two years. 
Officials in 34 states are opting to slash Medicaid and poor children's health insurance coverage as a path of least resistance to the balanced budgets mandated by law.
 States have raised poverty standards beyond federal requirements, increased bureaucratic delays and even shut down children's health programs entirely to keep entitled poor people off the rolls. For each dollar thereby saved in the state budget, statehouses are losing $4 to $7 in federal aid. Yet more such counterproductive "economizing" can be expected next year, according to the study, by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a government watchdog group. 
 During the 1990's boom, those who despaired of getting universal health insurance through federal action looked to expanding state programs as the best way to protect the working poor. But many of the same states that were increasing health coverage were also cutting taxes. Unlike the feckless tax-cutters in Congress, they cannot simply bury the resulting deficits in future debt. Something had to give, and it turns out to be programs like the hard-won gains in health insurance.
Things would be even worse except for the $20 billion in state emergency aid that the Republican-led Congress was embarrassed into approving at the height of the tax-cut frenzy this year. Since Congress is showing no signs of picking up the slack when it comes to health coverage, it should vote at least a renewal of this aid next year.

HEADLINE: Prison Union Seeks Ouster Of the Chief Of Corrections 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 30 

 BODY:
The union representing sergeants at New Jersey prisons is asking Gov. James E. McGreevey to dismiss Corrections Commissioner Devon Brown, saying he made racially charged comments in a speech about the inequitable treatment of blacks and Hispanics in the criminal justice system.
 In a letter to the governor last week, the union, the New Jersey Law Enforcement Supervisors Association, said that the commissioner's speech at a conference on minorities in prison was "highly inappropriate and racially charged," and that it would aggravate tensions between inmates and corrections officers. 
 Mr. Brown, who is black, said at the Nov. 8 conference at Rutgers that he was distressed by huge racial disparities in the prison population. "This state and nation has lost a generation of young African-Americans and Hispanics, both male and female, to the criminal justice juggernaut."
The union also expressed dismay over comments drawing parallels to slave-era plantations.
"'There are those who with some degree of justification have proclaimed our prisons as being America's new plantations," he said, "for not since slavery has our country promoted policies which have visited such enormous economic and human calamity on the black community."
A Corrections Department spokesman said the commissioner declined to comment on the union's demand, which was reported on Tuesday by The Record of Hackensack. "It's a personnel issue, and we're treating it internally," said the spokesman, Chris Carden.
Mr. Brown told The Record on Monday that the union was angered by proposals that could result in cuts in prison staffing. He has supported a state commission to revisit sentencing laws, as have several legislators who have voiced concern about prison costs, which have risen to $1.1 billion from $200 million in the last 20 years. 
The letter from the union's president, Robert A. Cardone, and first vice president, Thomas Moran, said, "We are extraordinarily concerned that the State of New Jersey has implemented a policy to return violent criminals to all of our neighborhoods simply to save money."
But Ellen Mellody, a McGreevey spokeswoman, said: "The state has not adopted any such policy. The letter is inaccurate, and the governor does not support the early release of prisoners as a cost-saving measure."
Ms. Mellody also said the governor supported Mr. Brown, whom he appointed in March 2002. 
Mr. Cardone and Mr. Moran did not respond on Tuesday to a message requesting comment. 
In 2001, the last year for which statistics are available, the state prison population was 63 percent black and 18 percent Hispanic. The total inmate population peaked in 1999 at 31,493 and has declined to 27,492.

HEADLINE: Korean War Vet's Protest May Keep a Hospital Open 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE YORK

DATELINE: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Dec. 30 

 BODY:
In August 1952, Cpl. Ralph A. Calabrese was wounded when his Army barracks collapsed during an attack in Korea. 
 He recovered from some injuries, but he never told doctors he was blind in his right eye. He taught himself to aim with his left eye and returned to the battlefields. "I didn't want to leave my buddies," he explained. 
 Mr. Calabrese said he felt that way again this August -- 51 years later -- when a federal plan was released suggesting that veterans services be streamlined and that several veterans hospitals be closed, including three in New York State, one of them here in his hometown. Mr. Calabrese helped organize a protest that officials say was among the loudest in the nation. 
The outcry may have been effective. Charles Battaglia, a member of a federal commission that has been studying consolidation, said on Tuesday that it plans to recommend that the hospital here stay open. "The consensus is we ought to retain Canandaigua," he said.
The commission is completing recommendations that it will deliver in about five weeks to the secretary of veterans affairs, Anthony J. Principi, who can accept or reject them. The fate of the other hospitals, in Manhattan and Montrose, in Westchester County, will be decided then as well. 
In 1999, a federal study showed that the nation spends $1 million a day maintaining unused space at veterans hospitals. This summer, federal officials suggested that closing some hospitals while building up others would be more cost-effective and could provide better care. 
On paper, Canandaigua may have been an obvious target. The hospital sits on a 171-acre campus next to historic gardens in a Finger Lakes community 30 miles southeast of Rochester. The hospital's amenities include a nine-hole golf course, bowling lanes, barber shop, pharmacy and general store. And the number of patients has shrunk substantially -- to only 200 today from a high of 1,700. 
But those figures don't tell the whole story, supporters maintain. The hospital serves as many as 16,000 people on an outpatient basis, and its amenities provide rehabilitative opportunities. For example, many unskilled veterans are trained as landscapers on the golf course.
The hospital's tranquil setting helps recovering patients like Marion E. Williams, whose alcohol abuse unraveled his life. Mr. Williams lost his job in 1985 and his home in 1997. After rotating between shelters and the streets, he asked to be admitted into a detoxification program in Canandaigua. "I just gave up and wanted to do better," he said. 
Today, at 55, Mr. Williams is employed at the hospital in housekeeping services. He lives in a group home and says he is sober. "This place is really needed," he said. 
Mr. Calabrese said he felt that way, too. He has relied on veterans services to help him cope with lingering problems from his injury, including migraines he described as so severe they had brought him to the brink of suicide. 
It would be unfair, he said, to ask veterans to drive to the next closest hospital, nearly 50 miles away. "They're playing with human beings," he said, "not numbers."
So Mr. Calabrese helped organize a grass-roots effort that included protest signs and old-fashioned letter writing. Of the 200,000 letters received by the commission in response to the consolidation plan, 109,000 were about the Canandaigua hospital, Mr. Battaglia said.
The campaign to prevent its closing received high-level political help too. "It would be a terrible blow to Canandaigua," Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Monday. 
David Baker, president of the community's Chamber of Commerce, said the local economy would lose $250,000 a year if the hospital's 800 jobs were eliminated or moved. "In some fashion, everyone is touched by the V.A.," he said. 
Dr. Lawrence Flesh, chief medical officer for the branch of Veterans Affairs that covers western New York, the office that recommended Canandaigua's closing, said many of the protesters were misinformed, thinking services would be abolished instead of relocated. "We're not going to abandon care," he said.
Still, he acknowledged, the proposal was released at a bad time. "It's not a good thing to do when the country's at war," he said. 
Mr. Battaglia said that although Canandaigua's protest was among the loudest, it was only one of many. "Everyone's in favor of cutting costs," he said. "But no one wants it to happen in their community."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ralph A. Calabrese, an Army veteran of the Korean War, on the grounds of the veterans hospital in Canandaigua, N.Y., which he has been fighting to keep open. Canandaigua is his hometown. (Photo by Allison Cooper for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Office Pool, 2004 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
In last year's office pool, for the second year running, I accurately predicted the best-picture Oscar winner. Forget all of the other predictions, which were varying degrees of mistaken; I shoulda been a film critic. 
The multiple choices include one, all or none. My picks are down below. Do not save this page. 
 1. Next tyranny to feel the force of U.S. liberation: (a) North Korea; (b) Iran; (c) Syria; (d) Venezuela. 
 2. Iraq will (a) split up, like all Gaul, into three parts; (b) defeat the insurgents and emerge a rudimentary democracy; (c) succumb to a Sunni coup.
3. First to fall from power will be (a) Little China's Chen Shui-bian, whose two-China campaign oratory on Taiwan is asking for trouble with Big China; (b) Pakistan's Musharraf, double-crossed by his Islamist military; (c) the U.S.'s Bush, after abandoning fiscal restraint; (d) Russia's Putin as his electorate miraculously awakens; (e) Cuba's Castro. 
4. Long-overdue exoneration will come to embattled media megastar (a) Martha Stewart; (b) Michael Jackson; (c) Kenneth Lay; (d) Pete Rose.
5. The economy will (a) see a booming 13,000 Dow and 3,000 Nasdaq; (b) grow more slowly as a weakening dollar drives up interest rates; (c) be rocked by the abuse of manipulative derivatives in hedge funds.
6. The fiction best seller will be (a) "Retribution" by Jilliane Hoffman; (b) "Confessions of a Bigamist" by Kate Lehrer; (c) "Flying Crows" by Jim Lehrer (presumably one of Kate's husbands). 
7. The nonfiction sleeper will be (a) "Inside -- A Public and Private Life" by Joseph Califano Jr.; (b) Carl Zimmer's brainy "Soul Made Flesh"; (c) Michael Korda's biography of U. S. Grant; (d) Gertrude Himmelfarb's "The Roads to Modernity."
8. The scientific advance of the year will be (a) age retardation enhanced by memory protection; (b) a single pill combining erectile dysfunction treatment with a fast-acting aphrodisiac; (c) neuroscientists' creation of a unified field theory of the brain; (d) the awakening of geneticists to the liberating study of bioethics. 
9. Best-Picture Oscar: (a) Anthony Minghella's "Cold Mountain"; (b) Edward Zwick's "The Last Samurai"; (c) Clint Eastwood's "Mystic River"; (d) Sofia Coppola's "Lost in Translation"; (e) Gary Ross's "Seabiscuit." (This is the category I'm good at.)
10. Bush's domestic initiative will be (a) Social Security personal accounts; (b) community college scholarships; (c) a moon colony; (d) snowmobile restrictions in Florida parks. 
11. The U.S. Supreme Court (a) will decide that the rights of alien detainees in Guantanamo have not been violated; (b) will deadlock, 4-4 (Scalia recused), in the Pledge of Allegiance case, thereby temporarily affirming the Ninth Circuit decision declaring "under God" in the pledge unconstitutional; (c) in Tennessee v. Lane will uphold a state's immunity to lawsuits, limiting federal power in the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
12. Howard Dean will (a) sweep Iowa and New Hampshire and breeze to a boring nomination; (b) lose to Gephardt in Iowa and do worse than expected in N.H., leading to a long race; (c) transform himself into the centrist, affable "new Dean"; (d) angrily bolt and form a third party if the nomination is denied him.
13. The "October surprise" affecting our election will be (a) the capture of bin Laden in Yemen; (b) the daring escape of Saddam; (c) a major terror attack in the U.S.; (d) finding a buried bag of anthrax in Tikrit. 
14. Debating Cheney on TV will be the Democratic running mate (a) Wes Clark; (b) Bob Graham; (c) Bill Richardson; (d) Dianne Feinstein; (e) John Edwards; (f) Carl Levin. 
15. The next secretary of state will be (a) Richard Holbrooke; (b) Paul Bremer; (c) Donald Rumsfeld; (d) John Kerry.
16. Israel, staunchly supported during the U.S. election year, will (a) build its security barrier including the Ariel salient and the Jordan Valley; (b) undermine Arafat by negotiating territory with Syria after Assad quiets Hezbollah in occupied Lebanon; (c) close down illegal outposts before "redeploying" settlers out of Gaza. 
My picks: 1. (none), 2. (b), 3. (e) (I've made this yearly prediction for three decades and now is not the time to stop), 4. (a), 5. (all), 6. (b), 7. (a), 8. (d), 9. (c) (Make my day, Clint!), 10. (b), 11. (all), 12. (b), 13. (c), 14. (b), 15. (b) 16. (all). This last one is pure, unsourced thumb-sucking; Sharon didn't return my call.

HEADLINE: Ranchers and Companies Support New Restrictions 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
In an effort to maintain consumer confidence and to appeal to countries that have closed their borders to American beef, domestic cattle ranchers and food companies said yesterday that they largely supported the Department of Agriculture's decision to increase restrictions on beef production.
 Ann M. Veneman, the secretary of agriculture, said yesterday that the government would enact several new regulations on beef production, including banning the use of small intestines and head and spinal tissues from older cattle. The government also said it would start a national animal identification program and prohibit cattle that are unable to walk when they enter the slaughterhouse, or downers, from entering the food supply. 
 The National Cattlemen's Beef Association, which represents 95 percent of the country's ranchers, said that while its members supported the government's actions they had not erred in their business practices. 
"It's important for us to recognize that the systems that we have had in place did work," Terry Stokes, the association's president, said in a conference call. "Having said that, we now have had a case in the United States. It's important for us to look at and evaluate these systems and enhance them based upon this new information."
Since the single case of mad cow disease was announced last week, more than 30 nations have banned imports of American cattle. Trade with those countries, which include Japan and South Korea, represents about 90 percent of the $3.7 billion American beef export business, the association said. Regaining the confidence of its importers, ranchers said, is worth the millions of dollars they will probably have to pay to absorb the costs of the new rules.
"We do believe that these are extraordinary measures that go well beyond what the international standards would dictate," said Janet M. Riley, a spokeswoman at the American Meat Institute. "In light of these, our trading partners should re-establish beef trade with us immediately."
Several ranchers and food companies said they had been in compliance with some of the new regulations for several years. Tyson Foods, Smithfield Foods and Swift Foods each said they did not use downer animals, which the beef association said made up only 0.18 percent of the cattle slaughtered each year. All the companies applauded the government's actions. 
"The steps being implemented by U.S.D.A. will have a minimal impact on Tyson's beef operations, since the company is already doing much of what will be required," Tyson said in a statement.
Swift Foods also announced its own cattle-tracing program yesterday, saying it was the first beef company to do so before the government required such a program.
Consumer groups also lauded the government's announcement but said the agency should have acted earlier to prevent the case of mad cow disease in Washington State. Caroline Smith DeWaal, the director of food safety at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said her group had been lobbying the Agriculture Department since 2001 to ban the use of spinal column and neck bone meat in the nation's food supply. While the agency has banned the use of such tissues in older cattle, it can still be harvested from cattle that are younger than 30 months.
"There's no way consumers can avoid it," Ms. DeWaal said. "While the meat should be more safe than it is today, it's still not safe enough."
Commodity traders said yesterday that cattle futures were showing signs of improvement after posting steep declines in the days immediately after the discovery of the case of mad cow. While cattle for February delivery still fell the maximum of 5 cents a pound yesterday -- to 76.175 cents, down 6.2 percent -- the futures traded for about three hours before hitting the limit. In the previous three sessions, they reached the limit immediately after the opening.
Equity markets stabilized, with most fast-food and restaurant stocks rising for a second consecutive session. One of theday's biggest winners was GeneThera Inc., a small Colorado company that said it had developed a test that could detect mad cow disease in live animals. The company's stock rose 30 percent, to $3.42 a share.

HEADLINE: Pocketbook Issues at Top of Agenda as Democrats Swarm South Carolina 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, S.C, Dec. 30 

 BODY:
Calling himself a Vermont Yankee, Howard Dean pitched a populist economic message on Tuesday in this depressed coastal town where 563 jobs disappeared when a steel plant closed in October and where the county unemployment rate is 14.5 percent.
 "It doesn't matter if you're North or South: if you're from a rural state and you need jobs, you're an American," Dr. Dean told several hundred people outside a historic mansion. "That's good enough for me and I hope it's good enough for you." 
 He focused on pocketbook issues like jobs and health insurance in hopes of luring working-class voters from the Republican Party, whose hold on the South helped George Bush win the White House in 2000. Two of his rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Gen. Wesley K. Clark, followed suit in comments Tuesday directed at Southerners hard pressed by manufacturing losses. 
"This is not some crackpot socialist idea from some liberal state up in the North; Harry Truman put this in the Democratic platform in 1948," Dr. Dean said of his universal health insurance plan. "I want more than anything to bring South Carolina back to its proud tradition of voting Democrat year after year after year."
The day was a contrast to the intense campaigning in Iowa and New Hampshire, where Dr. Dean, the former governor of Vermont, spends much of his time fending off attacks from the other Democratic contenders. Here, Dr. Dean seemed still to be introducing himself to voters, and many said they showed up for the novelty of seeing a candidate.
The novelty is not likely to last.
General Clark landed in South Carolina on Tuesday night for the finale of his two-day, True Grits tour of Southern states, while Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut also arrived to place his name on the primary ballot. Carol Moseley Braun and the Rev. Al Sharpton each opened campaign offices on Tuesday in the state capital, Columbia.
With this year's compressed nominating calendar, several of the candidates see South Carolina, the signature state among seven voting on Feb. 3, as the key to halting Dr. Dean's momentum. For Dr. Dean, South Carolina -- along with Arizona and New Mexico, which vote the same day -- is an opportunity to lock up the nomination early.
General Clark, who grew up in Arkansas, emphasized his heritage of "Southern values," including patriotism, faith, family and inclusiveness, as he campaigned in Charleston, Memphis, Nashville and Savannah, Ga., on the second day of his tour of Southern states. 
The sizes of his crowds have grown steadily as he has proceeded across the South, and a raucous crowd of more than 300 people wedged shoulder-to-shoulder at state Democratic headquarters in Nashville to welcome him. 
At every stop on Tuesday, he recited a biographical sketch long on Southern symbols and short on the final "g" in words like living, helping and raising. He noted that as a boy he said the Pledge of Allegiance every day in school, adding "and we meant it." He told of going to Sunday school and Baptist Training Union. 
"And my stepfather took me out; we went hunting and fishing every weekend," General Clark said. 
In Memphis he said, "It's hard to be talking about family values when there are 8.8 million unemployed in this country." 
Mr. Lieberman, in his last planned trip South before the New Hampshire primary on Jan. 27, said the election "presents a clear choice, between George Bush on one end and Howard Dean on the other," and offered himself as the moderate alternative.
"I'm the man in the mainstream who's going to build from the mainstream values that are held so dearly in South Carolina and throughout the country," he said in Columbia.
Even Mr. Gephardt, campaigning in New Hampshire, talked about South Carolina in a conference call attacking Dr. Dean, a near-daily occurrence in the Democratic race. 
"I think when voters in South Carolina understand what I've done on trade, what Howard's done on trade, I'm going to win a lot of their votes and I'm going to win in South Carolina," Mr. Gephardt said, referring to Dr. Dean's support of international trade agreements in the 1990's. "He's had an 11th-hour conversion and now he's saying what I said for 15 years. Well, you can't change the record that quickly, and I think people are going to see through it."
Dr. Dean, as he does daily, acknowledged his support for Nafta and other treaties but said he would sign no more until trading partners raised their labor and environmental standards. Next to Dr. Dean on the rostrum here was the president of the local steelworkers' union, who could not hold the rally at his local's hall because his parent union has endorsed Mr. Gephardt.
Earlier, Dr. Dean spoke at a breakfast meeting of Democrats in Florence, S.C., and cut a ribbon there at his fifth field office in the state. 
The trip, Dr. Dean's ninth to South Carolina, was planned in part because he was to give a talk, "Why I Want to Be President," at the Renaissance Weekend retreat in Charleston on Tuesday. The sessions, in which Dr. Dean has participated for the past two years, are closed to the public and press. Mr. Clark and Ms. Braun also were scheduled to give speeches there.
This state's Feb. 3 primary is seen by some as a test of Dr. Dean's national appeal. The Dean campaign has tripled its South Carolina staff to 25 in the past three weeks, and plans to add a half-dozen more next week.
Dr. Dean's strategy in the state seems more focused on uniting working-class Southerners for a November general election face-off with President Bush than attracting the African-American votes essential to winning the Democratic primary. 
Both in Florence, where blacks make up 40 percent of the population, and in Georgetown, which is 57 percent African-American, the crowds that turned out were nearly all white. Dr. Dean and his aides have frequently said they do not expect black voters to come to campaign rallies in large numbers, and that they plan to have black legislators and ministers do outreach for them. 
Tuesday's appearance made it clear that some voters were still trying to sort out the candidates. Ernest Nance, 69, who lives in Wedgefield, said of Dr. Dean: "He's solid, and he's from North Carolina."
Actually, that is Senator John Edwards.

"If you're from a rural state and you need jobs, you're an American." (Photo by Brad Nettles, The Post and Courier, via Associated Press)
